Battle of Cotyaeum: The Isaurian rebels are defeated by the Eastern Roman army, under John the Scythian and John the Hunchback (subordinate commanders include the future Justin I). They retreat to their mountain fortresses, and continue guerrilla warfare against the Roman forces until .

King Theoderic the Great conquers Rimini, and brings his Ostrogoth fleet to blockade the harbours  miles from the capital of Ravenna. Important provisions, food and supplies are cut off, and the inhabitants are starved to death.
War with the Volsci is averted because a pestilence affects the Volsci.  Rome sends additional colonists to Velitrae and establishes a new colony in Norba.

When Camarina, a Syracusan colony, rebels, Hippocrates, the tyrant of Gela, intervenes to wage war against Syracuse. After defeating the Syracusan army at the Heloros River, he besieges the city. However, he is persuaded by the intervention of forces from the Greek mainland city of Corinth to retreat in exchange for the possession of Camarina.
Tisicrates wins the stadion race for a second time at the 72nd Olympic Games.

The first expedition of King Darius I of Persia against Greece commences under the leadership of his son-in-law and general, Mardonius. Darius sends Mardonius to succeed his satrap (governor) in Ionia, Artaphernes, with a special commission to attack Athens and Eretria.
Mardonius loses some  ships in a storm off Mount Athos, which forces him to abandon his plans to attack Athens and Eretria.
Mor Hananyo Monastery is established by Mor Shlemon, converting a former Roman fortress (ex temple) in the Tur Abdin region on the Turkish/Syrian border.
Emperor Xiao Wen Di starts adopting a sinicization policy as well as various reforms. He marries Feng Qing, who becomes empress of the Northern Wei Dynasty.

Theodoric the Great allies with the Franks and marries Audofleda, sister of Clovis I. He also marries his own female relatives to princes or kings of the Burgundians, Vandals and Visigoths, establishing a political alliance with the Germanic kingdoms in the West.
March – Battle for the Body of St. Patrick: The Uí Néill Dynasty fights over the body of Saint Patrick with the Airgialla Kingdom (according to the Annals of the Four Masters).
Onoulphus, brother of Odoacer, is killed during the siege of Ravenna by archers while seeking refuge in a church.
During his second consulate, the Roman consul Spurius Cassius Vecellinus concludes a treaty with the Latin League, the Foedus Cassianum, confirming Roman primacy in Latium.
The secession of the plebs concludes.
Themistocles starts the construction of a fortified naval base at Piraeus, the port town of Athens.
The Athenian people elect Themistocles as archon, the chief judicial and civilian executive officer in Athens. He favours resistance against the Persians.
The Athenian poet Phrynicus produces a tragedy on the Fall of Miletus. The Athenian authorities ban the play from further production on the grounds of impiety.
An earthquake devastates the port town of Latakia (modern Syria).
Emperor Xiao Wen Di moves the capital of Northern Wei from Datong to Luoyang. He makes Chinese the official language of his court, and orders his nobility to adopt Chinese names.
Gelasius I delineates the relationship between church and state (Doctrine of the two swords, formulated in his letter Famuli vestrae pietatis to the East Roman Emperor Anastasius I.)
Gelasius I canonizes Saint George.
The Decretum Gelasianum is attributed.
The Roman consul Aulus Verginius Tricostus Caeliomontanus defeats the Volsci, and a Roman colony is planted at Velitrae.
The Spartan king, Cleomenes I inflicts a severe defeat on Argos at Sepeia near Tiryns (approximate date).

The Thracians and Scythians drive Miltiades the Younger from the Chersonesos. Miltiades loads five boats with his treasures and makes for Athens. One of the boats, captained by Miltiades' eldest son, Metiochos is captured. Metiochos is taken as a lifelong prisoner to Persia.

The aediles, magistrates of ancient Rome who are in charge of the temple and cult of Ceres, are first established. They are two officials of the plebeians, created at the same time as the tribunes, whose sanctity they share.
The Roman consul Titus Veturius Geminus Cicurinus defeats the Aequi at the request of Rome's Latin allies.
Emperor Xiao Wen Di of Northern Wei builds the Shaolin Monastery in Henan for the monk Batuo (for alternate founding date see  or ).
Cerdic of Wessex and his son, Cynric, land somewhere on the south coast, probably near the Hampshire-Dorset border. Their followers establish the beginnings of the Kingdom of Wessex.

Pope Gelasius I gains support from Italian bishops, in his assertion that the spiritual power of the papacy is superior to the emperor's temporal authority. Like his predecessors, the pope opposes the Byzantine emperor Anastasius I's efforts to establish Miaphysite doctrine.
The Volsci launch an invasion against Rome, but are defeated, and in retaliation Rome plunders Suessa Pometia.
Roman troops defeat an invading force of Sabines.
A temple is built on the Circus Maximus, between the Aventine and Palatine hills, in Rome, in honour of the god Mercury and was dedicated on  May.
Roman troops defeat an army of the Aurunci near the town of Aricia.
The beginning of discord between the plebs and patricians leading to the first secession of the plebs.
December  – Clovis I is baptized into the Catholic faith at Rheims, by Saint Remigius. The conversion strengthens the bonds between his Gallo-Roman subjects, led by their Catholic bishops.
Thrasamund succeeds his brother Gunthamund after his death, and becomes king of the Vandals. Under his rule, he resumes the persecution of the Catholics.
November  – Gelasius I dies after a -year reign, and is succeeded by the Rome-born Anastasius II as the 50th pope.
Emperor Xiao Wen Di of Northern Wei starts the Sinicization process, by changing his clan name to the Han Chinese surname Yuan.
King Kavadh I of Persia is deposed and exiled to Susiana by his younger brother Djamasp. He is installed by the nobles to the Sassanid throne.
Hipparchos, son of Charmos (a relative of the  BC tyrant Peisistratus), wins the archonship of Athens as leader of the peace party which argues that resistance against the Persians is useless.
Tisicrates of Kroton wins the stadion race at the 71st Olympic Games.
King Goujian of Yue defeats and mortally injures King Helü of Wu

The former Etruscan King of Rome, Tarquinius Superbus, who had been exiled by the Romans in , and his ally Octavius Mamilius, of Tusculum, together with the Latins are defeated by the Roman Republic army in the Battle of Lake Regillus, near Frascati. The outcome of this battle establishes Roman supremacy over the Latins.
Aryabhata, Indian astronomer and mathematician, calculates pi (π) as ≈ 62832/20000 = ., correct to four rounded-off decimal places.

Emperor Anastasius I gives formal recognition to the Ostrogoth king Theodoric the Great, as his representative (viceroy) in Italy. He sends the imperial standard to Ravenna. Theodoric respects the agreement and allows Roman citizens within the Ostrogothic Kingdom to be subject to Roman law.
Emperor Xiaowen of Northern Wei  fought several battles
The Ambrosian Iliad, an Illuminated manuscript on vellum, of the Iliad of Homer, is produced in Constantinople (approximate date).
The Shaolin Temple (Henan) is founded (according to the Jiaqing Chongxiu Yitongzhi). (For alternate founding date, see  or ).
December  – Consecration of the newly constructed Temple of Saturn in the Roman Forum, and Saturnalia festival first celebrated.
The Persians launch an expedition on the Hellespont and later Caria.
Artybius ends the rebellion in Cyprus.
Emperor Anastasius I abolishes the chrysargyron tax throughout the Eastern Roman Empire, before reforming the monetary system, using Greek numerals instead of Roman.
Prince Buretsu, age , succeeds his father Ninken and becomes the 25th emperor.
Flavian II succeeds Palladius as patriarch of Antioch.

November  – Anastasius is succeeded by Symmachus as the 51st pope, in the official papal selection in the Lateran Palace (Rome). Meanwhile, Antipope Laurentius is elected "pope" in the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore, causing a schism.

Kavadh I returns from exile with support of , Hephthalites (White Huns), and again assumes the Sassanid throne. He punishes his opponents and probably his brother Djamasp, who usurped the throne from him.

Kaunos and Caria, followed by Byzantium and towns in the Hellespont also revolt against the Persians. Cyprus also joins the rebellion, as Onesilus removes his pro-Persian brother, Gorgos, from the throne of Salamis.
Retreating to the coast, the Greek forces are met by the Persians under Artaphernes and defeated in the Battle of Ephesus.

Athens and Eretria respond to the Ionian plea for help against Persia and send troops. An Athenian and Eretrian fleet transports Athenian troops to Ephesus. There they are joined by a force of Ionians and march upon Sardis, the capital of Artaphernes (the satrap of Lydia and brother to Darius I of Persia). Artaphernes, who has sent most of his troops to besiege Miletus, is taken by surprise. However, Artaphernes is able to retreat to the citadel and hold it. Although the Greeks are unable to take the citadel, they pillage the town and set fires that burn Sardis to the ground.
Alexander I succeeds his father Amyntas I as king of Macedonia.

After the assassination of Cleander, tyrant of Gela, power is transferred to his brother, Hippocrates, who subdues the Sicels and conquers the Chalcidian cities of Callipoli, Leontini, Naxos and Zancle (now known as Messina). He also captures the Syracusan city of Camarina, but is prevented from capturing Syracuse itself when Corinth and Corcyra interferes in the war.
March  – During a synod in Rome, which is attended by  bishops and all of the Roman clergy, Pope Symmachus makes Antipope Laurentius bishop of the diocese of Nocera in Campania.

April  – Emperor Xiaowen of Northern Wei dies of starvation in his capital at Luoyang, after a -year reign in which he has Sinicized his tribal relatives (Tuoba clan), created a Chinese-style government and instituted a land-reform program.

September – The  Nicopolis earthquake takes place in the borders between the regions of Mesopotamia, Pontus, and Roman Armenia. It affects the cities of Nicopolis, Neocaesarea (modern Niksar), Arsamosata, and Abarne, as well as the cultural areas of Anatolia (Asia Minor) and Mesopotamia.

Crown prince Xuan Wu Di, age , succeeds his father Xiaowen and becomes emperor of Northern Wei. He appoints his uncle Yuan Xie provincial governor, who serves temporarily as regent to form a new government.
Indian mathematician Aryabhata writes his magnum opus, the Āryabhaṭīya.
Aristagoras seeks help with the revolt against the Persians from Cleomenes I, king of Sparta, but the Spartans are unwilling to respond.

After a failed attack on the rebellious island of Naxos in c.  (on behalf of the Persians), Aristagoras, tyrant of Miletus, to save himself from the wrath of Persia, plans a revolt with the Milesians and the other Ionians. With the encouragement of Histiaeus (his father-in-law and former tyrant of Miletus), Aristagoras induces the Ionian cities of Asia Minor to revolt against Persia, thus instigating the Ionian Revolt and beginning the Greco-Persian Wars between Greece and Persia. The pro-Persian tyrant of Mytilene is stoned to death.

Miltiades the Younger, the ruler of the Thracian Chersonese, which has been under Persian suzerainty since approximately , joins the Ionian revolt. He seizes the islands of Lemnos and Imbros from the Persians.
The Codex Argenteus, Gothic manuscript of bishop Ulfilas's translation of the Bible, is written (approximate date).

Burgundian Civil War: Battle of Dijon: A coalition of Franks and Burgundians crush the forces under Gundobad. King Clovis I pursues him to Avignon, where he surrenders and promises to pay a yearly tribute.
Possible date at which Fergus Mór begins his reign – the historicity of Mór is doubtful.
Traders from southern Arabia settle in northern Ethiopia.

Possible date for the Battle of Mons Badonicus: Romano-British and Celts defeat an Anglo-Saxon army, that may have been led by the bretwalda Aelle of Sussex or possibly Cerdic of Wessex (approximate date; suggested dates range from  to ). This battle may have influenced the legend of King Arthur.
Mesoamerican calendars are developed by the Olmec civilisation
Hanno the Navigator's naval exploration of the western coast of Africa could have reached as far south as Gabon.
Refugees from Teos resettle Abdera.
Vulca makes Apollo of Veii, from Portonaccio Temple, now kept at Museo Nazionale di Villa Giulia, Rome.
Early Pandyan Kingdom was ruled by the Pandyas during the second Sangam period.
Dong Hun Hou is killed during a siege of the capital Jiankang. He is succeeded by his  brother Qi He Di, who becomes emperor of Southern Qi (China).

The Maya are peaking in economic prosperity. The civilization at Teotihuacan begins to decline and its people are migrating to the greatest Mayan city, Tikal, bringing with them ideas about weaponry and new ritual practices.
June  – Ahkal Moʼ Nahb I becomes the new ruler of the Mayan city-state of Palenque (in what is now the state of Chiapas in southern Mexico), and reigns until his death in .
Domangart Réti succeeds his father Fergus Mór, after he dies during a campaign against the Picts. He becomes the new king of Dál Riata (modern Scotland) (according to the Annals of Tigernach).

Pope Symmachus, accused of various crimes by secular authorities who support an ecclesiastical opponent, asserts that the secular ruler has no jurisdiction over him. A synod held in  will confirm that view.

The Nanhua Temple, located southeast of Shaoguan, is founded by the Indian monk Zhiyao Sanzang. The temple covers an area of . hectares ( acres) and consists of a set of historical Buddhist buildings.
December  - Xiao Yan names Xiao Tong his heir designate.
The Persian philosopher Mazdak declares private property to be the source of all evil.
October  – The Synodus Palmaris, called by Gothic king Theodoric the Great, clears Pope Symmachus of all charges, thus ending the schism of Antipope Laurentius.
The Bulgars ravage Thrace. A semi-nomadic people, they have absorbed the surviving Huns and meet no opposition from Byzantine forces.
May – Areobindus, Byzantine general (magister militum), is stationed as commander at Dara, with an army of , men to keep watch at the Persian stronghold of Nisibis (modern Turkey).

War with Sassanid Persia: Emperor Anastasius I sends a Byzantine army (, men) to Armenia, but is defeated. The Romans attempt an unsuccessful siege of the Persian-held city Amida, on the Tigris. King Kavadh I invades Osroene, and lays siege to the city of Edessa (Northern Mesopotamia).
Mundhir III, king of the Lakhmids (Arab Christians), raids Palaestina Salutaris and Arabia Petraea. He captures a large number of Romans.
King Ernakh, third son of Attila the Hun, dies after a -year reign. He is succeeded by his two sons (Utigur and Kutrigur), who share the power with the unified Bulgars.
Theodoric the Great builds the Basilica of Sant'Apollinare Nuovo, originally dedicated to Christ the Redeemer.
King Theodoric the Great defeats the Gepids, and drives them out of their homeland (Pannonia).
War with Sassanid Persia: Emperor Anastasius I gains the upper hand in Armenia, with the renewed investment of Amida.
The Ostrogoths sack Belgrade, on the Danube and Sava rivers (modern Serbia).
King  Kavadh I hands over the fortress-city of Amida, and agrees to an armistice with the Byzantine Empire.
Lý Nguyên Khải, Jiaozhou's governor, rebels against the Liang dynasty, but is suppressed by Lý Tắc, a state official,  and subsequently prosecuted.
Emperor Anastasius I agrees to pay his share of the cost of defending the Caucasian Gates, against nomadic invasions from East Asia.
Anastasius I decides to rebuild the village of Dara (Northern Mesopotamia). He constructs a new strategic fortress to guard the frontier.
The Colosseum (Amphitheatrum Flavium) in Rome suffers damage from an earthquake, as it did in .
The white Huns (Hephthalites) from the Caucasus invade the Persian Empire.
The Visigoths capture the city of Dertosa in Catalonia. They arrest and execute the Roman usurper Peter, sending his head as a trophy to Saragossa (Spain).
Antipope Laurentius is persuaded by Theoderic the Great to resign his claim to the throne of Pope Symmachus, ending a schism in the Catholic Church; Laurentius then fasts until his death.

November – Emperor Anastasius I accepts a peace agreement with the Sasanian Empire (Persia), based on the status quo. He upgrades the fortifications at Batnae, Edessa and Amida (Northern Mesopotamia).

February  – King Alaric II issues the "Lex Romana Visigothorum" or Breviary of Alaric, an abstract of Roman laws and imperial decrees, compiled by a commission appointed to provide a law code for Alaric's Roman subjects. The "Lex Romana" will be the standard for justice in the Visigothic realm.
September  – Council of Agde: The bishops of Visigothic Gaul under the presidency of Caesarius of Arles meet.
Wooden coffins and wooden tools are used in the burial places of the Alemanni.
A Mayan altar with the head of the death god is built in Copán, Honduras.

Battle of Vouillé: A Frankish army under command of Clovis I invades the Visigothic Kingdom, and defeats King Alaric II near Poitiers. The Visigoths refuse to be enslaved, and retreat to Septimania (Southern Gaul). Clovis annexes Aquitania, and captures Toulouse.
Keitai becomes the 26th emperor of Japan (according to the Nihon Shoki).
The town of Guilin, China, is renamed Guizhou.

King Clovis I fails in an effort to take the walled city of Carcassonne (Southern Gaul). He establishes Paris (Lutetia) as his capital and gets baptized, making Roman Catholicism the official religion of the Kingdom of the Franks.
Emperor Anastasius I formally recognizes Clovis I of the Salian Franks as ruler of Gaul. He sends a Byzantine fleet of  warships to raid the coasts of Italy.
King Theodoric the Great sends an Ostrogoth army, led by his sword-bearer Theudis, drives the Franks out of Provence, and recovers Septimania (Languedoc) from the Visigoths.
Battle of Netley: King Cerdic of Wessex moves with an Anglo-Saxon army inland, and defeats the British king, Nudd-Lludd (according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle).
Winter – All the rivers in England are frozen for more than two months.

Clovis I (Chlodowech) becomes the first Catholic king of the Franks, uniting all the Frankish tribes under his rule. He controls an immense territory in Gaul (modern France), and delivers a major blow for the Church against the Arian heresy.
Battle of Llongborth (possibly Langport or Portsmouth): King Budic II of Brittany seeks refuge at the court of Aergol Lawhir, in Dyfed (Wales) after the battle.
The Sasanian Persians conquer the independent kingdom of Caucasian Albania, a state converted to Christianity in the  by Armenian missionaries (approximate date).

King Theodoric the Great raises the Frankish siege at Arles; the city is heroically defended by its inhabitants, assisted by the Ostrogothic general Theudis. The Ostrogoths overrun Provence (Southern Gaul), and consolidate their gains in the region.
Theodoric the Great appoints his friend Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius, Roman philosopher, to the rank of consul of the Ostrogothic Kingdom.
Hippias, second son of Pisistratus and tyrant of Athens, is expelled by a popular revolt supported by Cleomenes I, King of Sparta and his forces.
Euphronios completes Death of Sarpedon, a red-figure decoration on a calyx krater. Euxitheos is a potter. It is now at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
Darius I subdues the Getae and east Thrace in his war against the Scythians.
Construction of Apadana of Darius and Xerxes, ceremonial complex, at Persepolis, Iran started.
Darius I began construction of Parsa (Persepolis).
First Council of Orléans: Clovis I convenes a synod of Gallic bishops to reform the Church, and create a link between the Crown and the Catholic episcopate.
The convent of Saint-Césaire is built in Arles.
Riots erupt in the streets of Antioch, between supporters of Patriarch Flavian II and Emperor Anastasius I, in sympathy with Non-Chalcedonianism.

November  – King Clovis I dies at Paris (Lutetia) at age , and is buried in the Abbey of St. Genevieve. The Merovingian dynasty is continued by his four sons (Theuderic I, Chlodomer, Childebert I and Chlothar I), who divide the Frankish Kingdom and rule from the capitals at Metz, Orléans, Paris and Soissons, respectively.
Macedonius II is deposed as patriarch of Constantinople, and replaced by Timothy I.
Emperor Anastasius I ends a period of moderate eclectic policy, and starts strongly favoring his own monophysitist beliefs.
Areobindus, Byzantine general, is proclaimed emperor during a riot at Constantinople but refuses to take part in the usurpation.
The first written text in the Arabic alphabet is recorded at Zabad (Syria).
The island nation of Usan-guk is conquered by the Silla dynasty (Korea), under general Kim Isabu.
Anastasius I constructs a wall from the Black Sea to the Sea of Marmara, to protect Constantinople from raiding Bulgars and Slavs.
Vitalian accepts an agreement and returns with his army to Lower Moesia. After a few inconclusive skirmishes, Anastasius I sends a Byzantine army (, men) under his nephew Hypatius.

Revolt of Vitalian: Byzantine general Vitalian revolts against Emperor Anastasius I, and conquers a large part of the Diocese of Thrace. He gains the support of the local people, and assembles an army of ,–, men.
King Kavadh I adopts the doctrine of the Mazdakites, and breaks the influence of the magnates' (nobility).
Vitalian defeats the Byzantines at Acris (Bulgaria), on the Black Sea coast. He attacks their fortified Laager in darkness, and in a crushing defeat kills a large part of the imperial army.
Anastasius I sends an embassy under the former consul Patricius to start negotiations. Vitalian declares his aims: restoration of Chalcedonian Orthodoxy and the settling of the Thracian foederati.
Cissa of Sussex becomes king of the South Saxons after his father's death (approximate date).
July  – Pope Symmachus dies at Rome after a tenure of  years,  months and  days. He is succeeded by Hormisdas.

Vitalian, Byzantine general, marches again to Constantinople. A fleet of  vessels sails from the Black Sea ports and blockades the entrance of the harbor capital. Emperor Anastasius I is disquieted by riots in the city, which cost many casualties, and decides to negotiate with Vitalian.
Beopheung becomes king of the Korean kingdom of Silla.

Vitalian accepts the receipt of ransom money and gifts worth , pounds of gold for the release of Hypatius, a nephew of Anastasius I who has been a prisoner since the attack at Acris (see ). Vitalian retreats back to Lower Moesia.
As a sign of his victory, Anastasius I leads a procession to Sosthenion, and attends a service of thanks at the local church dedicated to the Archangel Michael.

Emperor Anastasius I gives Marinus, former praetorian prefect of the East, command over the Byzantine army. He defeats the rebel fleet at the harbor entrance, using a sulfur-based chemical substance, similar to the later Greek fire.
The St. Maurice's Abbey (Switzerland) is founded by Sigismund of Burgundy. He sets up five groups of monks to whom he entrusts the liturgy of the praise of God.
Marinus lands with an army on the shore of Sycae and defeats the rebels. Disheartened by the losses suffered, Vitalian flees north under cover of the night.

Autumn – Revolt of Vitalian:  Byzantine general (magister militum) Vitalian mobilises his army, and marches again towards Constantinople. He captures the suburb of Sycae (modern Turkey) across the Golden Horn, and encamps there.
November  – The Council of Tarragona (modern Spain) is held.
Hygelac, king of the Geats (Sweden), raids the Lower Rhine, and is defeated by a Frankish force led by Theudebert (according to the "History of the Franks").
King Gundobad of the Burgundians dies peacefully after a -year reign, and is succeeded by his eldest son Sigismund.

Emperor Wu appoints Lý Tắc, a Jiaozhou's state official, as the governor. Lý Tắc then suppresses the rebellion of Lý Tông Lão, a former subordinate of Lý Nguyên Khải, the previous governor of Jiaozhou, then beheads him to bring his head to Jiankang, as an offering to the emperor.

Emperor Wu Di of the Liang Dynasty becomes a Buddhist, and introduces the new religion to central China. He demands that sacrifices to imperial ancestors be changed to using dried meat, instead of the traditional animals (goats, pigs and cows).

Council of Epaone: Bishops of southern Gaul convene near Epao (present Anneyron) in Burgundy. The synod enacts the first legislation against wooden altars, forbidding the building of any but stone altars with chrism (a mixture of oil and spice).
Aryabhata compiles his manual of mathematics and astronomy (approximate date).
King Sigismund of Burgundy is opposed by his son Sigeric, and has him strangled. Overcome with remorse, he retreats to the monastery that he founded, St. Maurice's Abbey (modern Switzerland).
An earthquake destroys the city of Scupi (modern-day Skopje, North Macedonia), in what once was the Roman province of Moesia Superior.

Justin I founds the Justinian dynasty and makes his nephew Flavius Petrus Sabbatius (later Justinian I) his trusted advisor. He becomes the emperor's close confidant and possibly acts as regent. Theocritus, candidate to the throne, is accused of a conspiracy and executed.
Jabalah IV ibn al-Harith becomes the king of the Ghassanids. He invades Palestine, but is defeated by a Byzantine army under general (dux) Romanus.

July  – Emperor Anastasius I dies childless at Constantinople, age , after a -year reign in which he has abolished the sale of offices, reformed taxation, and perfected the empire's monetary system, but antagonized some with his heretical Monophysite religious policies. He is succeeded by Justin (Flavius Justinus), his comes excubitorum, commander of the palace guard. After his death, he leaves the imperial treasury richer by ,, solidi or , pounds of gold.
Battle of Badon, British defeat of the Saxons, traditionally associated with King Arthur
The Memoirs of Eminent Monks is compiled.
August  – Theodoric's tricennium, a -year statute of limitations, after which unlawful seizures of land during his  invasion of Italy can no longer be contested, ends.
Jacob of Serugh becomes bishop of Batnan (near modern Diyarbakir, Turkey).
March  – The Eastern and Western churches reconcile their differences, ending the Acacian Schism.
In Ireland, the Diocese of Kildare is erected.
The Kingdom of East Anglia is formed, by the merging of the English counties of Norfolk and Suffolk, and perhaps the eastern part of The Fens  (approximate date).
July – Byzantine general Vitalian becomes consul, and is shortly later murdered, probably on the orders of Justinian, the nephew and heir-apparent of Emperor Justin I.

Priscian, Latin grammarian, writes the Institutiones Grammaticae ("Grammatical Foundations"). In Constantinople, he codifies this manuscript in  volumes, which will be widely used through the Middle Ages. It provides the raw material for the field of speculative grammar.
The construction of the Basilica of San Vitale in Ravenna, is started (approximate date).
Ostrogothic ruler Theodoric the Great builds the Mausoleum of Theodoric as his future tomb in Ravenna (Italy).
Peisistratos a tyrant of Athens dies: his son Hippias inherits his power.
Gautama Buddha attains Enlightenment, and begins his ministry.
Bardiya succeeds Cambyses II as ruler of Persia.
Babylon rebels against Persian rule.
Psammetichus III succeeds Amasis II as king of Egypt.
Boethius introduces Greek musical letter notation to the West.
Ma`adikarib Ya`fur becomes king, supported by the Aksumites; he begins a military campaign against the Arabian tribes.
Ecclesius becomes a bishop of Ravenna.
February  – Samson of Dol is ordained as bishop in Brittany, on the Feast of the Chair of Saint Peter.
Future Byzantine emperor Justinian, age , is appointed consul. He later becomes Commander-in-chief of the Army of the East.
Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius, Roman philosopher, is arrested on charges of having conspired against Theodoric the Great. He is imprisoned at Pavia (Lombardy).
Dhu Nuwas seizes the throne of the Himyarite Kingdom in Yemen. He attacks the Aksumite garrison at Zafar, capturing the city and burning the churches.
Dhū Nuwas moves to Najran, an Aksumite stronghold. After accepting the city's capitulation, he massacres the Christian inhabitants (some sources estimate a death toll up to ,).
Amalaric, age , is proclaimed king of the Visigoths. His kingdom is threatened from the north by the Burgundians.
King Sigismund of Burgundy is defeated by the invading Franks under Chlodomer, Childebert I and Chlothar I. He is captured and taken as prisoner to Aurelianum (modern Orléans).
Hilderic succeeds his uncle Thrasamund after a -year reign, and becomes king of the Vandals and Alans. He favours Catholicism and grants the inhabitants religious freedom.
The Songyue Pagoda is completed during the Northern Wei era; the circular-based tower is still  m ( ft) in height.
Leptis Magna (modern Libya) is sacked by Berber (Moor) raiders. Gelimer leads a successful expedition in North Africa.
Seong becomes king of Baekje, one of the Three Kingdoms of Korea.
May  – King Sigismund of Burgundy is executed at Orléans after an -year reign, and is succeeded by his brother Godomar. He rallies the Burgundian army and begins plundering Frankish territory.

October  – Anicius Manlius Boethius, one of Rome's most prolific writers and philosophers, is beaten to death at the prison at Pavia, where he has been imprisoned for treason. During his prison sentence, he has written his final work,  The Consolation of Philosophy. The date of the death of St. Boethius is later celebrated as his feast day on the Roman Catholic Calendar of Saints.
Date unknown – Queen Guntheuc, widow of Chlodomer, is forced into marrying his brother, Chlothar I. Her two children are murdered by him, but the eldest son Clodoald survives by escaping to Provence.

January  – Venantius Opilio is appointed by Byzantium's Emperor Justin to administer the Western Roman Empire as the Roman consul, replacing Anicius Maximus. The Emperor Justin appoints himself as consul for the West, an office vacant since , but has Theodorus Filoxenus administering the west.

June  – Battle of Vézeronce: The Franks under Chlodomer, Childebert I and Chlothar I are defeated by the Burgundians and allied Ostrogoths near Isère (France), averting the Frankish advance into Burgundy. During the fighting Chlodomer is killed. Later Childebert annexes the cities of Chartres and Orléans.
King Theodoric the Great sends Pope John I to Constantinople, to negotiate a withdrawal of Byzantine emperor Justin's edict against Arian Christianity.
Bernicia (North East England) is settled by the Angles (approximate date).

Cosmas Indicopleustes, Alexandrian explorer-geographer, travels up the Nile. He will venture as far to the east as Ceylon, become a monk, and write "Topographia Christiana" to vindicate the biblical account of the world (see ).
Buddhist caves are completed at Ajanta (India) with stone carvings (approximate date).
The Arian baptistery of Santa Maria is built in Ripa (Rome).
Amalaric, age , becomes king of the Visigoths, and assumes full royal power.
Ecclesius, bishop of Ravenna, commissions two new churches, one for Ravenna and one for its port, Classis.
May  – John I dies of starvation after a -year reign. Theodoric the Great selects Pope Felix IV as the 54th pope.
Amalasuintha rules the Ostrogothic Kingdom that extends throughout the Italian Peninsula, Dalmatia, Sicily, Sardinia and Corsica.
Probably between May  and May  –  Antioch earthquake: A great earthquake kills approximately , people in Syria and Antioch.
Æscwine becomes the first king of Essex (approximate date), defeating Octa in battle at Hackney, west of the River Lea.
King Cerdic of Wessex and his son Cynric defeat the Britons at Cerdicesleah (modern Chearsley).
The Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem is rebuilt until , restoring the architectural tone of the basilica.
August  – Justin I, age , dies at Constantinople and is succeeded by Justinian I, who becomes sole emperor.
Justinian I outlaws pagan religious practices in Egypt, and dispatches Byzantine missionaries to southern territories (approximate date).
April  – Xiaoming's daughter is replaced by the - or -year-old Yuan Zhao as emperor of Northern Wei, by order of Empress Dowager Hu
The Hephthalites (White Huns) move from the Hindu Kush into the Punjab region, and eastward across the Ganges Delta, ravaging cities and Buddhist monasteries.

February  – Emperor Justinian I appoints a commission (including the jurist Tribonian) to codify all laws of the Roman Empire that are still in force from Hadrian to the current date; this becomes the Corpus Juris Civilis.
Bulguksa, a Buddhist temple, is built in South Korea.
Justin, Byzantine general (magister militum), dies in battle against the Bulgars on the frontier of the Danubian limes in Moesia. He is succeeded by Constantiolus.
Rudravarman is granted investiture by China, as the first king of the fourth dynasty of Champa (modern Vietnam).
The Samaritans revolt and are defeated; the Church of the Nativity is burnt down during the Rebellion.
Al-Harith ibn Jabalah becomes the fifth king of the Ghassanids. He helps the Byzantines to suppress the wide-scale Samaritan Revolt.
The Canons of the Council of Orange are established, approving the  Augustinian doctrine of sin and grace over Pelagianism and Semi-Pelagianism, but without Augustine's absolute predestination.
April  – Emperor Justinian I issues the Codex Justinianus (Code of Civil Laws), reformulating Roman law in an effort to control his unruly people (see ).
The Vishnu Temple at Deogarh, Uttar Pradesh (India) is built.
Xiao Tong, eldest son of emperor Wu Di, compiles the Wen Xuan (Literary Selections), a famous anthology of works dating from the Han to the Liang dynasty (approximate date).
September  – Pope Felix IV dies at Rome after a tenure of four years, two months and  days, in which he has condemned semi-pelagianism. He is succeeded by Boniface II, who becomes the 55th pope.
Emperor Xiao Zhuang Di is arrested and imprisoned in a Buddhist temple at Jinyang (Shanxi). He is succeeded by Chang Guang Wang, who becomes the new ruler of Northern Wei.
Tribonian becomes quaestor sacri palatii and chief editor of the compilation of the old Roman lawyers' writings.
Kroisos Kouros, from a cemetery at Anavysos, near Athens is made. It is now on display at the National Archaeological Museum, Athens.
Lucius Tarquinius Superbus becomes seventh King of Rome, after murdering the sixth king Servius Tullius.
—Battle between the Gods and the Giants, fragments of the north frieze of the Siphnian Treasury, from the Sanctuary of Apollo, Delphi, is made. It is now at the Delphi Archaeological Museum.
Cambyses II starts to rule in Persia.
Temple of Apollo at Delphi is built.
The reign of Chang Guang Wang, ruler of Northern Wei, ends. Gao Huan, Chinese general, begins a rebellion and declares another member of the imperial clan, An Ding Wang, emperor.

April  – Battle of Callinicum: A Byzantine army (, men), commanded by Belisarius, is defeated by the Persians at Raqqa (northern Syria). Emperor Justinian I negotiates an end to the hostilities, and Belisarius is hailed as a hero.
Anwon becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Goguryeo.
King Kavad I, age , dies after a -year reign. Khosrau I, his favourite son, is proclaimed successor over his elder brothers.
King Childebert I receives pleas from his sister Clotilde, wife of King Amalaric, claiming that she is abused by her husband. Childebert invades Septimania (Gaul).
First year in which the Anno Domini calendar is used for numbering the years.

September – Justinian I signs a peace treaty, the "Eternal Peace", with the Persian king Khosrau I, ending the Iberian War (-). Both sides agree to return all occupied territories, and Justinian makes a one-off payment of  centenaria (, pounds of gold), as a contribution to the defense of the Caucasus passes.

February  – Emperor Justinian I orders the building of a new Orthodox Christian basilica in Constantinople – the Hagia Sophia. He chooses Isidore of Miletus and Anthemius of Tralles as architects. The material for the construction is brought from all over the empire, such as large stones from quarries in Porphyry, Egypt. More than , people are employed.

January  – Nika riots in Constantinople: Anger among the supporters of the most important chariot teams—the Blues and the Greens—escalates into violence towards the emperor. For the next five days the capital is in chaos. The fires that start during the tumult result in the destruction of much of the city. The insurrection is put down a week later by Belisarius and Mundus; , people are killed in the Hippodrome.
Silla conquers the city-state of Geumgwan Gaya (Korea) during the Three Kingdoms period.

June  – A Byzantine expeditionary fleet under Belisarius sails in  transports, escorted by  war vessels (dromons), manned by , seamen from Constantinople, to attack the Vandals in Africa, via Greece and Sicily. The fleet carries , infantry, about half Byzantine and half foederati, and , cavalry, consisting of , Byzantine horsemen, , foreign allies (Huns and Heruli) and , of Belisarius' retainers (bucellarii). On the flagship Belisarius is accompanied by his military secretary Procopius, and his wife Antonina.
March  – In a letter, Emperor Justinian I declares the Bishop of Rome (currently John) to be "head of all Bishops, and the true and effective corrector of heretics."

Spring – Vandalic War: Anti-Vandal revolt in Tripolitania and Sardinia; Gelimer, king of the Vandals, dispatches the bulk of the Vandal fleet ( ships and , men) under his brother Tzazo to Sardinia. Byzantine forces from Cyrenaica occupy Leptis Magna and Tripolis.

January  – After an interregnum of  months and  days, Pope John II becomes the 56th pope of Rome, and the first to adopt a regnal name upon elevation to the papacy (his birth name, Mercurius, being of pagan origin).
Theudebert I succeeds his father Theuderic I and becomes king of Austrasia.
November  – A second and final revision of the Codex Justinianus is published.

March – King Gelimer surrenders to Belisarius, after spending a winter in the mountains of Numidia. He and large numbers of captured Vandals are transported to Constantinople. The Vandal Kingdom ends, and the African provinces return to the Byzantine Empire.
Toledo becomes the capital of the Visigothic Kingdom that controls the Iberian Peninsula. King Theudis expands Visigoth rule in the southern regions (Hispania Baetica).
The Frankish kings Childebert I and Chlothar I overthrow Godomar, king of the Burgundians, and end the Kingdom of Burgundy.

Summer – Belisarius arrives in Constantinople and is permitted by Emperor Justinian I to celebrate a triumph, the first non-imperial triumph for over  years. In the procession the spoils of the Temple of Jerusalem and the Vandal treasure are paraded.
The death of Amalasuintha gives Byzantine Emperor Justinian I a pretext to invade Italy and begin the Gothic War.
Spring – Solomon defeats the Moorish rebels at Mount Mammes and Mount Bourgaon. He secures Byzacena (modern Tunisia) and establishes fortifications along the Numidian border.
April – Justinian I reorganises the province as an African prefecture, centered in Carthage. He restores frontier defences, and returns property to the Catholic Church.
Justinian I issues the Lex Julia and declares that a wife has no right to bring criminal charges of adultery against a husband. This makes divorce almost impossible in the Byzantine Empire.
Anthimus I becomes patriarch of Constantinople (–).
Before March  – Anthimus I is deposed as patriarch of Constantinople in favour of Menas.
August – Volcanic winter of : Snow falls in China, which causes the harvest to be delayed.

March – Ostrogothic King Theodahad cedes Provence and upper Alamannia to the Franks, gaining their support in the war. He sends a large Gothic army into Dalmatia. They defeat the Byzantines, Mundus is killed during the fighting at Salona, and the Byzantine army withdraws.

Winter – Belisarius sets up his headquarters on the Pincian Hill, and repairs the neglected city walls of Rome. He stations a ,-man garrison, of whom half are his personal bodyguard (bucellarii). To hold parts of the city, he recruits , young Romans to man the walls.
March – April – Belisarius sails to Carthage with , men, to suppress a mutiny against Solomon. Meanwhile, Carthage is besieged by , rebels, including many Vandals, under Stotzas.

December – Belisarius sends John "the Sanguinary" with a force of , men towards Picenum, to plunder the east coast of Italy. He arrives at Ariminum (Rimini), where he is welcomed by the local Roman population.
December  – The construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople (begun in ) is completed.
John Cottistis starts a short-lived rebellion against Justinian I. He is declared emperor at Dara, but is killed four days later by conspiring soldiers.
The Aqua Virgo aqueduct is destroyed by the Goths; they try to use the underground channel as a secret route to invade Rome.

June – In Rome, famine brings the city to despair; Belisarius sends his secretary Procopius to Naples for more reinforcements and supplies. Vitiges arranges a three-month armistice for Gothic envoys to travel to Constantinople.
The Kofun period ends and the Asuka period, the second part of the Yamato period in Japan, begins.
Gabrán mac Domangairt becomes king of Dál Riata (Scotland).
March  – Siege of Rome: King Vitiges of the Ostrogoths ends his siege (after  days) and abandons Rome. He retreats with his Gothic army northeast along the Via Flaminia.
The Third Council of Orléans takes place, and prohibits rural labor on Sunday.

King Seong of Paekche (Korea) moves the capital from Ungjin (present-day Gongju) further south to Sabi (present-day Buyeo County), on the Geum River. He sends a diplomatic mission that formally introduces Buddhism to the Japanese imperial court (see also ).
Emperor Justinian I becomes alarmed by renewed barbarian incursions across the Danube frontier from the Slavs, the Bulgars,  the Gepids, and the Avars.
Kinmei succeeds his brother Senka, and ascends as 29th emperor to the throne of Japan.
November  – Antioch is struck by an earthquake.
Walthari murders his uncle Wacho and becomes king of the Lombards.

Belisarius, still besieging Ravenna, negotiates a treaty with Theodebert I (whose forces are suffering from dysentery), and the Franks retreat to Gaul. The Byzantine fleet controls the Adriatic Sea and blockades the port of the capital from supplies.
In Britain various kingdoms are united by a ruler (High King) or overlord, while wars are fought between others.
May – Gothic War: Belisarius conquers Mediolanum (modern-day Milan) and the Gothic capital Ravenna. Vitiges and his wife Matasuntha are taken as captives to Constantinople.
Jinheung becomes king of the Korean kingdom of Silla.

King Khosrow I breaks the "Eternal Peace" treaty with the Byzantine Empire after eight years. Responding to an embassy from the Ostrogoths urging action against Emperor Justinian I's expanding power, he leads the Persian army up the River Euphrates. Extracting tributes from towns along the way, Khosrau I besieges and captures Antioch. He plunders the city extensively, transporting valuable artworks, including marble statues and mosaics, back to Persia.
King Custennin ap Cado is deposed, and returns to Dumnonia in the south-west of Great Britain.
Amasis Painter makes Dionysos with maenads, black-figure decoration on an amphora. It is now at Bibliotheque Nationale de France, Paris.

Sparta and Argos fight the Battle of the  Champions. Both sides had agreed beforehand to resolve their dispute with just  picked men on each side, in the end just one Spartan and two Argive soldiers remained alive. Both sides claimed victory.
A coup d'état in Qi kingdom.
The peace conference between the kingdoms in China. A treaty between Jin, Chu and some other kingdoms was signed.
Cyrus establishes a garrison in Sardis and incorporates the Greek cities of Ionia in Asia Minor into Persian Empire. Thus he gains the important ports that look out to the Mediterranean world.

Emperor Justinian I recalls Belisarius from Italy to handle the situation in Armenia. He arrives in Upper Mesopotamia and attacks the fortress city of Nisbis. After an unsuccessful siege he ravages the countryside.
Autumn – Totila is elected king by the Ostrogothic nobles after the death of his uncle Ildibad. He wins the support of the lower classes by liberating slaves and distributing land to the peasants.
Lý Bí initiates a rebellion against the ruling Chinese Liang dynasty in Giao Châu province.

Lazic War: King Khosrau I intervenes in Lazica (modern Georgia), and supports the weakened king Gubazes II against a full-scale uprising. He sends an expeditionary force under Mermeroes and captures the Byzantine stronghold of Petra, located on the coast of the Black Sea, which provides the Persians a strategic port.
Winter – Siege of Verona: Totila defends the city of Verona against a numerically superior Byzantine army. He gains control over the Po Valley and prepares a Gothic offensive in Central Italy.
Battle of Mucellium: Totila marches down into Tuscany and defeats the Byzantines at Florence, in the valley of Mugello. He treats his prisoners well, and many are induced to join his banner.
Gildas, British monk, writes his work "De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae" (approximate date).
Spring – Battle of Faventia: King Totila scatters the Byzantine forces near Faventia (modern Faenza) with , men, beginning the resurgence of Gothic resistance to the reconquest of Italy.
Siege of Naples: Totila besieges the city of Naples in Campania. A Byzantine relief force from Sicily is intercepted and almost destroyed by Gothic warships.

Lazic War – Justinian I sends a Byzantine army (, men) to Armenia. The Persians, severely outnumbered, are forced to retreat, but at Dvin the Byzantines are defeated by a force of , men in an ambush, and are completely routed.
The Hephthalites threaten the Sasanian Empire from the East. They extend their domain in Central Asia (approximate date).

Barsanuphius, a famous hermit close to Gaza, retreats fully from the world after the death of Seridus, abbot of the nearby monastery, and fellow hermit John the Prophet with whom he wrote over  letters to people seeking his advice and guidance. Aelianos follows Seridus as abbot of the monastery.
King Pulakeshin I establishes the Chalukya dynasty in India. He extends his kingdom by conquering Vakataka and the west coast of Karnataka, giving him access to the valuable Arabian Sea trade routes.
The fortress city of Old Dongola (modern Sudan) along the River Nile becomes the capital of the Kingdom of Makuria. Several churches are built, including the "Old Church" (approximate date).

Spring – Siege of Naples (–): The Byzantine garrison (, men) in Naples surrenders to the Ostrogoths, pressed by famine and demoralized by the failure of two relief efforts. The defenders are well treated by King Totila, and the garrison is allowed safe departure, but the city walls are partly razed.
Jacob Baradaeus consecrates Sergius of Tella as patriarch of Antioch, opening a permanent schism between the Syriac Orthodox Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church.
Belisarius defeats the Gothic army under King Totila, who unsuccessfully besieges the city of Otranto (southern Italy). After their retreat, the Byzantines march towards the city of Rome.
Justinian I issues a new edict condemning the Three Chapters. In Western Europe, Pope Vigilius refuses to acknowledge the imperial edict and is ordered to summon to Constantinople.
October – The Liang dynasty retaliates against Van Xuân, and sends an imperial army (, men) under Chen Baxian to re-occupy the region.
February – Lý Bí is declared emperor and establishes the empire Van Xuân (modern Vietnam). His armies repel attacks from the kingdom of Champa.
King Khosrau I signs a five year truce with the Byzantine Empire, but war continues to ravage the Caucasus region, especially in Armenia.
Emperor Justinian I sends Narses, Byzantine general, to the rulers of the Heruli, to recruit troops for the campaigns in Italy and Syria.
Yangwon becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Goguryeo.
The Synod of Brefi is held at Llanddewi Brefi, to condemn the Pelagian heresy. Dubricius, archbishop of South Wales, resigns his position in favour of David (approximate date).
Gothic War: King Totila establishes his military base at Tivoli (Central Italy), and prepares a campaign to reconquer the region of Latium.

December  – Sack of Rome: After almost a year's siege, the capture of a grain fleet sent by the exiled Pope Vigilius near the mouth of the Tiber, and failure of troops of the Byzantine Empire under Belisarius to relieve the city, the Ostrogoths under King Totila plunder Rome and destroy its fortifications. He then withdraws to Apulia (Southern Italy).
Audoin receives subsidies from Justinian I, to encourage him to battle the Gepids in the Carpathian Mountains.
May  – First Tikal-Calakmul War: After a victory by Calakmul, Aj Wosal Chan K'inich is installed as the new ruler of the Mayan city state of Naranjo in Guatemala, and reigns until his death in .
Audoin murders and succeeds Walthari as king of the Lombards.
The Basilica of San Vitale (Ravenna) is completed by bishop Maximianus, during the Byzantine Exarchate of Ravenna.
Theudebald, age , succeeds his father Theudebert I after a reign of  years, and becomes king of Austrasia (or ).
The mosaic panels of Justinian I and Theodora I with attendants, in the Basilica of San Vitale (Ravenna), are made (approximate date).
The Tonkin revolt (Vietnam), led by Lý Nam Đế, is suppressed by the Chinese Liang dynasty.
King Ida establishes the kingdom of Bernicia. He builds Bamburgh Castle (northeast England) as a fortress that will become the seat of Anglo-Saxon kings (according to the Historia Brittonum).

Battle of Marta: The Byzantine army under John Troglita is defeated by Moorish tribes in Tripolitania. He flees to Lunci ( km south of Mahares), and is forced to withdraw north to the fortress of Laribus (near modern El Kef).
Theudigisel, Visigothic general, proclaims himself ruler over the Visigothic Kingdom, after King Theudis is assassinated.
Mermeroes stations a garrison of , men in the stronghold of Petra, and marches to Armenia. The Persians, lacking sufficient supplies, secure the supply routes and plunder Lazica.
Emperor Justinian I relieves Belisarius from military service, in favour of -year-old Byzantine general Narses.
Gubazes II besieges the fortress of Petra, located on the Black Sea. The Persian army under Mermeroes defeats a small Byzantine force guarding the mountain passes, and relieves Petra.
Saint Catherine's Monastery is established in the Sinai Peninsula.
Agila I succeeds Theudigisel as king of the Visigoths, after he is murdered by a group of conspirators during a banquet in Seville.
– – Transfiguration of Christ, mosaic in the apse, Church of the Virgin, Saint Catherine's Monastery in Egypt, is made.

Spring – Lazic War: The Byzantine army under Bessas combines forces with King Gubazes II, and defeats the Persians in Lazica (modern Georgia) in a surprise attack. The survivors retreat into Caucasian Iberia.
The Romans unsuccessfully besiege Petra, Lazica.
Jianwen Di succeeds his father Wu Di as emperor of the Liang Dynasty (China).
Siege of Rome: The Ostrogoths under Totila besiege Rome for the third time, after Belisarius has returned to Constantinople. He offers a peace agreement, but this is rejected by Emperor Justinian I.
January  – Gothic War: The Ostrogoths under king Totila recapture Rome after a long siege, by bribing the Isaurian garrison.

The churches of Lazica (Georgia) and Armenia split. While the Armenian Church remains independent, the Georgian church unites with the Byzantine Empire. This ecclesiastical union deepens political and cultural contact between the two states. As a sign of Lazica's status vis-à-vis Byzantium, Lazic princes are vested with honorific titles of the Byzantine court, including kouropalates, or "minister of the imperial palace" (approximate date).
The Gupta Empire falls; India is again ruled by regional kingdoms (approximate date).
Summer – Totila plunders Sicily, after he subdues Corsica and Sardinia. He sends a Gothic fleet to raid the coasts of Greece.
Construction of Quiriguá (Guatemala) begins (approximate date).
The Temple of Artemis is completed in Ephesus.
Abdera is destroyed by the Thracians.
Medo-Persian conflict, the Persian king Cyrus II overthrows the Median king Astyages, establishing the First Persian Empire.
King Cambyses I of Anshan dies and is succeeded by his son Cyrus II the Great.
Nabonidus succeeds Labashi-Marduk as king of Babylon.

After the death of his cousin Germanus, Justinian I appoints Narses new supreme commander, and returns to Italy. In Salona on the Adriatic coast, he assembles a Byzantine expeditionary force totaling , or possibly , men and a contingent of foreign allies, notably Lombards, Heruls and Bulgars.

Gothic War: Narses arrives in Venetia and discovers that a powerful Gothic-Frank army (, men), under joint command of the kings Totila and Theudebald, has blocked the principal route to the Po Valley. Not wishing to engage such a formidable force and confident that the Franks would avoid a direct confrontation, Narses skirts the lagoons along the Adriatic shore, by using vessels to leapfrog his army from point to point along the coast. In this way he arrives at the capital Ravenna without encountering any opposition. He attacks and crushes a small Gothic force at Ariminum (modern Rimini).
, Kutrigurs appear in Europe led by Chinialus and others to assist the Gepids.

Spring – Lazic War - Siege of Petra (–): The Byzantine army and their Sabir allies (some , men) under Bessas recapture the strategic Byzantine fortress of Petra, located on the coast of the Black Sea. He orders the city walls razed to the ground.

Autumn – Xiao Dong, great-nephew of the rebellious general Hou Jing, succeeds Jianwen Di as emperor of the Liang Dynasty. Xiao Dong has no real power and Hou Jing controls the imperial government at the capital Jiankang.
Eutychius becomes patriarch of Constantinople.
Buddhism in Japan is introduced, according to the Nihon Shoki.
Teia becomes the last king of the Ostrogoths in Italy.
Emperor Justinian I dispatches a small Byzantine force (, men) under Liberius to Hispania, according to the historian Jordanes. He conquers Cartagena and other cities on the southeastern coast.
The Roman Catholic Diocese of Meath is established in Ireland.

Gothic War: Frankish invasion — Two Frankish-Alemanni dukes, brothers Lothair and Buccelin, cross the Alps from Germany with a force of , men, mostly Frankish infantry. In the Po Valley, they win an easy victory over a much smaller Byzantine force at Parma, and are joined by remnants of the Gothic armies, bringing the total strength of the invaders to about , men. Narses, gathering his forces as quickly as possible, marches north to harass the Franks, but is not strong enough to engage them in battle. In Samnium (Southern Italy) the brothers divide their forces: Lothaire goes down the east coast, then returns to the north, to winter in the Po Valley. Buccelin follows the west coast into Calabria, where he spends the winter — his army being seriously wasted by attrition and disease.
The Sassanid commander Mihr-Mihroe force the Byzantines to retreat from Telephis and later Ollaria. (See Battle of Telephis–Ollaria).
May  – The Fifth Ecumenical Council is held in Constantinople. In an edict, Emperor Justinian I condemns the Three Chapters, causing further schisms and heresies of monoenergism and monothelitism.
King Seong of Baekje attacks the kingdoms of Goguryeo and Silla. However, under a secret agreement, Silla troops attack the exhausted Baekje army, and take possession of the entire Han River valley.

Battle of Mons Lactarius: King Teia secretly marches to join forces with his brother Aligern in Campania, to relieve the siege of Cumae. Meanwhile at Mons Lactarius (modern Monti Lattari), Narses lays an ambush. The combined Gothic force is crushed in a hopeless last stand for two days (south of Naples), and Teia is killed in the fighting. Aligern escapes, but surrenders a few months later.
The second and larger of the two Buddhas of Bamyan is erected in central Afghanistan.
August  – The  Anatolia earthquake takes place in the southwest coasts of Anatolia (Asia Minor). It affects the Güllük Gulf (Mandalya Gulf), and the island of Kos.
Al-Mundhir III ibn al-Nu'man is defeated and killed by the Ghassanids under al-Harith ibn Jabalah, at the battle of Yawm Halima; 'Amr III ibn al-Mundhir succeeds as king of the Lakhmids.
After a protracted siege, Jiangling fell to the Western Wei army.
Wei Shou completes compilation of the Book of Wei.
An earthquake devastates the city of Latakia (modern Syria).
Chinese Liang dynasty: Jing Di, age , succeeds his father Yuan Di and is declared emperor by general Chen Baxian.
Cybi Felyn, abbot of Holyhead, dies at his monastery in Caer Gybi (approximate date).
The Rouran Khaganate ends; it is defeated by the Göktürks under Muqan Qaghan, who expands his rule in Central Asia.
Around this time, the historian Jordanes writes several books, among them De origine actibusque Getarum (The origin and deeds of the Goths).
Siege of Phasis: The Persians are defeated at the besieged town of Phasis in Lazica, held by the Byzantines.
Lazic War: A Byzantine expeditionary force under Justin retakes Archaeopolis (modern Georgia), and routs the Persian army.
King Khosrau I opens negotiations with Justinian I, leading to the establishment of a  year peace agreement in .
King Cynric and his son Ceawlin of Wessex fight against the Britons at Beranburh, now identified as Barbury Castle (Wiltshire) in South West England.
April  – The diplomatic representative (apocrisiarius) to Constantinople is elected as Pope Pelagius I, succeeding Vigilius as the 60th pope of Rome.
The Western Wei Dynasty ends: Yuwen Hu deposes emperor Gong Di, and places Yuwen Tai's son Xiaomin on the throne. Yuwen Hu becomes regent and establishes the Northern Zhou dynasty in China.

The Avars arrive in the northern region of the Caucasus, between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea. They send envoys to the Byzantines in Lazica (modern Georgia). Like the Huns, the Avars are the former elite of a central Asian federation, which has been forced to flee westwards.
The Jiming Temple in Nanjing is built; the Buddhist pagoda is located near Xuanwu Lake.
King Chlothar I of the Franks founds the Abbey of St. Medard at Soissons (Northern France).
The Liang dynasty ends: Chen Wu Di, a distinguished general, becomes the first emperor of the Chen dynasty in Southern China.
The Bangor Abbey is founded by the Irish abbot Comgall in Northern Ireland (approximate date).
The Avars and the Slavs occupy the Hungarian Plain on the Balkans. The threat of Avar domination prompts the Lombards to migrate to Italy.
May  – In Constantinople, the dome of the Hagia Sophia collapses due to an earthquake. Emperor Justinian I orders the dome to be rebuilt.
December  – The Abbey of Saint-Germain-des-Prés is dedicated by Germain, bishop of Paris.
December  – Chlothar I is crowned King of the Franks.

Winter – The Kutrigurs and Huns under Zabergan cross the frozen Danube River, and invade the Balkans. They raid Thracia and Macedonia, but are driven back near Constantinople by a Byzantine force under Belisarius.

First successful human flight: a kite carrying Yuan Huangtou lands in the proximity of Ye, China. Emperor Wen Xuan Di sponsors the flight; Yuan is taken prisoner; other imprisoned kite flyers also fly, but those die and Yuan survives. Yuan is executed afterwards.
Pyeongwon becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Goguryeo.
Battle of Melantias: Outside the city walls of Constantinople, Belisarius defeats the combined "barbarians" with his veteran cavalry (bucellarii), and a few thousand hastily raised levies.
Glappa succeeds his father Ida as king of Bernicia (North East England). During his rule, Anglian settlers expand their territory in what is now southeastern Scotland.
Ælla becomes king of Deira (this according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle).
Ceawlin succeeds his father Cynric as king of Wessex (approximate date).
Alboin succeeds his father Audoin after his death, as king of the Lombards.
Columba quarrels with Finnian of Moville over authorship of a psalter, leading to a pitched battle the next year.
Adda succeeds his brother Glappa as king of Bernicia (approximate date).
The statue known as The Calf Bearer (Moschophoros), from the Acropolis, Athens, is completed.
The 24th Jain Tirthankara, Mahavira, takes Diksha.
May, —Servius Tullius, king of Rome, celebrates a triumph for his victory over the Etruscans.
Neriglissar succeeds Amel-Marduk as king of Babylon.
The first known Panathenaic Games of Ancient Greece are held in Athens.
The Battle of Cúl Drebene (modern Ireland) is fought between the Northern and Southern Uí Néill (approximate date).
March  – Pope Pelagius I dies in Rome after a five-year reign, and is succeeded by John III as the 61st pope.

November  – King Chlothar I ("the Old") dies at Compiègne at age . The Merovingian dynasty is continued by his four sons (Charibert I, Guntram, Sigebert I and Chilperic I), who divide the Frankish Kingdom and rule from the capitals at Paris, Orléans, Reims and Soissons, respectively.
Sky Witness is crowned as leader of Calakmul.
The First Council of Braga is held. The council condemns the doctrine of Priscillianism.
Spring – Xiao Ming Di, age , succeeds his father Xuan Di as emperor of the Chinese Liang Dynasty.
The last Ostrogothic strongholds at Verona and Brixia are taken by the Byzantine Empire, ending the Gothic War.
First Tikal-Calakmul War: The Maya state of Caracol (Belize) defeats King Wak Chan K'awiil (Double Bird) of Tikal in battle, ending his dynasty.
Silla, by order of king Jinheung, wages war upon Gaya (Three Kingdoms of Korea) and conquers it.
King Sigebert I repels an attack on Austrasia by the Avars at Regensburg (Germany). He moves his capital from Reims to Metz (approximate date).
Emperor Justinian I pardons Belisarius; he orders his release from prison, and  restores his properties and honours. He permits the general to live in obscurity, and gives him a veterans' pension.
The new Hagia Sophia (cost: , pounds of gold), with its numerous chapels and shrines, octagonal dome and mosaics, becomes the centre and most visible monument of Eastern Orthodoxy.

Columba, Irish missionary monk, travels to Scotland with twelve companions. He lands on the Kintyre Peninsula, near Southend, and begins his evangelising mission to the Picts. On the island of Iona, he founds a monastery (Iona Abbey) on the west coast in the Inner Hebrides.

Tauredunum event: A mountain landslide into the Rhone river destroys a fort and two villages, and creates a tsunami in Lake Geneva. The wave which reaches Lausanne is thirteen metres high, and eight metres high by the time it hits Geneva. Describing the event, Marius Aventicensis writes that the tsunami "devastated very old villages with their men and cattle, it even destroyed many sacred places", and swept away "the bridge in Geneva, windmills and men".
Samson of Dol, one of seven founder saints of Brittany, attends a council in Paris and witnesses several royal decrees (approximate date).
August  – Columba reports seeing the Loch Ness Monster at the River Ness (according to the "Life of St. Columba").
Tulum, Maya walled city, on the Yucatán Peninsula (modern Mexico) is first mentioned on a stele inscription.
Cadoc, abbot of Llancarfan (Wales), settles in Weedon and is made bishop (approximate date).

January  – Patriarch Eutychius of Constantinople is deposed as Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople by Justinian I after he refuses the Byzantine Emperor's order to adopt the tenets of the Aphthartodocetae, a sect of Monophysites. From April  he is replaced by John Scholasticus.
February  – Kʼan Joy Chitam I, ruler of the Mayan city-state of Palenque, in what is now the state of Chiapas in southern Mexico, dies after a reign of exactly  years.
Agathias begins to write a history, beginning where Procopius finished his work.
Columba, an Irish missionary, spots the Loch Ness Monster on the River Ness (in present day Scotland) and saves the life of a Pict (approximate date).

November  – Justin II succeeds his uncle Justinian I as emperor of the Byzantine Empire. He begins his reign by refusing subsidies to the Avars, who conduct several large-scale raids through the Balkan Peninsula.
Ainmuire mac Sétnai becomes High King of Ireland, and rules from – (this according to the Book of Leinster).

Emperor Justin II, facing an empty treasury, breaks the treaty with the Gepids that has existed since . King Alboin of the Lombards makes an alliance with the Avars under Bayan I, at the expense of tough conditions. They demand a tenth of the Lombards' cattle and half of the war booty.

A Byzantine army, under command of Baduarius, assists the Gepids in their war against the Lombards. The Byzantines win the first battle in the lower Danube (Moesia), but Gepid King Cunimund refuses to hand back the fortress city of Sirmium (modern Serbia), as he had promised.
Kirtivarman I succeeds his father Pulakeshin I as king of the Chalukya dynasty (India). During his rule he completes the subjugation of the Kadambas and annexes the port of Goa.
A major volcanic eruption occurs in the Antarctic.
King Charibert I dies without an heir; his realm (region Neustria and Aquitaine) is divided between his brothers Guntram, Sigebert I and Chilperic I.
John III, patriarch of Constantinople, organizes a compromise between the Chalcedonians and Monophysites.
The Lombard–Gepid War () ends with a Lombard-Avar victory, and the annihilation of the Gepids.
Liuva I succeeds his predecessor Athanagild, after an interregnum of five months, and becomes king of the Visigoths.
The Second Council of Tours is held. It decrees that any cleric found in bed with his wife will be excommunicated.
Paulinus I, patriarch of Aquileia, flees with the treasures of his church and transfers them to the island of Grado.
Æthelric succeeds his brother Adda as king of Bernicia (modern Scotland). He rules from – (approximate date).
Emperor Justin II and his wife Sophia send the Cross of Justin II ("Vatican Cross") to Rome, to improve the relations with the Byzantine Empire.

Spring – The Lombards, led by King Alboin, cross the Julian Alps. Their invasion of Northern Italy is almost unopposed; withered Byzantine forces, that remain in the Po Valley and are based at Ravenna, are no match for the overwhelming Lombard incursion. Residents of the Italian countryside flee at the Lombards' approach. Some retreat to the barrier islands along the shore of the Northern Adriatic Sea, where they establish permanent settlements: the nascent city of Venice.

The Byzantines abandon present-day Lombardy and Tuscany, to establish a frontier march in the hills south of Ravenna (still known as Le Marche). Bavarians, Sarmatians, Saxons and Taifali, join the invasion en route. As they advance, the vacuum left behind them on the Balkan Peninsula is filled by Avars, Bulgars and Slavs.
Gisulf I, nephew of Alboin, is appointed as the first duke of Friuli (approximate date).
November  – In Poitiers the "Vexilla Regis" is first sung during the Procession.
John of Ephesus completes his "Biographies of Eastern Saints" (approximate date).
The Nubian kingdom of Alodia is converted to Christianity by Byzantine missionaries (according to John of Ephesus).
September – The Lombards conquer Forum Iulii (Cividale del Friuli) in northeastern Italy. Later in the year, the Lombards conquer Milan.

Muhammad, Islamic prophet, is born in Mecca (today's Saudi Arabia). His father Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib dies a few months before his birth, so he and his mother Aminah bint Wahb are protected by Muhammad's paternal grandfather, Abdul Muttalib, who is recognized as the leading figure in his tribe, the Quraysh.
A limestone statue of Boddhisattva is created in Henan (approximate date).
The anonymous Pilgrim of Piacenza travels the Holy Sites of Christianity in Syria, Palestine and Sinai, an experience that he later writes down as a travel report (approximate date).

Abraha, Christian ruler of coastal Yemen, who was acting as a general for the Christian kingdom in Abyssinia, begins a military expedition in Arabia against the predominantly pagan Quraysh of Mecca, known as the Year of the Elephant.
Spoleto becomes the capital of an independent duchy, under the Lombard chieftain Faroald (approximate date).
Temples and public buildings begin to grace Rome. The main temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus is built.
The François Vase, a volute krater with black figure decoration, is made by a pair of Greek craftsmen: the potter Ergotimos and the painter Kleitias.
The Nemean Games are founded at Nemea (traditional date).
Amasis II succeeds Apries as king of Egypt.
Servius Tullius succeeds the assassinated Lucius Tarquinius Priscus as the sixth King of Rome (traditional date).
The Monophysites again reject the Council of Chalcedon, causing another schism.
Benevento becomes the capital of an independent duchy, under the Lombard chieftain Zotto (approximate date).
Battle of Bedcanford: The Anglo-Saxons under King Cuthwulf fight against the Britons, and conquer the settlements of Aylesbury, Benson, Eynsham and Limbury (according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle).
Wuffa becomes the first king of East Anglia, as recorded in the Anglo-Saxon royal genealogies (approximate date).

The Visigoths under King Liuvigild invade the Byzantine province of Spania (modern Andalusia), and seize the city of Córdoba.   After the death of his brother Liuva I, he becomes sole ruler of the Visigothic Kingdom (approximate date).

June  – Alboin, king of the Lombards, is murdered at Verona in his palace, at the instigation of his wife Rosamund (daughter of the Gepid king Cunimund), and her henchman, Helmechis (the king's squire); both flee to seek Byzantine protection in Ravenna. Alboin is succeeded as king by Cleph, who is not related by blood.

Byzantine–Sassanid War of –: Emperor Justin II refuses to pay the annual tribute to Khosrau I, putting an end to the -year peace treaty established ten years earlier. The Armenians are considered allies to the Byzantine Empire, and Justin sends a Byzantine army into Persian territory, besieging the fortress city of Nisibis (modern Turkey).
Theodric succeeds his brother Æthelric as king of Bernicia (southeastern Scotland). He rules until .
Calakmul defeats Tikal, bringing an end to the First Tikal-Calakmul War.
Bidatsu succeeds his father Kinmei and ascends to the throne of Japan as the 30th emperor.
Sigibert I appoints Gregory to succeed his mother's cousin, Eufronius, as bishop of Tours (approximate date).
King Cleph completes the Lombard conquest of Tuscany (Central Italy) and extends his dominion to the gates of Ravenna.

Byzantine–Sassanid War: Persian forces under the command of King Khosrau I capture the Byzantine stronghold of Dara, after a six-month siege. Meanwhile, a smaller Persian army under Adarmahan advances from Babylon through the desert, crosses the Euphrates River and ravages Syria. The cities of Apamea and Antiochia are plundered.

King Sigibert I goes to war against his half brother Chilperic I of Neustria at the urging of his wife, Brunhilda. He appeals to the Germans on the right bank of the Rhine for help, and they obligingly attack the environs of Paris and Chartres.
The Lombards again raid Southern Gaul, but are defeated by the Franks under Mummolus, patricius and son of the Gallo-Roman count of Auxerre, and are driven out.
King Cleph is murdered after an -month reign by a guard, a slave who he has mistreated. For the next decade, the Lombard Kingdom is governed by independent duchies (Rule of the Dukes).
December  – Emperor Justin II retires due to recurring seizures of insanity; he abdicates the throne in favour of his general Tiberius. Justin proclaims him Caesar and adopts him as his own son.
July  – Pope John III dies at Rome after a -year tenure. The Holy See becomes sede vacante until June of the following year.
The Visigoths under King Liuvigild invade Cantabria (Northern Spain), and destroy the city of Amaya (Burgos). He massacres the inhabitants and adds the province to the Visigothic Kingdom.
A major volcanic eruption occurs in the Antarctic.
Tardu succeeds his father Istämi, as governor (yabgu) of the Western Turkic Khaganate (Central Asia).

The Franks under Sigibert I pursue his half brother Chilperic I, and conquer the cities Poitiers and Tournai. While he is proclaimed new king of Neustria by the nobles, Sigibert is assassinated at Vitry-en-Artois (Northern Gaul) by hirelings of Fredegund.
The Visigoths under King Liuvigild invade the Suebian Kingdom (Northern Spain). Intermarriage between Goths and non-Goths is allowed in the Visigothic Kingdom (approximate date).
June  – Pope Benedict I succeeds Pope John III as the 62nd pope.
The Anglo-Saxon kingdom of East Anglia is divided into the English counties of Norfolk and Suffolk, and perhaps the eastern part of the Cambridgeshire Fens (approximate date).
The Göktürks under Tardu cross the Cimmerian Bosporus into the Crimea, and besiege the city of Panticapaeum (Ukraine).
Jinji becomes king of the Korean kingdom of Silla.
Baduarius, son-in-law of the Byzantine emperor Justin II, is sent to Italy to resist the Lombard conquest. He leads an aborted counter-assault against the Lombards and dies soon after.

Byzantine–Sassanid War: A Persian army under King Khosrau I breaks through the Caucasus into Anatolia (modern Turkey). They attack the cities of Theodosiopolis and Caesarea, but are thwarted. Khosrau is forced to retreat and sacks Sebasteia. On the way home, he is intercepted by a Byzantine force under Justinian (magister militum of the East), and severely defeated near Melitene. The royal baggage is captured, and many Persians drown, while escaping across the Euphrates.
The Visigoths under King Liuvigild establish the capital of their kingdom in Toledo, located in central Spain (approximate date).
The Temple of Dendur, dedicated to the Egyptian gods Isis, Harpocrates (Horus) and Osiris, is converted for use as a Christian church (approximate date).
Summer – Tiberius, Byzantine co-ruler (Caesar), establishes a naval base at Derbent on the Caspian Sea to construct a Byzantine fleet (approximate date).

Battle of Deorham: The Anglo-Saxons under Ceawlin of Wessex invade the lower Severn Valley, and defeat the British Celts at Dyrham (South West England). After the battle, the Saxons occupy the three cities: Cirencester, Gloucester and Bath, bringing their advance to the Bristol Channel (according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle).
Muhammad, age , returns to his immediate family, but within a year his mother Aminah bint Wahb dies.
Byzantine–Sassanid War: A Byzantine expeditionary force under command of Justinian (magister militum) invades Caucasian Albania, launching raids across the Caspian Sea against the Persians.
Summer – Emperor Wu Di engages in military campaigns on two fronts: against the invading Göktürks to the north and against the Chen dynasty in the south.

Byzantine–Sassanid War: A Byzantine army under command of Maurice (magister militum per Orientem) invades Upper Mesopotamia, and raids on both sides of the Tigris. He deports , captives from Hyrcania to Cyprus, and installs military colonists to guard the strategic locations.
Kongō Gumi, the world's oldest construction company (–), is founded in Osaka (Japan).
Wu Di, age , dies from an illness, and is succeeded by his eldest son Xuan Di as emperor of Northern Zhou.

October  – Emperor Justin II dies after several periods of insanity. On the advice of his wife Sophia, he has raised his general Tiberius to the rank of co-emperor (Caesar). From December  he has ruled jointly with Sophia, and now succeeds them as emperor of the Byzantine Empire.
Summer – Hormizd IV refuses to give up territories, and breaks off negotiations with the Byzantine Empire. The Türks invade Khorasan and reach Hyrcania on the Caspian Sea.
Frithuwald succeeds his brother Theodoric as king of Bernicia (Scotland). He rules from – (approximate date).
July  – Pope Benedict I dies after a -year reign, and is succeeded by Pelagius II as the 63rd pope. During the Lombard siege of Rome, he labors to solve the problems of famine.
Heavy taxes levied by Merovingian king Chilperic I of Neustria produce a revolt at Limoges (central France), as he sells bishoprics to the highest bidder.
September  – Uneh Chan becomes the ruler of the Mayan city state of Calakmul in southern Mexico and reigns until .
The Northern Zhou dynasty, strategically based in the basin of the Wei River, is supreme in Northern China. In the south only the Chen dynasty remains a rival.
The Chinese city of Ye (Henan) is razed to the ground by Yang Jian, future founder of the Sui dynasty, who defeats a resistance force under Yuchi Jiong.
King Liuvigild calls for an Arian synod in Toledo (central Spain), which modifies several doctrines; he tries to unify the Christians within the Visigothic Kingdom.
The Lombards drive the last Ostrogoths across the Alps (Northern Italy). During the "Rule of the Dukes" the Lombards adopt Roman titles, names, and traditions.
Siege of Sirmium: The Avars march to the right bank of the River Sava, and besiege the Byzantine stronghold of Sirmium (Pannonia).
Croesus succeeds Alyattes as King of Lydia.
Kirrha is destroyed, ending the First Sacred War.
May —A solar eclipse occurs while Alyattes of Lydia fights Cyaxares of Media at a battle on the Halys river, leading to a truce. This is a cardinal date from which other dates can be calculated.
/—Astyages succeeds Cyaxares as King of the Medes.
Apries succeeds Psamtik II as king of Egypt.
The  Northern Zhou dynasty ends: Yáng Jiān executes the last ruler, -year-old Jing Di, along with  royal relatives at Chang'an. He proclaims himself emperor, and establishes the Sui dynasty in China.
Al-Nu'man VI, son (de facto) of Mundhir III, revolts with the Ghassanids against the Byzantine Empire, after his father is treacherously arrested.
The Göktürks under Taspar Qaghan besiege the city of Chersonesos Taurica (modern Ukraine), located at the Black Sea; their cavalry keep plundering the steppes of the Crimean Peninsula until .
In the Turkic Empire an interregnum begins, since there are several candidates to the throne: Talopien (late khagan's candidate), Ishbara (Kurultai's choice) and Tardu (western yabghu).
Second Council of Mâcon: In a council of Christian bishops in Mâcon (Burgundy), Jews are prohibited from serving as judges or customs officers.
April  – John Nesteutes becomes the 33rd bishop or patriarch of Constantinople.
