August  – King Louis X of France, nicknamed "Louis the Quarrelsome", marries the -year-old Clementia of Hungary, daughter of Charles Martel of Anjou (titular king of Hungary) following the death in prison of his uncrowned first wife, Margaret of Burgundy. Louis and Clementia are on August  crowned at Reims. Louis is the 12th Capetian ruler of France following the death nine months earlier of his father, Philip IV. After his coronation, Louis passes the throne of the Kingdom of Navarre to his younger brother, who becomes Philip II of Navarre, nicknamed "Philip the Tall".

March  ( Dhu al-Hijjah  AH) – The Emir of Mecca, Abu al-Ghayth, is defeated in a battle near Mecca by his brother Humaydah ibn Abi Numayy. Wounded in battle, then captured by the enemy, Abu al-Ghayth is executed by order of his brother at Khayf Bani Shadid.

October  – Banastre Rebellion: A group of English knights start an uprising in Lancashire and revenge themselves on Thomas of Lancaster. After the rebellion, Liverpool Castle is granted to Robert de Holland.
July  – Otto II, Prince of Anhalt-Aschersleben, dies without leaving any heirs, bringing an end to the Principality. His assets are seized by his cousin and creditor, Bishop Albert of Halberstadt.
January  – The English Parliament is convened at Lincoln to hear the reading of the Articuli Cleri, the list of grievances against the church in England. The parliament ends on March .

November  – John of the House of Capet is born four months after the death of his father, King Louis X of France and, as the eldest (and only) son of King Louis, becomes King John I of France from the moment of his birth, with his uncle, Prince Philip the Tall, serving as regent. John dies, four days after his birth, on November .
November  – Upon the death of the infant John I, Philip the Tall, eldest surviving brother of King Louis X of France, becomes King Philip V

February  – Battle of Skaithmuir: Scottish forces under James Douglas, Lord of Douglas defeat an English raiding party near Coldstream. During the skirmish, Edmond de Caillou (nephew of Piers Gaveston) is killed.

March  – After leading a six-week-long revolt from Wales against England's, and retreating to Glamorgan, Welsh rebel Llywelyn Bren finally surrenders to King Edward's general, Humphrey de Bohun at Ystradfellte.
September  – The coronation of Jacques Deuze as Pope John XXII takes place at Avignon in France, as he becomes the 196th pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church. His papacy will last until .

November  – Yahballaha III, Patriarch of the Church of the East in Byzantium, dies after serving  years as leader of the Eastern Orthodox Church. Timothy II of Seleucia-Ctesiphon will be elected to succeed him.
July  – Mongol Prince Abu Sa'id Bahadur Khan becomes the ruler of the Ilkhanate, the Mongol-controlled area of the Middle East.

December  – The Portuguese Royal Navy, with  warships, is created by order of King Denis. The Navy has  armed galleys as warships, under the command of Admiral Manuel Pessanha and will celebrate its 700th anniversary in  as the oldest continuously serving navy in the world.

A Hungarian document mentions for the first time Basarab I as leader of Wallachia (historians estimate he was on the throne since about ). Basarab will become the first voivode of Wallachia as an independent state, and founder of the House of Basarab (until ).

February  – Manuel Pessanha of Genoa is appointed as the first Chief Admiral of Portugal (Almirante-mor) by King Denis, and charged with organizing a permanent navy for the kingdom, with  warships and hiring Genoese captains to recruit sailors. The organization of the Portuguese Royal Navy is completed by December .

July  – Rashid al-Din Hamadani, the Grand Vizier of the Ilkhanate in Iran during the reign of the Mongol Ilkhan Öljaitü, is convicted of the  murder of the Ilkhan, and is executed (along with his son Ibrahim Izzaddin).

January  – Sir Gilbert Middleton, an English knight who had rebelled against King Edward II and kidnapped the Bishop of Durham on September , is convicted of treason and then executed by being hanged, drawn and quartered.

July  – In Italy, Jacopo I da Carrara becomes the first Lord of Padua, founding the Carraresi dynasty that will rule the independent city state for almost  years before its conquest and annexation by the Republic of Venice following a war in .
November  – Grand Prince Mikhail of Tver is summoned by Özbeg Khan at Sarai, the capital of the Golden Horde. After his arrival, he is executed.
August  – Treaty of Leake: Edward II signs an agreement with the "Middle Party" led by his cousin, Earl Thomas of Lancaster, and his court followers at East Leake in Nottinghamshire.

November  – King Eric VI of Denmark dies after a -year reign at Roskilde, leaving a vacancy that will not be filled until the January election of his brother Christopher II. During his rule, he attempts to control the routes of the Hanseatic League. The Hanse, an association of Baltic merchants, expels the English and Scots, and gains a monopoly of trade with Norway.
January  – The Earl of Pembroke and the Earl of Hereford persuade Walter Reynolds, Archbishop of Canterbury, to consecrate Stephen Gravesend as the Bishop of London.

September  – Battle of Myton: Scottish forces (some , men) led by James the Black, Lord Douglas, defeat an English army in an encounter known as the "Chapter of Myton" because of the large number of clergymen involved. David Dalrymple, Lord Hailes, writes  years later, "The English were instantly routed. Three thousand were left dead on the field, and great part of fugitives drowned in the Swale. In this action there fell three thousand ecclesiastics, [20th September.] According to the savage peasantry of those times, this rout was termed by the Scots, the Chapter of Mitton." After the battle, King Edward II is forced to raise the siege at Berwick Castle and retreats south of the River Trent, allowing the Scots to ravage Cumberland and Westmorland unmolested. Queen Isabella, who is in York at this time, manages to escape to safety at Nottingham.

February  – ( Dhu al-Hijjah  AH) Rumaythah ibn Abi Numayy and  Sayf al-Din Bahadur al-Ibrahimi, both former Emirs of Mecca, are arrested by the incumbent Emir, Shams al-Din Aq Sunqur al-Nasiri and taken from Mecca to Cairo for imprisonment. Rumaythah is charged with having provided support to his brother, Humaydah ibn Abi Numayy and al-Ibrahimi is accused of allowing Humaydah to escape. Rumaythah is pardoned a month later after arriving in Cairo.

June  – Within the Mongol Empire, Özbeg Khan of the Golden Horde (the Mongol-controlled area of what is now Uzbekistan and Russia) fights a battle against the Ilkhanate (the Mongol-controlled Middle East) in an attempt to expand the Golden Horde's territory, with a confrontation in Ilkhanate territory at Mianeh (now in Iran). The troops of Özbeg Khan are supplemented with rebels led by an Ilkhanate prince, Yasa'ur. The Ilkhan Sultan, Abu Sa'id Bahadur Khan and his general, Amir Chupan, lead the defenders to victory and take many of the rebel officers prisoner. Afterward,  emirs and seven viceroys are executed for treason, including Qurumushi of Georgia and Irinjin of Anatolia.
February  – Pope John XXII grants a mandate to the Archbishop of York, William Melton, to order restitution of confiscated Knights Templar property in England to the Knights Hospitaller.

September  – Battle of Saint George: Byzantine forces under Andronikos Asen defeat the army of the Principality of Achaea, securing the possession of Arcadia. During the battle, Latin commander Bartholomew II Ghisi is taken prisoner, along with several high-ranking nobles of the principality, and is sent to Constantinople.
July – Shepherds' Crusade: Many followers are arrested and executed, after which there are no further incidents and the crusade disperses.
September  – Pope John IX of Alexandria is elected as the new spiritual leader of the Coptic Orthodox Church, succeeding Pope John VIII.
Henri de Mondeville, French surgeon and physician, writes La Chirurgie, the first textbook on surgery by a Frenchmen.
th Dynasty comes to an end.
The reign of Ay comes to an end.
Death of Pharaoh Tutankhamun of Egypt.
The Hittite Empire prince Zannanza was killed on his way to Egypt at the request of the Egyptian queen Ankhesenamun to become her husband and king of Egypt.

July  – María de Molina, grandmother of and regent for -year-old King Alfonso XI of Castile, dies at the age of , two relatives assume the regency and split Castile between themselves while chaos exists inside the Spanish kingdom. Alfonso's uncle, Don Juan Manuel de Ivrea, and cousin Juan de Castilla y Haro (called Juan el Tuerto or Juan the One-Eyed) remain in power until Alfonso XI reaches majority on  August .
September  – Italian author Dante Alighieri, known for The Inferno, dies of malaria at Ravenna after having undertaken a diplomatic mission in the Republic of Venice.
May  – Wars of the Rügen Succession: Dukes Otto I of Pomerania, Vartislav IV of Pomerania-Wolgast and Barnim III of Pomerania-Stettin reach a mutual inheritance contract with Vitslav III of Rügen.
May  – In Egypt's Mamluk Sultanate, a campaign by Muslims starts against the Christian settlements of the Coptic Orthodox Church. Over  churches and monasteries are burned.

April  – At Easter, the Byzantine civil war of – breaks out in the Byzantine Empire as Co-Emperor Andronikos III Palaiologos flees Constantinople to Adrianople, where he sets up his court and initiates an uprising against his grandfather, the Byzantine Emperor Andronikos II Palaiologos. The -year-old Andronikos is joined by Theodore Synadenos and John Kantakouzenos in the rebellion.  Syrgiannes Palaiologos leads an expeditionary army towards the capital, forcing the emperor to negotiate.

February  – The collapse of the central crossing tower of Ely Cathedral in eastern England, possibly as a result of digging foundations for the Lady Chapel, allows the construction of the Octagon that takes its place.
Dmitry of Tver, nicknamed "Dmitry of the Fearsome Eyes", Grand Prince of Tver in Russia, becomes the new monarch of the Grand Principality of Vladimir.
June  – Alice de Lacy, Countess of Lincoln, widow of the Contrariant leader Thomas of Lancaster, surrenders almost all of her properties to King Edward II of England in order to avoid execution.
June  – In Italy, Galeazzo I Visconti becomes the new Lord of Milan upon the death of his father Matteo I Visconti.

September  – Battle of Mühldorf: Bavarian forces (some , men) led by King Louis the Bavarian defeat the Austrians commanded by his cousin, Frederick the Fair, Duke of Austria and self-proclaimed pretender to the Bavarian throne (or anti-king) at Mühldorf in  southern Bavaria. During the battle, Frederick is captured together with his -year-old brother, Henry the Friendly (along with , nobles). Frederick is imprisoned at Trausnitz Castle for two and a half years before his release by the signing of the Treaty of Trausnitz on March , .

October  – Lord Raymond-Bernard, of the Aquitaine town of Montpezat, burns the village of Saint-Sardos to the ground and hangs the French royal sergeant who acted as agent for King Charles IV. France's government blames the England's Baron Basset of the Duchy of Gascony, for hiring Lord Raymond-Bernard.

March  – Treaty of Paris: Count Louis I relinquishes Flemish claims over the County of Zeeland. He acknowledges William II the Good as count of Avesnes, Holland, and Zeeland as a state within the Holy Roman Empire. William occupies most of the Bishopric of Utrecht and tries to conquer Friesland (or Frisia) but is repelled by Governor Hessel Martena.
April  – Elizabeth of Carinthia marries Peter, Crown Prince of Sicily, co-ruler (with his father Frederick II) of the Kingdom of Sicily.

March  – Siege of Warangal: Sultan Ghiyath al-Din Tughluq sends an expeditionary army led by his son, Muhammad bin Tughluq, to the Kakatiya capital Warangal – after ruler Prataparudra has refused to make tribute payments. He besieges the city and finally, after a campaign of  months, Prataparudra surrenders on November .

December  – John of Nottingham and Robert of Coventry, two Englishmen believed by Coventry residents to be expert on necromancy, begin the process of casting a spell to kill King Edward II, Sir Hugh le Despenser of Winchester, as well as the prior of Coventry. John allegedly accepted  pounds sterling, and starts his necromancy by making wax figurines of the targets of elimination and then using them for the next six months. The two men will later be prosecuted for sorcery after one of the designated victims allegedly dies after a pin is driven into his figurine.
August  – The Blitar Regency is established on the island of Java (part of modern-day Indonesia) by Java's King Jayanegara of Majapahit.

July  – ( Rajab  AH) Mansa Musa, the extraordinarily-wealthy Emperor of Africa's Mali Empire, arrives in Cairo after three days of camping by the pyramids of Giza, and brings with him a large entourage of fellow Muslim pilgrims and a vast supply of gold. Musa, who is making the pilgrimage to Mecca, meets with Egypt's Sultan al-Nasir Muhammad and stays in Cairo for three months before departing with the pilgrims on October .

September  – The War of Saint-Sardos ends after Charles, Count of Valois, forces the surrender of Edmund of Woodstock, 1st Earl of Kent at La Réole, the last English fortress at the Duchy of Aquitaine. A six-month truce follows

Ottoman Sultan Osman I dies after a -year reign at Bursa. He is the founder of the Ottoman Empire (first known as a Turkmen principality in the northwest of Anatolia). He is succeeded by his -year-old son Orhan I as the second ruler (bey), who places his residence at Söğüt in Bilecik Province (approximate date).

William of Ockham, English Franciscan friar and philosopher, is summoned from Oxford to the papal court at Avignon; either at this time or later he comes into conflict with Pope John XXII and never returns to England.
June  – At Stuttgart in Germany, Ulrich III becomes the new Count of Württemberg upon the death of his father, Eberhard I.
(approximate date) – Tenochtitlan, the predecessor of Mexico City, is founded by the Mexica, led by Tenoch, on an island in Lake Texcoco.

November  – War of the Bucket: At the Battle of Zappolino in northern Italy, the ,-man Ghibelline forces backed by the Holy Roman Empire defeat the much stronger (,-men) Guelph army under sent by Pope John XXII near Bologna. After the battle, Ghibelline influence in the region is consolidated.

May  – In Germany, Henry II, Lord of Mecklenburg cedes the territories of Prignitz and the Uckermark to the Margraviate of Brandenburg in an unfavorable peace treaty signed at Daber (modern-day Dobra Nowogardzka in Poland).

March  – Queen Isabella of England, wife of King Edward II of England and sister of King Charles IV of France, departs from England on a mission to Paris to mediate an end to the war between the two kingdoms. She is directed to return to England by midsummer.
April  – The Peace of Arques, brokered by King Charles IV of France, ends the Flemish Revolt, but the treaty is not supported by rebel districts in Flanders.
November  – King Edward II of England is captured at Neath Abbey in Wales and brought to England, where he is imprisoned at Kenilworth Castle in Warwickshire.

July  – The Scottish Parliament meets at Cambuskenneth and votes to restore -year-old Robert Stewart, grandson of Robert the Bruce to the line of succession to the throne of Scotland. Robert is granted lands in Argyll, Roxburghshire and the Lothians, and will eventually become King of Scotland in .
Autumn – Gerhard III, Count of Holstein-Rendsburg allies himself with the Danish magnates. In response, the Hanseatic towns of Demmin, Stralsund, Greifswald and Anklam join the alliance.
Clare College, the University of Cambridge's second oldest (still surviving) college, is founded.

October  – Elizabeth de Burgh, Queen consort of Scotland as the wife of King Robert the Bruce, is fatally injured when she falls from her horse while traveling with her entourage to Cullen Castle in Banffshire.

February  – The coronation of King Edward III as ruler of England takes place at Westminster Abbey with the approval of the English Parliament. Walter Reynolds, Archbishop of Canterbury, places the crown upon the new King.
April  – In the civil war in Granada, Prince Uthman ibn Abi al-Ula captures the fortress of Laujar de Andarax (now in the Almeria province of Spain).

February  – (1st waning of Kason  ME, Burmese calendar) In Burma (now Myanmar), Tarabya I becomes the new King of Sagaing, located in northern Myanmar on the Irrawaddy River with a capital in the city of Sagaing. Tarabya succeeds his brother, upon the death of his brother, King Saw Yun, despite the fact that Saw Yun has an heir, Prince Kyaswa.

March  – King Charles IV of France makes a peace treaty with England, he returns Aquitaine and Gascony to English rule. Charles receives , livres and has seized all the English possessions in France. The territories of Limousin, Quercy and Périgord county come under French control.
August  – Battle of Cassel: French troops stop an uprising of Flemish farmers.
May  – King Philip VI of France is crowned, founding the House of Valois, after the death of King Charles IV of France, who has no sons to inherit.
May  – William of Ockham secretly leaves Avignon, under threat from Pope John XXII.
Undated – The Augustiner-Bräu is first recorded as the brewery of an Augustinian monastery at Munich.
January  – Louis the Bavarian is crowned Emperor at Rome's St. Peter's Basilica. Being excommunicated by the Pope, the ceremony is carried out by three Italian bishops.
February  – King John of Bohemia (of the Teutonic Order) captures Medvėgalis, an important fortress of the pagan Grand Duchy of Lithuania, and baptizes , of its defenders.
April – Antipope Nicholas V is excommunicated by Pope John XXII.
Construction begins on the Archcathedral Basilica of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary and Saint Andrew in Frombork, Poland.
Aimone of Savoy becomes Count of Savoy.
Michael of Cesena is deposed as General of the Franciscans.

Undated
Ivan Alexander becomes the despot of Lovech.
Vilnius, Lithuania receives its coat-of-arms, granted to the city in the seventh year of its existence.
December  – The British Isles are hit by a great storm, creating large areas of sand dunes on Anglesey.
November – – Battle of Posada: The Wallachians, under Basarab I, defeat the Hungarians, though heavily outnumbered, thus making a firm statement towards the independence of Wallachia.
Ivan Alexander becomes the despot of Lovech.
October  – King Edward III of England starts his personal reign, arresting his regent Roger Mortimer, and having him executed.
Tutankhaten becomes Pharaoh of Egypt and marries Ankhesenpaaten, his half sister and cousin as well as a daughter of his predecessor Akhenaten.
Pharaoh Akhenaten of Egypt names Smenkhkare as a co-ruler.
: Amarna period in Ancient Egypt ends.
Inner coffin of Tutankhamun's sarcophagus, from the tomb of Tutankhamun, Valley of the Kings near Deir el-Bahri is made. 18th dynasty. It is now in Egyptian Museum, Cairo.
Pharaoh Tutankhaten of Egypt renames himself to Tutankhamun and abandons Amarna, returning the capital to Thebes.
The Genkō War begins in Japan.
The Sieges of Cividale del Friuli and Alicante begin.
September  – Battle of Płowce: The German Teutonic Knights and the Poles battle to a draw.
September  – Stefan Dušan declares himself king of Serbia.
The first recorded outbreak of the Black Death occurs, in the Chinese province of Hebei.
November  – Lucerne joins the Swiss Confederation with Uri, Schwyz, and Unterwalden.
February  – Amda Seyon I, Emperor of Ethiopia, begins his campaigns in the southern Muslim provinces (possibly in ).
September – Edward Balliol crowns himself King of Scotland.
August – – Battle of Dupplin Moor: Edward Balliol rebels, and the English defeat the loyalists of David II in Scotland.
December  – Battle of Annan: The loyalists of David II defeat Edward Balliol in Scotland.
The Kapellbrücke wooden bridge over the Reuss in Lucerne (Switzerland) is built; by the  it will be the world's oldest truss bridge and Europe's oldest covered bridge.
November  – The River Arno floods, causing massive damage in Florence, as recorded by Giovanni Villani.

A great famine takes place in Southern Europe. It is known to historians of Catalonia as Lo mal any primer [es], "the First Bad Year" (equivalent to the Great Famine of – further north), an early notice of the catastrophes of the second half of this century.
July  – The reign of Emperor Kōgon of Japan, first of the Northern Court (Ashikaga) Pretenders, ends.
Jan IV of Dražic, Bishop of Prague, founds a friary and builds a stone bridge at Roudnice in Bohemia.
Autumn – Battle of Adramyttion: A Christian league defeats the fleet of the Turkish Beylik of Karasi.
July  – The bishop of Florence blesses the first foundational stone laid for the new campanile (bell tower) of the Florence Cathedral (the tower was designed by the artist Giotto di Bondone).
December  – Pope Benedict XII succeeds Pope John XXII, as the 197th pope.
May  – Otto the Merry, Duke of Austria, becomes Duke of Carinthia.
Aabenraa is chartered as a city.
October  – Ex-emperor Hanazono (95th emperor of japan) becomes a Zen priest.
Pope Benedict XII begins to reform the Cistercians.
The excommunication of Frederick III of Sicily and the interdict placed on Sicily end.
Rather than be taken captive by the Teutonic Knights, , defenders of Pilėnai, Lithuania commit mass suicide.
September  – The reign of Emperor Kōmyō, second of the Ashikaga Pretenders to the Northern Court of Japan, begins.
May  – The governor of Baghdad, Oirat 'Ali Padsah, defeats Arpa Ke'un near Maraga, contributing to the disintegration of the Ilkhanate.
July – – Second War of Scottish Independence: Aberdeen, Scotland is burned by the English.
July  – Battle of Minatogawa: Ashikaga Takauji defeats Japanese Imperial forces, under Kusunoki Masashige and Nitta Yoshisada.
March  – Edward, the Black Prince establishes the Duchy of Cornwall, becoming the first English Duke.
Siege of Nicomedia: After its foundation by Osman I in about , the Ottoman Empire expanded across Bithynia in north-west Anatolia by capturing territory from the Byzantine Empire.
The famine in China, which had lasted since  and killed ,,, comes to an end.
October – Hundred Years' War: Edward III of England formally rejects Philip VI's claim to the French throne, initiating hostilities between France and England.
November – Battle of Cadzand: English troops raid the Flemish island of Cadzand.
A Black Death plague strain originates near Lake Issyk-Kul in modern Kyrgyzstan, according to Syriac tombstone inscriptions and genetic material from exhumed bodies.
Philip VI of France besieges Guienne in Southwest France, and his navy attacks Portsmouth, England.
Nicomedia is captured by the Ottoman Empire.
Ashikaga Takauji is granted the title of shōgun by the emperor of Japan, starting the Ashikaga Shogunate.

Hundred Years' War: Louis IV, Holy Roman Emperor appoints Edward III of England as a vicar-general of the Holy Roman Empire. Louis supports Edward's claim to the French throne, under the terms of the Treaty of Koblenz.
June – Battle of Laupen: The Canton of Bern defeats the forces of Fribourg.

Shams-ud-Din Shah Mir, having defeated Kota Rani, Hindu queen regnant of Kashmir, in battle at Jayapur (modern Sumbal), asks her to marry him, but she commits suicide rather than do so; thus he takes over sole rule of Kashmir, beginning the Muslim Shah Mir Dynasty.
September  – Emperor Go-Murakami accedes to the throne of Japan.
All streets in the city of Florence are paved, the first European city in post-Roman times where this has happened.
September  (or ) – Simone Boccanegra is elected, as the first Doge of Genoa.
Valdemar IV of Denmark, son of deceased King Christopher II, is elected to the throne, following  years of interregnum.
June  – Rotterdam is officially declared a city.
An epidemic in northern Italy is recorded by Augustine of Trent, in his Epistola astrologica.
April  – Marinid galleys, under the command of Muhammad ibn Ali al-Azafi, rout the Castellan fleet, off the coast of Algeciras.
September  – Hundred Years' War: The temporary Truce of Espléchin is signed between England and France.
Akhenaten and his family, relief from Akhetaten (modern el-Amarna) was made. 18th dynasty. It is now in Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Stiftung Preußischer Kulturbesitz, Ägyptisches Museum.
Amenhotep IV of Egypt begins his Cult of Aten and begins construction of Amarna intended to be his new capital.
Amenhotep IV of Egypt renames himself to Akhenaten.
–King Šuppiluliuma I of the Hittites invades the Anatolian heartland and launches two campaigns against the Mitanni. This culminates in the sack of the Mitanni capital Washukanni.
Pharaoh Amenhotep IV changes his name to Akhenaten.
January  – An earthquake with a magnitude of . and a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe) affects Crimea (disputed event).
Casimir III of Poland builds a masonry castle in Lublin, and encircles the city with defensive walls.
April  – Petrarch is crowned poet laureate in Rome, the first man since antiquity to be given this honor.
The sultan of Delhi Muhammad bin Tughluq chooses Ibn Battuta to lead a diplomatic mission to Yuan Dynasty China.
Tbilisi becomes a capital of European Christian Cathedra, after the city of Smirna. George V (the Brilliant) returns Jerusalem and the Grave of Christ from the Muslims.
Byzantine civil war of – – The Zealots seize power in Thessalonica, expelling its aristocrats and declaring themselves in favour of the regency.
Guy de Lusignan becomes Constantine II, King of Armenia (Gosdantin, Կոստանդին Բ).
May  – Pope Clement VI succeeds Pope Benedict XII, as the 198th Pope.
The Greek Orthodox patriarch of Antioch is transferred to Damascus, under Ignatius II.
August  – Louis "the Child", age , succeeds his father, Peter II, as king of Sicily and duke of Athens; he is crowned on September  in Palermo Cathedral.

January  – Pope Clement VI issues his bull Unigenitus, defining the doctrine of "The Treasury of Merits" or "The Treasury of the Church" as the basis for the issuance of indulgences by the Catholic Church.
August  – Magnus IV of Sweden abdicates from the throne of Norway, in favor of his son Haakon VI of Norway. However, Haakon is still a minor, allowing Magnus to remain de facto ruler.
May  – St. George's Night Uprising: The "Four Estonian kings" are murdered, at the negotiations with the Livonian Order.
August  – A naval league is formed between the Pope, the Republic of Venice, the Knights Hospitaller and the Kingdom of Cyprus, to prepare the Smyrniote Crusades.
January  – Arnošt of Pardubice becomes the last bishop of Prague and, subsequently, the first Archbishop of Prague.
April  – Constantine II, King of Armenia, is killed in an uprising and succeeded by a distant cousin, Constantine III.
A large public dial clock is installed in the tower of the Palazzo Capitaniato, Padua, commissioned by Prince Ubertino I da Carrara and supervised by Jacopo Dondi dell'Orologio.
May  – Battle of Pallene: A Christian fleet defeats a Turkish fleet at Pallene, Chalcidice.
December  – Five-year-old Erik Magnusson, the eldest son of King Magnus IV of Sweden, is appointed heir to the Swedish throne, even though Sweden is an elective monarchy at this time.

March  – Reconquista: The Siege of Algeciras (–), one of the first European military engagements where gunpowder is used, ends with the Muslim city of Algeciras surrendering and being incorporated into the Kingdom of Castile.

March  – Guy de Chauliac observes the planets Saturn, Jupiter, and Mars conjoined in the sky, under the sign of Aquarius, and a solar eclipse on the same day. This sign is interpreted as foreboding by many, and Chauliac will later blame it for the Black Plague.
April – Edward III of England offers "defiance" of Philip VI of France.
September – Holland, Hainaut and Zeeland are inherited by Louis IV, Holy Roman Emperor, and remain part of the imperial crown domain until .
October  – Battle of Auberoche in Gascony: The English defeat the French.
August – Gascon campaign of  -  Battle of Bergerac, Gascony: English troops are victorious over the French.
July  – Charles IV, Count of Luxembourg and King of Bohemia, is elected King of the Romans.
August  – Jaume Ferrer sets out from Mallorca for the "River of Gold", the Senegal River.
July – – Edward III and the English army cross the English Channel and begin an invasion of France.
July – Edward III orders the closing of English ports to stop information from reaching France.
July – – The English raid and burn neighbouring towns and villages in the Cotentin Peninsula.
January  – Charles University in Prague is founded by a bull issued by Pope Clement VI, at the request of Charles I, King of Bohemia.

May
The agreement reorganizing the Byzantine Empire's affairs is finalized, as Anna of Savoy's son John V Palaiologos marries Kantakouzenos' -year-old daughter Helena.
Genoese ships fleeing the  Black Death plague in Theodosia stop in Constantinople, contaminating the city.
December – Plague hits the island of Mallorca.
Pope Clement VI unites several of Rome's upper-class nobility, who drive Cola di Rienzo out of the city.
May  – Cola di Rienzo, a Roman commoner, declares himself Emperor of Rome, in response to years of baronial power struggles.
April  – Edward III of England creates the first English order of chivalry, the Most Noble Order of the Garter.

By June  – The Black Death pandemic reaches England, having probably been brought across the English Channel by fleas on rats aboard a ship from Gascony to the south coast port of Melcombe (modern-day Weymouth, Dorset); by November it will have reached London and by  will have killed one third to a half of its population.

January  – The .-magnitude  Friuli earthquake centered in Northern Italy is felt across Europe. Contemporary minds link the quake with the Black Death, fueling fears that the Biblical Apocalypse has arrived.
Hundred Years' War (–): The effects of the Black Death cause a de facto truce to be observed between England and France until .
November  – The anti-royalist Union of Valencia attacks the Jews of Murviedro because they are serfs of the King of Valencia and thus "royalists".
December  – The rise of Alexios III of Trebizond to the throne ends the Trapezuntine Civil Wars.
May  – In Breslau, Silesia,  Jews are murdered following a disastrous fire which destroys part of the city.
November  – Ibn Battuta arrives in Fez, Morocco.
January  – An earthquake affects L'Aquila in southern Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme), causing severe damage, and leaving , dead.
September  –  Apennine earthquakes. An earthquake in Rome causes extensive damage, including the collapse of the southern exterior facade of the Colosseum.
January  – Giovanni II Valente becomes Doge of Genoa.
Approximate date – Latest likely date for first permanent settlement of New Zealand by Māori people.
September  – Hook and Cod wars in the County of Holland: Conservative noblemen found the Hook League and sign the Hook Alliance Treaty.
The Black Death first appears in Scotland and Sweden.

November  – To pay for the expenses of the revived war with the Republic of Venice, the Republic of Genoa has to subscribe a loan at an interest rate of %, from an association of creditors known as the Compera imposita per gerra Venetorum.
Yin becomes the new capital of Shang dynasty China.
– Amenhotep III (Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt) dies and is succeeded as Pharaoh by Amenhotep IV.
April  – Hundred Years' War: Battle of Saintes. – The French are defeated by the English.
Statute of Provisors prevents the Pope from appointing clergy to English benefices.
March  – The Ayutthaya Kingdom is established by King Uthong (Ramathibodi I) in modern-day Thailand. He begins to propagate Theravada Buddhism as the state religion.
November  – Emperor Sukō abdicates as 3rd Emperor of the Northern Court of Japan.
The Red Turban Rebellions break out in China, leading to permanent weakening of the Mongolian-run Yuan dynasty.
Lionel of Antwerp marries Elizabeth, daughter of William de Burgh, 3rd Earl of Ulster.
Following the death of his father Basarab, Nicholas Alexander becomes voivode of Wallachia, after being co-ruler for about eight years.

Earliest surviving illustration of someone wearing spectacles, a fresco in the chapter house of the Dominican convent of San Nicolò, Treviso by Tommaso da Modena (anachronistically) depicting Hugh of Saint-Cher.
Reginald de Cobham, 1st Baron Cobham becomes a Companion of the Most Noble Order of the Garter of England.
September  – Emperor Go-Kōgon becomes 4th Emperor of the Northern Court of Japan.
The Decameron is finished by Giovanni Boccaccio.
The Moroccan traveler Ibn Battuta makes the first recorded visit to Timbuktu and Kabara, when returning from a stay in the capital of the Mali Empire.
The Lao kingdom of Lan Xang is founded by Fa Ngum.
August  – War of the Straits and Sardinian–Aragonese war – Battle of Alghero: The allied Aragonese and Venetian fleets crush  the Genoese fleet, most of which is captured.
The Black Death () subsides.
October  – Cola di Rienzo, self-proclaimed "tribune" of Rome, is killed by an angry mob.
December  – The reign of John VI Kantakouzenos as Byzantine Emperor is ended, after John V Palaiologos retakes Constantinople and is restored as sole emperor.
After  years of struggling for independence, since the Battle of Posada, Nicholas Alexander of Wallachia becomes a vassal to Hungarian king Louis I.

August  – War of the Straits: The Venetian-ruled town of Poreč is sacked by the Genoese under Paganino Doria, who carry off the relics of saints Eleutherius and Maurus of Parentium to Genoa, where they were deposited at the church of San Matteo.

March  –   During the night between  and  March, a strong earthquake destroyed the city of Gallipoli and its city walls, weakening its defenses, along with destroying the neighboring villages and towns in the area.
March  – Red Turban Rebellions: Han Lin'er, a claimed descendant of Emperor Huizong of Song, is proclaimed emperor of the restored Song dynasty in Bozhou.
August – Battle of Nesbit Moor: The Scottish army decisively defeats the English.
April  – Charles IV is crowned Holy Roman Emperor in Rome.
April  – In Venice, the Council of Ten beheads Doge Marin Falier, for conspiring to kill them.
April – Philip II, Prince of Taranto, marries Maria of Calabria, daughter of Charles, Duke of Calabria, and Marie of Valois.
October  – Erik XII proclaims himself king of Sweden, in opposition to his father, King Magnus IV. Thus begins a civil war in Sweden between father and son, which will last until Erik's death in .
January  – Edward Balliol surrenders his title as King of Scotland, to Edward III of England.
June  – The city of Lwów is granted Magdeburg rights by Casimir III of Poland. The advantages of the rights are not only economic, but also political.
The Castelvecchio Bridge in Verona is probably completed this year; its main span of . m ( ft) is the world's longest arch at this time.
December  – Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor, promulgates the Golden Bull, a constitution for his empire.
Influenza is first identified as a disease.

Battle of Bubat: The Sundanese royal family is massacred by the Majapahit Army on the orders of Gajah Mada; the death toll includes Sundanese King Lingga Buana and Princess Dyah Pitaloka Citraresmi, who commits suicide.
The Wat Phra Si Rattana Mahathat (Famous Wat Yai) Temple is constructed in Phitsanulok, Thailand.
July  – On the death of Jani Beg, he is succeeded as Khan of the Blue Horde by his son Berdi Beg who orders the death of at least  of his close kinsmen to secure his position.
The first public exhibition of the Shroud of Turin is recorded.
May  – Hundred Years' War: The Jacquerie – A peasant rebellion begins in France, which consumes the Beauvais, and allies with Étienne Marcel's seizure of Paris.
July  – Battle of Mello: The Jacquerie rebellion is defeated by a coalition of nobles, led by Charles II of Navarre.

Mubariz al-Din Muhammad, leader of the Arab Muzaffarid tribe, expels the Blue Horde from Ilkhanate territory in Persia. The Muzaffarid then release control of the Il-Khanate, after being marched on by the Mongol Jalayirid tribe, ruled by Shaikh Uvais. Shaikh Uvais becomes the new Il-Khan. The Ilkhanate is effectively now disbanded, and replaced by the Jalayirid dynasty of Persia.
February  – Treaty of Zadar, between Louis I of Hungary/Croatia and the Republic of Venice: The Venetians lose influence over their former Dalmatian holdings.
January  – Muhammad II as Said becomes ruler of the Marinid dynasty in modern-day Morocco after the assassination of Abu Inan Faris.
Abu Salim Ali II overthrows Muhammad II as-Said as ruler of the Marinid dynasty, in modern-day Morocco.
August – Qulpa becomes Khan of the Blue Horde after the death of Berdi Beg.
probable date – Battle of Megara: A Christian coalition defeats a Turkish raider fleet.
Berlin joins the Hanseatic League.

December  – The Catalan Courts are held in Cervera, giving birth to the Deputation of the General of Catalonia (Diputació del General de Catalunya), also called Generalitat of Catalonia (Generalitat de Catalunya).
Earliest known Kırkpınar oil wrestling tournament in the Ottoman Empire, which will still be staged into the .
June – Valdemar IV Atterdag attacks Skåne and conquers  Lindholmen Castle.

August – Peace is concluded between Sweden and Denmark with the arbitration in Helsingborg. Magnus IV Eriksson cedes the Scanian lands except northern Halland to Denmark. In return, Valdemar IV Atterdag must help Magnus against his domestic enemies.
Nawruz Beg overthrows his brother Qulpa as Khan of the Blue Horde.
Dmitri Konstantinovich is installed as ruler of Vladimir (in modern-day western Russia) by the Khan of the White Horde.
First credible mention of "Urusalim" (Jerusalem) in the Amarna letters.
Rule of Canaanite warlord Labaya.
Chinese rebels capture the Goryeo capital.
March  – An-Nasir Hasan, Mamluk Sultan of Egypt, is killed by one of his own mamluks, Yalbugha al-Umari, who, with the senior Mamluk emirs, has al-Mansur Muhammad installed as the new sultan.
Great Troubles: the Blue Horde descends into anarchy. Between  and , over  khans succeed each other in different parts of the Blue Horde's territory.
May  – King Magnus IV Eriksson sends a letter to the citizens of Visby, with a warning of an upcoming Danish invasion.
The earliest known musical keyboard instrument is built, with the layout of black and white keys that becomes standard.
September  – Pope Urban V succeeds Pope Innocent VI, as the 200th pope.
July  – Valdemar IV of Denmark defeats the Hanseatic League in the naval Battle of Helsingborg.
Battle of Brignais: The Free Companies defeat a French army.

Red Turban Rebellions: Hu Dahai, aide to Zhu Yuanzhang, is killed by Miao chieftains in Yanzhou (part of modern-day Jinhua and Hangzhou). Chaghan Temur is killed and succeeded by his nephew Köke Temür.
The Öræfajökull volcano erupts in Iceland, resulting in the destruction of the district of Litlahérað by flood and tephra fall.
Dmitry Donskoy, Prince of the Grand Duchy of Moscow, dethrones Dmitry of Suzdal to become Grand Prince of Vladimir.
April  – Haakon VI of Norway marries Margaret I of Denmark.
Al-Afdal al-Abbas succeeds Al-Mujahid Ali as Rasulid Sultan of Yemen.
Philip the Bold becomes duke of Burgundy.

August –October  – Battle of Lake Poyang: The Dahan rebel forces of Chen Youliang are defeated by the Red Turban Rebel forces of Zhu Yuanzhang, during the final decade of Yuan dynasty control over China. Zhu's naval forces of , are pitted against Chen's naval forces of , troops, in what is not only the largest naval battle of the medieval age, but also one of the largest naval battles in history.
Vladislav I (also known as Vlaicu-Vodă) becomes voivode of Wallachia.
Anavema Reddy succeeds Anavota Reddy, as ruler of the Reddy Dynasty in Andhra Pradesh (part of modern-day southern India).
Rana Kshetra Singh succeeds Rana Hamir Singh, as ruler of Mewar (part of modern-day western India).
February  – David II of Scotland marries Margaret Drummond.
Bogdana Monastery is built in Moldavia.
June  – The Hungarian occupation of Vidin begins, with the capture of the city by Louis I of Hungary's forces, and the imprisonment of Ivan Sratsimir of Bulgaria.
Muhammed V begins building the Maristan of Granada (a hospital) in Granada (in modern-day Spain).
In modern-day southern India, Bahmani Sultan Mohammed Shah I invades the Vijayanagara Empire.
March  – Battle of Gataskogen: Albert of Mecklenburg defeats and captures Magnus Eriksson, obtaining the throne of Sweden.
March  – The University of Vienna is founded.
March  – Henry II deposes his half-brother, Pedro of Castile, to become King of Castile.
Dmitri Donskoi, ruler of Moscow and Vladimir, makes peace with Dmitri Konstantinovich, former ruler of Vladimir.
The Statutes of Kilkenny are passed, aiming to curb the decline of the Hiberno-Norman Lordship of Ireland.
October  – Comet 55P/Tempel–Tuttle passes . AU (,, km; ,, mi) from Earth.
Abu Faris Abd al-Aziz I of Morocco succeeds assassinated Abu Zayyan as Sultan of the Marinid Empire in Morocco.
Petru I succeeds his grandfather Bogdan I as voivode (ruler) of Moldavia.
October  – Pope Urban V makes the first attempt to move the Papacy back to Rome from Avignon. This move is reversed in , when he is forced to return to Avignon, and shortly afterwards dies.

April  – Battle of Nájera: Pedro of Castile is restored as King of Castile (in modern-day Spain) after defeating his half-brother, Henry II. Pedro is aided in the battle by the English under Edward, the Black Prince, and Henry by the French.
January  – Ferdinand I becomes King of Portugal after the death of his father, Peter I.
December  – Red Turban Rebellions: Hu Mei captures Shaowu, while Xu Da and Chang Yuchun capture Jinan, bringing both under Zhu Yuanzhang's control.
Timur ascends the throne of Samarkand (in modern-day Uzbekistan).
The Bibliothèque nationale de France (National Library of France) is founded as the Royal Library at the Louvre Palace in Paris, by Charles V of France.
The King of Norway sends the last Royal Ship from Norway to the Greenland Eastern Settlement. This event is part of both the Norse colonization of the Americas, and of the History of Greenland.
A peace treaty is signed between Norway and the Hanseatic League.
Lațcu, son of Bogdan I, deposes his nephew Petru I, and becomes voivode of Moldavia. (Other sources state that Lațcu had succeeded his father Bogdan in ).
May – King Charles V of France renounces the Treaty of Brétigny, and war is declared between France and England.
The Hongwu Emperor of the Chinese Ming dynasty issues a decree ordering every country magistrate in the empire to open a Confucian school of learning.
November  – Hundred Years' War: Charles V of France recaptures most of Aquitaine from the English.
March  – Battle of Montiel: Pedro of Castile loses to an alliance between the French and his half-brother, Henry II.
Košice becomes the first town in Europe to be granted its own coat of arms.

April  – Timur becomes first Amir of the Timurid Empire, following the Siege of Balkh which establishes his rule over the Chagatai Khanate, completing his conquest of Central Asia and parts of Persia.
December  – Pope Gregory XI succeeds Pope Urban V, as the 201st pope.
Khun Luang Pa-Ngua, ruler of Suphanburi, marches and usurps the throne of the Ayutthaya Kingdom.
October  – Philip of Anjou, Titular Emperor of Constantinople, marries as his second wife Elizabeth of Slavonia (daughter of Stephen of Anjou and Margaret of Bavaria).
Hugues Aubriot begins construction of the fortress of the Bastille in Paris.
Old Assyrian Empire disestablished.
Minoan culture ends on Crete.
Site of palace complex Knossos is abandoned.
March  – The London Charterhouse, a Carthusian monastery, is founded in Aldersgate.

The Hongwu Emperor of the Ming dynasty in China introduces the census registration system of lijia, or the hundreds-and-tithing system, throughout the Yangzi Valley. This system groups households into units of ten and groups of one hundred, whereupon their capacities for paying taxes and providing the state with corvée labor service can be assessed. The system becomes fully operational in , when it counts ,, people living in China (the historian Timothy Brook asserts that the number was much higher, somewhere between  million and  million).
January – Edward, the Black Prince, gives up the administration of Aquitaine and returns to England, because of his poor health and heavy debts.
Byzantine co-emperor John V Palaiologos pledges loyalty to the Ottoman Empire, to prevent the Turks from invading Constantinople.
Zhao Bing Fa becomes King of Mong Mao (in modern-day south China/north Myanmar) after the death of his father, Si Kefa.

July  – The Treaty of Tagilde is signed between Ferdinand I of Portugal and representatives of John of Gaunt of England, marking the beginning of the Anglo-Portuguese Alliance, which remains in effect into the .
Peace is declared between the Kingdom of Sicily and the Kingdom of Naples.
The city of Aachen, Germany, begins adding a Roman numeral Anno Domini date to a few of its coins, the first city in the world to do so.

May – Owain Lawgoch makes a second attempt to take the throne of Wales, sailing with French support from Harfleur. Whilst attacking the island of Guernsey, he abandons the invasion in order to fight for France at La Rochelle.
November  – Trần Duệ Tông succeeds his brother Trần Nghệ Tông as King of Vietnam.
April  – Hundred Years' War: The French re-capture most of Brittany from the English, but are unable to take Brest.
The Adina Mosque is built in Bengal.

The Chinese emperor of the Ming dynasty, the Hongwu Emperor, suspends the traditional civil service examination system after complaining that the  new jinshi degree-holders are too incompetent to hold office; he instead relies solely upon a system of recommendations, until the civil service exams are reinstated in .
August – Hundred Years' War: John of Gaunt launches a new invasion of France.
May  – English anchoress Dame Julian of Norwich receives the sixteen Revelations of Divine Love.
Rao Biram Dev succeeds Rao Kanhadev as ruler of Marwar (the modern-day Jodhpur district of India).
Musa II succeeds his father, Mari Djata II, as Mansa of the Mali Empire (modern-day Mali and Senegal).
The Château de Compiègne royal residence is built in France.
Robert de Juilly succeeds Raymond Berenger as Grand Master of the Knights Hospitaller.
A form of the Great Plague returns to Europe.
Petru succeeds as Voivode (ruler) of Moldavia (modern-day Moldova & eastern Romania). He is the first ruler from the dynastic House of Bogdan.
The Grand Duchy of Moscow and Tver sign a truce. Tver agrees to help Moscow fight the Blue Horde.

June  – Hundred Years' War: The English, weakened by the plague, lose so much ground to the French that they agree to sign the Treaty of Bruges, leaving them with only the coastal towns of Calais, Bordeaux and Bayonne.
The Russian town of Kostroma is destroyed by the ushkuynik pirates from Novgorod.
April  – Mujahid Shah succeeds his father, Mohammed Shah I, as ruler of the Bahmani Sultanate in the Deccan Plateau of southern India.
March  – Pope Gregory XI excommunicates all members of the government of Florence, and places the city under an interdict.
November  – Richard of Bordeaux, son of the Black Prince, is created Prince of Wales in succession to his father.
December  – John of Gaunt presents his nephew, Richard of Bordeaux, to the feudatories of the realm and swears to uphold Richard's right to succeed Edward III.
March – The peace treaty between England and France is extended until April, .
April  – The Good Parliament begins in England (so called because its members attempt to reform the corrupt Royal Council).
October  – Richard II of England's first parliament meets.
August  – Battle on Pyana River: The Russians are defeated, while their commander drowns in the river.

May
Continuous riots in Rome induce Pope Gregory XI to move temporarily back to Avignon.
Władysław II Jagiełło succeeds his father, Algirdas, as Grand Duke of Lithuania. Jagiello removes his uncle, Kęstutis, as co-ruler.

August – The Hongwu Emperor of the Ming dynasty of China scraps the Office of Reports Inspection (established in ) for a new Office of Transmission, in his efforts to create a more efficient communicatory system in the empire. A month before this he noted that anyone could send memorials to the throne; commoners often did, although the only times their petitions were read aloud to the emperor were when they called for the impeachment of local officials who were not up to par with their official duties.
July  – Fourteen-year-old Maria of Sicily succeeds her father, Frederick the Simple.
Sa'im al-Dahr is hanged for blowing the nose off the Great Sphinx of Giza.
The Raseborg Castle is mentioned for the first time in documents, but its actual date of foundation is unknown.
January – Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor, visits his nephew Charles V of France in Paris, to celebrate publicly the friendship between their two nations.
September – A contract is set up between Richard le Scrope, 1st Baron Scrope of Bolton and the mason Johan Lewyn, for the construction of Bolton Castle in the north of England.
January  – Balša II succeeds his brother, Durađ I, as ruler of Lower Zeta (modern-day Montenegro).
In the Hundred Years' War, the French lose control of most of Brittany to the English.
Bairam Khawaja establishes the independent principality of the Kara Koyunlu (Turkomans of the Black Sheep Empire), in modern-day Armenia.

July  – Forces of the Republic of Venice and Ottoman Turks, having invaded Constantinople, restore John V Palaiologos as Byzantine co-emperor. Andronikos IV Palaiologos is allowed to remain as co-emperor, but is confined to the city of Silivri for the remainder of his life.
September  – The Treaty of Neuberg is signed, splitting the Austrian Habsburg lands between brothers Albert III and Leopold III. Albert III retains the title of Duke of Austria.
Dmitry Donskoy of Moscow raids Estonia.
Sir William Walworth, a member of the Fishmongers Guild, becomes Lord Mayor of London for the second time.
March  – The southern England town of Winchelsea in East Sussex is attacked and burned by an expeditionary force from France for a second time.
Khan Tokhtamysh of the White Horde dethrones Mamai of the Blue Horde. The two hordes unite to form the Golden Horde.
The Hongwu Emperor purges the chancellor of China, Hu Weiyong, and abolishes that office, as he imposes direct imperial rule over the six ministries of central government, for the Ming Empire.
October  – Caterina Visconti marries her first cousin, Gian Galeazzo Visconti, later Duke of Milan, at the Church of San Giovanni in Conca.
Pharaoh Amenhotep III of Egypt marries Tiye, his Chief Queen.
Decline of the Minoan Culture in Crete.
Amenhotep III attempts to connect the Nile and the Red Sea with a canal, this however would not be done successfully until almost  years later with the opening of the Canal of the Pharaohs.
June  – Peasants' Revolt: In England, rebels from Kent and Essex, led by Wat Tyler and Jack Straw, meet at Blackheath. There the rebels are encouraged by a sermon, by renegade priest John Ball.

Due to Joanna I of Naples' support for Antipope Clement VII, Pope Urban VI bestows Naples upon Charles of Durazzo. With the help of the Hungarians, Charles advances on Naples and captures Joanna. James of Baux, the ruler of Taranto and the Latin Empire, claims the Principality of Achaea after Joanna's imprisonment.

In Ming dynasty China, the lijia census registration system begun in  is now universally imposed, during the reign of the Hongwu Emperor. The census counts ,, people living in China in this year. This depicts a drastic drop in population since the Song dynasty, which counted  million people at its height in the early . A modern historian states that the Ming census is inaccurate, as China at around this time has at least ,, inhabitants, if not ,,.
Sonam Drakpa deposes Drakpa Changchub as ruler of Tibet.
Hajji I succeeds Alah-ad-Din Ali as Mamluk Sultan of Egypt. The Egyptian government continues to be controlled by rebel leader Barquq.
October  – Winchester College is founded in England.
May  – Charles of Durazzo executes the imprisoned Joanna I of Naples, and succeeds her as Charles III of Naples.

September – Following the death of Louis I of Hungary and Poland:
Louis' daughter Mary is crowned the "King" of Hungary.
The Poles, who do not wish to be ruled by Mary's fiancee, the future Holy Roman Emperor Sigismund, choose Mary's younger sister, Jadwiga, to become ruler of Poland. After two years of negotiations, Jadwiga is eventually crowned "King" in .

Khan Tokhtamysh of the Golden Horde overruns Muscovy, as punishment for Grand Prince Dmitry Donskoy's resistance to Khan Mamai of the Blue Horde in the 1370s. Dmitry Donskoy pledges his loyalty to Tokhtamysh, and is allowed to remain as ruler of Moscow and Vladimir.
September  – The inhabitants of Trieste (now in northern Italy) donate their city to Duke Leopold III of Austria.
Löwenbräu beer is first brewed.
The Wat Phra That Doi Suthep Temple is built in modern-day Thailand, by King Kuena of Lanna.
The Teutonic Knights recommence war against pagan Lithuania.
Otto, Duke of Brunswick-Grubenhagen, the widower of Joanna I of Naples, becomes ruler of Taranto (eastern Italy).
Louis I, Duke of Anjou inherits the claim to the Latin Empire (western Turkey), but never uses the title of Emperor.
Zain Al-Abidin succeeds his father, Shah Shuja, as ruler of the Muzaffarids in central Persia.
Katharine Lady Berkeley's School is founded in Gloucestershire, England.
Qara Muhammad succeeds Bairam Khawaja, as ruler of the Kara Koyunlu ("Black Sheep Turkomans"), in modern-day Armenia and northern Iraq.
May – September  – Siege of Lisbon by the Castilian army, during the – Crisis in Portugal.
The Nasrid princes of Al-Andalus replace Abu al-Abbas with Abu Faris Musa ibn Faris, as ruler of the Marinid dynasty in modern-day Morocco.
September  – Battle of Savra: Serbian forces under Balša II and Ivaniš Mrnjavčević are defeated by Ottoman commander Hayreddin Pasha, near Berat.
Bodiam Castle (East Sussex, England)

August 
Battle of Aljubarrota: John of Aviz defeats John I of Castile in the decisive battle of the – Crisis in Portugal. John of Aviz is crowned King John I of Portugal, ending Queen Beatrice's rule, and Portugal's independence from the Kingdom of Castile is secured.
The Union of Krewo establishes the Jagiellonian dynasty in Poland and Lithuania, through the proposed marriage of Queen regnant Jadwiga of Poland and Grand Duke Jogaila of Lithuania, and sees the acceptance of Roman Catholicism by the Lithuanian elite, and an end to the Greater Poland Civil War.
August  – King Richard II of England begins an invasion of Scotland. The English burn Holyrood and Edinburgh, but return home without a decisive battle.
July  – Charles VI of France marries Isabeau of Bavaria; the wedding is celebrated with France's first court ball.
Construction begins on the Brancacci Chapel in Florence.

March  – Grand Duke of Lithuania Jogaila (having been baptised on February  in Wawel Cathedral, Kraków, and on February  married Jadwiga, -year-old queen regnant of Poland) is crowned Władysław II Jagiełło, King of Poland, beginning the Jagiellonian dynasty.
Mary is reinstated as Queen of Hungary and Croatia.
The mother and sister of Queen Jadwiga of Poland are kidnapped by rebels in Hungary-Croatia.
October  – Heidelberg University (Ruprecht-Karls-Universität Heidelberg), the oldest in Germany, is founded at the behest of Rupert I, Elector Palatine, by charter of Pope Urban VI.
Timur conquers the Muzaffarid Empire in central Persia, and appoints three puppet rulers.

December  – Battle of Radcot Bridge: Forces loyal to Richard II of England are defeated by a group of rebellious barons known as the Lords Appellant. Richard II is imprisoned, until he agrees to replace all the councillors in his court.
Khan Tokhtamysh of the Golden Horde invades the Timurid Empire, but has to withdraw soon after, due to heavy snow.
September  – Petru of Moldavia pays homage to Władysław II Jagiełło, making Moldavia a Polish fief (which it will remain until ).
Maghan II succeeds his brother, Musa II, as Mansa of the Mali Empire
August  – Battle of Bileća:  The Bosnians check the Ottoman advance.
Cozia Monastery is built in Wallachia.
The title of Prince of Asturias is created.

Omar I is succeeded by Sa'id, as King of the Kanem-Bornu Empire (modern-day east Chad and Nigeria). Sa'id is succeeded in the same year by Kade Alunu. Omar and Sa'id are both killed by Bilala invaders from the west.
Ljubostinja Monastery is built in Serbia.
June – The Käpplinge murders take place in Stockholm in Sweden.
Wikramawardhana succeeds Hayam Wuruk, as ruler of the Majapahit Empire.
Carmo Convent is built in Lisbon, Portugal.
Abd ar-Rahmân II succeeds Musa II as ruler of the Ziyanid Dynasty, in present-day western Algeria.
Biri II succeeds Kade Alunu as King of the Kanem-Bornu Empire (now eastern Chad and Nigeria), and the Empire loses its land in present-day Chad to the Bilala.
Manuel III succeeds his father, Alexios III, as Emperor of Trebizond (now north eastern Turkey).
Mahmud succeeds Sandaki as Mansa of the Mali Empire, restoring the Keita dynasty.
April  – Robert III succeeds his father, Robert II, as King of Scotland.
Templo Mayor, the main temple of the Aztec capital of Tenochtitlan (now Mexico City), is built.
Barquq is restored as Mamluk Sultan of Egypt, after overthrowing Sultan Hadji II.
Hittites ruled by King Arnuwanda I (until ).
–: Queen Tiy, bust from Kom Medinet el-Ghurab (near el-Lahun) was made. 18th dynasty. It is now in Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Stiftung Preußischer Kulturbesitz, Ägyptisches Museum.
Pandion I, legendary King of Athens, dies after a reign of  years and is succeeded by his son Erechtheus II of Athens.
Manuel II Palaiologos becomes Byzantine emperor after his father, John V Palaiologos, dies of a nervous breakdown, due to his continued humiliation by the Ottoman Empire.
The Chinese invent toilet paper for use by their emperors.

June  – Massacre of : Anti-Jewish pogroms erupt in Seville, Spain. Many thousands of Jews are massacred, and the violence spreads throughout Spain and Portugal, especially to Toledo, Barcelona and Mallorca. This event marks a turning-point in the history of the Spanish Jews, with most of the survivors leaving the Iberian Peninsula or being forced to convert.
The Ming government orders  million trees planted in the Nanjing area.
The University of Ferrara is founded on the Italian Peninsula.

King Jogaila of Poland and Lithuania appoints his cousin Vytautas the Great as regent of Lithuania, in return for Vytautas giving up his claim to the Lithuanian throne. Vytautas replaces Jogaila's unpopular brother Skirgaila as regent.
Penistone Grammar School, later to be one of the first community comprehensive schools in England, is founded near Barnsley, England.
The city of Afyonkarahisar (in modern-day western Turkey) is conquered by Sultan Beyazid I, of the Ottoman Empire.
Erfurt University is founded in Erfurt, central Germany.
General Yi Sŏng-gye crowns himself Taejo of Joseon, ending the Goryeo dynasty in the Korean Peninsula, and establishing the Joseon dynasty, which will last for more than  years.
Bosnia resists an invasion by the Ottoman Empire.
King Stjepan Dabiša of Bosnia signs the Contract of Djakovice, establishing peace with King Sigismund of Hungary.
Samsenethai succeeds his father, Fa Ngum, as King of Lan Xang (now Laos).
Raimondo Del Balzo Orsini succeeds Otto, Duke of Brunswick-Grubenhagen, as Prince of Taranto (now southeastern Italy).
Sikander Shah I succeeds Muhammad Shah III, as Sultan of Delhi. Sikander Shah I is succeeded two months later by Mahmud II.
Abu Zayyan II succeeds his brother, Abul Hadjdjadj I, as ruler of the Abdalwadid dynasty in present-day eastern Algeria.
After the death of Sultan Mahmud II, civil war breaks out in the Delhi Sultanate, splitting the state between east and west.
September  – Antipope Benedict XIII is elected to succeed Antipope Clement VII.
Gyeongbokgung Palace and the Jongmyo royal ancestral shrine are built in Hanseong (now Seoul).
Abd al-Aziz II succeeds Abu al-Abbas Ahmad II, as ruler of the Hafsid dynasty in present-day Tunisia.
Ramaracha succeeds Ramesuan as ruler of the Ayutthaya Kingdom in present-day southern Thailand.
Mary of Hungary dies, ending of the reign of Hungary by the Capet-Anjou family. Her co-reigning estranged husband, King Sigismund, becomes sole ruler of Hungary.

April  – Tokhtamysh–Timur war – Battle of the Terek River: Timur defeats Tokhtamysh of the Golden Horde at the Volga. The Golden Horde capital city, Sarai, is razed to the ground, and Timur installs a puppet ruler on the Golden Horde throne. Tokhtamysh escapes to Lithuania.
The Gwanghwamun Gate and the Jogyesa Temple are built in present-day Seoul.
September  – The death of King Stjepan Dabiša leads to the election of his wife Jelena Gruba as Queen of Bosnia. However, most of the Bosnian land is soon appropriated by King Sigismund of Hungary.
November  – Ralph Neville, 1st Earl of Westmorland, marries Joan Beaufort in England.

July  – Queen Margaret I of Denmark, Norway and Sweden publishes the Treaty of Kalmar, proposing the personal union of the three kingdoms of Denmark, Norway (with Iceland, Greenland, the Faroe Islands, Shetland and Orkney) and Sweden (including Finland and Åland).
Timur orders the construction of a garden in a meadow, House of Flowers.
October – A Transylvanian expedition captures Vlad I Uzurpatorul, thus allowing the restoration of Mircea I of Wallachia to the throne.

October  – The widowed Richard II of England (), and six-year-old Isabella of Valois (daughter of Charles VI of France), are married in Calais, resulting in a temporary peace between the kingdoms of England and France.
September  – The Treaty of Kalmar is signed.
The Università, a form of local government, is established in Malta.
John Holland, Earl of Huntingdon is created Duke of Exeter, by his half-brother King Richard II of England.
February  – John Beaufort becomes Earl of Somerset in England.
November  – Thomas Arundel, accused of high treason by King Richard II of England, is replaced by Roger Walden as Archbishop of Canterbury.
April–May – The Bosnian nobility dethrone Queen Helen and replace her with Stephen Ostoja.
Bunei succeeds his father, Satto, as King of Chūzan (modern-day central Okinawa, Japan).
Glendalough monastery in Wicklow, Ireland is destroyed by English troops.
The Teutonic Knights conquer the island of Gotland, near Sweden, which has previously been run by the piratical Victual Brothers.

September
King Richard II of England exiles his cousin Henry Bolingbroke (the future Henry IV of England) for  years, in order to end Henry's feud with Thomas de Mowbray, 1st Duke of Norfolk, who is also exiled.
As France withdraws its support for Antipope Benedict XIII, an army led by Geoffrey Boucicaut occupies Avignon, and starts a five-year siege of the papal palace.

February  – The Principality of Piombino is formed after Prince Gherardo Appiani sells the city of Pisa to the Duchy of Milan for , florins and possession of five cities and three islands (including Elba).
The Principality of Achaea (now southern Greece) resists an invasion by the Ottoman Empire.
October  – Henry Bolingborke is crowned as King Henry IV of England  at Westminster Abbey.
March  – Richard II of England cancels the legal documents allowing the exiled Henry Bolingbroke to inherit his father's lands, leading to Henry's decision to overthrow King Richard.
January  – In the Delhi Sultanate in what is now the Uttarakhand state of India,  Timur the Lame captures and sacks Haridwar.

August  – King Henry IV leads the English Army into Scotland, after receiving no answer from Scotland's King Robert III to his August  demand. The troops reach Haddington, East Lothian the next day and at Leith, on the outskirts of Edinburgh, by August . As historian  James Hamilton Wylie will note almost  years later, "the walls of Edinburgh did not fall before this ram's-horn blast, and August 23rd came and went without the required homage or recognition."
August  – Rupert, Count Palatine of the Rhine, is elected as King of the Romans.

April  – Sir Thomas Percy, 1st Earl of Worcester, resigns as England's Admiral of the North and West to join the resistance against King Henry IV. The office will remain vacant for more than six years. Percy will be beheaded in  after his defeat in the Battle of Shrewsbury.
April – King Swa Saw Ke, of Ava, the largest kingdom in Burma, dies after a reign of  years and is succeeded by his son, King Tarabya, who reigns less than seven months before being assassinated.
October  – ( Rabi' I  AH) Tamerlane begins the destruction of the Syrian city of Aleppo overwhelming the Mamluk Sultanate defenders.
Linear A reaches its peak of popularity.
The height of the Canaanite town of Ugarit.
April ,  Lunar Saros  begins.
–  – Garden of Nebamum (Pond in a Garden) wall painting from the tomb of Nebamum, Thebes. Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt. It is now kept in The British Museum, London.
Palace of Minos destroyed by fire.

December  – Jingnan campaign: Rebel General Zhu Di adopts a new approach in his war against the Chinese Imperial troops and departs from Beiping to drive troops southward to the Yangtze River, capturing Dong'e, Dongping, Wenshang, and Pei over the next two months.
July  – Jingnan campaign: Chinese Empire troops, led by Fang Zhao, launch a raid on the Yan principality capital at Beiping, forcing Yan PrinceZhu Di to bring his troops back north.

February  –
Jingnan campaign: After a month's recovery from defeat in battle in China, Prince Zhu Di mobilizes his troops at Beijing and marches south to fight the Ming dynasty Emperor Huizong.
John Barry is appointed as the new Attorney-General for Ireland.
March  – Jingnan campaign: Prince Zhu Di of Yan leads his troops across the Jia River into the Heibei province. China's Ming dynasty Emperor Huizong directs that Zhu Di is not to be killed.
January  – The Parliament of England is opened at Westminster by King Henry IV.

June  – Jingnan campaign: After crossing the Huai River into what is now Jiangsu province, and taking Yangzhou (May ) and Luhe (May ), the Yan Army of Zhu Di crosses the Yangtze River at Guazhou and is within striking distance of the Imperial Chinese capital at Nanjing by June , forcing Emperor Zhu Yun Wen to prepare terms of surrender that include granting the Yan Kingdom areas north of the Yangtze. Zhu Di refuses.
June  – Zhu Di, King of the Yan State at Beijing, becomes the new Ming Dynasty Emperor of China at Nanjing, uniting north and south China.
Maria II Zaccaria succeeds her husband, Pedro de San Superano, as regent of the Principality of Achaea (modern-day southern Greece).

December  – ( Jumada al-Awwal  A.H.) With , troops, Tamerlane, Amir of the Timurid Empire covering much of what is now Iraq, Iran and Afghanistan begins the Siege of Smyrna (now Izmir in Turkey). Smyrna is captured after two days of attacks on its outer walls. After the Christian Knights of Saint John, who are ruling Smyrna, refuse to convert to Islam or pay tribute, Timur has the entire Christian population massacred. The Knights subsequently begin building Bodrum Castle in Bodrum, to defend against future attacks.
August  – Edward of Norwich becomes the second Duke of York in England upon the death of his father, Edmund of Langley. He will serve until his death in  in the Battle of Agincourt.

January  – The Yongle Era in China begins with the first day of the Chinese New Year, six months after King Zhu Di of the Yan State arrived at Nanjing, deposed the southern Chinese Emperor Zhu Yun Wen, and proclaimed himself as the Emperor Cheng Zu.
Stefan Lazarević establishes Belgrade, as the capital of the Serbian Despotate.
October  – An English fleet organised by John Hawley of Dartmouth and Thomas Norton of Bristol seizes seven French merchant vessels in the English Channel.

January  – In what is now Myanmar is the king of the jungle, peace negotiations begin between King Razadarit of Hanthawaddy at his capital Pegu, with the emissaries of Minkhaung I, ruler of the Kingdom of Ava,  days after the Ava forces defeated Razadarit's army at the Battle of Nawin.
December  – Local English forces defeat an attempted French raid on the Isle of Wight under Waleran III, Count of Ligny.
Timur is hit by a fever, while preparing to invade China.
Stephan Tvrtko II succeeds Stefan Ostoja as King of Bosnia.
Virupaksha Raya succeeds Harihara Raya II, as ruler of the Vijayanagara Empire in modern-day southern India.

February  – King Guadarfia of the Canary Islands surrenders to the French explorer Jean de Béthencourt, who declares himself to be the new king, but subservient to the sponsor of the expedition, King Enrique III of Castile (part of modern-day Spain)
A civil war, lasting two years, breaks out in the Majapahit Empire in modern-day Indonesia.

November  – The War of Padua in Italy comes to an end as Padua and Ferrara surrender to the armies of the Venetian Republic, commanded by General Malatesta IV. The Republic of Venice then annexes the territory of the defeated lordships.

April  – The three sons of Philip the Bold—John the Fearless, Philip II, and Anthony— agree at Arras to partition the Burgundian lands of their father between themselves, with John to retain Flanders, Philip to take the County of Nevers, and Anthony to retain Rethel as well to purchase the Duchy of Brabant from John.

November – As an aftermath to the War in Gotland (-), Queen Margaret I buys the rights to Visby for  marks from  Albrecht of Mecklenburg during negotiations in Flensburg. This strengthens the Kalmar Union and pushes out the Teutonic Order, angering grand master Konrad von Jungingen.
June  – Richard le Scrope, Archbishop of York and Thomas Mowbray, Earl of Norfolk, are executed in York on Henry IV's orders.
December  – King Zsigmond of Hungary marries for the second time, in a wedding to Barbara of Cilli.

March  – On "Monday before the Annunciation", Prince James, the -year-old son of King Robert III of Scotland, is captured while being taken across the English Channel from Scotland to France when the ship he is on, Maryenknyght, by privateers Hugh atte Fen, William Oxeney, John Hacon and Nicholas Steyward of Cley. The crown prince is delivered to London where he is held hostage by King Henry IV of England for the next  years.

January  – After the Venetian Republic is victorious in the War of Padua against Francesco Novello da Carrara, the Venetian Consejo de i Diexe (Council of Ten) concludes that Novello and his sons are too dangerous to be left alive. Novello is taken from his cell at the Doge's Palace, where he has been held since November , and is strangled to death. His sons Francesco and Giacomo are executed the next day.

August  – Chen Yanxiang and his crew of  people, sailing to Korea for trading, come under attack by  ships of Japanese pirates (Wokou) off of the coast of Gunsan. After a two day battle,  of the crew are dead and the ship is looted, but remains with Chen. The  survivors are able to reach the Korean shore.

November  – Cardinal Angelo Correr of is elected as Pope after a -day conclave in Rome to select a successor to Pope Innocent VII, who died on November . Correr, the Patriarch of Constantinople takes the regnal name of Pope Gregory XII as the 205th pope of the Roman Catholic Church.
September  – At Appenzell in what is now Switzerland, a group of nobles create the "Order of St. George's Shield" at Hegau in the Duchy of Swabia.
March  – At  years old, Gianfrancesco I Gonzaga becomes the new Marquis of Mantua, and area encompassing much of the Lombardy region of Italy, upon the death of his father, Francesco I Gonzaga.

October  – A group of high officials of the former Vietnamese government are put on trial before China's Emperor Cheng Zu at Nanjing, and charged with treason for killing the previous Vietnamese ruler. Most of the prisoners are executed.
November  – A solemn truce  is agreed upon between John the Fearless, Duke of Burgundy and Louis I, Duke of Orléans under the auspices of John, Duke of Berry.

May  – Ming–Việt War: A Vietnamese force of , troops attempts to stop the advance of the Chinese at the Hong River at the Ham Tu pass in what is now Vietnam's Hưng Yên province. With superior firepower, the Chinese kill over , Viet troops and capture hundreds of warships.

April  – After several invitations by the Emperor Cheng Zu of China, the lama Deshin Shekpa, the fifth Karmapa of the Karma Kagyu sect of Tibetan Buddhism, finally visits the Emperor at Nanjing, the Ming dynasty. In his -day visit, the Karmapa thrills the Ming court with alleged miracles that are recorded in a gigantic scroll, translated into five different languages. In a show of mystical prowess, Deshin Shekpa adds legitimacy to a questionable succession to the throne by Cheng Zu, who had killed his nephew the Jianwen Emperor in the culmination of a civil war. For his services to the Ming court, including his handling of the ceremonial rites of Cheng Zu's deceased parents, Deshin Shekpa is awarded the title Great Treasure Prince of Dharma (大寶法王).

April  – Appenzell Wars: In the Appenzell region of Switzerland, the alliance of the region with St. Gallen, the  ("alliance over the lake", referring to the nearby Lake Constance fails in its attempt to liberate the city of Bregenz from Austrian rule. From the Holy Roman Empire, King Rupert of Germany orders the dissolution of the Bund ob dem See.
Mihail I becomes co-ruler of Wallachia, with his father Mircea cel Bătrân.

March – (late in the month of Tagu, which ended March ,  ME) Ava–Hanthawaddy War: In Burma (now Myanmar), King Razdarit leads the invasion of the Kingdom of North Arakan and overthrows its ruler, Anawrahta of Launggyet, then has him executed.

June  – After receiving the news that France will no longer support his Avignon Obedience, the Antipope Benedict XIII issues the Bull Celestis altitudo, summoning the a council to meet on November  at the French city of Perpignan, and then flees from the French-controlled Italian region of Genoa to avoid arrest.
March  – John of Bourbon, son of Louis II, Duke of Bourbon, is appointed as the Grand Chamberlain of France by King Charles VI.

October  – Jean de Montagu, Grand Master of France and a leading advisor to the mentally unstable King Charles VI of France, is arrested on orders of John the Fearless, Duke of Burgundy. Montagu is publicly beheaded  days later at the Gibbet of Montfaucon in Paris.
June  – By order of the Council of Pisa, Pietro Filargo is crowned as Pope Alexander V, producing the anomaly of three different popes of the Roman Catholic church.
July  – Martin I, King of Aragon, becomes King Martin II of Sicily upon the death of his son, Martin I of Sicily.
September  – The new Pope Alexander V issues a papal bull granting a charter to the University of Leipzig.
Ulugh Beg becomes governor of Samarkand.
October  – The Polish-Lithuanian alliance defeats the Teutonic Knights in the Battle of Koronowo.

May  – King Martin I of Aragon (who is also King Martin II of Sicily) dies at the age of , leaving a question of who his successor will be, and five contenders for the thrones of both nations argue until the crown is awarded to Martin's nephew, Ferdiand, in .

September  – After nearly two months of no progress against the defending Teutonic Knights, and the dissatisfaction of the Lithuanians and Poles in continuing a long-term conflict, the siege of Marienburg is lifted.

At the Onon River, the Chinese Army, under the command of the Emperor Cheng Zu, annihilates the Mongol forces of the Khagan Öljei Temür Khan, also known as Bunyashiri. The Khagan escapes and the Chinese troops pursue Arughtai, chingsang of another branch of the Northern Yuan.
March  – The Aragonese capture Oristano, capital of the Giudicato di Arborea in Sardinia.
Incumbent Shahram from Persia declared his kingdom.
Hebrew Exodus from Egypt (one proposed date).
July  – Sigismund is formally elected unanimously as King of the Romans by the seven electors of the Holy Roman Empire present.
December  – King Henry IV of England issues pardons to all but two of the Welsh rebels in the Glyndŵr rebellion except for the leaders, Owain Glyndŵr and Thomas of Trumpington
July  – Battle of Harlaw in Scotland: Domhnall of Islay, Lord of the Isles, and an army commanded by Alexander Stewart, Earl of Mar, battle to a bloody draw.

October  – At the Abbey of St Vaast in Arras in France, John the Fearless, Duke of Burgundy hosts English Bishop Henry Chichele and several envoys who are ready to negotiate terms for English support of Burgundy in the ongoing French civil war with the Armagnacs. The negotiations fail to attract much support other than to hire some of the English soldiers as mercentaries.
November  – The English Parliament is assembled after being summoned by King Henry IV, and again elects Thomas Chaucer as Speaker of the House of Commons.

May  – In Cairo, Abu’l-Faḍl Abbas Al-Musta'in, the Caliph of Cairo, is installed by rebels as the new Sultan of Egypt as a temporary replacement for his father, the Sultan An-Nasir Faraj. Al-Musta'in serves as the puppet ruler for six months before he returns to full time duty as the Caliph.
September  – King Ferdinand I of Aragon is declared Count of Barcelona.
April  – Albert V, son of the former King of Sweden, Duke Albert IV, becomes the Duke of Mecklenburg (part of modern-day Germany) upon the death of his father.

May  – The Treaty of Bourges  is signed between King Henry IV of England and Charles, Duke of Orléans, as the Armagnacs offer England full sovereignty over Aquitaine and Gascony in return for , troops and military aid against the Burgundians and John the Fearless.
December  – China's Emperor Cheng Zu orders the fourth of the Ming treasure voyages, to be led by Admiral Zheng He.

December  – The betrothal ceremony of Prince Charles of France (age ), son of King Charles VI, to Marie of Anjou (age ), daughter of Louis, Duke of Anjou, takes place at the Palais du Louvre in Paris. The two will marry in .

March  – King Henry IV of England dies at Westminster Abbey, where the English Parliament has been meeting, and passes on while in the Jerusalem Chamber of the house of the Abbot, William de Colchester.
July  – Battle of Çamurlu: Mehmed I defeats his brother Musa, ending the Ottoman Interregnum.
February  – The 10th and final English Parliament of King Henry IV opens its session, but closes abruptly after six weeks because of the death of the King.
October  – The Kingdom of Poland and Grand Duchy of Lithuania sign the Union of Horodło.
