November  – In the Battle of Tedorigawa, Uesugi Kenshin's forces decisively defeat the forces of Oda Nobunaga, in what will be Kenshin's last victory before his death the following year.
October  – Alessandro Farnese succeeds his uncle, Don John, as Governor of the Spanish Netherlands.

June  – After having come into conflict on May  with his fellow officer, Thomas Doughty, during their circumnavigation of the world, Francis Drake puts Doughty on trial while the flagship Pelican is docked at what is now Argentina. A jury of sailors convicts Doughty of treason and attempted mutiny. Doughty is beheaded on July .
Fur trade begins in Newfoundland in North America.

February  – Two days after the Battle of Gembloux, Spanish troops capture the city of Leuven, forcing Willem, Prince of Orange, to flee Brussels and relocate to Antwerp.Geoffrey Parker, The Dutch Revolt (Cornell University Press, ) p.
Battle of the Spoiling Dyke at Trumpan on the Scottish Isle of Skye: the Clan MacLeod are victorious over the MacDonalds of Uist in a feud.
January   – The Union of Arras unites the southern Netherlands under the Duke of Parma, governor in the name of king Philip II of Spain.
October  – At Banda Aceh, on the island of Sumatra in what is now Indonesia, Alauddin Mansur Syah becomes the new Sultan of Aceh upon the death of Sultan Zainul Abidin.

September  – (5th waning of Tawthalin  ME) In the Kingdom of Mrauk U in what is now Myanmar and Bangladesh, King Min Phalaung becomes the owner of the first of three white elephants, and gives himself the title of Hsinbyushin.

December  – After Willem van Pamele, the Spanish Governor of Flanders, is forced to flee during the Dutch Revolt, the Duke of Parma orders Pamele and the Catholic members of the Council of Flanders to convene at Douai as the temporary Flemish capital.
October  – Semiz Ahmed Pasha is appointed as the new Ottoman Grand Vizier by Sultan Murad III.
The Old City of Zamość is established in Poland, by Jan Zamoyski.

June  – Rebels of the Dutch Union of Utrecht, aided by French soldiers, make a surprise attack on the Spanish Netherlands city of Diest in the Duchy of Brabant, and overwhelm the strategic location, now in Belgium, in one day.

October  – Lorenzo Suárez de Mendoza, the Spanish Count of Coruña, arrives in Mexico City to take office as the Viceroy of New Spain, administering Mexico and Central America on behalf of King Philip II.

June  ( Cemazi ul-evvel  AH) – England signs a commercial treaty with the Ottoman Empire, and Sultan Murad III sends a letter to Queen Elizabeth I informing her, "Just as the merchants of Poland and France and Venice come and go, the merchants of your domain also shall bring wares to our Well-Protected Domains and take away wares." In return, Murad III is able to purchase English metals (iron, brass and tin) for his war with Persia.

October  (5th waning of Tazaungmon  ME) – King Bayinnaung of Bruma dispatches a naval force of  ships and , soldiers to invade the Kingdom of Mrauk U (now in the Rakhine State of Myanmar), but the attempt fails after a year. Burmese troops are ordered withdrawn after Bayinnaung dies and is succeeded by his son Nanda Bayin.

The Egyptians invented a new and better calendar. It is based on both the moon and a star. They observed the annual appearance of the brightest star in the sky, Sirius. This calendar was more advanced than the Babylonian calendar.
April  – Following his circumnavigation of the world, Francis Drake is knighted by Elizabeth I of England.
May  – (10th waning of Nayon  ME) In Burma, Thiri Thudhamma Yaza of Martaban becomes the new Viceroy of Martaban  (now Mottama in the Mon State of Myanmar) after the demise of Minye Nandameit.
October  – King Bayinnaung of Burma, who created the largest empire in mainland southeast Asia, dies at age .
December  – In England, Jesuit priest Edmund Campion is executed for treason.

February  – (7th waxing of Tabaung  ME) Prince Shin Thissa, later to become King of Burma in  as Nyaungyan Min, receives his first executive job when he is appointed to be Governor of Nyaungyan by his father, King Bayinnaung.

October  (Julian) (October  Gregorian) – The Julian calendar is discarded at the end of the day in Italy, Poland, Portugal, and Spain as Pope Gregory XIII implements the Gregorian calendar. In the nations where the calendar is accepted, Thursday, October  is followed the next day by Friday, October .
The sultanate of Morocco begins to press southward, in search of a greater share of the trans-Saharan trade.
March  – Scryer Edward Kelley arrives at John Dee's house in London. They practice angelic magic together and Dee develops the Enochian language.

June  – (2nd day of the sixth month, Tenshō ) The Honnō-ji Incident occurs in Kyoto in Japan, as Japanese warlord Oda Nobunaga, on the verge of unifying Japan under his rule, is assassinated following a betrayal by a rebel subject, Akechi Mitsuhide.

April  –  Ancuancu earthquake: Ancuancu (in modern-day La Paz Department, Bolivia) is struck by an earthquake that reportedly buries all of the inhabitants, except for one chief, who reportedly loses the ability to speak. On the place where the village had stood, the Jacha Kalla (Achocalla) valley is formed as a result of the earthquake.

September  – King James VI of Scotland orders a gift to Colonel William Stewart in recognition of Stewart's rescue of the King from prison. Colonel Stewart is presented with some of the jewels of Mary, Queen of Scots (the King's mother).
April  – In a clash between a ,-man Persian Empire force and the Ottoman Empire for control of the Caucasus region in modern-day Russia, the Ottomans are routed.

October  – In Scotland, the University of Edinburgh holds its first classes, accepting more than  students as "Tounis College". In continuous operation for more than  years, the University will have more than , students.

April  – A Burmese Army force of , men, commanded by Thado Dhamma Yaza II of Prome and Nawrahta Minsaw of Lan Na to suppress the rebellious of the Shan States in the modern-day Yunnan province of China, is welcomed by King Nanda Bayin at the royal capital, Pegu, after a successful punitive expedition. The commanders bring with them the rebel chief from the Sanda state.
August  – Petru Cercel enters Bucharest, and becomes Prince of Wallachia.
This year, according to Italian heretic Jacopo Brocardo, is regarded as an apocalyptic inauguration of a major new cycle.

June  – Walter Raleigh sends Philip Amadas and Arthur Barlowe to explore the Outer Banks of Virginia (modern-day North Carolina), with a view to establishing an English colony; they locate Roanoke Island.

September  – In what is now Belgium, the Calvinist Republic of Ghent comes to an end after seven years when its capital, Ghent, falls following a siege of  months. Jan van Hembyze, leader of the republic since October , surrenders the city to Alexander Farnese, Governor of the Spanish Netherlands.

Belgian cartographer and geographer Abraham Ortelius features Ming dynasty-era Chinese carriages with masts and sails, in his atlas Theatrum Orbis Terrarum; concurrent and later Western writers also take note of this peculiar Chinese invention.

November  – In the wake of the Throckmorton Plot to overthrow her government, Queen Elizabeth convenes a new session of the English House of Commons since . John Puckering is appointed by her as the Speaker of the House of Commons, which has  members. The parliament passes the Safety of the Queen Act and the Jesuits Act ,

July  – The Treaty of Nemours forces King Henry III of France to capitulate to the demands of the Catholic League, triggering the Eighth War of Religion (also known as the War of the Three Henrys) in France.

June – Toyotomi Hideyoshi begins the invasion of the Japanese island of Shikoku with an army of , men on  ships. The troops are divided into three groups, with , commanded by Hashiba Hidenaga and Hashiba Hidetsugu toward the provinces of Awa and Tosa; , under Ukita Hideie at the province of Sanuki; and , under Kobayakawa Takakage and Kikkawa Motoharu for the province of Iyo.

July  – Aboard the English ship Tiger, Roanoke expedition leader Ralph Lane negotiates an agreement with the Secotan people, who are represented by Granganimeo, the brother of the Secotan leader, King Wingino. Although the Secotans grant Lane's request to allow the English to live on Roanoke Island, he is told that they will receive no assistance from the natives, because of problems the previous year with Walter Raleigh.

September  – King Henry IV of Navarre, who is also the heir presumptive to France's King Henry III, is excommunicated from the Roman Catholic Church by Pope Sixtus V, who effectively declares that French Catholics are not required to recognize his claim to the throne.
August  – English explorer John Davis enters Cumberland Sound in Baffin Island, in his quest for the Northwest Passage.

September  – In one of the most spectacular feats of engineering up to that time, devised by Domenico Fontana, the  feet ( m) tall, -ton Vatican obelisk is erected at St. Peter's Square in Rome after being transported between April  and May  from its previous location on orders of Pope Sixtus V.
July  – The Treaty of Berwick is signed between Queen Elizabeth I of England and King James VI of Scotland.
October – Mary, Queen of Scots, is convicted of treason and sentenced to death. She will be beheaded on February .
July  – Sir Francis Drake and his crew return to England, arriving at Portsmouth to heroes' welcome.
May  – English privateers, commanded by Sir Francis Drake, carry out a raid on the Spanish settlement of St. Augustine, Florida.

June  – Gabriel VIII becomes the new Pontiff of the Coptic Christian Church in Egypt, being enthroned as Pope Gabriel VIII and filling a vacancy that had existed for nine months since the death of Pope John XIV of Alexandria. Gabriel will reign until his death on May , .
November  – A final Austrian attack on Kraków by Archduke Maximilian III is repelled by the Polish defenders.

April  – Singeing the King of Spain's Beard: On his expedition against Spain, English sailor Sir Francis Drake leads a raid in the Bay of Cádiz, sinking or capturing at least  ships of the Spanish fleet, delaying by a year the sailing of the Spanish Armada for England.

January  – In Japan, Chancellor of the Realm Toyotomi Hideyoshi ends Portugal's control of the port of Nagasaki after six years. Omura Sumitada had leased the fishing village to Portuguese Jesuits on August , .

February  (1st waxing of Tabaung  ME) – King Nanda of Burma appoints his eldest son and heir apparent, Minye Kyawswa II, as Viceroy of Ava, later part of upper Burma, with a capital at Inwa (located in the modern-day Mandalay Region of Myanmar).
May  – Day of the Barricades in Paris: Henry I, Duke of Guise seizes the city, forcing King Henry III to flee.

February  – In modern-day Sri Lanka, the siege of Colombo by King Rajasinha I of Sitawaka ends when Portuguese Admiral Pedro Teixeira arrives with a fleet of  ships and frees the capital of Portuguese Ceylon. King Rajasinha and his troops flee back to his capital at Seethawakapura.
The Armada Portrait of Elizabeth I of England is created, to celebrate the English defeat of the Spanish Armada, and to assert the strength of Elizabeth herself.
April  – Christian IV becomes king of Denmark–Norway, upon the death of his father, Frederick II.

January  – War of the Polish Succession: The Battle of Pitschen takes place at Pitschen (modern Byczyna in Poland) with Polish and Lithuanian troops commanded by the Polish hetman Jan Zamoyski defending against an invading Austrian force commanded by Maximilian III, Archduke of Austria. After his army is routed, Archduke Maximilian surrenders and is taken as a prisoner of war, and will be held for more than a year until his release is compelled by the intervention of Pope Sixtus V.
July  – The English Armada, commanded by Sir Francis Drake, returns to Portsmouth after almost three months of pillaging the Spanish kingdoms.

August  – King Henry III of France is assassinated by a fanatical Dominican friar Jacques Clément, who approaches the King on the pretext of delivering a secret message. Henry tells his guards to stand aside, and Clément approaches and fatally stabs the King. Clément is subsequently killed by the guards. King Henry dies the next day.
May  – Ercole Grimaldi becomes the new Lord of Monaco upon the death of his older brother Charles II.

October  – King James VI of Scotland sails to Norway to meet his bride, Anne of Denmark as part of a fleet of six Scottish Navy ships, and is accompanied by Lord Maitland of Thirlestane, the Lord Chancellor of Scotland.

August  – Following the death of Henry III of France, his army is thrown into confusion and an attempt to retake Paris is abandoned. Henry of Navarre succeeds to the throne as King Henry IV of France, but is not recognized by the Catholic League, who acclaim the imprisoned Charles, Cardinal de Bourbon, as the rightful King of France, Charles X.

June  – The Japanese samurai Toyotomi Hideyoshi sends an army of , men, led by generals Maeda Toshiie and Uesugi Kagekatsu, in an attack on the Hachiōji Castle in what is now Tokyo. The castle is lightly defended, by only , men, because the samurai Hōjō Ujiteru has most of his troops engaged in defending Hideyohsi's siege of Odawara. The castle is captured after one day, and later destroyed on orders of the shogun Tokugawa Ieyasu.

September 
After the eight day conclave, Giovanni Battista Castagna, the Cardinal-Priest of San Marcello al Corso receives the necessary two-thirds majority despite support for Cardinal Marco Antonio Colonna. Castagna becomes Pope Urban VII but contracts malaria and dies  days later.
The estimated . magnitude Neulengbach earthquake causes significant damage and some loss of life, in Lower Austria and Vienna; the effects are felt as far as Bohemia and Silesia.

October 
(5th waxing of Tazaungmon  ME) – In what is now Myanmar, King Nanda Bayin of Burma sends a ,-man army, led by the Viceroy Thado Dhamma Yaza III of Prome, and General Natshinnaung to suppress a rebellion in the Shan state of Mogaung.
German astronomer Michael Maestlin becomes the first person to record an observation of the occultation of the planet Mars by the planet Venus.

July  – The day after his 12th birthday, Ferdinand of Habsburg becomes the new  Archduke of Inner Austria (Innerösterreich) upon the death, in Graz, of his father Charles II. A regency council rules in the place of Ferdinand until .

October  – Saadian invasion of the Songhai Empire: An army of , troops, led by Judar Pasha is dispatched from Marrakesh in the Saadi Sultanate (now Morocco), on orders of Sultan Ahmad al-Mansur. The Saadi Army's objective is to conquer the Songhai Empire, led by the Emperor Askia Ishaq II, in North Africa, corresponding to what is now the Republic of Mali.
ca. —Mursili I, king of the Hittites, sacks Babylon. This brings an end to the rule of the descendants of Hammurabi in that kingdom.

September  – The Kunohe rebellion, which was started by Kunohe Masazane on March  on northern Honshu island in Japan's Mutsu Province (in the modern-day Iwate Prefecture), is suppressed by the samurai Toyotomi Hideyoshi, Chancellor of the Realm. The victory completes the unification of Japan.
November  – Hundred Years' Croatian–Ottoman War: The Ottoman Empire successfully captures the Croatian rebel fort of Ripač.
December  – Pope Innocent IX dies only two months after having been elected as the Pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church, leaving the Papacy vacant for the 4th time in  months.
July  – Siege of Knodsenburg: Dutch Republic stadtholder Maurice of Nassau and English General Francis Vere defeat the Duke of Parma outside Nijmegen after a four-day siege.
English merchant James Lancaster sets off on a voyage to the East Indies.

May 
The Malta plague epidemic begins when galleys from the Grand Duchy of Tuscany arrive on the island with  prisoners of war from Egypt, and  ill crewmembers; over the next  months, , people on Malta die of the bubonic plague.
Battle of Okpo: The Korean navy is victorious over Japan.
November  – The city of San Luis Potosí is founded.
August  – Battle of Hansan Island: The Korean navy defeats the Japanese.
Negotiations begin for the annulment of the childless marriage of Henry IV of France and Marguerite of Valois.
September  – The captured Madre de Deus enters Dartmouth harbour in England and is then subjected to mass theft.
May  – English dramatist Thomas Kyd is arrested over the "Dutch church libel". "Atheist" literature found in his home is claimed to be Marlowe's.
January  – The Roman Inquisition opens the seven-year trial of scholar Giordano Bruno.
October  – Supposed date of the event described in the  transported soldier legend.

March  – The Pi Day, giving the most digits of pi when written in mm/dd/yyyy format, (i.e. .141593, //) occurs, as realized later. During  Flemish mathematician Adriaan van Roomen is working on the most accurate calculation of pi up to that time and arrives at  decimal places of pi using the polygon approximation method), and publishes it in his treatise Ideae mathematicae pars prima (Antverpiae, ).
May  – A warrant for the arrest of Christopher Marlowe is issued. On May  he presents himself to the Privy Council.
June  – Philip II of Spain recognizes the rights and privileges of the local nobles and chieftains in the Philippines, which paves the way for the stabilization of the rule of the Principalía.

November  – After the Principality of Wallachia (now in Romania) joins other Eastern European nations in a Holy League, a rebellion breaks out in Bucharest as Christian residents massacre the soldiers of the Ottoman Muslim garrison, entering Wallachia into the ongoing Thirteen Years' War.
February  – England's Admiral Richard Hawkins and the crew of the ship HMS Dainty become the first Europeans to see the Falkland Islands.

August  – Farkas Kovacsóczy, who has served as Chancellor of Transylvania for  years, is arrested on orders of Prince Sigismund Báthory, and István Jósika is appointed in his place. Kovacsóczy is imprisoned at Szamosújvár (now Gherla in Romania) and executed by strangulation on September .

September  – A fleet of six ships, commanded by the privateer Martin Frobisher, arrives at Morlaix and prepares to bombard the city, under siege by the French Army. The Spanish Army commander of the Morlaix garrison surrenders, rather than facing the city's destruction.
Sir Walter Raleigh of England departs from Plymouth to begin an expedition to South America

November  – The Battle of Guadalupe Island is fought between nine English Navy warships (led by Sir Francis Drake) and eight Spanish frigates off in the North Atlantic Ocean. The Spanish force wins the battle, capturing one ship and killing  English sailors. Both sets of ships proceed toward Puerto Rico.
July  – The Spanish raid Cornwall, England.
February  – The Goa state archives are established at the city of Panaji in Portuguese India (now India's Goa state) by historian Diogo do Couto.
December  – What is probably the first performance of William Shakespeare's play, Richard II, takes place in London.
Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, is founded.
July  – Capture of Cádiz: An English fleet, commanded by Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex, and Lord Howard of Effingham, sacks Cádiz.
June  – Pope Clement VIII appoints  new Cardinals.

July  –  Queen Elizabeth I of England issues "an open warrant to the Lord Mayor of London and the aldermen and his brethren, and to all other vice-admirals, mayors, and other public officers whatsoever to whom it may appertain" directing that Africans in the realm will be deported. Citing a request from Casper van Senden "to have licence to take up so many blackamoors  here in this realm  and to transport them into Spain and Portugal," the Queen notes that "Her majesty... considering the reasonableness of his request to transport so many blackamoors from hence, doth think it a very good exchange and that those kind of people may be well spared in this realm being so populous and numbers of able persons the subjects of the land and Christian people that perish for want of service, whereby through their labor they might be maintained."
August – David Fabricius discovers the variable nature of the star Mira.

October  – The Spanish Armada reaches the English Channel without opposition. An English ship sees the invading force's approach, but is intercepted and sunk, with the survivors being taken prisoner. The Armada encounters a storm the next day.

November  – In the last major action during the war of the 3rd Spanish Armada, the galleon Bear of Amsterdam is captured as it approaches Falmouth, where an English squadron intercepts it and leads it into Dartmouth.
Abbas I ends the Uzbek raids on his lands.

June  – The Staten-Generaal of the Dutch Republic  approves a proposal for the Generaliteitscollege, a common board for the Republic's five separate navies, the Admiralty of Amsterdam, the Admiralty of Rotterdam, the Admiralty of Zeeland, the Admiralty of the Noorderkwartier and the Admiralty of Friesland.

December  – Queen Elizabeth of England appoints George Nicholson as the English Resident in Scotland, the London's chief diplomatic official to Edinburgh, with a letter of accreditation for Nicholson to present to King James VI of Scotland.
November  – Pope Clement VIII authorizes the marriage between Albert of Austria and Isabella Clara Eugenia of Spain. The two will be married on April .
The Parliament of England passes the Vagabonds Act, that allows transportation of convicts to colonies.
Pentecost – Calvinist congregations in Zurich introduce music into their services.

September  (Keichō , 5th day of the 8th month) – With his own death imminent, General Toyotomi Hideyoshi of Japan issues an order directing the Council of Five Elders to bring their children to the Osaka Castle to join Hideyoshi's designated successor, his son Hideyori.
January  – In Berlin, Joachim Frederich of the House of Hohenzollern becomes the new Elector of Brandenburg upon the death of his father, Johann Georg von Brandenburg.

September  – The first reported performance at the Globe Theatre in London (erected over Spring/Summer), a presentation of Shakespeare's Julius Caesar (probably new to that year), is recorded by Swiss traveller Thomas Platter the Younger.
The first Capuchin friar is entombed in the Catacombe dei Cappuccini in Palermo (Sicily).
October  – Battle of Sellenberk: Michael the Brave, Prince of Wallachia, defeats the army of Andrew Báthory near Șelimbăr, leading to the first recorded unification of the Romanians.
May  – Anglo-Spanish War (–): The Siege of Zaltbommel, located in the Dutch Republic, is begun by Spanish general Francisco López de Mendoza.
May  – Essex takes Cahir Castle, supposedly the strongest in Ireland, after a short siege.
October  – Persian diplomats, led by Husayn 'Ali Beg of Persia, and Englishman Anthony Shirley (who serves as translator) arrive in Prague to meet with Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor.
June  – Barrister Nicholas Fuller is granted the exclusive right in England to manufacture playing cards.

June  – In England, a fire destroys much of the town of North Walsham, Norfolk, burning down  homes,  shops, and most of the stalls in the market square. The fire is traced to the home of one person who tries to flee town after the blaze begins. Many of the persons left homeless are given shelter at the St Nicholas Church.
January  – Sebald de Weert makes the first recorded sighting of the Falkland Islands.
February  – On his way to be burned at the stake for heresy in Rome, Giordano Bruno has his tongue "imprisoned" after he refuses to stop talking.
–—Hittite (Anatolia) iron tools and weapons.
Kings and princes on the mainland Greece have begun building large aboveground burial places commonly referred to as beehive tombs because of their rounded, conical shape.
The overthrow of the ruling Amorite dynasty in Aleppo, Syria.
The date of the earliest discovered rubber balls.
Shang dynasty instituted in China.

July  – The Siege of Ostend, which will last more than three years and claims more than , casualties for both Spain and the Netherlands, begins as Albert of Austria, Governor General of the Habsburg Netherlands, leads an attack on the Dutch Netherlands fortress at Ostend. The Spanish forces eventually triumph on September , , albeit in a Pyrrhic victory that will see at least , soldiers killed, wounded, or dead from disease.
Jesuit Matteo Ricci becomes the first European to enter the Forbidden City in Beijing, China, being invited by the Ming Dynasty Emperor.
December  – The 10th Parliament of Elizabeth I is adjourned. Another English Parliament will not be assembled until  when summoned by James I.
November  – Cyril I is selected as the new leader of the Eastern Orthodox Church as Patriarch of Constantinople and Greek Patriarch of Alexandria, succeeding Meletius I Pegas, who died on September .

February  – The Earl of Essex becomes the first of the Essex's Rebellion participants to be executed. He is beheaded at Tower Hill. His co-conspirator, the Earl of Southampton, sentenced to death, but Queen Elizabeth commutes his penalty to life imprisonment; Southampton will be released two years later.

June  – Dutch explorer Joris van Spilbergen lands on the eastern side of the island of Sri Lanka, at Santhamuruthu, and begins the process of attempting to establish a relationship with the rulers of the Kingdom of Kandy.
October  – Battle of the Narrow Seas: An English fleet, joined by the Dutch, begins a pursuit of six Spanish galleys through the Strait of Dover, and defeats them the next day.

December  – A surprise attack by forces under the command of Charles Emmanuel I, Duke of Savoy, and his brother-in-law, Philip III of Spain, is repelled by the citizens of Geneva (this actually takes place after midnight, in the early morning of December , but commemorations/celebrations on Fête de l'Escalade are usually held on December  or the closest weekend).

June  – James Lancaster's East India Company fleet arrives at Achin (modern-day Aceh), Sumatra to deal with the local ruler. Having defeated Portugal's ally, the ruler is happy to do business, and Lancaster seizes a large Portuguese galleon and loots it.
The Safavid Empire of Persia and the Spanish Empire conclude a defensive alliance and declare war on the Ottoman Empire.

May  – The Battle of Sluis is fought at sea off of the Belgian Netherlands as Spanish ships try unsuccessfully to break through a blockade port of the port of Sluis. The Spanish ships are forced to return to port after at least  sailors are killed.

October  – Yemişçi Hasan Pasha, the Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire, is executed on orders of Sultan Mehmed III, after failing to respond more quickly to the Safavid Empire's actions to take Tabriz. The Sultan appoints Yavuz Ali Pasha, the Ottoman Governor of Egypt to replace Yemişçi Hasan.
Yaqob is deposed as Emperor of Ethiopia for the first time by Za Sellase, who appoints his cousin Za Dengel to replace him.

Ottoman–Safavid War (–): Led by Iranian Emperor Abbas the Great, the Safavid Army of Iran stages a surprise attack on Tabriz, which had been taken from the Safavids by the Ottoman Empire in . Tabriz is recaptured after  days.
November – Rokugō rebellion: More than , rōnin rebel in support of their exiled lord, Onodera Yoshimichi, in Japan.

October  – Kepler's Supernova (SN ) is first observed from the northern parts of the Italian Peninsula. Beginning on October , Johannes Kepler begins a year's observation of it from Prague. There won't be another supernova visible to the "naked-eye" until . As of , this is the last supernova to be observed in the Milky Way.

July 
On  Safar  AH in the Islamic calendar, the decree of Ottoman Sultan Ahmed I is read aloud in the Great Mosque of Mecca, declaring that Idris ibn Hasan has been proclaimed the new Sharif of Mecca, in partnership with Idris's brother Fuhayd ibn Hasan and Idris and Fuhayd's nephew, Muhsin ibn Husayn
King James angrily dismisses the English parliament after failing to get full financial subsidies. He tells the members in his closing speech, "I am not of such a stock as to praise fools."
September  – Sri Guru Granth Sahib, the religious text of Sikhism, whose compilation by Guru Arjan was completed on August , is installed at Harmandir Sahib in Amritsar.

June  – Ottoman–Safavid War: General Cigalazade Yusuf Sinan Pasha, commander of the eastern Ottoman Army, leads troops on a march from Constantinople to fight the Persia's Safavid Army in Armenia, but arrives too late to save the city of Yerevan.

August  – The Dutch siege of Sluis in the Spanish Netherlands ends after three months, a day after relief troops commanded by General Ambrogio Spinola retreat. At least , of the members of the Spanish garrison inside had been killed or incapacitated by disease and famine. Sluis becomes part of the Netherlands afterward.
In England, John Winthrop, later governor of the future Massachusetts Bay Colony, marries his first wife (of ), Mary Forth, daughter of John Forth, of Great Stambridge, Essex.

The Priory of St. Gregory's is founded at Douai, Flanders, at this time in the Spanish Netherlands, by its first prior, John Roberts, and other exiles, thus becoming the first English Benedictine house to renew conventual life after the English Reformation. More than two centuries later the community will establish Downside Abbey back in England.
July  – Claiming to be Dmitriy, son of Ivan the Terrible, a pretender is officially crowned Tsar Dimitriy Ioannovich of Russia in Moscow by Patriarch Ignatius.

April  – Cardinal Alessandro Ottaviano de' Medici, the Bishop of Pistoia, is elected by the assembled  cardinals at the papal conclave after  days of balloting. He takes the regnal name of Pope Leo XI to become the 232nd pope, but serves for less than four weeks.
July  – The  Guangdong earthquake, of . magnitude, strikes China's Hainan Province causing widespread damage and thousands of deaths.

April  – Charter of : The First Charter of Virginia is adopted, by which King James I of England grants rights to the Virginia Company (comprising the London Company and Plymouth Company) to settle parts of the east coast of North America.

England deports  Roman Catholic priests, including Thomas Garnet, putting them on board a ship bound for Flanders in what is now Belgium. A royal proclamation is read to the group, warning them that they will be put to death if they ever return to the British Isles.

June  – A treaty is signed in Vienna between the Archduchy of Austria and the semi-independent  Principality of Transylvania.  Archduke Rudolf agrees to recognize Stephen Bocskai as Prince of Transylvania in return for Bocksay's guarantee of constitutional and religious rights to the ethnic Hungarians within Transylvania's borders.
March  – Ferdinando I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany, in the Fortezza Vecchia Chapel of Saint Francesco, elevates Livorno to the rank of city.
Simion Movilă becomes the new Prince of Moldavia upon the death of his older brother, Ieremia Movilă. Simion will reign for only  months before being poisoned on September , .

June  – At Jamestown, the triangular fort is completed and armed: "The fifteenth of June we had built and finished our Fort, which was triangle wise, having three Bulwarkes, at every corner, like a halfe Moone, and foure or five pieces of Artillerie mounted in them. We had made our selves sufficiently strong for these Savages. We had also sowne most of our Corne on two Mountaines." The colony reportedly bears extreme toil in strengthening the fort.
May  – From Jamestown, Christopher Newport, George Percy, Gabriel Archer and others travel six days exploring along the James River up to the falls and Powhatan's village.

July  – Zebrzydowski Rebellion: The Battle of Guzów is fought in Poland near Guzów against rebels by the combined armies of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, led by Poland's Hetman, General Stanisław Żółkiewski, and the Hetman of Lithuania, Jan Karol Chodkiewicz. The rebels, led by Mikołaj Zebrzydowski and Janusz Radziwiłł, are forced to retreat.

August  – The ship Gift of God of the Plymouth Company arrives at the mouth of the modern-day Kennebec River in Maine. English colonists establish Fort St. George, also known as the Popham Colony. The settlement lasts little more than a year, before residents return to England in the first oceangoing ship built in the New World, a -ton pinnace called The Virginia.

July  – The second "False Dmitry", one of three people claiming to be Dmitry Ivanovich, son of the late Tsar Ivan the Terrible, appears at the Russian town of Starodub and persuades residents that he is the rightful heir to the Russian throne.

November  – At the colony of Portuguese Macau, a port on the Chinese mainland leased from the Chinese Empire, a group of  Japanese samurai, wielding katana and muskets engage in a fight with musket-armed Portuguese soldiers commanded by Governor André Pessoa.  Around  Japanese are killed and the others are imprisoned until they sign an affidavit blaming themselves for the incident. Tokugawa Ieyasu, the principal shogun of Japan, subsequently ends the "red seal ships" program of authorizing Japanese nationals to visit Macau. The incident eventually leads to much larger naval battle in , the Nossa Senhora da Graça incident.
The Uniform Land-Tax Law is imposed in Korea.
September  – John Smith is elected council president of Jamestown, and begins expanding the fort.

November  – Sir Thomas Gates, Governor of the London Company's colony at Jamestown, Virginia, is ordered by the Board of Directors to forcibly convert the native Indians in the area to Christianity as Anglicans.
January  – At Jamestown, Virginia, fire destroys "all the houses in the fort"; the fort is repaired in March.
The Scrooby Congregation of Protestant English Separatists (predecessors of the Pilgrim Fathers) moves from Amsterdam to Leiden.
January  – One of the world's first newspapers, Avisa Relation oder Zeitung, begins publication in Wolfenbüttel (Holy Roman Empire).
August  (August  O.S.) – English astronomer Thomas Harriot becomes the first person to make a detailed drawing of the Moon, based on his observations through a telescope.
June  – The Battle of Tashiskari is fought as General Giorgi Saakadze of the Georgian Kingdom of Kartli repels invading troops from the Ottoman Empire before they can capture Tbilisi.

January  – The Basque witch trials are started in Spain as the court of the Inquisition at Logroño receives a letter from the commissioner of the village of Zugarramurdi, and orders the arrest of four women, including María de Jureteguía and María Chipía de Barrenetxea.

November  – After the Parliament of England gives King James only £ , of an agreed to £ , of debt relief promised in February under the Great Contract, the King demands the rest of the funds. Parliament is outraged and declares the Contract abandoned on November .

April  – The Treaty of Brussol is signed between Charles Emmanuel I, Duke of Savoy, and a representative of King Henry IV of France, at a meeting at Bruzolo near Turin. The agreement for France and Savoy to remove Spanish occupiers from Italy, is never carried out because King Henry is assassinated one month later.
September  (September  O.S.) – Forces of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth capture Moscow and begin occupation of the Kremlin for the next two years.
February  – English courtier Thomas Roe sets out on an expedition to The Guianas and Amazon River.
January  – Galileo Galilei first observes the four Galilean moons of Jupiter: Ganymede, Callisto, Europa and Io, but is unable to distinguish the latter two until the following day.
The Chinese records a famine accompanied with frost in July. They also recorded a dim sun and yellow fog during this time.
A volcanic eruption at Thera island destroyed the ancient city of Akrotiri.
April  – Denmark-Norway declares war on Sweden, then captures Kalmar.
April  – The priest implicated in the Aix-en-Provence possessions in France is executed.

February  – Sunspots are observed by telescope, by Frisian astronomers Johannes Fabricius and David Fabricius. Johannes publishes the results of these observations, in De Maculis in Sole observatis in Wittenberg, later this year. Such early discoveries are overlooked, however, and the first sighting is claimed a few months later, by Galileo Galilei and Christoph Scheiner.
June  – English explorer and sea captain Henry Hudson, his teenage son John, and seven crewmen are set adrift in or near Hudson Bay, after a mutiny on his ship Discovery. They are never seen again.
May–December – Entrepreneur Thomas Sutton founds Charterhouse School, on the site of the old Carthusian monastery in Charterhouse Square, Smithfield, London.
March  – The False Dmitry III, one of three pretenders to the Russian throne who all claim to be sons of Ivan the Terrible, is recognized as Tsar of Russia by the Cossacks.

January  – Gustavus Adolphus replies to Metropolitan Isidor, Odoevskij and the estates of Novgorod, stating that he himself wishes to assume responsibility for the government of Novgorod and also of all Russians. A number of land grants signed the same day show that the Swedish king has assumed the title of Tsar.
June  – The coronation of Matthias as Holy Roman Emperor takes place at the Frankfurt Cathedral.
Thomas Shelton's English translation of the first half of Don Quixote is published. It is the first translation of the Spanish novel into any language.
July  – (8th waxing of Waso  ME) In what is now Myanmar, Min Khamaung becomes the new King of Arakan upon the death of his father, King Min Razagyi.

June  (July  N.S.) – From Jamestown, John Rolfe makes the first shipment to England of tobacco grown in Virginia, dispatching it on the ship The Elizabeth.  The tobacco arrives in England after a voyage of three weeks.
June  – Fire destroys London's famed Globe Theatre, during a performance of Shakespeare's Henry VIII.
The Date Maru, carrying the Japanese diplomatic mission commanded Hasekura Tsunenaga, reaches North America, sighting Cape Mendocino on the California coast.
October  – Gabriel Bethlen is elected as the new Prince of Transylvania.
February  – King Anaukpetlun of Burma blockades the Portuguese port at Syriam with  warships and , men, then sets about to tunnel into the city.

October  – The French Estates General begins its last session. The session, with  deputies representing the nobility, the lower and middle classes, and the clergy, closes on February , . For the next  years, the Kingdom of France will be governed as an absolute monarchy until the calling of a new Estates General in  at the start of the French Revolution.
February  – In Japan, the practice of Christianity is banned, and an edict is issued for the expulsion of all foreign missionaries.

April  (April  O.S.)
Pocahontas, the -year-old daughter of Chief Wahunsenacawh of the Powhatan Algonquian  native tribe in the modern-day U.S. state of Virginia, is forced into child marriage with English colonist John Rolfe at Jamestown, a year after her capture in war. She is given the name of Rebecca Rolfe and departs with John Rolfe to England in , dying before she can return.
The Addled Parliament is assembled in England as the second parliament of King James I, and the first in more than nine years. Its members serve for two months. A new parliament will not be seated until more than six years later.
The Republic of the Netherlands and the Kingdom of Sweden enter into a treaty at the Hague.
Possible date – John Webster's revenge tragedy The Duchess of Malfi is first performed in public, at the newly-reconstructed Globe Theatre in London.
July  – Raid of Żejtun: Ottoman forces make a final attempt to conquer the island of Malta, but are beaten back by the Knights Hospitaller.
November  – Alexandru Movilă is installed as Prince of Moldavia by Poland as Prince Ștefan IX Tomșa is driven from the throne.
September  – An estimated . magnitude earthquake strikes Arica (now part of Chile in the Spanish colonial Viceroyalty of Peru and collapses the city's fort, but causes no deaths.

March  – John Ogilvie, a Jesuit priest, is hanged and drawn at Glasgow Cross in Scotland for refusing to pledge allegiance to King James VI of Scotland; he will be canonised in , becoming the only post-Reformation Scottish saint.
The Perse School in Cambridge, England, is founded by Dr Stephen Perse.
October  – In Russia, the siege of Pskov ends with the withdrawal of Swedish Army troops. The siege is the last battle of the Ingrian War.
Istanbul's Sultan Ahmed Mosque (also known as the Blue Mosque) is completed during the rule of Ahmed I.

February  – In the aftermath of the – anti-Jewish pogrom called the Fettmilch uprising in Frankfurt, Germany, mob leader Vincenz Fettmilch is beheaded, but the Jews, who had been expelled from the city on August , , following the plundering of the Judengasse, can return only as a result of direct intervention by Holy Roman Emperor Matthias. After long negotiations, the Jews are left without any compensation for their plundered belongings.
William Harvey gives his views on the circulation of blood, as Lumleian Lecturer at the Royal College of Physicians. It is not until  that he gives his views in print.

November 
The Tepehuán Revolt begins in Nueva Vizcaya with the attack of a Spanish wagon train that is on its way to Mexico City. It tests the limits of Spanish and Jesuit colonialism, in western and northwestern Durango and southern Chihuahua, Mexico.
Marco Antonio de Dominis, Roman Catholic Archbishop of the See of Spalato and Primate of Dalmatia, having run afoul of Pope Paul V over secular matters relating to Venice, submits to King James I of England and later becomes Dean of Windsor.

Captain John Smith publishes his book A description of New England in London. Smith relates one voyage to the coast of Massachusetts and Maine, in , and an attempted voyage in , when he was captured by French pirates and detained for several months before escaping.
October  – The Treaty of Pavia is signed between Spain and Savoy, under which Savoy returns Monferrato to Mantua.
February  – The Treaty of Stolbovo ends the Ingrian War between Sweden and Russia. Sweden gains Ingria and Kexholm.

December  – Lord Clifton is imprisoned at the Tower of London for threatening Francis Bacon, Lord Chancellor. Clifton is prosecuted by the Star Chamber on March  and eventually commits suicide in Fleet Prison.
April  – Second Battle of Playa Honda: The Spanish navy defeats a Dutch fleet in the Philippines.

May  – King James I of England is escorted by the Earl of Home across the border to return to Scotland (where he reigns as King James VI) for the first time since the Union of the Crowns  years earlier in . He is given lodging at Home's Dunglass Castle, East Lothian.
October  – Residents of Mogilev revolt against Uniate bishop Josaphat Kuntsevych.
September  – The Siege of Pilsen begins as the first major battle of the Thirty Years' War, as Bohemian Protestants lay siege to the Bohemian Catholic city and lasts for more than two months.
November  – The Synod of Dort has its first meeting.

January 
Jahangir, ruler of the Mughal Empire in northern India, gives an audience for the first time to a representative of the British East India Company, receiving Sir Thomas Roe at the capital at Ahmedabad.
Ben Jonson's play Pleasure Reconciled to Virtue is given its premiere performance, presented at the Palace of Whitehall in London.
December  – Russia and Poland sign the Truce of Deulino.
November  – Thirty Years' War–  Battle of Humenné:  Polish Lisowczycy troops assist the Holy Roman Emperor by defeating a Transylvanian force, forcing Gabor Bethlen to raise his siege of Vienna.
Dutch statesman Johan van Oldenbarnevelt is executed in The Hague, after having been convicted of treason.
October  – Thirty Years' War – The Treaty of Munich is signed by Ferdinand II and Maximilian I, Elector of Bavaria.
An expedition in Sri Lanka, led by Filipe de Oliveira, deposes and executes the last Jaffna king (Cankili II), putting an end to the Jaffna Kingdom.
A Spanish expedition sails around Tierra del Fuego, mapping the coast and discovering the Diego Ramírez Islands.
February  – Prince Bethlen Gabor secures a peace treaty with Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor.
History of submarines: Cornelis Drebbel demonstrates the first navigable undersea boat in the Thames in England.

January  – Ben Jonson's play News from the New World Discovered in the Moon is given its first performance, a presentation to King James I of England. In addition to dialogue about actual observations made by telescope of the Moon, the play includes a fanciful discussion of a lunar civilization, featuring a dance by the "Volatees", the lunar race.
The Finnish town of Kokkola (Swedish: Karleby) is founded by King Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden.
June  – The oldest stone church in French North America, Notre-Dame-des-Anges, is begun at Quebec City in modern-day Canada.
Mursili I becomes King of the Hittite Empire (middle chronology).
Lullaia becomes the King of Assyria.

Beginning of a period of cooling of the world climate lasting several years, recorded in tree-rings all over the world. Various volcanic eruptions have been suggested for the cause of this climatic event; the Minoan eruption of Thera, the Avellino eruption of Mount Vesuvius, or the eruption of Mount Aniakchak.
Samsu-Ditana becomes King of Babylon (middle chronology).
June  – The Dutch West India Company is founded.
November  – The ship Fortune arrives at Plymouth Colony, with  more settlers.
October  – The Treaty of Khotyn is signed between the Ottoman Empire and the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, ending the First Polish-Ottoman War.
March  – Samoset, a Mohegan, visits the settlers of Plymouth Colony and greets them: "Welcome, Englishmen! My name is Samoset."

December  – Thirty Years' War: The Peace of Nikolsburg is signed between Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor and Gabor Bethlen, Prince of Transylvania. Bethlen agrees to renounce his claims to Hungary. In return Bethlen receives several counties and lands along the eastern border of the Holy Roman Empire, and Moravia is granted religious freedom.
April  – Hormuz is captured from the Portuguese, by an Anglo-Persian force.

May  – Thirty Years' War: While waiting for the Protestant forces of Christian the Younger of Brunswick to join them, Mansfeld and Georg Friedrich of Baden-Durlach split up their forces as a diversion for the Imperial army of Tilly. Their plan fails, as Tilly manages to cut off Georg Friedrich at Wimpfen. At the ensuing Battle of Wimpfen, Georg Friedrich's army is almost completely destroyed.
June  – Dutch–Portuguese War – Battle of Macau: The outnumbered Portuguese forces successfully defend Macau from the Dutch fleet, keeping a Portuguese foothold in the Far East.
February  – King James I of England dissolves the English Parliament.
September  – Armand Jean du Plessis becomes Cardinal Richelieu.
On the coast of Massachusetts Bay, the settlement that will become the City of Gloucester, Massachusetts, is first inhabited by men from Dorchester, Dorset, England.
March  – Richard Frethorne begins writing a letter to his parents from Jamestown, Virginia.

August 
 papal conclave: Pope Urban VIII (Maffeo Barberini) succeeds Pope Gregory XV, as the 235th pope.
Thirty Years' War: Pursued by the army of the Catholic League (Germany) led by Johann Tserclaes, Count of Tilly, the army of the Protestant Electoral Palatinate led by Christian the Younger of Brunswick attempts to flee to the Dutch Republic. Tilly's army catches Brunswick five miles from the border. In the resulting Battle of Stadtlohn, Christian's army is destroyed. This brings the Palatinate campaign to an end.
March  – In the Korean kingdom of Joseon, Crown Prince Yi Ji is deposed and exiled to Ganghwa Island, where he dies soon after.
February  – Thirty Years' War: Duke Maximilian I of Bavaria becomes Elector of the Electorate of the Palatinate.
Henry Briggs publishes Arithmetica Logarithmica.
April  – Louis XIII of France appoints Cardinal Richelieu to the Conseil du Roi (Royal Council).
April  – Garcia Mvemba a Nkanga is enthroned as King Garcia I of the southern African nation of Kongo (now in Angola), upon the death of his father, King Pedro II.
June  – Treaty of Compiègne is signed between the Kingdom of France and the Dutch Republic.
January  – Korean General Yi Gwal leads an uprising of , soldiers against King Injo in what is called then the Joseon Kingdom, and occupies Hanseong.
June  – Eighty Years' War: Spanish troops under Ambrogio Spinola conquer Breda, after a nine-month siege.
April  – Stadtholder Maurice of Nassau of the Dutch Republic dies, and is succeeded by his younger brother, Frederick Henry.
February  – Bogislaw XIV becomes the final Duke of Pomerania, an office that becomes extinct after his death in .
January  – Led by the Duke of Soubise, the Huguenots launch a second rebellion against King Louis XIII, with a surprise naval assault on a French fleet being prepared in Blavet.
June  – Prince Frederick Henry is sworn in as the stadtholder of Holland and Zeeland.
July  – George II becomes the new Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt upon the death of his father, Louis V.
Establishment of the coastal settlement of Salem, Massachusetts.
December  – Pasha Muhammad ibn Farukh, tyrannical Governor of Jerusalem, is forced out.
September  – Nurhaci, chief of the Jurchens and founder of the Qing dynasty, dies and is succeeded by his son Hong Taiji.
The Würzburg and Bamberg witch trials, which will lead to the mass executions of hundreds of people until /, begin.
September  – Mohammed Adil Shah begins his reign as the new Sultan of Bijapur in south India, after the death of his father, Ibrahim Adil Shah II.
April  – The 't Gulden Zeepaert reaches Batavia in the Dutch East Indies.
October  – The Mughal Emperor Jahangir dies of a respiratory illness near Bhimber while attempting to return to his palace at Lahore.

March  – After the First Manchu invasion of Korea, the Joseon dynasty of Korea becomes a tributary state of the Manchus, but still pays respects to the Ming dynasty of China. After rejecting a Manchu alteration to the original diplomatic terms in , the Manchus invade again in .

June 
Hinchingbrooke House in the east of England is sold by Sir Oliver Cromwell, to Sidney Montagu.
Turkish Abductions: Barbary corsairs from Salé raid the fishing village of Grindavík in Iceland and take captives into slavery, the first of several raids.
April  – Cardinal Girolamo Grimaldi-Cavalleroni is appointed as the Governor of Rome by Pope Urban VIII.

December  – At the age of , Chetthathirat is crowned as the new King of Thailand upon the death of his father, Intharacha III. Prince Chetthathirat takes the regnal name of Borommaracha II and is killed less than a year later.
September  – Thirty Years' War – Battle of Wolgast: Wallenstein defeats Christian IV of Denmark's army.
William Harvey publishes Exercitatio Anatomica de Motu Cordis et Sanguinis in Animalibus in Frankfurt, containing his findings about blood circulation.
August  – The Swedish -gun sailing ship Vasa sinks  minutes into her maiden voyage, in Stockholm Harbor.
January  – Sam Mirza, son of the late Mohammad Baqer Mirza and grandson of Abbas the Great, is crowned as the new Shah of Persia and takes the regnal name Safi.
July  – Anglo-French War (–): New France's Samuel de Champlain surrenders the city of Quebec to an English force led by David Kirke.

February  – Puritan migration to New England (–): Around  English Puritans on six ships, led by Francis Higginson in the Lyon's Whelp, sail from Yarmouth, Isle of Wight, heading to the Massachusetts Bay Colony in America. They arrive on June .

July  – In Morocco, the city of Salé is bombarded by French Admiral Isaac de Razilly with a fleet composed of the ships Licorne, Saint-Louis, Griffon, Catherine, Hambourg, Sainte-Anne, Saint-Jean; his forces destroyed three corsair ships
June  – The Dutch States-General ratifies the Dutch West India Company's Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions, making it more attractive to invest in the colony of New Netherland in North America.
October  – War of the Mantuan Succession: the Peace of Regensburg is signed. Charles Gonzaga is confirmed as Duke of Mantua.

July 
The Success, last ship of the Winthrop Fleet, lands safely at Salem harbor, Massachusetts Bay Colony.
Swedish intervention in the Thirty Years' War begins when King Gustav Adolf of Sweden, leading an army of , on the Protestant side, makes landfall at Peenemünde, Pomerania.
September  – The first ship of de Sauce's emigrants arrive at Southampton Hundred, on the James River in Virginia.
July – The Italian plague of – reaches Venice.
January  – Nicolò Contarini is elected as the new Doge of the Republic of Venice and spends most of his time fighting a bubonic plague epidemic, but dies in office on April , .
Before  – —Landscape (Spring fresco), wall painting with areas of modern reconstruction from Akrotiri, Thera, Cyclades, is made. It is now at National Archaeological Museum, Athens.
Gazette de France, the first weekly French newspaper, is published.
December  – A volcanic eruption of Mount Vesuvius at Pompeii occurs, for the first time in several centuries.
Antonio Colmenero de Ledesma's [es] Chocolate: or, An Indian Drinke.
June  – War of the Mantuan Succession: The Treaty of Cherasco is signed, ending the War of the Mantuan Succession.
June  – The death in childbirth of Mumtaz Mahal at Burhanpur causes her husband Shah Jahan to commission the Taj Mahal at Agra, as a mausoleum for her. Construction is started in , and finished in .
The Portuguese are driven out of Bengal.
King Władysław IV Vasa of Poland forbids anti-Semitic books and printings.
November  – Wladyslaw IV Waza is elected king of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, after Sigismund III Vasa's death.
July  – Three hundred colonists for New France depart Dieppe.
December  – Indians wipe out a new Dutch settlement of Swanadael in New Netherland.
Mission San Luis de Apalachee is built in the New World by two Spanish friars.
April  – Galileo Galilei is convicted of heresy by the  Roman Catholic Church.
September  – a group from the Plymouth Colony settles in Windsor, Connecticut, making it the first settlement in the state.
March  – Samuel de Champlain reclaims his role as commander of New France, on behalf of Cardinal Richelieu.
September  – King Louis XIII enters into Nancy, marking the occupation of the Duchy of Lorraine by France.
April – The first performance of the Oberammergau Passion Play is held in Bavaria.
March  – The Russians vacate their camp, ending the Siege of Smolensk.
Moses Amyraut's Traité de la predestination is published.
September  – A gunpowder factory explodes in Valletta, Malta, killing  people and damaging several buildings.
October  – The Burchardi flood (also known as the second Grote Mandrenke) strikes the North Sea coast of Germany and Denmark, causing at least , deaths and perhaps as many as ,.
February  – The Académie française in Paris is formally constituted, as the national academy for the preservation of the French language.
May  – Thirty Years' War – The Peace of Prague is signed, which ends the German civil war aspect of the conflict.

In Edo period Japan, the Sakoku Edict of  enforces isolationism. Japanese are forbidden to travel abroad and unauthorised Europeans forbidden to enter under penalty of death. Christianity (Catholicism) is absolutely prohibited. Foreign merchants – Chinese and those of the Dutch East India Company – are restricted to enclaves in Nagasaki and access by the Portuguese is completely forbidden: an imperial memorandum decrees, "Hereafter entry by the Portuguese galeota is forbidden. If they insist on coming, the ships must be destroyed and anyone aboard those ships must be beheaded."
Guadeloupe and Martinique are colonized by France.

December  – Shah Jahan, Emperor of India's Mughal Empire, issues a decree against Portuguese Jesuits, ordering that the Agra Church be demolished and barring them from attempting to convert Hindus and Muslims to the Christian faith, but allows them to conduct their religious ceremonies in private.
March  (February  Old Style) – King Christian IV of Denmark and Norway gives an order, that all beggars that are able to work must be sent to Brinholmen, to build ships or to work as galley rowers.
August  – The Spanish capture Corbie, France.
April  – Eighty Years' War: The nine-month Siege of Schenkenschans ends, when forces of the Dutch Republic recapture the strategically important fort from the Spanish.
July  – The Senate of the Venetian Republic votes,  to , in favor of renewing the charter of Jewish merchants to sell within the city, after a delay of almost six months.
July  – In France, Cardinal Richelieu persuades King Louis XIII to issue an ordonnance excusing the French nobility from military service if they pay a tax which allows the hiring of paid cavalry.
Richard Norwood's book The Seaman's Practice is published for the first time.
May – Chinese encyclopedist Song Yingxing publishes his Tiangong Kaiwu ("Exploitation of the Works of Nature"), considered one of the most valuable encyclopedias of classical China.

June  – The first English venture to China is attempted by Captain John Weddell, who sails into port in Macau and Canton during the late Ming dynasty with six ships. The voyages are for trade, which is dominated here by the Portuguese (at this time combined with the power of Spain). He brings , pairs of eyeglasses, perhaps the first recorded European-made eyeglasses to enter China.

October  – English Royal Navy first-rate ship of the line Sovereign of the Seas is launched at Woolwich Dockyard at a cost of £,, adorned from stern to bow with gilded carvings, after a design by Anthony van Dyck.
Elizabeth Poole becomes the first female founder of a town (Taunton, Massachusetts) in the Americas.
March  – Dutch merchant Willem Kieft is appointed Director of New Netherland by the Dutch East India Company to succeed Wouter van Twiller.
May  – The Kandyan Treaty is signed between Singhala King Rajasimha II and the Dutch, to rid Ceylon of the Portuguese.
Anne Hutchinson is banished from the Massachusetts Bay Colony for heresy and goes to Rhode Island.
February  – The Scottish National Covenant is signed in Edinburgh, Scotland, in opposition to changes to the Church of Scotland proposed by King Charles I.

A fleet of  Spanish ships led by Governor-General Sebastián Hurtado de Corcuera attacks the Sultanate of Sulu in the Philippines by beginning an invasion of Jolo island, but Sultan Muwallil Wasit I puts up a stiff resistance.

The Casiquiare canal, a river forming a natural channel between the Amazon River and Orinoco River basins, is first encountered by Europeans, an expedition led by Pedro Teixeira and Cristóbal Diatristán de Acuña.

April  – In the Battle of Chemnitz, Swedish forces under Johan Banér inflict a crushing defeat on the army of the Holy Roman Empire, prolonging the Thirty Years' War and allowing the Swedes to occupy Pirna and advance into Bohemia.
March  – The early settlement of Taunton, Massachusetts, is incorporated as a town.
July  – Parthenius I becomes the new leader of the Eastern Orthodox Christian church as he is selected as Patriarch of Constantinople, succeeding Cyril II.

Dejima, an island trading post off Nagasaki, becomes the only official port of trade allowed for Europeans, with the multi-national United East Indies Company (Vereenigde Oostindische Compagnie) as the only European party officially allowed. Trading parties from China, India and other places are still officially allowed, though the VOC will become the usual broker for them.
July   – John Punch, a servant of Virginia planter Hugh Gwyn, is sentenced to a life of servitude after attempting to escape, making him the "first official slave in the English colonies"
August  – Forty-one Spanish delegates to Japan at Nagasaki are beheaded.
August  – Second Bishops' War – Battle of Newburn: The Scottish Covenanter army led by Alexander Leslie defeats the English army near Newburn in England.
September  – The Siege of Turin ends in Italy after almost four months with a victory by French and Piedmontese after having started on May , and the city is recaptured from Spain.
May / Following the Short Parliament's dissolution, an angry and armed mob attacked Lambeth Palace in the hope of killing the unpopular Archbishop, William Laud.

April  – The Battle of Songjin begins in the modern-day North Korean city of Kimch'aek, at the time part of the Chinese Empire controlled by the Ming dynasty. The Ming, led by General Wu Sangui, defeat the Qing rebels.
February  – King Charles I of England gives his assent to the Triennial Act, reluctantly committing himself to parliamentary sessions of at least fifty days, every three years.
June  – Bavarian and Spanish troops capture the town of Bad Kreuznach during the Thirty Years' War,  months after it had been taken in a French and Saxon attack.
May  – Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford, former director of England's Council of the North, is publicly beheaded in London in front of a crowd of thousands of people.

September  – The English ship Merchant Royal sinks off Cornwall along with its cargo of , pounds (, kg) of gold and  of its  crew. More than  years later, treasure seekers  will still not have located the wreckage.
June  – Irish Confederate Wars: The Battle of Glenmaquin takes place in County Donegal, with the Protestant Laggan Army decisively defeating Confederate Ireland soldiers.

December  – First English Civil War: After routing Edward Ford's royalist troops at the Battle of Muster Green, William Waller follows Ford's retreating force to Chichester as the Parliamentarians besiege the city, which falls on December  after eight days. The inhabitants of Chichester agree to pay the Parliamentarians an additional month's pay to prevent the town from being plundered.
Rembrandt finishes his painting The Night Watch (Militia Company of District II under the Command of Captain Frans Banninck Cocq) in Amsterdam.
October  – The first Confederate Assembly of Ireland is held in Kilkenny where it sets up a provisional government, largely Catholic Royalist; start of the Irish Confederate Wars.

November  – Abel Tasman and his crew become the first Europeans to discover "Van Diemen's Land", later the Australian island  and state of Tasmania, and the island is claimed for the Netherlands on December  at what becomes Prince of Wales Bay.
March  – First English Civil War: First Battle of Middlewich – Roundheads (Parliamentarians) rout the Cavaliers (Royalist supporters of King Charles I) at Middlewich in Cheshire.
December  – Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean is sighted and named by Captain William Mynors of the British East India Company ship Royal Mary.

May 
Thirty Years' War: Battle of Rocroi: The French defeat the Spanish at Rocroi in France.
The New England Confederation is formed as a military alliance between Massachusetts Bay Colony, Plymouth Colony, Saybrook Colony (Connecticut), and New Haven Colony.
August  – Dutch expedition to Valdivia: A Dutch fleet establishes a new colony in the ruins of Valdivia in southern Chile.

May  – Louis XIV succeeds his father Louis XIII as King of France at age . His rule will last until his death at age  in , a total of  years, which will be the longest reign of any European monarch in recorded history.
May  – Ming general Wu Sangui forms an alliance with the invading Manchus and opens the gates of the Great Wall of China at Shanhaiguan Pass, letting the Manchus through towards the capital Beijing.
February  – Prince of Transylvania George I Rákóczi invades Hungary to aid Sweden against the Habsburgs
September  – English Civil War: Battle of Tippermuir – Montrose defeats Lord Elcho's Covenanters, reviving the Royalist cause in Scotland.
January  – First English Civil War: Battle of Nantwich – The Parliamentarians defeat the Royalists, allowing them to end the -week siege of the Cheshire town.
February  – The first livestock branding law in America is passed in Connecticut.
May  – Battle of Auldearn: Scottish Covenanters are defeated by Montrose.
February  – Battle of Inverlochy: The Scottish Covenanters are defeated by Montrose.
January  – Archbishop of Canterbury William Laud is executed for treason on Tower Hill, London.
September  – English Civil War: Scottish Covenanters abandon the Siege of Hereford and retreat northwards
The Solar cycle enters the -year Maunder Minimum, during which sunspots will be rare.
January  – The English House of Commons approves a bill to provide for Ireland to be governed by a single Englishman.
First English Civil War: Raglan Castle in Wales surrenders to General Fairfax after a -month siege; it is later destroyed.
March  – Joseph Jenkes obtains the first colonial machine patent, in Massachusetts.
October  – France takes Dunkirk from the Spanish Netherlands for the first time.

July  – The populist political movement called the Levellers appears in England with the publication of the Levellers manifesto,  A Remonstrance of Many Thousand Citizens by Richard Overton and William Walwyn.
February  – The Yongli era is proclaimed as Zhu Youlang is declared the Yongli Emperor of the Southern Ming.

September  – The Dutch merchant ship Princess Amelia runs aground off of the coast of Mumbles Point, Wales and sinks, killing  of the  people aboard, including former New Netherlands Governor Willem Kieft.
Aberystwyth Castle in Wales, a former Royalist stronghold, is razed to the ground after "a battery of cannon erected on the top of Pendinas hill by Cromwell" and the Parliamentarian troops.
January  – The Westminster Assembly begins debating the biblical proof texts, to support the new Confession of Faith.
November  – Battle of Knocknanuss: An Irish confederate force is destroyed by the army of Parliament; Alasdair MacColla is killed.

Manchu invaders of China's Fujian province capture Spanish Dominican priest Francisco Fernández de Capillas, torture him and then behead him.  Capillas will be canonized more than  years later in  in the Roman Catholic Church as one of the Martyr Saints of China.

February  – England's parliament passes stricter laws against performance of stage plays, providing for demolition of seats in theatres, imprisonment for actors and fines for spectators.  The vote comes six days after the King's Men Players are arrested at the Cockpit Theatre during an illegal performance of Rollo Duke of Normandy.
The epic poem Padmavati is written by Alaol.
May  – England's Commonwealth Army massacres  Cornish royalists at Penzance, leading to a rebellion against England's Parliamentarians.
The Dutch artist Rembrandt produces the works Rembrandt drawing at a window and Beggars at the Door.

July  – The Commonwealth of England Parliament passes the "Act for the promoting and propagating the Gospel of Jesus Christ in New England" to create the "Company for Propagation of the Gospel in New England and the parts adjacent in America" for Christian missionary ministries to Native American tribes.  The New England Company will continue to operate more than three and a half centuries later.

The English Parliament, having voted February  against a proposal to continue the monarchy under Oliver Cromwell, passes the "Act Abolishing the Kingship" with the goal of creating a republic under a Lord Protector selected by an elected Parliament.
March  – The rebel Frondeurs and the French government sign the Peace of Rueil.
Alexis, Tsar of the Russian Empire orders all English merchants to leave Moscow.

January  – The deposed King Charles I is beheaded outside the Banquet Hall in the Palace of Whitehall, London. The Commonwealth of England, with a republican form of government, replaces the monarchy as the form of government of England and members of the Long Parliament serve as government. Charles, Prince of Wales declares himself as King of England, Scotland and Ireland pending restoration of the monarchy.
June  – Claimant King Charles II of England, Scotland and Ireland arrives in Scotland (at Garmouth), the only one of the three kingdoms that has accepted him as ruler.
The town of Sharon, Massachusetts is founded.
September  – The Kolumbo volcano on Santorini experiences a massive eruption (VEI ).
Puritans chop down the original Glastonbury Thorn in England.
March  – João Rodrigues de Vasconcelos, Portuguese Count of Castelo Melhor, becomes the new Governor of Brazil.
Greeks start to live in Mycenae.
The Rhind Mathematical Papyrus is produced.
Second Intermediate Period starts in Ancient Egypt (other date is ).
The last Woolly mammoths die on Wrangel Island, rendering the species extinct.
Tan-Uli, the ruler of the Elamite Empire, dies.

August 
The "Onfall of Alyth takes place in the Scottish town of the same name when most of the members of Scotland's governing body, the Committee of States, are betrayed to English invaders. The Earl of Leven, the Earl of Crawford, the Earl Marischal, Lord Nairne and other prominent people are captured and imprisoned in the Tower of London. 
The Battle of Upton is fought at Upton-upon-Severn in England, where Scottish invaders commanded by Major General Edward Massey are defeated by the English Parliamentarians led by John Lambert.  The retreat of the Scots clears the way for the successful English attack at Worcester.

February  – St. Peter's Flood: A first storm tide in the North Sea strikes the coast of Germany, drowning thousands. The island of Juist is split in half, and the western half of Buise is probably washed away.
August  – The troops of King Charles II of Scotland force the retreat of English Commonwealth troops at the Battle of Warrington Bridge, the last victory of Scotland over England in battle.
March  – The town of Kajaani is founded by Count Per Brahe the Younger.
January  – Parliament of Boroa in Chile: Spanish and Mapuche authorities meet at Boroa, renewing the fragile peace established at the parliaments of Quillín, in  and .
July  – A mob kills  people, including judges, in the massacre at the Hôtel de Ville, Paris.
November  – The Netherlands takes control of the English Channel after the Battle of Dungeness ends in a Dutch victory over the English Royal Navy.
January  – Michiel de Ruyter marries the widow Anna van Gelder and plans retirement, but months later becomes a vice-commodore in the First Anglo-Dutch War.

February  – Oliver Cromwell, England's Lord Protector, announces that his Council of Scotland will regulate church affairs as part of the Terms of Incorporation of Scotland into England, and eliminates Presbyterianism as Scotland's state religion.
October  – The Great Fire of Oulu destroys almost all of the houses of the town’s bourgeoisie, the provision warehouses and the drawbridge of Oulu Castle, in the town of Oulu, Finland.

April  –  The Great Fire of Marlborough destroys  houses and much of the textile businesses in the Wiltshire town which, "at that date was one of considerable importance, and had merchants of affluence and repute."

September  – A violent storm off the west coast of Scotland sinks the English Navy warship Swan, and the commandeered merchantmen Speedwell and Martha and Margaret, all of which have been anchored off of Mull.  Most of the crews had gone ashore, but  of the men on the ship Speedwell are killed.
March  – A Dutch fleet defeats the English in the Battle of Leghorn in the Mediterranean but the Dutch commander, Johan van Galen, later dies of his wounds.
July  – John Thurloe becomes Cromwell's head of intelligence.
July  – Barebone's Parliament, named for a prominent Puritan member, Praise-God Barebone, opens its session in London with elected representatives to pass laws for the Commonwealth of England.

August  – Jewish arrival in New Amsterdam:  Sephardic Jews arrive as refugees from Brazil and settle in New Amsterdam, forming the nucleus of what will be the second largest urban Jewish community in history, that of New York City, and of Congregation Shearith Israel, the first synagogue in North America.
October  – Ferdinand Maria, Elector of Bavaria, is crowned. His absolutist style of leadership becomes a benchmark for the rest of Germany.

July 
Peter Vowell and John Gerard are executed in London for plotting to assassinate Oliver Cromwell.
Don Pantaleon, brother of the Portuguese ambassador to England, is executed after the death of an innocent man following a fracas at the exchange in Exeter.

December  – An English Navy fleet of  warships and  transports, carrying  cannons, , seamen, and , troops, under the command of Admiral William Penn departs from Portsmouth to begin Oliver Cromwell's planned surprise attack on Spain's colonies in the New World.
December  – Jerónimo de Ataíde, Count of Atouguia, becomes Portugal's new Governor-General of Brazil, succeeding João Rodrigues de Vasconcelos e Sousa.
July  – Russo-Polish War (–): The Russian army enters the capital of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, Vilnius, which it holds for  years.

July 
The Jews in New Amsterdam petition for a separate Jewish cemetery.
The Netherlands and Brandenburg sign a military treaty.
April  – The Dutch West India Company denies Peter Stuyvesant's request to exclude Jews from New Amsterdam (Manhattan).
November  – English Lord Protector Oliver Cromwell announces measures against the Laudian party, which are enforced starting on January .
The Netherlands and Brandenburg sign a military treaty.

March  – Zurnazen Mustafa Pasha is appointed as the Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire after persuading Mehmet IV to rescind the February  selection of Gazi Hüseyin Pasha.  Zurnazen Mustafa's rule lasts only four hours and he is sent into exile the same day.

June  – The Treaty of Marienburg is signed by representatives of Sweden and of Brandenburg and Prussia to create a military alliance during the Second Northern War.  King Karl X Gustav signs for Sweden and the Elector Friedrich Wilhelm signs for Brandenburg and Prussia.

May  –  Nine days after the wreck of the Vergulde Draeck, a steersman and six crew members are dispatched to Batavia to get help.  The other  survivors remain at Ledge Point and await rescue but are not seen again.

October  – King Si Suthammaracha of Ayutthaya (now Thailand) is overthrown in a coup d'etat by his nephew and former ally, Prince Narai,  weeks after having staged a coup to seize the throne.  Narai is crowned as King Ramathibodi III.
The Stockholm Banco, the first bank to issue banknotes, is founded in Stockholm, Sweden.
January  – Miles Sindercombe and his group of disaffected Levellers are betrayed in their attempt to assassinate Oliver Cromwell by blowing up the Palace of Whitehall in London and are arrested.
October  – Treaty of Raalte: William III, Prince of Orange is no longer stadtholder of Overijssel.
October  – French troops occupy Mardyck.
The Accademia del Cimento is founded in Florence, Italy.
November  – Brandenburg and Poland sign the Treaty of Bromberg.
Portuguese traders are expelled from Ceylon by Dutch invaders.
October  – The Netherlands enters the Dano-Swedish War to come to the rescue of Denmark, sending a -ship fleet from Vlie.
November  – The Mexican Inquisition carries out the execution, by public burning, of  men convicted of homosexuality, while another  arrested are either released or given less harsh sentences.
December  – Polish and Danish forces defeat a Swedish Army in the Battle of Kolding in Denmark.

August  – Just six months after winning territory from Denmark-Norway in war and subsequent treaty, Sweden's King Charles X Gustav declares a second war against Denmark.  By August , the King's troops have surrounded Denmark's capital, Copenhagen, while the Swedish Navy blocks the harbor to prevent the city from being resupplied, and begins bombardment.
July – Christiaan Huygens's important work on astronomy, Systema Saturnium, is published.
Diego Velázquez's portrait of Infanta Maria Theresa is first exhibited.

May  – Richard Cromwell resigns as English Lord Protector, submitting "a letter that may have been dictated to him." In the letter, signed by Cromwell in front of Sir Gilbert Pickering and Lord Chief-Justice St. John, "I have perused the Resolve and Declaration, which you were pleased to deliver to me the other Night," and after listing his personal debts to be paid in return for stepping down, "As to that Part of the Resolve, whereby the Committee are to inform themselves, How far I do acquiesce in the Government of this Commonwealth, as it is declared by this Parliament; I trust, my past Carriage hitherto hath manifested my Acquiescence in the Will and Disposition of God; and that I love and value the Peace of this Commonwealth much above my own Concernments: And I desire, that by this, a Measure of my future Deportment may be taken; which, thro' the Assistance of God, shall be such as shall bear the same Witness; having, I hope, in some degree, learned rather to reverence and submit to the Hand of God, than to be unquiet under it: And, as to the late Providences that have fallen out amongst us, however, in respect of the particular Engagements that lay upon me, I could not be active in making a Change in the Government of these Nations, yet through the Goodness of God, I can freely acquiesce in it, being made; and do hold myself obliged." The executive government is replaced by the restored Council of State, dominated by Generals John Lambert, Charles Fleetwood and John Desborough. The Council of State is dismissed by the Rump Parliament on October  and replaced by the "Committee of Safety" on October .
December  – General George Monck demands free parliamentary elections in Scotland and resolves to overthrow the military government that has ruled the British Isles since .
Peter Swink, the first known non-white settler to own land in Massachusetts, and first known African to live in Springfield, Massachusetts, arrives. He holds a seat in the town meetings.
May  – The Irish Parliament declares Charles to be King of Ireland.

March  – The Long Parliament, after having been reassembled for the first time in more than  years, votes for its own dissolution and calls for new elections for what will become the Convention Parliament to make the return from republic to monarchy.
May  – John Thurloe is arrested for high treason, for his support of Oliver Cromwell's regime.
The Expulsion of the Carib indigenous people from Martinique is carried out by French occupying forces.

At daybreak, English Army Colonel George Monck, with two brigades of troops from his Scottish occupational force, fords the River Tweed at Coldstream in Scotland to cross the Anglo-Scottish border at Northumberland, with a mission of advancing toward London to end military rule of England by General John Lambert and to accomplish the English Restoration,  the return of the monarchy to England.  By the end of the day, he and his soldiers have gone  mi ( km) through knee-deep snow to Wooler while the advance guard of cavalry had covered  mi ( km) to reach Morpeth.
Gravitational interactions with Saturn result in the centaur Chiron being forced into a different orbit.
