January  – The body of Oliver Cromwell is exhumed and subjected to a posthumous execution in London, along with those of John Bradshaw and Henry Ireton.
February  – George Monck’s regiment becomes The Lord General's Regiment of Foot Guards in England (which later becomes the Coldstream Guards).

September  – Nicolas Fouquet, the Superintendent of Finances for France, is arrested in Nantes and charged with embezzlement of the state treasury.  Spared the death penalty by a jury, Fouquet spends the rest of his life in prison until his death in .

March  – General Zheng Chenggong of China, known as "Koxinga" leads an invasion of the island of Taiwan, at the time under the control of the Dutch East India Company (VOC), bringing , soldiers and sailors on hundreds of boats to claim the territory.
October  – Guru Har Krishan becomes eighth of the ten Sikh gurus, and at age  the youngest, following the death of his father Guru Har Rai.
Joan Blaeu publishes Atlas Maior, sive cosmographia Blaviana in Amsterdam (first complete edition,  volumes in Latin).

Royal assent is also given to England's new hearth tax law, with one shilling charged for each stove or fireplace in a building, to be collected on  September and on  March each year in order to provide the £,, annual household income for King Charles II. The unpopular tax is abolished in .
May  – Samuel Pepys witnesses a Punch and Judy show in London (the first on record).

April  – Three of the former members of the English Parliament who had signed the death warrant for Charles I of England in  and then fled into exile in the Netherlands after the Restoration of the Monarchy in  — Miles Corbet, John Okey and John Barkstead — are hanged after having been extradited, returned to England, and convicted of regicide. Their bodies are then drawn and quartered.

August  – The Act of Uniformity goes into effect on St Bartholomew's Day, making mandatory in the Church of England the forms of worship prescribed in the new edition of the Book of Common Prayer the deadline having been set for "every clergyman and every schoolmaster... to express, by August , his unfeigned consent to everything contained in the Book of Common Prayer. This is followed by the resignation of over , clergy who resign "for conscience sake". Those who refuse to take the required oath of conformity to the established church are subject to the Great Ejection from their jobs.

January  – The Treaty of Ghilajharighat is signed in India between representatives of the Mughal Empire and the independent Ahom Kingdom (in what is now the Assam state), with the Mughals ending their occupation of the Ahom capital of Garhgaon, in return for payment by Ahom in silver and gold for costs of the occupation, and King Sutamla of Ahom sending one of his daughters to be part of the harem of Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb.

October  – With , men under his command, Petar Zrinski, the Viceroy of Croatia within the Holy Roman Empire, defeats a much larger force of , Ottoman soldiers in the Battle at Jurjeve Stijene, near the modern town of Otočac.  The Croatians lose  soldiers killed; the Ottoman invasion force suffers over , deaths.

October  – The Farnley Wood Plot, a conspiracy in the English county of West Yorkshire to overthrow the recently-restored monarchy and to return to the military rule that had been established by the late Oliver Cromwell, fails when only  men gather at Farnley. The group is arrested and  of the rebels are later executed for treason.

September 
The Gloucester County Conspiracy, the first slave rebellion in British North America, is foiled after one of the plotters, John Birkenhead, reveals the plan of African slaves and English indentured servants to kill their masters.  Birkenhead is freed by his master as a reward for betraying the rebels.
After a siege of more than a month, the Hungarian fortress at Érsekújvár (now Nové Zámky in Slovakia) surrenders to the Ottoman Empire.  In accordance with the treaty of surrender negotiated by the Hungarian commander, Count Ádám Forgách, the European residents are allowed free passage to Austria, and the Ottoman Grand Vizier, Fazil Ahmed Pasha provides a document certifying that the fort's defenders fought bravely.
February  – English pirates led by Christopher Myngs and Edward Mansvelt carry out the sack of Campeche in Mexico, looting the town during a two week occupation that ends on February .

March  – King Charles II of England makes royal charter for territory in North America that leases to his brother, James, Duke of York, a patent for a large amount of land in what is now the northeastern United States.  According to the Charter, James receives "all that part of the mayne land of New England" between "New Scotland in America" and the river of Kenebeque", along with "Mattowacks or Long Island" and "Martins Vineyard and Nantukes", and the lands between the "Connecticutte and Hudsons rivers" and the lands "from the west side of "Connecticutte to the east side De la Warre Bay".  The lease, which includes the territory claimed by the Dutch Republic as New Netherland is for most of the U.S. state of Maine and parts of Connecticut, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

June  – In the city of Mantua in Italy, the world's oldest continuously published private newspaper, Gazzetta di Mantova, publishes its first-known issue. The newspaper would celebrate its 350th anniversary in .
December  – All but  members of the over -person crew of the Dutch ship Kennemerland are killed when the trade ship sinks in a storm near the Out Skerries islands off of the coast of Scotland.
February  – A peace treaty is signed in Turin in Italy to end the War of the Banished between the Duchy of Savoy and the Waldensians.
December  – The English warships HMS Nonsuch and HMS Phoenix are wrecked in a storm at Gibraltar.
June  – King Charles II of England issues a second charter for the Province of Carolina, which clarifies and expands the borders of the Lords Proprietors' tracts.
December  – The Royal Netherlands Marine Corps is founded by Michiel de Ruyter.
June  – Battle of Montes Claros between Spanish and a combined Anglo-Portuguese force ends with a decisive Portuguese victory.
July  – King Charles II of England leaves London with his entourage, fleeing the Great Plague. He moves his court to Salisbury, then Oxford.
May  – Great fire of Newport, Shropshire, England.
February  – The joint English and Scottish royal court returns to London as the Great Plague of London subsides.
September  – Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb grants the French East India Company a royal mandate to trade at the port of Surat.
March – The Tavernier Blue, precursor to the Hope Diamond, is first recorded, when French gem merchant Jean-Baptiste Tavernier purchases it from the Kollur Mine in the Mughal Empire in uncut form.

October  – Abbas II, the Shah of Iran, dies at the age of  after a reign of  years, without designating a successor. His -year old son Sam Mirza is crowned as the new Safavid dynasty emperor six days later.

July  – The Agreement of Legonice is signed, with Poland restoring the titles of Jerzy Sebastian Lubomirski and Lubomirski's officers, granting amnesty to all the rebels, and King Jan II Kazimierz abandoning further reform plans.
June  – Louis XIV of France conquers Tournai.
The first military campaign of Stenka Razin is conducted in Russia.
April –May  – Second Anglo-Dutch War: A Dutch flotilla under Admiral van Ghent enters the Firth of Forth in Scotland and bombards Burntisland.
Isaac Newton has investigated and written on optics, acoustics, the infinitesimal calculus, mechanism and thermodynamics. The works will be published only years later.

February  (February  O.S.) – Joasaphus II is elected by the Council of Bishops as the new Patriarch of Moscow, leader of the Russian Orthodox Church, after conservative clerics depose Patriarch Nikon for his reformation of the Church.

March  – King Charles II of England signs an agreement with representatives of the English East India Company to lease the Indian city of Bombay (modern-day Mumbai) to the company for a rent of  pounds sterling per year, with transfer taking effect on September .

June  – A group of Spanish Jesuit missionaries become the first European settlers to arrive at the island of Guam, founding a mission to convert the Chamorro people of the Mariana Islands to Christianity.
July  – The magnitude . Shandong earthquake kills at least , people in China's Shandong province.
April  – The Treaty of Breda, signed in  and ending the Second Anglo-Dutch War, goes into effect worldwide.

March  – The Bawdy House Riots of  take place in London when a group of English Dissenters begins attacking brothels, initially as a protest against the harsh enforcement of laws against private worshippers and the lack of enforcement of laws against prostitution. Over a period of three days, rioters who join in the violence destroy brothels in the London districts of Poplar,  Moorfields, East Smithfield, St Leonard's, Shoreditch, St Andrew's and Holborn.

October  – Dutch painter Rembrandt van Rijn dies at the age of , after completing his final known work Self-Portrait at the Age of .  Despite his wealth, is buried in an unmarked grave in Amsterdam's Westerkerk.  After  years, his remains are removed and destroyed in accordance with church custom.
September  – The formal coronation of Michał Korybut Wiśniowiecki as King of Poland (and Grand Duke of Lithuania) takes place in Kraków.

October  – The English ship Nonsuch returns to London with the first products acquired from trade around Canada's Hudson Bay, a cargo of fine furs.  The bounty from the Nonsuch expedition attracts investors for the soon-to-be-chartered Hudson's Bay Company.
September  – Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor grants the status and privileges of a university to the Jesuit Academy in Zagreb, the precursor to the modern University of Zagreb.

November  – In India, the Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb learns of a rebellion of Hindu residents of in various parts of the Mathurá where he had given the order for the destruction of non-Muslim temples, with rioting in Mauza' Rewarah, Chandarkah, and Surkhrú. The Emperor's historian, Saqi Mustaid Khan, records Aurangzeb's dispatch of General Hasan 'Ali Khán to attack the rebels, and  of them are "sent to perdition" while the Mughals lose "many imperial soldiers".  Another  surviving rebels are arrested.  Kokilá Ját, leader of the rebels, is among the prisoners put to death a month later.
The first French settlers arrive on the Petite Côte of modern-day Senegal.
Niani, capital of the Mali Empire, is sacked by the Bambara people of the emerging Segou Empire.
January  – The Muslim emperor Aurangzeb of the Mughal Empire in India issues an order for the destruction of all Hindu temples and schools in the empire, including the Keshvadeva Temple in Mathura.

August  – The Parliament of France enacts a uniform criminal code for the nation with the passage of the Criminal Ordinance of , which takes effect on January . The code remains in force until October , , when it is abrogated during the French Revolution.
Stenka Razin begins the rebellion of Cossacks in Russia.
Egypt—Start of the Fifteenth Dynasty.
End of Middle Kingdom in Ancient Egypt. Start of the Second intermediate period, the 15th–17th Dynasties.

July  – Awashonks, the female sachem who leads the Sakonnet Indians in what is now the U.S. state of Rhode Island, signs a peace agreement with the English leaders of the neighboring Plymouth Colony (now part of Massachusetts), along with chiefs Totatomet, Tattacommett and Somagaonet.

October  – The Republic of Venice and the Ottoman Empire sign a treaty delineating the borders between their territories in modern-day Greece, with Venice acknowledging the loss of the island of Crete in the Cretan War.

November  – In southwest Africa, troops of the Army of Portugal, under the command of Luís Lopes de Sequeira, win the Battle of Pungo Andongo, capturing the fortress capital of the Kingdom of Ndongo after nine months and deposing King Ngola Hari.  The kingdom is annexed into the Portuguese colony of Angola.
June  – The Ottoman Empire declares war on Poland.
January  – The ballet Psyché, with music composed by Jean-Baptiste Lully, premieres before the royal court of King Louis XIV at the Théâtre des Tuileries in Paris.

November  – After more than five years of administration of the Treasury of England by a five-member commission, Lord Clifford of Chudleigh, one of the commission members, becomes the Lord High Treasurer of England.

February  (February ,  O.S.) – Isaac Newton sends a paper for publication regarding his experiments on the refraction of light through glass prisms and makes the first identification of the "primary colors" of visible light on the electromagnetic spectrum, reporting that "The Original or primary colours are, Red, Yellow, Green, Blew, and a Violet-purple, together with Orange, Indico, and an indefinite variety of Intermediate gradations."
Foundation of the Chorina Comedy, the first theater in Russia.
July  – William III of Orange is appointed Stadtholder of Holland and Zeeland.
January  – The Theatre Royal, located at the time on Bridges Street in London, burns down.  A replacement structure is built on Drury Lane in .

December  – Pedro Nuño Colón de Portugal dies only five days after arriving in Mexico City to take office as the new viceroy of New Spain.  He is replaced on December  by Payo Enríquez de Rivera, the former Roman Catholic Archbishop of Mexico.
The Mitsui family's trading and banking house is founded in Japan.
Archpriest Petrovich Avvakum writes his Zhitie (Life), as the first Russian autobiography.
July  – The Netherlands and Denmark-Norway sign a defense treaty.

December  – In China, General Wu Sangui begins the Revolt of the Three Feudatories, a rebellion against the Qing dynasty by killing the Governor of the Yunnan province, Zhu Guozhi.  Within  days, he leads troops on an expedition to take over the neighboring Guizhou province and by  controls  of China's provinces.

July  – A Dutch fleet under Cornelis Tromp Captures the island of Noirmoutier on the French coast. For nearly three weeks, the Dutch occupied the French island and the Dutch fleet captured many French ships in the meantime. The whole coastline from Brest to Bayonne was in turmoil, and French forces gathered to prevent the Dutch from landing. On  July the island of Noirmoutier was however abandoned after the Dutch blew up the castle and demolished the coastal batteries.
June  – The British East India Company arranges a commercial treaty with the Maratha Empire after Henry Oxenden, the company's deputy governor, meets Emperor Shivaji for his recent coronation.

October 
The Battle of Entzheim takes place in France with , Holy Roman Empire troops and , French defenders during the Franco-Dutch War, with the forces fighting near Entzheim south of Strasbourg.  While the battle is inconclusive, the outnumbered French win a strategic victory by keeping the Germans from entering French territory. Most of the former battlefield now lies beneath the Strasbourg International Airport.
A second coronation is held by the Maratha Empire for the Chhatrapati Shivaji Bhonsle, after the Vedic priest Nischal Puri Goswami decides that the June  coronation was "held under inauspicious stars".
The first Dutch West India Company is dissolved.
May  – John III Sobieski is elected by the nobility, as King of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth (to ).

June  – Colonial authorities of Rhode Island, Plymouth, and Massachusetts attempt a negotiation with Metacomet (King Philip), leader of the Wampanoags, and seek guarantees of fidelity from the Nipmuck and Narragansett tribes.  The negotiations end after  days, closing on June .
August  – The Massachusetts Council orders that Christian Indians are to be confined to designated praying towns.
September  – The Bremen-Verden Campaign of the Northern Wars begins, with the invasion of Amt Wildeshausen by the Münster army, and their advance on Verden via the city of Bremen.

June  – The Torsåker witch trials is concluded in Sweden with the execution of  people ( of them women) executed on the same day at the village of Häxberget. The condemned prisoners are beheaded and their bodies are then burned.
August  – King Charles II of England places the foundation stone of the Royal Greenwich Observatory near London; construction begins.
September  – Pope Innocent XI succeeds Pope Clement X, as the 240th Pope of the Roman Catholic Church.
December  – Scanian War – Battle of Lund: Sweden defeats the forces of Denmark.
July  – Captain Benjamin Church and his soldiers begin sweeping Plymouth Colony, for any remaining Wampanoag tribesmen.
June  – The Indian coalition attacks Hadley, Massachusetts, but are repelled by Connecticut troops.
October  – Battle of Gegodog: Trunajaya defeats the Mataram Sultanate.
April  – Franco-Dutch War: Battle of Cassel – A French force under Philippe I, Duke of Orléans, defeats a combined Dutch-Spanish force under William of Orange in French Flanders.

December  – Father Louis Hennepin of Belgium, exploring North America, becomes the earliest known European person to discover Niagara Falls, and the first to report its existence.  In his book A New Discovery of a Vast Country in America, published in , Hennepin writes "Betwixt the lakes Ontario and Eire there is a vast prodigious Cadence of water which falls down after a surprising and astonishing manner, inasmuch that the Universe does not afford its parallel."

Robert Plot publishes The Natural History of Oxford-shire, Being an Essay Toward the Natural History of England, in which he describes the fossilised femur of a human giant, now known to be from the dinosaur Megalosaurus.
July  – Battle of Landskrona: Sweden and its , troops, under the command of King Charles XI, successfully repel a ,-man invasion force from Denmark, commanded by King Christian V.

December  – The French Navy, led by Charles de Courbon de Blénac with a land force of  men, lands at the Caribbean island of Tobago, lays siege to the Dutch fort defending the territory during the Franco-Dutch War, and destroys the structure when it fires a cannon overlooking the fort, striking the gunpowder arsenal. The explosion kills  of the defenders, including Dutch Admiral Jacob Binckes and  officers.  Combined with the sinking of four ships of the Netherlands Navy, the victory at Tobago ends Dutch military power in the Antilles.
August – – The Battle of Saint-Denis is fought after the signing of peace in the Franco-Dutch War.
August  – The Treaties of Nijmegen end the Franco-Dutch War. The County of Burgundy is ceded to the Kingdom of France.
January  – The first fire engine company in North America goes into service in Boston.

September  – Titus Oates begins to present allegations of the "Popish Plot", a supposed Roman Catholic conspiracy to assassinate king Charles II of England. Oates applies the term Tory to those who disbelieve his allegations.
April  – Ignatius Gregory Peter VI Shahbaddin is enthroned as the Patriarch of the Syriac Catholic Church in Aleppo, after receiving recognition by Ottoman Sultan Mehmed IV and by Pope Innocent XI.
March  – In England, the "Habeas Corpus Parliament" (or "First Exclusion Parliament") is opened.

October  – A sea battle is fought between England's Royal Navy and the navy of India's Maratha Empire (under the command of Mai Nayak Bhandari), with English bombardment driving the Maratha occupation of the island fortress at Khanderi (off of the western Indian coast south of Mumbai).
September  – The . Mw magnitude Sanhe-Pinggu earthquake devastates Beijing and Hebei in China.

April  – Aurangazeb, the Muslim ruler of the Mughal Empire in India, decrees the imposition of the jizya, an annual tax upon non-Muslims under Mughal jurisdiction, primarily Hindus.  The tax had been abolished by Aurangazeb's great grandfather, Akbar.
French explorer Daniel Greysolon, Sieur du Lhut, explores the Saint Louis River; the city of Duluth, Minnesota, will take its name from him.
May  – King Charles XI of Sweden marries Princess Elonora, daughter of the late King Frederick III of Denmark-Norway and sister of King Christian V.

March  – The Earl of Shaftesbury informs the Privy Council of England that the Roman Catholics of Ireland were about to launch a rebellion, backed by France.  The investigation leads to the arrest and ultimate execution of the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Armagh, Oliver Plunkett.

February  – The Marquis de Croissy, Charles Colbert, becomes France's Minister of Foreign Affairs and serves for  years until his death, when he is succeeded as Foreign Minister by his son Jean-Baptiste Colbert.

February  – The German Duchy of Saxe-Coburg is divided by treaty among the sons of the late Ernest I, Duke of Saxe-Gotha, who had died in .  The oldest son, Frederick, receives Saxe-Gotha-Altenburg.  The rest is divided among Albert (Duke of Saxe-Coburg); Bernhard (Saxe-Meiningen); Henry (Saxe-Römhild); Christian (Saxe-Eisenberg); Ernest (Saxe-Hildburghausen); and John Ernest (Saxe-Coburg-Saalfeld).

December  (December  O.S.) – The trial for treason of William Howard, 1st Viscount Stafford before his fellow members of the House of Lords having concluded after seven days, the Lords vote on whether to convict him of the articles of impeachment. The Lords vote,  to  to convict him and to impose the death sentence  and Lord Stafford is beheaded on  December ( January  N.S.)
Egypt—Start of the Sixteenth Dynasty.
Egypt—Development of leavened bread (date approximate).
April  – Following the death of its last count, the Palatinate-Landsberg passes to the King of Sweden.

January  – Prince Muhammad Akbar, son of the Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb, initiates a civil war in India.  With the support of troops from the Rajput states, Akbar declares himself the new Mughal Emperor and prepares to fight his father, but is ultimately defeated.
Collections are made in England for needy French refugees.

October  – Sir John Child of England becomes the new Governor of Bombay province and, unofficially, Governor-General of all of the settlements of the East India Company in India.  With the exception of a rebellion by Captain Richard Keigwin during the year , Child expands British control until involving the British in a war with the Mughal Empire.
August  – English perjurer Titus Oates is told to leave his state apartments in Whitehall; his fame begins to wane, and he is soon arrested and imprisoned for sedition.
October  – Sultan Mehmed IV departs Istanbul for Adrianople.
April  – René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle, exploring rivers in America, reaches the mouth of the Mississippi River.
February  – Thomas Otway's classic play Venice Preserv'd or A Plot Discover'd is given its first performance, premiering at the Duke's Theatre.
October  – The city of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania is founded by William Penn.
June  – The English trading freighter Johanna is wrecked off of the coast of South Africa with the loss of  of her  crew, becoming the first of Britain's East India Company fleet to be lost.
February  – The opera Giustino by Giovanni Legrenzi and about the life of the Byzantine Emperor Justin, premieres in Venice.

December 
Kara Mustafa Pasha, Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire since , is executed on orders of Sultan Mehmed IV after being blamed for the Ottoman loss of the Battle of Vienna on September .  The execution is carried out in Belgrade as Kara Mustafa is strangled with a silk cord.  The Sultan appoints Bayburtlu Kara Ibrahim Pasha as the new Grand Vizier.
George Ducas, the Prince of Moldavia installed by the Ottomans in , is arrested by Polish authorities while on his way back to Bucharest from the defeat by Poland in the Battle of Vienna.  Ducas is replaced by Ștefan Petriceicu.

George Ducas, the Prince of Moldavia installed by the Ottomans in , is arrested by Polish authorities while on his way back to Bucharest from the defeat by Poland in the Battle of Vienna.  Ducas is replaced by Ștefan Petriceicu.
September  – Qing Chinese admiral Shi Lang receives the formal surrender of Zheng Keshuang, ushering in the collapse of the Kingdom of Tungning, which is then incorporated into the Qing Empire.

October  – Germantown, Philadelphia is founded as the first permanent German settlement in North America (in  U.S. President Ronald Reagan declares a 300th Year Celebration, and in , it becomes an annual holiday, German-American Day).

February  – A treaty is signed between European German colonists in Brandenburg-Prussia, and the African chiefs in what is now Ghana to permit the German colonists to build a second fort on the Brandenburger Gold Coast, and the fortress of Dorotheenschanze is built.  The area is now the Ghanaian city of Akwida.
Japanese poet Ihara Saikaku composes , verses in  hours at the Sumiyoshi-taisha (shrine) at Osaka; the scribes cannot keep pace with his dictation and just count the verses.

June  – After a siege of six weeks that began on April , Luxembourg City is taken by the French Army from control by Spain, and the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, previously part of the Spanish Netherlands (now Belgium) is acquired by France.

February  (February  O.S.) – The Great Frost in Britain, during which the River Thames was frozen in London and the sea as far as  miles (. km) out from land and which started the previous December, ends as the Thames begins to thaw. William Maitland later writes that the Frost, which started in December , "congealed the river Thames to that degree that another city, as it were, was erected thereon; where by the great number of streets and shops, with their rich furniture, it represented a great fair, with a variety of carriages, and diversions of all sorts." During the freeze, there had been great loss of beast and of wildlife, especially birds, and similar reports from across Northern Europe. The Chipperfield's Circus dynasty began during the freeze, with James Chipperfield introducing performing animals to the country at the Frost Fair on the Thames in London.
March  – Pope Innocent XI forms a Holy League with the Habsburg Empire, Venice and Poland, to end Ottoman Turkish rule in Europe.

February  – Catholic James Stuart, Duke of York, becomes King James II of England and Ireland, and King James VII of Scotland, in succession to his brother Charles II (–), King of England, Scotland, and Ireland since . James II and VII reigns until deposed, in .

January  – American-born British citizen Elihu Yale, for whom Yale University in the U.S. is named, completes his term as the first leader of the Madras Presidency in India, administering the colony on behalf of the East India Company, and is succeeded by William Gyfford.
November  – Morean War: The Republic of Venice captures the fortress town of Igoumenitsa from the Ottoman Empire, and razes it to the ground.

May  – The Killing Time: Five Covenanters in Wigtown, Scotland, notably Margaret Wilson, are executed for refusing to swear an oath declaring King James of England, Scotland and Ireland as head of the church, becoming the Wigtown martyrs.
January  – Almost  people are arrested in Coventry by English authorities for gathering to hear readings of the sermons of the non-conformist Protestant minister Obadiah Grew
September  – The Ottoman fortress of Sinj in Dalmatia falls to the army of the Republic of Venice.

October  – Anglurah Agung, the virtual leader of the island of Bali as king of the paramount state of Gelgel, is killed in battle fighting Batu Lepang (who also dies in the fighting), ending the unification of the island (now part of Indonesia) and causing Bali to split into several principalities.
July  – Albany, New York, is granted a city charter by the colonial governor.

July  – An army of , Chinese troops demand Russian surrender of a Russian Empire fortress at Albazino on the Amur River.  The fortress is manned by only  Russian soldiers and militia but is armed with cannons.  Over the next several weeks, the Chinese troops are joined by another , men in supply boats, but the Russians hold off the attacks for the next five months.  By December, only  Russians remain, and Albazino is ceded to China in .

February  – Sweden's Council of State endorses the reforms proposed by King Charles XI for the Swedish Church Law , after having debated it in three sessions on February ,  and . The law confirms and describes the rights of the Lutheran Church and confirms Sweden as a Lutheran state; all non-Lutherans are banned from immigration unless they convert to Lutheranism; the Romani people are to be incorporated to the Lutheran Church; the poor care law is regulated; and all parishes are forced by law to teach the children within them to read and write, in order to learn the scripture, which closely eradicates illiteracy in Sweden.
November  – Suleiman II succeeds the deposed Mehmed IV, as Ottoman Emperor.
March  – The men under explorer Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle mutiny, while searching for the mouth of the Mississippi River.   Pierre Duhaut murders La Salle, near what is now Navasota, Texas.
May  – Emperor Higashiyama succeeds Emperor Reigen, on the throne of Japan.

February  – The Declaration of Indulgence is issued in Scotland by King James VII as one of the first steps in establishing freedom of religion in the British Isles, eliminating enforcement of criminal penalties against persons who failed to conform with Anglicanism.  As King James II of England, he issues a similar declaration on April .

October  – The legend of the Charter Oak begins as a successful attempt to hide the  Royal Charter of the British colony (and now a U.S. state) of Connecticut after Edmund Andros, the Governor of the Dominion of New England, makes a mission of attempting to confiscate the founding documents for the seven colonies that make up the new administrative area.  After Governor Andros arrives in Hartford and comes to the tavern of Zachariah Sanford to demand the Connecticut Colony charter, Captain Joseph Wadsworth spirits the parchment away from the and hides the Charter in a hollowed out portion of a white oak tree on Wyllys Hyll until Andros is recalled to London.
January  – Pirates Charles Swan and William Dampier and the crew of the privateer Cygnet become the first Englishmen to set foot on the continent of Australia.
September  – The Nine Years' War begins in Europe and America after Louis XIV attacks Philippsburg in the Holy Roman Empire.

November  (November  OS) – The Wincanton Skirmish between forces loyal to James II led by Patrick Sarsfield and a party of Dutch troops is one of the few armed clashes in England during the Glorious Revolution.
October  – The Venetians raise the siege of Negroponte.
January  – Fleeing from the Spanish Navy, French pirate Raveneau de Lussan and his  men arrive on the west coast of Nicaragua, sink their boats, and make a difficult  day march to the city of Ocotal.
Morocco wins in the Siege of Larache against Spain.
October  – Skopje fire of  occurs, lasting for two days and burning much of the city.

October  – The papal conclave in Rome unanimously elects Pietro Vito Ottoboni as the new Pope. Ottoboni takes the name Alexander VIII and succeeds Pope Innocent XI, to become the 241st pope, the first Venetian to hold the office in over  years.
December  – A great comet is visible from Pekin and sightings continue until December 24th, including many from Dutch ships near the equator.
January  – The first performance of the opera Henrico Leone composed by Agostino Steffani takes place in Hannover to inaugurate the new royal theatre in the Leineschloss.
November  – The opera Énée et Lavinie (Aeneas and Lavinia) by the French composer Pascal Collasse receives its first performance at the Académie Royale de Musique (the Paris Opera).
Serbian Patriarch Arsenije III Carnojevic leads the first of the two Great Serbian Migrations into the Habsburg Empire, following Ottoman atrocities in Kosovo.

French physicist Denis Papin, while in Leipzig and having observed the mechanical power of atmospheric pressure on his 'digester', builds a working model of a reciprocating steam engine for pumping water, the first of its kind, though not efficient.
April  – An estimated . magnitude earthquake strikes in the Caribbean Sea less than  miles ( km) from Barbuda and also affects St. Kitts and Nevis, as well as Antigua.
Giovanni Domenico Cassini observes differential rotation within Jupiter's atmosphere.
King Jie of China kills his minister Guan Longfeng according to Chinese legend.
Second Intermediate Period, in which the Hyksos invades Egypt, continues.
The Minoan and Harappan Civilizations continue to exist in Crete and Ancient India respectively.
The Exodus of the Israelites from Egypt, according to Thrasyllus of Mendes, an Egyptian mathematician and astronomer who lived in the reign of Tiberius (c. ).
Pope Innocent XII becomes the 242nd pope, succeeding Pope Alexander VIII.

The Society for the Reformation of Manners is founded in the London Borough of Tower Hamlets with the aim of suppressing profanity, immorality, and other lewd activities in general, and of brothels and prostitution in particular.
September  – War of the Grand Alliance: English and Dutch forces are defeated by the French in the Battle of Leuze.
January  – King William III of England, who rules Scotland and Ireland as well as being the Stadtholder of the Dutch Republic, departs from Margate to tend to the affairs of the Netherlands.
December  – Patrick Sarsfield and , troops of the Irish Army who had been supporters of the Jacobite Rebellion leave the country and relocate to France.

January  – English Army General John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough, a close adviser to King William III of England, is fired from all of his jobs by the English Secretary of State, the Earl of Nottingham, on orders of Mary II of England.
June  – The Salem witch trials' first victim, Bridget Bishop, is hanged for witchcraft.
September  – An earthquake in Brabant of scale . is felt across the Low Countries, Germany and England.
A total solar eclipse is visible in the South Atlantic Ocean.
The city of Ponce is founded in Puerto Rico.

April  – The Order of Saint Louis, the first medal to be awarded in France to military personnel who are not members of nobility, is created by order of King Louis XIV, and named after his ancestor, King Louis IX.
October  – The Great Storm changes the course of rivers and alters the coastline from Virginia to Long Island in America.
November  – The -gun Royal Navy frigate HMS Mordaunt founders off of the coast of Cuba.
June  – The first performance of the opera Didon by French composer Henri Desmarets takes place at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal in Paris.

December  – Diego de Vargas, Spanish colonial governor of Santa Fe de Nuevo México (now the area around the capital of the U.S. state of New Mexico), returns to the walled city of Santa Fe and requests the Pueblo people to accept the authority of the colonial government. Negotiations fail and a siege begins on December .  The Pueblo defenders surrender the next day and the  rebels are executed soon after. The  civilian women and children are made slaves and distributed to the Spanish colonists.
February  – Silvestro Valier is elected as the new Doge of Venice to replace the late Francesco Morosini
January  – French missionary Jean-Baptiste Labat arrives in the "New World", landing at the Caribbean island of Martinique.

May  – Taking advantage of a fog, the French Army, with , troops, fights the Battle of Torroella against an equally large Spanish Army force on the banks of the Ter in Spain, near the city of Girona during the Nine Years' War. The Spaniards suffer , casualties, while the French sustain .
January  – Sir James Montgomery of Scotland, who had been arrested on January  for conspiracy to restore King James to the throne, escapes and flees to France.

October  – A major windstorm begins and continues for several days, spreading the Culbin Sands over a large area of farmland in the Scottish Highlands in the County of Moray and burying the now-abandoned village of Culbin.

June  – The Commission of Enquiry into the Massacre of Glencoe in Scotland in  reports to the Parliament of England, blaming Sir John Dalrymple, Secretary of State over Scotland, and declares that a soldier should refuse to obey a "command against the law of nature".

September  – Nine Years' War: France surrenders Namur, Spanish Netherlands to forces of the Grand Alliance, led by King William III of England, Stadtholder of the Dutch Republic, following the -month Siege of Namur.
July  – The Siege of Namur begins in the Spanish Netherlands (now Belgium).

In Amsterdam, the bank Wed. Jean Deutz & Sn. floats the first sovereign bonds on the local market. The scheme is designed to fund a . million guilder loan to the Holy Roman Emperor. From this date on, European leaders commonly take advantage of the low interest rates available in the Dutch Republic, and borrow several hundred millions on the Dutch capital market.
August – – Nine Years' War: Brussels is bombarded by French troops.
March  – King William III of England departs from the Netherlands.
December  – The Inquisition in Portugal carries out the sentence of burning at the stake against several Marrano Jews in Évora.
March  – Robert Charnock, who had been arrested for the Jacobite plot to kill King William is hanged at the Tower of London.
March  – The Dutch bombard Givet during the Nine Years' War.

April – A fire destroys the Gra Bet (Left Quarter) of Gondar, the capital of Ethiopia. The fire starts "in the house of a prostitute" and destroys many buildings, including the churches of St. George, Takla Haymanot and Iyasu.
Martin Mere, England's largest lake, is drained by sir Thomas Fleetwood for farmland.
June  – The last mass execution for witchcraft in western Europe when the five Paisley witches are hanged and then burned in Scotland.
October  – Misión Loreto, the first Roman Catholic mission on Mexico's Baja California Peninsula, is founded by Spanish missionary Juan María de Salvatierra.
November  – Prince Eugene of Savoy, a field marshal within the Holy Roman Empire, purchases a large tract of land in Vienna for construction of the Belvedere Palace.

October  – The first opéra-ballet, combining elements of both mediums of entertainment, is performed as L'Europe galante makes its debut at the Salle du Palais-Royal in Paris. Composed by André Campra, with libretto by Antoine Houdar de la Motte, the opera and ballet is conducted by Marin Marais.
May  – The British Royal Navy ship HMS Hastings, a -gun fifth rate, is launched.

November – Tani Jinzan, astronomer and calendar scholar, observes a fire destroy Tosa (now Kōchi) in Japan at the same time as a Leonid meteor shower, taking it as evidence to reinforce belief in the "Theory of Areas".

A charter is granted by King William III of England to the new East India Company of England, called "the New Company" or "the English Company" to break the monopoly that has existed in India since  with the existing British East India Company.
October  – Iberville and Bienville sail from Brest to the Gulf of Mexico, to defend the southern borders of New France.
January  – The Abenaki tribe and Massachusetts colonists sign a treaty, ending the conflict in New England.

October  – The opera Marthésie, première reine des Amazones (Marthesia, First Queen of the Amazons), composed by André Cardinal Destouches, is performed for the first time, premiering at Fontainebleau near Paris.
March  – A total solar eclipse is visible across the southern Indian Ocean.
June  – England, France and the Dutch Republic agree on the terms of the Treaty of London () (Second Partition Treaty) for Spain.
February  – A group of  rebels in the Streltsy Uprising are executed in Moscow.
August  – Christian V, King of Denmark–Norway since , dies and is succeeded by his son, Frederick IV (to ).

November  – Cardinal Giovanni Francesco Albani, having been ordained as a Roman Catholic priest only two months earlier, is elected by the Papal conclave to succeed Pope Innocent XII, and becomes the 243rd pope, taking the name of Clement XI.
September – A Russian army invades Swedish Estonia, and besieges the town of Narva.
March  – The Treaty of London is signed between France, England and the Dutch Republic.

October  – The Battle of Jouami' al-Ulama takes place in Algeria with a surprise attack and ambush on the army of Murad III Bey of Tunis by two Algerian defenders, Hadj Mustapha, Dey of Algiers and Ahmed ben Ferhat, Beylik of Constantine.
Mission San Xavier del Bac is founded in New Spain near Tucson, as a Spanish Roman Catholic mission. Its location had first been scouted by the Spanish in .
– Lila-Ir-Tash starts ruling the Elamite Empire.
– The last woolly mammoth goes extinct on Wrangel Island.
– The Oxus civilization ends in today's Central Asia.
– The city of Knossos on Crete is destroyed by fire.
– Bronze Age starts in China.

December  (O.S., January ,  N.S.) – The Battle of Erastfer takes place near what becomes Erastvere in Estonia, as a large Russian force commanded by Boris Sheremetev invades Swedish Livonia and overwhelms a smaller force led by Wolmar Anton von Schlippenbach in  the first significant Russian victory in the Great Northern War.

July  – The Battle of Carpi, the first skirmish in the War of the Spanish Succession, takes place in Italy when French troops under the command of Nicolas Catinat are attacked by Austrian forces led by Prince Eugene of Savoy.
July  – A French emporium named Fort Ponchartrain is founded along the west side of the Detroit River in North America, and later becomes the site of the city of Detroit.

September  – Deposed King James II of England (James VII of Scotland) dies in exile, at the Château de Saint-Germain-en-Laye in France. His supporters, the Jacobites, turn to his son James Francis Edward Stuart (later called "The Old Pretender"), whom they recognise as James VIII and III. Louis XIV of France, the Papal States and Spain also recognise him as the rightful heir.

February  (February ,  O.S.) – The 5th Parliament of William III in England assembles. Future British Prime Minister Robert Walpole enters the House of Commons for the first time and soon makes his name as a spokesman for Whig policy.
Camisard hostilities begin in France with the assassination at le Pont-de-Montvert of a local embodiment of royal oppression, François Langlade, the Abbé of Chaila.
November  – The first performance of the opera Tancrède by André Campra takes place at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal in Paris.

March  (February  O.S.) – King William III of England is fatally injured in an accident when he is thrown from his horse, "Sorrel", when it trips on a molehill in Hampton Court Park near London. Already in poor health before the accident, he dies from complications  days later at the age of .
January  – A total solar eclipse is visible from the southern Pacific Ocean.

The travel diary Oku no Hosomichi ("Narrow road to the deep north"), a major work of haibun by the Japanese poet Matsuo Bashō and one of the major texts of Japanese literature of the Edo period, is published eight years after Bashō's death.

October  – Nine Roman Catholic residents of the French village of Sainte-Cécile-d'Andorge are massacred by a mob of more than  French Huguenot Protestants, the Camisards. A reprisal against Protestants in the nearby village of Branoux is made less than three weeks later.

October  – More than  Huguenots in the village of Branoux-les-Taillades are massacred by Roman Catholic vigilantes in reprisal for the October  attack on nearby Sainte-Cécile, slightly more than two miles away.
May  (May  OS) – The city of Saint Petersburg,  Russia is founded, following Peter the Great's reconquest of Ingria from Sweden during the Great Northern War.

March  (February  in the Chinese calendar) –  of the forty-seven rōnin of Japan carry out an order of seppuku (ritual suicide) for the killing they committed on January . The punishment is given by the shogun Tokugawa Tsunayoshi. The story continues to be dramatized more than  years later in Chūshingura theater, novels and film.
September  – War of the Spanish Succession: Habsburg Archduke Charles is proclaimed King of Spain, but never exercises full rule.
August  (July  Old Style) – War of the Spanish Succession – Gibraltar is captured from Spain, by English and Dutch forces under Sir George Rooke.

March  – War of the Spanish Succession: Prince Karl of Habsburg, brother of Joseph I, the Holy Roman Emperor and a pretender to the throne of Spain, arrives in Portugal on the English warship HMS Royal Katherine as part of George Rooke's English fleet sailing into Lisbon.
June  – Battle of Koroncó: Austrians and their allies from Denmark, Prussia, Croatia, Germany and Vojvodina defeat the Kurucs.
September  – Damat Hasan Pasha, Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire, is removed from office by Ottoman Sultan Ahmed III, and replaced by Kalaylikoz Ahmed Pasha.
August  (August  OS) – War of the Spanish Succession – The French and Anglo-Dutch fleets clash off Málaga, causing heavy casualties on both sides, but without sinking any ships.
October  –  people are killed in a colliery explosion at the Stony Flatt pit in Gateshead on Tyneside in England.

July  – Great Northern War: At the Battle of Gemauerthof, fought in modern-day Latvia, Swedish forces under the command of General Adam Ludwig Lewenhaupt overwhelm a much larger force of Russian troops commanded by Count Boris Sheremetev, killing , Russians and wounding as many as ,.

June  – The Pact of Genoa is signed by representatives of England and the Spanish Principality of Catalonia as a military alliance providing for English troops to be stationed in Catalonia as part of the War of Spanish Succession.
November  – The Dublin Gazette in Ireland publishes its first edition.
July  – The Battle of Warsaw is fought near Warsaw, Poland, in the Great Northern War.

May  – War of the Spanish Succession – Battle of Ramillies: English, Dutch, German, Swiss and Scottish troops led by John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough, defeat Franco-Bavarian forces in the Low Countries.

June  – Flemish Jesuit missionary François Noël is welcomed in China by the Kangxi Emperor at the Forbidden City in Beijing, and discusses the Emperor's disdain over the disapproval of Jesuit accommodation of Confucian rites by the Roman Catholic Church.
December  –  François Martin, the first Governor General of French India (now part of India's union territory of Puducherry), retires after seven years and is replaced by Pierre Dulivier.

October 
Augustus II, known as August der Starke (Augustus the Strong), Elector of Saxony, having ruled as King of Poland since , signs the Treaty of Altranstädt (), renouncing all claims to the throne to settle his fight with Sweden during the Great Northern War.
Iyasu I, Emperor of Ethiopia since , is assassinated on the island of Tana, on orders of his son, Tekle Haymanot I, who has ruled in Iyasu's place.  After being crowned as the new Emperor, Tekle Haymanot is stabbed to death in  on orders of Iyasu's brother, Tewoflos.
May  – A total eclipse of the Sun takes place and is visible in most of Europe, with a path crossing modern-day Spain, France, Germany, Poland and Russia
January  – John V is crowned King of Portugal and the Algarves in Lisbon.
October  – The Hōei earthquake (the most powerful in Japan until ) strikes, with an estimated local magnitude of . and kills at least , people.

The English Parliament establishes the first turnpike trusts, which place a length of road under the control of trustees, drawn from local landowners and traders. The trusts borrow capital for road maintenance against the security of tolls, and this arrangement becomes the common method of road maintenance for the next  years.

May  (May  Old Style) – The new sovereign state of Great Britain comes into being, as a result of the Acts of Union, which combine the Kingdoms of Scotland and England into a single united Kingdom of Great Britain, and merge the Parliaments of England and Scotland, to form the Parliament of Great Britain.

August  – Charles XII of Sweden launches his campaign to conquer Russia, marching to the east from Altranstädt with , coalition troops. Another , soldiers are waiting on the outskirts of Riga, guarding the Swedish supply lines.
September  (O.S.); September  (Swedish calendar); October  (N.S.) – Great Northern War: Battle of Lesnaya – Peter the Great of Russia defeats the forces of the Swedish Empire.
December  – The première of Electre by Prosper Jolyot de Crébillon takes place in Paris.
August  – A French-Native American attack in Haverhill, Massachusetts kills  settlers.
August  – In the Battle of Trenčín, , soldiers of the Imperial Army of the Habsburgs are victorious over the , Hungarian Kuruc forces of Francis II Rákóczi.
April  – Easter Sunday: The first performance of George Frideric Handel's oratorio La resurrezione takes place in Rome.
March  – Johann Friedrich Böttger reports the first production of hard-paste porcelain in Europe, at Dresden.
The first modern edition of William Shakespeare's plays is published in London, edited by Nicholas Rowe.
August  – The hot air balloon of Bartolomeu de Gusmão flies in Portugal.
April  – Mirwais Hotak takes control of Kandahar (in Afghanistan) by murdering the Persian governor, Gurgin Khan, known also as George XI.
June  – Trịnh Cương becomes the new king of northern Vietnam (Đàng Ngoài) upon the death of his grandfather,  Trịnh Căn, and begins a -year reign until his death on December ,
June  – The Tuscarora nation sends a petition to the Province of Pennsylvania, protesting the seizure of their lands and enslavement of their people, by citizens of the Province of Carolina.
August  – British Royal Navy -gun ship HMS Vanguard is relaunched from Chatham; Vanguard sank in Chatham Dockyard in the Great Storm of , but was raised in  for rebuilding.
March  – The ancient Roman Pillar of the Boatmen is found during the construction of a crypt under the nave of Notre-Dame de Paris.
August  – Total eclipse of the sun is visible at °′S °′W﻿ / ﻿.°S .°W﻿ / -.; -..

February  (Swedish calendar) February  (Julian). March  (Gregorian) – Battle of Helsingborg: Fourteen thousand Danish invaders, under Jørgen Rantzau, are decisively defeated by an equally large Swedish army, under Magnus Stenbock.
According to the middle chronology, Samsu-iluna dies and is succeeded by Abi-Eshuh.
September  – Bishop Bogusław Gosiewski sells the town of Maladzyechna in the Minsk Region of Belarus to the mighty Ogiński family.
November  – The Dutch East India Company ship Liefde runs aground and sinks off Out Skerries, Shetland, with the loss of all but one of her  crew.

September  – The Tuscarora War begins when Tuscarora natives under the command of Chief Hancock raid settlements along the south bank of the Pamlico River, within the Province of Carolina (modern-day North Carolina), killing around  people.
Rinaldo by George Frideric Handel, the first Italian opera written for the London stage, premieres at the Queen's Theatre, Haymarket.
October  – HMS Feversham is wrecked on Scaterie Island, Nova Scotia with the loss of  lives.
After many years of settlement, the Town on Queen Anne's Creek is established as a courthouse for Chowan County, North Carolina.  The town is renamed Edenton in , and incorporated in .
March  – HMS Dragon, a -gun fourth rate frigate of the British Royal Navy, is wrecked on Les Casquets rocks to the west of Alderney.
March  (February  Swedish Style, February  on the Julian calendar) – Sweden temporarily adopts the rare February , as a day to adjust the Swedish Calendar back to the Julian calendar.
August  – The British Royal Navy -gun ship HMS Rippon is launched at Deptford Dockyard.
November  – The first performance of George Frideric Handel's opera Il pastor fido takes place at the Queen's Theatre in the Haymarket, London.

October  – The Treaty of Schwedt is signed between Russia and Brandenburg-Prussia, with the latter accepting the annexation of Baltic territories and paying Russia expenses in return for the southern part of Pomerania, recently taken from Sweden in the Great Northern War.
December  – As part of the agreements made at Utrecht to end the War of the Spanish Succession, Great Britain and Spain sign a treaty of commerce and navigation.

January  – Tuscarora War: Colonel James Moore leads the Carolina militia out of Albemarle County, North Carolina, in a second offensive against the Tuscarora. Heavy snows force the troops to take refuge in Fort Reading, on the Pamlico River.
May  – The Parliament of Ireland is dissolved by Queen Anne and new elections are set.
Ars Conjectandi, a seminal work on probability by Jacob Bernoulli, is published eight years after his death, by his nephew, Niklaus Bernoulli.

June  – In France, Henri-Charles du Cambout de Coislin, the Roman Catholic Bishop of Metz, condemns the papal bull Unigenitus, issued by Pope Clement XI against the  commentary by Pasquier Quesnel of the four Gospels and inflaming the Jansenist controversy.
July  – The Imperial Russian Navy gains its first important victory against the Swedish Navy in the Battle of Gangut.
June  – Spain and the Netherlands sign a peace treaty to end hostilities between those two nations in the War of the Spanish Succession.

October  – Four Dutch investors, led by brothers Nicolaas and Hendrik van Hoorn, purchase the South American colony of Berbice from French mercenary Jacques Cassard, who had captured the colony from the Van Peere family.  A century later, in , the land is ceded to Great Britain and later merged with neighboring colonies to form what is now Guyana.
April  – Italian Jesuit missionary Niccolò Gianpriamo is dispatched from Portugal on an evangelical trip to Asia starting with the Portuguese Indian colony of Goa, where he arrives after five months.
November  – Battle of Preston: Government forces defeat the Jacobite incursion, at the conclusion of a five-day siege and action.

June  – Britain's Treason Act  takes effect, providing for forfeiture to the British Crown of property owned by any person convicted of treason in the Kingdom. The Act remains in effect until June , .
Filippo Juvarra starts rebuilding the church of San Filippo Neri, Turin, in which the roof had collapsed, during the siege of Turin, during the War of the Spanish Succession.
Coffee is first grown in the French colony of Saint-Domingue.
September  – King Louis XIV of France dies after a reign of  years, leaving his throne to his  year old great-grandson Louis XV. Philippe d'Orléans, the nephew of Louis XIV, serves as Regent.
August  – Battle of Petrovaradin: , Austrian troops of Prince Eugene of Savoy defeat , Ottoman Turks under Silahdar Damat Ali Pasha (who is killed).
Tsar Peter the Great of Russia studies with the physician Herman Boerhaave, at Leiden University.
April  – Austria, ruled by King Charles VI, renews its alliance with the Republic of Venice, leading the Ottoman Empire, ruled by Ahmed III, to declare war.
August  – Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor, returns from Italy.

June  – In India,  imprisoned members of the failed Sikh Khalsa rebellion against the Mughal Empire are executed on orders of the Emperor Farrukhsiyar. Banda Singh Bahadur, leader of the rebellion, is brutally tortured and mutilated before being killed.

March  – Benjamin Hoadly, Bishop of Bangor, brings the Bangorian Controversy within the Church of England into the open by delivering a sermon to, and supposedly at the request of, King George I of Great Britain, on The Nature of the Kingdom of Christ with the text "My kingdom is not of this world" (John :), concluding there is no Biblical justification for church government.

November  – Pirates led by Edward "Blackbeard" Teach and Benjamin Hornigold capture the French slave transport Concorde near island of Saint Vincent the West Indies. Blackbeard renames the vessel Queen Anne's Revenge, adds to its armaments, and makes it his flagship.  Hornigold soon accepts a British amnesty for all pirates, and Blackbeard teams up with Stede Bonnet and begins plundering ships approaching North American ports.

September  – King George I of Great Britain issues the "Proclamation for Suppressing of Pirates in the West Indies", an offer of amnesty to pirates, declaring that any pirates who surrender themselves to the government of Britain or one of its overseas territories, on or before September , , "shall have Our Gracious Pardon of and for his or their Piracy or Piracies" committed before January , .  The amnesty is later extended to July , .

June  – The Premier Grand Lodge of England, the Modern and first Free-Masonic Grand Lodge (which merges with the Ancient Grand Lodge of England in  to form the United Grand Lodge of England), is founded in London.
The Charleville musket enters service in France.

May  – Sailing the Queen Anne's Revenge English pirate Edward Teach ("Blackbeard") leads  sailors in four ships, and blockades the port of Charleston, South Carolina for an entire week, plundering all arriving ships.  After their departure, Queen Anne's Revenge and Adventure are both lost at Beaufort Inlet, North Carolina; a week later.  Blackbeard allows Stede Bonnet to command the Revenge (which is renamed the Royal James) once again. Bonnet rescues  sailors abandoned by Blackbeard on a sandbar and continues his life of piracy.
June  – The Treaty of Baden  is signed, ending the Toggenburg War.
August  – Battle of Cape Passaro: a Spanish fleet is defeated by the British Royal Navy under Admiral George Byng, off Capo Passero, Sicily, a prelude to the War of the Quadruple Alliance.
November  – Lightning strikes the powder magazine at the Old Fortress, Corfu, causing an explosion that kills a large number of people on the island.
December  – Following the death of Charles XII on November , his sister Ulrika Eleonora proclaims herself Queen regnant of Sweden, as the news of her brother's death reaches Stockholm.
October  – Sweden and Denmark-Norway sign an armistice, halting combat in the Great Northern War between them, with final terms agreed to in the Treaty of Frederiksborg on July , .
September  – The three-story tall Opernhaus am Zwinger, one of the largest opera houses in the world at the time, opens in Dresden by staging Antonio Lotti's Giovi in Argo.
January  – The Principality of Liechtenstein is created, within the Holy Roman Empire.
May  – An earthquake in Turkey damages İzmit and Istanbul, damaging some city walls and ruining mosques and palaces.

January  – Carolean Death March begins: A catastrophic retreat by a largely-Finnish Swedish-Carolean army under the command of Carl Gustaf Armfeldt across the Tydalen mountains in a blizzard kills around , men and cripples a further  for life.
The Town on Queen Anne's Creek, North Carolina is renamed Edenton, in honor of North Carolina Governor Charles Eden; it is incorporated in .
February  – The Treaty of The Hague is signed between Spain, Britain, France, Austria and the Dutch Republic, ending the War of the Quadruple Alliance with effect from May .
January  – Sweden and Prussia sign the Treaty of Stockholm (Great Northern War).
Il teatro alla moda, a satirical pamphlet by Benedetto Marcello, is published anonymously in Venice.
June  – British silversmiths are once again allowed to use sterling silver after  years of being limited to a higher quality (but softer) Britannia silver.
–Adasi, a native king of Assyria, seizes power.
–The Hyksos invade and conquer Egypt, establishing their capital at Avaris.
August  – The Sack of Shamakhi occurs, in the Persian Safavid Empire.
May  – Pope Innocent XIII succeeds Pope Clement XI, as the 244th pope.

June  – Dr. Zabdiel Boylston of the Harvard University School of Medicine begins the first public inoculation campaign in order to slow the smallpox epidemic in Boston, giving a vaccine to his own son, and then to his slave and the slave's infant son.

April  – The deadliest outbreak of smallpox in the history of Boston begins when the British ship HMS Sea Horse arrives in Boston Harbor with a crew of sailors who had survived a smallpox epidemic.  One of the Seahorse crew who had cleared quarantine develops symptoms the next day and infects other people in a lodging house.  Over the next  months, , cases of smallpox are recorded in Boston and  people die of the disease.
April  – Robert Walpole becomes the first Prime Minister of Great Britain (although this is more a term of disparagement at this time).

October  – The six-month-long Siege of Isfahan ends, when the Safavid capital Isfahan capitulates to the Afghan rebels. Safavid Sultan Husayn abdicates, and acknowledges Mahmud Hotak as the new Shah of Persia.

February  – Nasir-ud-Din Muḥammad Shah, the Grand Mogul of north India's Mughal empire, names Nizam-ul-Mulk as his Grand Vizier. Three years later, the Nizam will rebel against the Grand Mogul and create his own independent nation as the Nizam of Hyderabad, reigning as Asaf Jah.

Edenton is incorporated as the county seat of Chowan County, North Carolina. The governor and assembly of North Carolina move to Edenton, making it the de facto capital of North Carolina until , when the government is moved to New Bern.
July  – Father Rale's War (–) begins along the Maine and Massachusetts border.

September  – Wälättä Giyorgis, a -year-old who nursed Ethiopia's Emperor Bakaffa back to health after he fell ill, marries the Emperor and begins her rise to power as the Empress Mentewab. Upon Bakaffa's death in , Mentewab becomes the regent for her son by Bakaffa, Iyasu II.

April  – In Switzerland, the attempt by Major Abraham Davel to make the canton of Vaud independent of the Swiss government, is put down, one day after he and  men had taken control of the Vaudois capital, Lausanne.  Davel is arrested, tortured and tried for treason; he is beheaded on April .
July  – Christian von Wolff holds a lecture for students and the magistrates at the end of his term as a rector, as a result of which he is banned from Prussia, on a charge of atheism.

May  – Johann Sebastian Bach assumed the office of Thomaskantor in Leipzig, presenting his first new cantata, Die Elenden sollen essen, BWV , in the St. Nicholas Church on the first Sunday after Trinity.

October  – Russia's Emperor Peter the Great authorizes an incentive for men of Serbia to join a new Russian Imperial Army unit, the Serbian Hussar Regiment. The Emperor sends Jovan Albanez to recruit new officers and troops with a grant of farmable land in Russia, and , take advantage of the offer over the next two years.
December  – Bach leads the first performance of Darzu ist erschienen der Sohn Gottes, BWV , his first Christmas Cantata composed for Leipzig.
The Kaitokudō academy merchant school, part predecessor of Osaka University is founded in Japan.
April  – Johann Sebastian Bach leads the first performance of his cantata Du Hirte Israel, höre, BWV , illustrating the topic of the Good Shepherd in pastoral music.

December 
In the aftermath of an attack against Jesuit Catholics led by the Lutheran mayor of the Prussian city of Thorn (modern-day Toruń, Poland), ten Lutheran officials (including mayor Johann Gottfried Rösner) are executed in the town square. Rösner and seven others are decapitated by an axe, while two others are hanged, drawn and quartered for blasphemy.
By order of the Nizam, Hyderabad is made the permanent capital of the Indian princely state of the same name. It becomes capital of the Indian states of Telangana and Andhra Pradesh
September  – José de Grimaldo, who had been Prime Minister for Spain's King Philip V until the latter's abdication in January, resumes office with the return of King Philip.
October  – Muhammad bin Nasir is elected as the new Imam of Oman after the overthrow of his brother, Saif bin Sultan II.
Freemasonry is established in France, as an English import.

December  – Johan Willem Ripperda of the Netherlands, the former Dutch Ambassador to Spain, arrives in Madrid and claims that King Philip V has appointed him as the new Prime Minister. The bluff is successful and he is granted authority by the King's advisers, but after four months, he is forced to resign.
October  – Joan Paul Schaghen is appointed by the Dutch East India Company to serve as the Governor of Ceylon after the death of Johannes Hertenberg.

January  – James Macrae, a former captain of a freighter for the British East India Company, is hired by the Company to administer the Madras Presidency (at this time, the "Presidency of Fort St. George"), and begins major reforms. The area administered is most of Southern India, including what is now the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh, parts the states of Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Karnataka, Telangana, Odisha and the union territory of Lakshadweep.

October  – Russia dispatches , troops and  civilians to Russia's border with China, on a mission to survey the boundaries in order to make a treaty with the Chinese Empire.  Serbian adventurer Sava Vladislavich leads a group of cartographers to prepare maps in advance of traveling on to Beijing.
Late  – Nader Shah recaptures Mashhad.

March  – France's first ambassador to Russia, Jacques de Campredon, leaves after four years of trying to negotiate a Franco-Russian alliance with Catherine I and a failed attempt to arrange a marriage between King Louis XV and Catherine's daughter Elizabeth.

March  – China's Yongzheng Emperor issues a special edict instructing his "Vice Minister of Punishments" Huang Bing to interrogate Qin Daoran, who provides the evidence that Yongzheng's brothers Yintang, Yin-ssu and Yin-ti, had conspired to overthrow the Emperor.

September  – An explosion kills all but seven of the  passengers and crew on the Portuguese Navy galleon HMFMS Santa Rosa as its cargo of gunpowder blows up.  Historians speculate that of the  people on the ship, those who weren't killed by the explosion drowned or were killed by sharks as the ship went down off of the coast of Recife.
February  – The Parliament of Negrete (between Mapuche and Spanish authorities in Chile) brings an end to the Mapuche uprising of –.
Lt. Col. Francisco de Mello Palheta smuggles coffee seeds to Brazil in a bouquet, starting a coffee empire.
November  –  The Netherlands signs the Treaty of Seville.
June  – Spain ceases hostilities after its attempt to recapture Gibraltar from Britain fails.  A truce is signed the next day.
April  – Johann Sebastian Bach's St Matthew Passion (BWV 244b) premieres at St. Thomas Church, Leipzig.
December  – The London Evening Post, a conservative newspaper, publishes its first issue.  It continues in regular publication for  years.
July  – The First Kamchatka Expedition, led by Vitus Bering and his crew sail northward on the ship Archangel Gabriel from the Kamchatka Peninsula, through the Bering Strait, and round Cape Dezhnev.

November  – In India, the Maratha Empire's army invades the Mughal Empire's Malwa province, crossing the Narmada River.  On November , the two armies clash at the Battle of Amjhira; the Maratha troops, commanded by General Chimaji Appa, overcome the defenders of Malwa (now part of India's Andhra Pradesh state) and Malwa's Governor Girdhar Bahadur is killed.
May  – Pope Gregory VII (Hildebrand of Sovana), who served as pontiff from  to , is canonized as a Roman Catholic saint.

September  – John Deane, a colonial administrator of Britain's British East India Company, returns to Calcutta (Kolkata) after an absence of more than two years, and takes office at Fort William to return to administering the Bengal Presidency, an area now covering the Indian state of West Bengal and the nation of Bangladesh.

June  – The Congress of Soissons opens at the French town of Soissons to negotiate a treaty between Great Britain and Spain.    The treaty, which is concluded on November , , recognizes the Spanish royal family's rule of parts of Italy, and Britain's possession of Gibraltar and Menorca.

December  – Under the pretense of a peace offering, the Yazoo and Koroa warriors enter the French settlement at Fort St. Pierre (near modern-day Vicksburg, Mississippi) and kill most of the inhabitants.
August  – The Comet of , possibly the largest comet based on the absolute magnitude, on record, is discovered by Fr. Nicolas Sarrabat, a professor of mathematics at Marseille.

May  – Six English pirates, including Mary Critchett, seize control of the sloop John and Elizabeth while being transported to America to complete their criminal sentences. They overpower their captors but are later captured in Chesapeake Bay by HMS Shoreham and hanged in August.
July  – Baltimore, Maryland is founded.

January  – Frederick, the eldest son of King George II of Great Britain is made Prince of Wales at the age of , a few months after he comes to Britain for the first time after growing up in Hanover. For  years, Frederick is heir apparent to the British throne, but dies of a lung injury in .
March  – John Glas is deposed from the Church of Scotland; the Glasite sect forms around him.
July  –  Valparaíso earthquake: An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of . strikes Valparaíso, in modern-day Chile but at this time in the Viceroyalty of Peru.

June  – French explorer Alphonse de Pontevez, commanding the frigate Le Lys, claims an Indian Ocean atoll for France and names it after himself as the Alphonse Atoll. The next day, he claims and names the St. François Atoll.

March  – The  papal conclave to elect a new Pope for the Roman Catholic church begins with  Cardinals,  days after the death of Pope Benedict XIII. By the time his successor is elected on July , there are  Cardinals.
April  – Congregation Shearith Israel, the first synagogue in New York City, is dedicated.
According to the ultra-long chronology of the ancient Near East, this is the year the sack of Babylon occurred.

August  – The oldest known sports score in history is recorded in the description of a cricket match at Richmond Green in England, when the team of Thomas Chambers of Middlesex defeats the Duke of Richmond's team by  to .

Patrona Halil, an ethnic Albanian and a janissary who instigated a mass uprising in  within the Ottoman Empire that brought Mahmud I to power as the new Sultan, is strangled to death in Mahmud's presence after the rebellion is suppressed.
March  – The Treaty of Vienna is signed between the Holy Roman Empire, Great Britain, the Dutch Republic and Spain.
December  – Jacques Grimaldi, the husband of the reigning monarch of Monaco, Louise Hippolyte, succeeds to the throne after Louise's death from smallpox. Jacques I rules until his own death in .

Royal Colony of North Carolina Governor George Burrington asks the North Carolina General Assembly to pass an act establishing a town on the Cape Fear River, in what is seen as a political move to shift the power away from the powerful Cape Fear plantation class. The town is laid out in , and incorporated as Wilmington in .
March  – MPs John Birch and Denis Bond are expelled from the House of Commons of Great Britain after using their positions on the Commission for Forfeited Lands to make fraudulent sales.
Herman Boerhaave publishes the authorized edition of his Elementa chemiae, recognised as the first text on chemistry.
February  – Henry Fielding's comedy The Modern Husband premieres at the Royal Theatre on Drury Lane in London.
May  – Dirck van Cloon becomes the new Governor-General of the Dutch East Indies (now Indonesia).
December  – The original Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, London (the modern-day Royal Opera House) is opened.
January  – George Frideric Handel's classic opera, Orlando is performed for the first time, making its debut at the King's Theatre in London.

After British Prime Minister Robert Walpole's proposed excise tax bill results in rioting over the imposition of additional taxes and the use of government agents to collect them, Walpole informs the House of Commons that he will withdraw the legislation.
October  – The election of Augustus III, to succeed his father as King of Poland, sparks the War of the Polish Succession.
July  – The first Freemasons lodge, the Grand Lodge of Massachusetts, opens in what will become the United States of America.

June  – At Schloss Salzdahlum, Prince Frederick of Prussia, the -year-old heir to the throne reluctantly marries Duchess Elisabeth Christine of Brunswick-Bevern in order to avoid prosecution for desertion from the Prussian Army and to be guaranteed the throne.  Despite the unhappy marriage Frederick and Elisabeth later reign as King and Queen Consort of Prussia.
April  – Easter occurs on the latest possible date (the next time is in ).
March  – Salzburgers arrive at the mouth of the Savannah River in the British Colony of Georgia.

June  – In Montreal, New France, a black slave known by the French name of Marie-Joseph Angélique is tortured then hanged by the French authorities for allegedly setting a fire that destroyed part of the city.
June  – War of the Polish Succession: Russian troops take Gdańsk (German: Danzig), which had been besieged since February , after the failure of a French expedition to relieve the city.
Anton Wilhelm Amo becomes the first African to receive a doctorate in Europe and begins teaching at the University of Halle.
January  – Alexander Pope's poem Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot is published in London.
The King's Highway (Charleston to Boston) is completed.
Quebec: Construction begins on the Chemin du roy between Quebec and Montreal.
September  – Sir Robert Walpole, the prime minister of Great Britain, becomes the first British premier to move into London's  Downing Street.
June  – Lê Thuần Tông, Emperor of Đại Việt since , dies at the age of  and is succeeded by Lê Ý Tông.
June  – A French Academy of Sciences expedition, led by Pierre Louis Maupertuis, with Anders Celsius, begins work on measuring a meridian arc in Meänmaa, Finland.
German adventurer Theodor Stephan Freiherr von Neuhoff is crowned King Theodore of Corsica,  days after his arrival on Corsica on March . His reign ends on November  when he flees the island.
March  – Bellevue Hospital is founded in New York.
December  – Andrew Michael Ramsay gives an oration, in which he relates the heritage and internationalism of Freemasonry to that of the Crusades.
January  – The Civil Code of  is passed in Sweden.

April 
In Afghanistan, Persian shah Nader Shah begins the -month Siege of Kandahar against the Pashtun Emir of Afghanistan, Hussain Hotak. The surviving Afghanis surrender on March , .
Lots are first advertised for sale in the new town of Richmond, Virginia, by the placement of a notice by William Byrd in the Virginia Gazette.  According to the paper, "... on the North Side of James River, near the Uppermost Landing, and a little below the Falls, is lately laid off by Major Mayo, a Town, called Richmond, with Streets  Feet wide, in a pleasant and healthy Situation, and well supply'd with Springs of good Water. It lies near the Publick Warehouse at Shoccoe's, and in the midst of great Quantities of Grain, and all kind of Provisions. The Lots will be granted in Fee Simple, on Condition only of building a House in Three Years Time, of  by  Feet, fronting within  Feet of the Street. The Lots to be rated according to the Convenience of their Situation, and to be sold after this April General Court, by me, William Byrd."
July  – The direct male line of the Medici family becomes extinct, with the death of Gian Gastone de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany.

August  – The Portuguese frigate Nossa Senhora da Boa Viagem arrives at Maldonado (now in Uruguay) as Captain Duarte Pereira brings the news that the Spanish–Portuguese War ended by an agreement signed on March .
Benjamin Franklin creates the Philadelphia Police Force – the first city-paid force.
March  – The Battle of Delhi takes place between the Maratha Empire and the Mughals.
May  – The military phase of Cresap's War between the British North American Provinces of Maryland and Pennsylvania is ended when King George II of Great Britain negotiates a cease-fire.

Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach, having completed a law degree, is hired as a court musician by Crown Prince Frederick of Prussia, the future Frederick the Great (Bach will remain in Frederick's service until ).
January  – After the Maratha Empire of India wins the Battle of Bhopal over the Jaipur State, Jaipur cedes the Malwa territory to the Maratha in a treaty signed at Doraha.

January  – At least  African slaves drown when the Dutch West Indies Company slave ship Leusden capsizes and sinks in the Maroni River during its arrival in Surinam. The Dutch crew escapes, and leaves the slaves locked below decks to die.
April  – Serse, an Italian opera by George Frideric Handel, premieres in London.
June  – (June  Old Style); The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences is founded in Stockholm, Sweden.
July  – The British East India Company signs a treaty with the Maratha Empire to gain the right of free trade within the territory.
February  – Battle of Karnal: The army of Iranian ruler Nader Shah defeats the forces of the Mughal emperor of India, Muhammad Shah.
September  – The Stono Rebellion, a slave rebellion, erupts near Charleston, South Carolina.
March  – Nader Shah occupies Delhi, India and sacks the city, stealing the jewels of the Peacock Throne, including the Koh-i-Noor.
October – – Batavia Massacre: Troops of the Dutch East India Company massacre at least , Chinese Indonesians in Batavia.
July  – Pogrom: Jews are expelled from Little Russia.
August  – The song Rule, Britannia! is first performed at Cliveden, the country home of Frederick, Prince of Wales, in England.
December  – Frederick II of Prussia invades the Habsburg possession of Silesia, starting the War of the Austrian Succession.
June  – War of Jenkins' Ear: Siege of Fort Mose – A Spanish column of  regular troops, free Black militia and Indian auxiliaries storms Britain's strategically crucial position of Fort Mose, Florida.
Samsu-iluna succeeds Hammurabi as king of Babylon. However, his rule is not very effective, and Mesopotamia endures turmoil during his reign.
–Akkadian-Assyrian governor Puzur-Sin drives the Babylonians and Amorites into the north, out of the land of Assyria.
June  – Maria Theresa of Austria is crowned Queen Regnant of Hungary in Bratislava.
March  – War of the Austrian Succession: Prussian troops bring down the Austrian fortress of Glogau (modern-day Głogów in Poland).
July  – Jonathan Edwards repeats his Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God sermon at Enfield, Connecticut.
April  – War of the Austrian Succession: An Austrian army is defeated by Prussian troops of Frederick the Great in the Battle of Mollwitz.
December  – Anders Celsius develops his own thermometer scale, Centigrade, the predecessor of the Celsius scale.
February  – John Carteret, 2nd Lord Carteret becomes Secretary of State for the Northern Department in Great Britain.

March  – Acting in his capacity of Grand Duke of Lithuania, Poland's King Stanisław August Poniatowski issues a proclamation allowing Jews in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius to live anywhere except for two public streets, the Pilies street and the Galves Street.
June  – Christian Goldbach first describes Goldbach's conjecture ("Every even number is the sum of two primes") in a letter to fellow mathematician Leonhard Euler.
