Accompanied by  French Army observers, Choctaw Indians from the French Louisiana territory cross the Tombigbee River and raid Chickasaw Indian towns in Georgia. Over three days, the attackers lose  men, the Chickasaw defenders about .  For permitting the attack, the French Louisiana governor, the Sieur de Bienville, is summoned back to Paris.
Molde, Norway, becomes a city.
April  – The trustees of the English Province of Georgia vote to inaugurate public schools in the corporate territory.
April  – The Verendrye brothers make the first contact since  between Europeans and the Sioux Indians, whom they refer to as Les Gens de la Fleche Collee ("the people of the sheathed arrow").
April  – The British East India Company ship Princess Louisa is wrecked off the coast of Maio Island in the Cape Verde Islands, killing  of her  crew.
March  – A British expeditionary fleet under Sir Charles Knowles is defeated by the Spanish in the Battle of La Guaira.
The Verendryes, and two members of the Mandan Indian tribe, reach the foot of the mountains, near the site of what is now Helena, Montana.
May  – The Union of Germany is proclaimed in Frankfurt Frederick II of Prussia, as articles of union are signed between Prussia, Hesse-Kassel and the Rhineland Palatinate.
Spanish explorers Antonio de Ulloa and Jorge Juan y Santacilla complete their mission of exploration and depart from the Peruvian seaport of Callao for a return to Spain.

The Massachusetts General Court, colonial legislature for the Massachusetts Bay Province, approves an incentive for the killing of enemy Indians, authorizing the payment of  Massachusetts pounds for the scalping of a Mi'kmaq or Maliseet Indian, and  for the scalps of women or children.
April  – Siege of Villafranca (): A joint French and Spanish force defeats Britain and Sardinia.
June  – Alexey Bestuzhev-Ryumin is named as the new Chancellor of the Russian Empire by the Empress Elizabeth.
September  – Madame de Pompadour is officially presented at the court of Louis XV.
March  – Augustus III, the King of Poland and Elector of Saxony, declares his candidacy to become the next Holy Roman Emperor, but loses in September to Francis, Duke of Tuscany.

September  – Francis I, the Grand Duke of Tuscany, is elected Holy Roman Emperor by the nine prince-electors of the Empire (from Bavaria, Bohemia, Brandenburg, Cologne, Hanover, Mainz, the Palatinate, Saxony and Trier) with the support of his wife, Maria Theresa. He is the successor of Charles VII Albert of Bavaria, an enemy of the House of Habsburg, who died on January  of this year.
December  – For  days, fire destroys buildings in Istanbul.
December  – Two days after Prussian troops rout the Saxons at the Battle of Kesselsdorf, the Saxon capital of Dresden falls to Prussia's King Frederick the Great.

December  – Rallied by a teenage boy, Giovanni Battista Perasso (nicknamed Balilla"), the citizens of the Republic of Genoa rise up against the Austrian occupying troops and the collaborator Military Governor, the Genoese Marquis of Botta d'Adorno. By December , the Austrian soldiers are driven from the Italian city-state, but return a few months later.
March  – Zakariya Khan Bahadur, the Mughal Empire's viceroy administering Lahore (in what is now Pakistan), orders the massacre of the city's Sikh people.
October  – The College of New Jersey is founded in Princetown, New Jersey. In , it is renamed Princeton University.
January  – The Young Pretender Charles Edward Stuart occupies Stirling, Scotland.
June  – Battle of Piacenza: Austrian forces defeat French and Spanish troops.
January  –  The first venereal diseases clinic opens at London Lock Hospital.

April  – The Scottish Jacobite Lord Lovat is beheaded at Tower Hill, London, for high treason. He was the last person in Britain to be beheaded, although beheading would not be formally abolished until more than  years later.
August  – Great Britain, Russia and the Dutch Republic sign the Convention of Saint Petersburg ().
December  – Benjamin Franklin forms the Pennsylvania Associators, the first militia in the colony of Pennsylvania, which had no standing militia because of its foundation by pacifistic Quakers.
November – – The Knowles Riot breaks out in Boston, Massachusetts, protesting impressment into the British Royal Navy, .
The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences makes Eva Ekeblad its first female member.
March  – In battle near Manupur ( kilometres (. mi) northwest of Sirhind), Mughal forces under Prince Ahmad Shah Bahadur are victorious against Ahmad Shah Durrani.

May  – As word arrives that the Dutch Republic has agreed to return control of Maastricht to France, the French Army's leader of the siege, Count Löwendal, marches through the opened city gates with his troops and accepts its surrender.
November  – The Electorate of Hanover (now occupied by most of the northwestern German state of Niedersachsen or Lower Saxony) issues a decree banishing all adherents of the Moravian Church.
Leonhard Euler publishes Introductio in analysin infinitorum, an introduction to pure analytical mathematics, in Berlin.

December  – Father Junípero Serra begins his missionary work in the New World,  days after departing on a voyage from Spain and a day after his arrival at Veracruz in Mexico.  During the period from  to , Serra will be the founder of nine missions in the Province of Las Californias, including the sites around which future California cities will be built, including Mission Basilica San Diego de Alcalá in  and Mission San Francisco de Asís in .

August  – At a ceremony in San Antonio, Texas (then a part of the New Spain province of Nuevo Santander), four Apache chiefs and Spanish colonial officials and missionaries literally "bury the hatchet", placing weapons of war into a pit and covering it as a symbol that the Apaches and the Spaniards will fight no further war against each other.

September  – Grand Chief Jean-Baptiste Cope, of the Miꞌkmaq Indian nation in Canada, declares war against the British Empire after the building of the fort at Halifax, Nova Scotia and begins hostilities by taking  British hostages at Canso.

November  – In response to the increasing number of starving people moving into Paris from rural parts of France, King Louis XV issues an ordinance that "all the beggars and vagabonds who shall be found either in the streets of Paris, or in churches or church doorways, or in the countryside around Paris, of whatever age or sex, shall be arrested and conducted into prisons, to stay there as long as shall be necessary."

October  – At Falmouth, a part of the British Province of Massachusetts Bay that would later be the site of Portland, Maine, a peace treaty is signed between representatives of Massachusetts Bay and  sagamores and tribal chiefs of the Wabanaki Confederacy (encompassing the Penobscot, Kennebec, Odanak and Wôlinak tribes of the Abenaki Indians), temporarily settling territorial disputes in Maine during King George's War.

December  – Two physicians in Jamaica, Dr. John Williams and Dr. Parker Bennet, fight a duel "with swords and pistols" after having had an argument the day before about the treatment of bilious fever.  Both are mortally wounded during the fight.
December  – Prussia and Russia break off diplomatic relations after the Russians refuse to stop assisting the Electorate of Saxony.  Five years later, the two Empires fight the Seven Years' War.
July  – Halifax, Nova Scotia is almost completely destroyed by fire.

April 
A group of enslaved West African, bound for the Americas, successfully overpowers the crew of the British slaver ship Snow Ann, imprisons the survivors, and then navigates the vessel back to Cape Lopez in Gabon.  Upon regaining their freedom, the rebels leave the survivors on the Gabonese coast.
The Viceroy of New Spain, Juan Francisco de Güemes, issues a notice to the missionaries in Nuevo Santander (which includes parts of what are now the U.S. state of Texas, including San Antonio, and the Mexican state of Tamaulipas) to work peacefully to convert the indigenous Karankawa people to Roman Catholicism.

May  – Two weeks after police in Paris arrest six teenagers for gambling in the suburb of Saint-Laurent, rioting breaks out when a rumor spreads that plainclothes policemen are hauling off small children between the ages of five and ten years old, in order to provide blood to an ailing aristocrat.  Over the next two weeks, rioting breaks out in other sections of Paris.  Police are attacked, including one who is beaten to death by the mob, until order is restored and police reforms are announced.
: The complaint tablet to Ea-nāṣir is written.
The eruption of Mount Veniaminof, located on the Alaska Peninsula.
Hammurabi dies and is succeeded by his son, Samsu-iluna, who is already involved in Babylonian government.
Old Assyrian Empire disestablished

May  – The Pennsylvania Hospital, first hospital in the American colonies, is chartered in Philadelphia by the Pennsylvania legislature, which grants the right to Benjamin Franklin and to Dr. Thomas Bond.

December  – Battle of Arnee in India (Second Carnatic War): A British East India Company–led force under Robert Clive defeats and routs a much larger Franco-Indian army, under the command of Raza Sahib, at Arni.
June  – The first volume of Denis Diderot's Encyclopédie, ou dictionnaire raisonné des sciences, des arts et des métiers, often referred to as le Encyclopédie, is published
Ferdinando Galiani publishes the first modern economic analysis, Della Moneta.
October  – The Hōreki period begins in Japan.

April  – Adam Smith, appointed the year before as a professor of logic, is unanimously elected by the faculty of the University of Glasgow to be the new Professor of Moral Philosophy "on the express condition that he would content himself with the emoluments of the Logic Professorship until  October", in that the - salary budgeted for the job has already been distributed to faculty members who had substituted for the previous moral philosophy professor, Thomas Craigie; from April to October, Smith's remuneration for teaching moral philosophy is limited to fees paid directly to him by his students (a half guinea per semester for the public class, and a guinea per semester for the private class). Smith's lectures on ethics are first published in  in his work The Theory of Moral Sentiments.

March  – Shō Kei, the ruler of Okinawa Island and the Ryukyu Kingdom, dies at the age of  after a reign that began when he was  years old. He is succeeded by his -year-old son, Shō Boku, who reigns for  years.

June  – The Treaty of Logstown is signed by representatives of the Iroquois Confederation, Lenape and Shawnee leaders, and commissioners from Virginia, headed by Joshua Fry. Christopher Gist and William Trent represent the Ohio Company. The treaty grants control over lands south and east of the Ohio River to the English, along with permission to build a fort on the site of what is now Pittsburgh.

October  — In his Philadelphia newspaper, the Pennsylvania Gazette, Benjamin Franklin first describes the performance in Philadelphia of the kite experiment that he had proposed in his  book. Although the original account makes no claim that he was the first to do the experiment (which had been done by other scientists (including Thomas-François Dalibard in May), nor that he conducted the test, and it does not give a date for the experiment, it becomes embellished as the story that Franklin "discovered electricity"; in , the story first circulates that Franklin flew the kite in June , without specifying a date (as Franklin had done in other scientific accounts).
July  – The first of the Kronstadt canals, conceived by Peter the Great and designed to link two of the harbors of the Russian city, is completed and opened to maritime traffic.

August  – Russian scientist Georg Richmann becomes the first person to be electrocuted by his own equipment after he uses an insulated, but improperly grounded, lightning rod in an attempt to gather data on a thunderstorm. Richmann also becomes the first victim of ball lightning during his scientific experiment, in an attempt to replicate the experiments of American Benjamin Franklin.

August  – The Unity of Brethren, a branch of the Moravian Church, receives a grant the Wachovia Tract, , acres (. km) of land (approximately  square miles), in western North Carolina, for the benefit of German-speaking immigrants to America.  The area now includes Winston-Salem, North Carolina.
May  – The Jewish Naturalisation Act  passes the House of Commons  and later receives royal assent from King George II.

November  – Spain's King Fernando VI issues a set of  regulations and restrictions for theatrical performances, including a requirement that the directors of the acting troupes "take the greatest care that the necessary modesty is preserved" and that the actors should be reminded that chastity requires that "indecent and provocative" dances should be avoided.
James Lind writes A Treatise of the Scurvy.
March  – The Clandestine Marriages Act  comes into force in England and Wales, placing marriage in that jurisdiction on a statutory basis for the first time.
May  – The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews is founded in Scotland.

November  – Denmark establishes the Renteskirverkontor, an office within the Chamber of Finance, to oversee the colonial affairs of the Danish West Indies (Dansk Vestindien).  Peder Mariager, who had been a minor official of the Danish West Indies Company, becomes the first administrator.  The colony, consisting of the islands of Saint Thomas, Saint John and Saint Croix later is purchased by the United States from Denmark and is now the U.S. Virgin Islands.

May  – French and Indian War: Battle of Jumonville Glen – The war begins when George Washington, , leads a company of militia from the Colony of Virginia, in an ambush on a force of  French Canadians.

July  – Classes begin at Columbia University, founded on October  as King's College by royal charter of King George II of Great Britain.  The college is originally located in Lower Manhattan in the Province of New York. Instruction is suspended in , and the school reopens in  as Columbia College. With the college's growth in the , it is renamed Columbia University in .

September  – The Russian Academy of Sciences awards its prize for "the best explanation of the true causes of electricity including their theory" to Switzerland's Johann Euler for his paper Disquisitio de causa physica electricitatis.
February  – Treaty of Giyanti: The kingdom of Mataram on Java is divided in two, creating the sultanate of Yogyakarta and the sunanate of Surakarta.

September  – Sir Charles Hanbury-Williams, the new British Minister to Russia, secures an alliance signed by Empress Catherine the Great. The Russian Empire agrees to provide up to , troops to defend the Electorate of Hanover against invasion by Prussia. At the time, King George II of Great Britain is also the ruler of the German duchy; the Russian troops are provided in return for an annual payment of £,.
The brine shrimp Artemia salina is first described, in Linnaeus' Systema Naturæ.

September  – Two slaves, Mark and Phyllis, are publicly executed for the poisoning murder of their master, John Codman in front of a large crowd outside the Middlesex County Courthouse in Cambridge, Massachusetts.  Phyllis is burned to death. Mark's execution by hanging is made as an example to other African slaves in the Province of Massachusetts Bay. His body is transported to Charlestown Common in what is now Somerville and displayed on a gibbet for more than  years. In , Paul Revere mentions in his memoir that his famous ride of April , , started when he first spotted British Army officers at a site "nearly opposite where Mark was hung in chains", I saw two men on Horse back, under a Tree".
The first chocolate-candy factory begins operations in Germany.
August  – Seven Years' War: French and Indian War – Fort Oswego falls to the French.

February  – The massacre of the Guaraní rebels in the Jesuit reduction of Caaibaté takes place in Brazil after their leader, Noicola Neenguiru, defies an ultimatum to surrender by : in the afternoon. On February , Neenguiru's predecessor Sepé Tiaraju has been killed in a brief skirmish.  As two o'clock arrives, a combined force of Spanish and Portuguese troops makes an assault on the first of the Seven Towns established as Jesuit missions.  Defending their town with cannons made out of bamboo, the Guaraní suffer , dead, compared to three Spaniards and two Portuguese killed in battle.

September  – Abu l-Hasan Ali I, Bey of Tunis is forcibly removed after  years as the ruler of the North African emirate by his cousins, who are avenging the overthrow and execution of their father, Husayn in . Hasan Ali surrenders to the rebels and is imprisoned in Algiers, then executed on September  on orders of the new Bey of Tunis, Muhammad I ar-Rashid.
October  – An "Agreement of Friendship and Trade" is signed by Sultan Osman III and King Frederick V. Denmark appoints an extraordinary representative to the Ottoman Empire.
October  – News of the massacre of Muslim pilgrims first reaches Damascus; the Ottoman officials who had been in charge of protecting the pilgrimage are executed by beheading.
Nam tiến, the southward expansion of the territory of Vietnam into the Indochina Peninsula, is concluded.
February  – French artist Robert Picault begins the rescue of the frescoes at the King's Chamber of the Palace of Fontainebleau before architect Ange-Jacques Gabrel begins renovations.
December  – Seven Years' War: Battle of Leuthen – Frederick defeats Prince Charles's Austrian army, in what is generally considered the Prussian king's greatest tactical victory.

April 
The works of astronomer Galileo Galilei espousing heliocentrism are removed (with the approval of Pope Benedict XIV) from the Index Librorum Prohibitorum list of books banned by Roman Catholic Church, along with "all books teaching the earth's motion and the sun's immobility". Other works of heliocentrists Galileo, Nicolaus Copernicus, Johannes Kepler, Diego de Zúñiga and Paolo Foscarini remain on the list.
In the wake of public unrest in France, the King's Council issues a decree that bars anyone from writing, printing anything that would tend toward émouvoir les esprits (stir up popular sentiment) against the government, with violations punishable by death.
August  – Seven Years' War – Battle of Negapatam: Off the coast of India, Admiral Pocock again engages d'Aché's French fleet, this time with more success.

June  – Seven Years' War – Battle of Domstadtl: Austrian forces under Ernst Gideon von Laudon and Joseph von Siskovits rout an enormous convoy with supplies for the Prussian army, guarded by strong troops of Hans Joachim von Zieten.

Marquis Gabriel de Lernay, a French officer captured during the Seven Years' War, establishes a military lodge in Berlin, with the help of Baron de Printzen, master of The Three Globes Lodge at Berlin, and Philipp Samuel Rosa, a disgraced former pastor.

February  – A fleet of  British Royal Navy warships, under the command of Admiral Edward Boscawen, departs from Plymouth toward North America in an effort to conquer the French Canadian territories of New France.  Many of the sailors die of nutritional deficiencies along the way, including the scurvy that kills  of the crew of HMS Pembroke, captained by future world explorer James Cook on his first long voyage.
May  – Seven Years' War – French and Indian War: Mary Campbell is abducted from her home in Pennsylvania by members of the Lenape Nation.
January  – Távora affair: The Távora family is executed, following accusations of the attempted regicide of Joseph I of Portugal.
May  – Josiah Wedgwood founds the Wedgwood pottery in England.
Voltaire's satire Candide is published simultaneously in five countries.
October  – A fire destroys the Macedonian city of Salonika, reducing , houses to ashes.
January  – In Philadelphia, the first American life insurance company is incorporated.
April  – France's Marshal François Gaston de Lévis departs from Montreal up the St. Lawrence River with , troops on a plan to retake Quebec City from the British.
March  – The Great Fire of Boston, Massachusetts, destroys  buildings and marks the biggest conflagration in the American colonies up to this time.
April  – The Burmese Army, under the command of King Alaungpaya, reaches the outskirts of Siam's capital, Ayutthaya, but then retreats rather than laying siege to the city.
April  – Representatives of the remaining Penobscot Indian tribes in Maine and New Brunswick make peace with the British at Fort Pownal in Newfoundland.
July  – A lightning strike causes a major fire at Portsmouth Royal Dockyard in England.
The Shang dynasty in China conquers the Xia dynasty.
February  – An earthquake in London breaks chimneys in Limehouse and Poplar.
November  – A separate peace treaty is signed between the Cherokee Indians and the Colony of Virginia, bringing the Anglo-Cherokee War to a close.

November  – The Earl of Egremont, serving as Secretary of State for the Southern Department, initiated a policy which forbids the issuing of any land grants to white settlers in territory occupied by the American Indian tribes.
October  – Austrian field marshal Ernst Gideon von Laudon captures the Prussian town of Schweidnitz (now Świdnica in Poland) during the Seven Years' War.
December  – Seven Years' War: After four months of siege, the Russians under Pyotr Rumyantsev take the Prussian fortress of Kolberg.

Philosopher Jean-Jacques Rousseau's The Social Contract (Du Contrat social, ou Principes du droit politique) and Emile, or On Education (Émile, ou De l’éducation) are published in Amsterdam and The Hague respectively. In Rousseau's native Republic of Geneva they are publicly burned and prohibited in Paris.

September 
French and Indian War: Battle of Signal Hill – British troops defeat the French in the last battle of the North American theatre of the Seven Years' War, fought in the Newfoundland Colony.
Empress Go-Sakuramachi succeeds to the throne of Japan upon the death of her brother, the Emperor Momozono. She reigns for eight years before abdicating on January , . She was the last empress regnant of Japan up to this day.
May  – Marco Foscarini becomes the new Doge of the Republic of Venice after the death of Francesco Loredan, who had administered the Republic for  years.
March  – A Royal Navy fleet with , men departs Britain from Spithead and sets sail toward Cuba in order to seize strategic Spanish Empire possessions in the Americas.
June  – Battle of Wilhelmsthal: The Anglo-Hanoverian army of Ferdinand of Brunswick defeats the French forces in Westphalia. The British commander Lord Granby distinguishes himself.
September  – Catherine II of Russia endorses Ivan Betskoy's plans for a Foundling Home in Moscow.

February  – The colonial authorities in the Province of North Carolina establish Mecklenburg County from the western portion of Anson County. The county is named for Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz, who married George III in .
August  – Pontiac's War: Battle of Bushy Run – British forces led by Henry Bouquet defeat Chief Pontiac's Indians at Bushy Run, in the Pennsylvania backcountry.

April  – Marie-Josephte Corriveau is hanged near her home at Saint-Vallier, Quebec before being gibbeted after being found guilty by a military tribunal of twelve officers of murdering her husband.  She becomes famous in French Canadian folklore as "la Corriveau".
March  – Charles Townshend becomes President of the Board of Trade in the British government.
Cesare Beccaria - On Crimes and Punishments (Dei delitti e delle pene), a founding work of penology

March  – After the British victory in the French and Indian War, the first post-war British expedition to explore the newly acquired territories east of the Mississippi River comes under attack by Tunica warriors.  The  British Army men, under the command of Major Arthur Loftus, were at a spot south of Natchez, Mississippi and were forced to flee in their boats back toward the port of New Orleans while under fire from an unknown number of Tunicas firing from both banks.

July  – The Niagara Conference begins at the invitation of Sir William Johnson, the British Superintendent of Indian Affairs for the northern district, who hosts "one of the largest conventions of red men ever held on the continent" to negotiate the end of the hostilities from the French and Indian War.  Reportedly, , representatives of the North American tribes meet at upstate New York coming from distances ranging "From Dakota to Hudson's Bay, and from Maine to Kentucky."
Horace Walpole - The Castle of Otranto "a story, translated by William Marshal, Gent., from the original Italian of Onuphrio Muralto", the first Gothic novel
November  – Mary Campbell, a captive of the Lenape during the French and Indian War, is turned over to forces commanded by Colonel Henry Bouquet.
December  – The Pennsylvania Gazette reports that Dr. Huston, the recently instated Distributor of Stamps for the Royal Colony of North Carolina, has resigned his post in protest at the Stamp Act.
August  – Joseph II becomes Holy Roman Emperor.

January  – One week before his death, Mir Jafar, who had been enthroned as the Nawab of Bengal and ruler of the Bengali people with the support and protection of the British East India Company, abdicates in favor of his -year-old son, Najmuddin Ali Khan.
In Lisbon, the auto-da-fé parade (often an excuse for violence against Jews or Christian 'heretics') is abolished.
Catherine the Great establishes the first secondary education school for non-noble females in Russia: the Novodevichii Institute, for the daughters of commoners.

January  – Burmese–Siamese War: Outside of the walls of the Thailand capital of Ayutthaya, tens of thousands of invaders from Burma (under the command of General Ne Myo Thihapate and General Maha Nawatra) are confronted by Thai defenders led by General Phya Taksin. The defenders are overwhelmed and the survivors take refuge inside Ayutthaya. The siege continues for  months before the Burmese attackers collapse the walls by digging tunnels and setting fire to debris. The city falls on April , , and King Ekkathat is killed.
February – Ferocious wolf attacks occur in France, such as the Beast of Gévaudan or Wolves of Périgord.

November  – A British sloop-of-war is searching all vessels passing near Cape Lookout, North Carolina, and some vessels have been seized, according to an observer in New York City, in the Province of New York, reporting to the Pennsylvania Gazette.
December  – Mapuches in Chile launch a series of surprise attacks against the Spanish starting the Mapuche uprising of .

February  – The Pennsylvania Gazette reports that a British sloop off Wilmington, North Carolina, has seized a sloop sailing from Philadelphia, and another sailing from Saint Christopher, on the charge of carrying official documents without stamps. In response, local residents threaten to burn a Royal Man-of-War attempting to deliver stamps to Wilmington, forcing the ship to return to the mouth of the Cape Fear River.

May  – Ahmed al-Ghazzal, the emissary from Sultan Mohammed ben Abdallah of Morocco to the Spanish Empire, makes a triumphant return to Marrakesh with almost  Muslims who had been held captive in Spain, as well as sacred Islamic manuscripts that had been seized by the Spanish in .  The negotiation of the release had started with al-Ghazzal's meeting with Spain's King Carlos III on August , .

December  – Oconostota and Attakullakulla arrive at Johnstown, New York where they, along with leaders of the Six Nations of the Iroquois Confederacy (the Mohawk, Onondaga, Oneida, Cayuga, Seneca and Tuscarora tribal nations) meet with Sir William Johnson to begin peace negotiations with the British Empire.

October  – A boycott, of  types of goods  imported from England, is resolved by Boston merchants meeting at Faneuil Hall as a response to the taxes imposed by Great Britain, and one of the first "Buy American" campaigns is started in order to encourage the purchase of items manufactured and produced in the  colonies.  Copies of the agreement, to be signed by participating merchants, are circulated beyond the Province of Massachusetts Bay to other colonial provinces in New England.

January  – The first annual volume of The Nautical Almanac and Astronomical Ephemeris, produced by British Astronomer Royal Nevil Maskelyne at the Royal Observatory, Greenwich, gives navigators the means to find longitude at sea, using tables of lunar distance.
February  – King Carlos III of Spain issues a decree expelling the Jesuits from the dominions of the Spanish Empire worldwide.
December  – King Prithvi Narayan Shah unifies several small kingdoms to establish  modern-day Nepal; this kingdom will collapse in .

Mohammed bin Khalifa Al Khalifa, the founder of the Al Khalifa dynasty, constructed Qal'at Murair in the town of Zubarah in present-day Qatar. The fortress served to consolidate his control over Zubarah and neighboring tribes.

April  – The New York Chamber of Commerce, first of its kind in the American colonies, is founded by  New York merchants at Bolton and Sigel's Tavern at  Pearl Street in New York City. Former New York City mayor John Cruger Jr. is elected the Chamber's first president.
September  – Louis XV appoints René de Maupeou as Grand Chancellor of France (an office he will hold until ), and orders him to crush the judicial opposition.
August  – The palace of the Ottoman Grand Vizier is destroyed by a fire in Constantinople
May  – Charles III of Spain sends Spanish missionaries, who found California missions in San Diego, Santa Barbara, San Francisco and Monterey, and begin the settlement of California.

March  – Louis Antoine de Bougainville returns to Saint-Malo, following a three-year circumnavigation of the world with the ships Boudeuse and Étoile, with the loss of only seven out of  men; among the members of the expedition is Jeanne Baré, the first woman known to have circumnavigated the globe.  She returns to France some time after Bougainville and his ships.

August  – Brescia Explosion: The city of Brescia, Italy is devastated when the Church of San Nazaro is struck by lightning. The resulting fire ignites , lb (, kg) of gunpowder being stored there, causing a massive explosion, which destroys / of the city and kills , people.
September – – David Garrick holds a Shakespeare Jubilee festival at Stratford-upon-Avon in England.
May  – Cardinal Giovanni Vincenzo Antonio Ganganelli is elected as the 249th pope, succeeding the late Clement XIII and choosing to take the regnal name of Pope Clement XIV.
February  – Scottish explorer James Bruce arrives at Gondar, capital of Abyssinia (modern-day Ethiopia) and is received by the Emperor Tekle Haymanot II and Ras Mikael Sehul.
January  – The foundation of Fort George, Bombay is laid by Colonel Keating, principal engineer, on the site of the former Dongri Fort.
July  – Lexell's Comet (D/ L1) passes the Earth at a distance of ,, kilometres (,, mi), the closest approach by a comet in recorded history.
December  – King Louis XV of France issues the "Edict of December", dismissing the rebellious magistrates of the Parlements of Paris and the other  provinces.
October  – Phillis Wheatley becomes the first African American woman to have her work published, after having written a poetic elegy to the late Reverend George Whitefield.
Babylon becomes the largest city in the world, taking the lead from Thebes, Egypt.
Investiture of Zimri-Lim, a painting of Zimri-Lim receiving the ring and staff from the goddess Ishtar, is made at the Royal Palace of Mari, Court , from around  to . It is now at the Louvre, Paris.

December  – Men, women and children of the Choctaw and Chickasaw tribes begin a -day encampment at Mobile, part of the British colony of West Florida, at the invitation of British Southern Indian superintendent John Stuart, as their leaders negotiate a treaty.
January  – The Great Kalmyk (Torghut) Migration is led by Ubashi Khan, from the east bank of the Lower Volga River back to the homeland of Dzungaria, at this time under Qing dynasty rule.
May  – Battle of Lanckorona: A force of , Russians under Alexander Suvorov defeat a Polish formation of , men.

May  – War of the Regulation – Battle of Alamance: Regulators reject an appeal by Governor Tryon to disperse peacefully. Governor Tryon's forces crush the rebellion, causing many Regulators to move to frontier areas outside of North Carolina.
March  – The Smeatonian Society of Civil Engineers first meets in London, the world's oldest engineering society.

June  – The crisis of  is triggered when, following the flight of their partner Alexander Fordyce to France, the London banking house of Neal, James, Fordyce and Down (which has been speculating in East India Company stock) suspends payment. The resultant panic causes other banks to fail, extends to Scotland, Amsterdam and the Thirteen Colonies and threatens the East India Company with bankruptcy.
Frederick II, Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin, demands that all bodies remain unburied for three days to ensure that death has actually taken place.

Second voyage of James Cook: The crew of HMS Resolution finds that the ice floes encountered on their journey south are a source of fresh water, a "discovery... of utmost importance to the success of the voyage."
March  – Biela's Comet is first discovered by French astronomer Jacques Leibax Montaigne, but not proven to be a periodic comet until , when Wilhelm von Biela correctly identifies its return.
November  – American Revolutionary War: Samuel Adams and Joseph Warren form the first Committee of Correspondence.

October  – The Komisja Edukacji Narodowej (Polish for Commission for the Education of the People), formed in the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, is considered to be the world's first ministry of education.

June  – The Regulating Act is given royal assent by King George III, creating the office of Governor General, with an advising council, to exercise political authority over the territory under British East India Company rule in India.
February  – The construction of Christ Church (Alexandria, Virginia), known for being the house of worship for George Washington and the visiting site for subsequent U.S. presidents, is completed.
August  – Second voyage of James Cook in the Tuamotus: Captain Cook discovers Tekokota, which he names Doubtful Island.

October  – French astronomer Charles Messier discovers the Whirlpool Galaxy, an interacting, grand design spiral galaxy located at a distance of approximately  million light-years, in the constellation Canes Venatici.
November  – English chemist Joseph Priestley becomes the first person to discover and identify sulfur dioxide.
September  – George Mason and George Washington found the Fairfax County Militia Association, a military unit independent of British control.

February  – The Privy Council of Great Britain, as advisors to King George III, votes for the King's abolition of free land grants of North American lands.  Henceforward, land is to be sold at auction to the highest bidder.

December  – The two month long Siege of Melilla begins as armies led by the Sultan of Morocco, Mohammed ben Abdallah, attack the North African Spanish colony of Melilla (which remains a part of Spain into the ).

February  –  The Province of Massachusetts Bay House of Representatives votes,  to , to impeach Superior Court Chief Justice Peter Oliver, but Provincial Governor Thomas Hutchinson refuses to allow the trial to proceed.
March  – Catherine the Great of Russia issues a manifesto prohibiting freed serfs from being returned to serfdom.
April  – American Revolution – Battles of Lexington and Concord: Hostility between Britain and its American colonies explodes into bloodshed, igniting the American Revolutionary War.
January  – Siamese conquest of Chiang Mai and the Lan Na Kingdom.
August  – American Revolution: Refusing to even look at the Olive Branch Petition, King George issues a Proclamation of Rebellion against the American colonies.

June 
Coronation of Louis XVI takes place in Reims. The last coronation of the Ancien Regime before the French Revolution
American Revolutionary War – Battle of Machias: In the first naval engagement of the American Revolution, Patriot forces capture the schooner HMS Margaretta.
June  – A fire destroys major parts of the town of Askersund, Sweden.
March – Restrictions on the cereal trade in Sweden are lifted.
American Revolutionary War – Battle of Fort Washington: Hessian forces under Lieutenant General Wilhelm von Knyphausen capture Fort Washington (Manhattan) from the American Continental Army.

November 
American Revolutionary War – Battle of Fort Washington: Hessian forces under Lieutenant General Wilhelm von Knyphausen capture Fort Washington (Manhattan) from the American Continental Army.
The captain of the American navy ship Andrew Doria fires a salute to the Dutch flag on Fort Oranje, and Johannes de Graaff answers with  gun shots.
October  – American Revolutionary War – Battle of White Plains: British forces arrive at White Plains, attack and capture Chatterton Hill from the Americans.
George II Frederic is crowned as king of the Miskito Kingdom.
April  – Friedrich Maximilian Klinger's play Sturm und Drang is premiered by the Seyler Theatre Company in Leipzig, giving its name to the whole Sturm und Drang movement in German literature.
June  – Encyclopædia Britannica Second Edition begins publication in Edinburgh.
October  – American Revolutionary War – Battle of Saratoga: British General John Burgoyne surrenders to the American troops.
June  – The Stars and Stripes is adopted by the Continental Congress as the flag of the United States.
August  – The La Scala Opera House opens in Milan, with the première of Antonio Salieri's Europa riconosciuta.
July  – American Revolutionary War: George Rogers Clark takes Kaskaskia.
September  – The Treaty of Fort Pitt is signed, the first formal treaty between the United States and a Native American tribe (the Lenape or Delaware).

February  – In the United States:
South Carolina becomes the first state to ratify the Articles of Confederation.
General John Cadwalader shoots and seriously wounds Major General Thomas Conway in a duel after a dispute between the two officers over Conway's continued criticism of General George Washington's leadership of the Continental Army.
August  – American Revolutionary War: The tactically inconclusive Battle of Rhode Island takes place, after which the Continental Army abandons its position on Aquidneck Island.
February  – Captain James Cook is killed on the Sandwich Islands, on his third voyage.
November  – The North Carolina General Assembly carves a new county from Dobbs County, North Carolina and names it Wayne County, in honor of United States General Anthony Wayne.
June  – American Revolutionary War – In support of France, Spain declares war on Britain.

July  – American Revolutionary War – American forces, led by Commodore Dudley Saltonstall, launch the Penobscot Expedition in what is now Castine, Maine, resulting in the worst naval defeat in U.S. history, until surpassed by the attack on Pearl Harbor in .

May  – War of the Bavarian Succession – Russian and French mediators at the Congress of Teschen negotiate an end to the war. In the agreement Austria receives a part of the Bavarian territory (the Innviertel), and relinquishes the rest.
May  – The Cumberland Compact is signed by American settlers, in the Cumberland Valley of Tennessee.
Jose Gabriel Kunturkanki, businessman and landowner, proclaims himself Inca Túpac Amaru II.
April  – American Revolutionary War: The Spanish commander of the Fortress of the Immaculate Conception on the San Juan River in modern-day Nicaragua surrenders it to the British San Juan Expedition.
May  – The first Epsom Derby horse race is run on Epsom Downs, Surrey, England. The victor is Diomed.
June  – American Revolutionary War – Battle of Springfield: The Continental Army defeats the British in New Jersey.
In Egypt, the Twelfth Dynasty ends, and the Thirteenth and Fourteenth Dynasties begin.
The Amorite civilization conquers Uruk and Isin.
The last known population of woolly mammoths on Wrangel Island died out, possibly due to a combination of climate change and hunting.
Charles Messier publishes the final catalog of Messier objects.
March  – The United States Continental Congress implements the Articles of Confederation, forming its Perpetual Union as the United States in Congress Assembled.
The Bank of North America is chartered by the Continental Congress.
May  – A Spanish army sent from Lima puts down the Inca rebellions, and captures and savagely executes Túpac Amaru II.
September  – American Revolution – Battle of the Chesapeake: A British fleet under Thomas Graves arrives and fights de Grasse, but is unable to break through to relieve the Siege of Yorktown.
February  – The Spanish defeat British forces and capture Menorca.
Saint Petersburg, Russia has , inhabitants.

January  – The Laird of Johnstone (George Ludovic Houston) invites people to buy marked plots of land which, when built upon, form the planned town of Johnstone, Scotland, to provide employment for his thread and cotton mills.
January  – Superintendent of Finance Robert Morris goes before the United States Congress to recommend establishment of a national mint and decimal coinage.
August  – A combined British and Native American force defeat Kentucky militiamen in the Battle of Blue Licks in the last major battle of the American Revolutionary War.
December  – At Fraunces Tavern in New York City, U.S. General George Washington formally bids his officers farewell.
April – – Second Anglo-Mysore War: Siege of Bednore – Tipu Sultan of Mysore with , troops besieges  British East India Company troops who are obliged to surrender with honours of war.
Loyalists from New York settle Great Abaco in the Bahamas.
July  – Grants of land in Canada to American Loyalists are announced.

March  – Newburgh Conspiracy: A potential uprising in the Continental Army stationed at Newburgh, New York, is defused, when George Washington asks the officers to support the supremacy of the United States Congress.
July  – The Bank of New York opens as the first in New York state and continues to operate under that name for almost  years until being acquired by Mellon Financial and becoming BNY Mellon.
Madame du Coudray, pioneer of modern midwifery, retires.
Great Tenmei famine in Edo period Japan continues, as , die of starvation.
December – Immanuel Kant's essay "Answering the Question: What Is Enlightenment?" is published.
April  – The Congress of the Confederation passes the Ordinance of Governance to set guidelines for adding to the original  states in the United States of America.
Thomas Jefferson is appointed the new U.S. Minister to France, and Benjamin Franklin's request for permission to return home is accepted.
July  – Don Diego de Gardoqui arrives in New York City as Spain's first minister to the United States.

March 
American engineer James Rumsey sends a letter to George Washington informing of his plans to create a steamboat.
Thomas Jefferson is appointed the new U.S. Minister to France, and Benjamin Franklin's request for permission to return home is accepted.
Friedrich Heinrich Jacobi publishes Letters on the Teachings of Spinoza, and starts the Pantheism controversy.
The British government establishes a permanent land force in the Eastern Caribbean, based in Barbados.
September–December – Goethe undertakes his Italian Journey (published in ).
October  – General David Cobb of the Massachusetts militia defeats a body of rebel insurgents at Taunton, Massachusetts in one of the battles of Shays' Rebellion.
October  – HMS Bellerophon begins service with the Royal Navy.

September – - The Annapolis Convention is held by delegates from six of the  states (Maryland, Virginia, Pennsylvania, Delaware, New Jersey and New York) resulting in the scheduling of the Philadelphia Convention to draft a national constitution.
Winter / – English captain George Dixon becomes the first European to visit the Hawaiian island of Molokaʻi.
July  – The United States ratifies its first treaty with the Sultanate of Morocco.
The North Carolina General Assembly incorporates Waynesborough, and designates it the seat for Wayne County, North Carolina. The town becomes extinct after .
February  – A charter is granted, establishing the institution which will become the University of Pittsburgh.
December  – James Rumsey demonstrates his water-jet propelled boat on the Potomac River.

March  – In the British House of Commons, Henry Beaufoy files the first motion to repeal the Test Act , which restricts the rights of non-members of the Church of England.; Beaufoy's motion is rejected, and the Act is not repealed until .
April  – Maryland ratifies the United States Constitution, and becomes the seventh U.S. state.
July  – A hailstorm sweeps across France and the Dutch Republic, with hailstones 'as big as quart bottles' that take 'three days to melt'; immense damage is done.
February  – Isaac Briggs and William Longstreet patent a steamboat.
September  – The United States Congress of the Confederation passes an act providing a timeline for the voting for the first President under the new U.S. Constitution.
August  – King Louis XVI agrees to convene the Estates-General meeting in May , the first time since .
November  – Pope Pius VI creates the first diocese in the United States at Baltimore, and appoints John Carroll the first Roman Catholic bishop in the United States.
November  – North Carolina ratifies the United States Constitution, and becomes the 12th U.S. state.
June – The Inconfidência Mineira is the first attempt at Brazilian independence from Portugal.
Peggy of Castletown, Isle of Man, the world's oldest surviving private yacht, is built.
The Theatre War officially ends in Scandinavia.

January  – U.S. Secretary of the Treasury Alexander Hamilton submits his proposed plan for payment of American debts, starting with $,, to pay the foreign debts of the confederation, followed by $ million for domestic debts, and $. million for the war debts of the states. The plan is narrowly approved - in the Senate, and - in the House.
October  – At least , people die in Algeria when an earthquake and tsunami strikes the city of Oran. The city is destroyed and Spanish forces eventually flee in .
March  – The first United States Census is authorized; it is held later in the year.
December  – The Aztec calendar stone is discovered at El Zócalo, Mexico City.

January 
The first boat specialized as a rescue lifeboat is tested on the River Tyne in England.
Olowalu Massacre: American Captain Simon Metcalfe opens fire with cannon towards villagers in canoes, killing about one hundred Hawaiians, and wounding many others.

September 
An ordinance is written barring the game of baseball within  yards of the Meeting House in Pittsfield, Massachusetts, the first known reference to the game of baseball in North America.
Declaration of the Rights of Woman and of the Female Citizen is written by activist Olympe de Gouges in response to the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen.
September  – The first serious secondary education school open to girls in Denmark, the Døtreskolen af , is founded in Copenhagen.
August  – John Fitch is granted a patent for the steamboat in the United States.
August  – The Brandenburg Gate in Berlin (Prussia) is finished.
August  – George Hammond is appointed as Great Britain's first minister to the United States.
Claude Chappe successfully demonstrates the first semaphore line, between Paris and Lille.
March  – A settlement is formed in Sierra Leone in West Africa as a home for freed slaves.
January  – The Treaty of Jassy ends the Russian Empire's war with the Ottoman Empire over Crimea.
September  – Chickamauga Cherokee launch an attack on Middle Tennessee to exterminate the White settlers; they are stopped at the opening battle at Buchanan's Station outside Nashboro.
April  – United States President George Washington vetoes a bill designed to apportion representatives among U.S. states. This is the first time the presidential veto is used in the United States.
May  – French expedition to Sardinia: The last French troops occupying the small Sardinian island of San Pietro surrender to a Spanish fleet.

October  – French Revolution: Marie Antoinette, the widowed queen consort of Louis XVI, is guillotined in the Place de la Révolution in Paris at the conclusion of a -day trial before the Revolutionary Tribunal.
August –November  – The yellow fever epidemic of  hits Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; , die.
October  – French Revolution:The French Republican Calendar is adopted by the National Convention.
September  – The cornerstone to the future United States Capitol is dedicated by U.S. President Washington at the site of the new Federal City on the Potomac River.
June–July – Mount Vesuvius erupts in Italy; the town of Torre del Greco is destroyed.

May –June  – The Glorious First of June (Battle of Ushant): The British win a crushing tactical victory over the French fleet, but the merchant convoy escorted by the French fleet arrives safely in France.
April –May  – Battle of Boulou: The French defeat the Spanish and Portuguese forces.

March  – General Antoni Madaliński, a commander of the National Cavalry in the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, disobeys an order from the ruling Russian Empire and Kingdom of Prussia imposing demobilization, advancing his troops from Ostrołęka to Kraków.
January  – King George III of Great Britain delivers the speech opening Parliament and recommends a continuation of Britain's war with France.
September  – The Alliance of St Petersburg is formed between Britain, Russia and Austria against France.
September  – French Revolutionary Wars – Invasion of the Cape Colony: British forces capture Cape Town in the Dutch Cape Colony, to use its strategic facilities against the French Navy.
June – – The Copenhagen Fire of , starting in a naval warehouse, destroys  houses.
September  – Battle of the Diamond: Protestant forces defeat Catholic troops in Loughgall, Ireland, leading to the foundation of the Orange Order.
December  – Construction of Yonge Street, formerly recognized as the longest street in the world, begins in York, Upper Canada (modern-day Toronto).
April  – War of the First Coalition – Battle of Montenotte: Napoleon Bonaparte gains his first victory as an army commander.
July  – The United States takes possession of Detroit from Great Britain, under the terms of the Jay Treaty.
October – Jane Austen begins writing her first draft of Pride and Prejudice, under the title First Impressions (the book will not be published until ).

November 
Battle of Caldiero: French forces are defeated by the Austrians at Caldiero, and pushed back to Verona. This marks Napoleon's first defeat, losing nearly , men and  guns.
Groton, New Hampshire is incorporated as a town.
June – – Ragunda lake in Sweden bursts and drains completely leaving the Döda fallet dry.
March  – Protestant missionaries from the London Missionary Society land in Tahiti, from the Duff (celebrated as Missionary Day in French Polynesia).
March  – Médée, an opera by Luigi Cherubini, is premiered in Paris.

The secret Lautaro Lodge as the Logia de los Caballeros Racionales ("Lodge of Rational Knights") is founded, perhaps in Cádiz; membership will include many leaders of the Spanish American wars of independence such as Francisco de Miranda, Bernardo O'Higgins and José de San Martín.
February  – Invasion of Trinidad: Spanish Governor José María Chacón peacefully surrenders the colony of Trinidad to a British naval force, commanded by Sir Ralph Abercromby.

November –  Rugby School rebellion: The students at Rugby School in England rebel against the headmaster, Henry Ingles, after he decrees that the damage to a tradesman's windows should be paid for by the students.
The first census in Brazil counts  million blacks in a total population of . million.

August  – Battle of the Nile (near Abu Qir): Lord Nelson defeats the French navy under Admiral Brueys.  of the  French battleships are captured or destroyed, including the flagship Orient whose magazine explodes; Nelson himself is wounded in the head.
July  – Napoleon occupies Cairo.
January – Eli Whitney contracts with the U.S. federal government for , muskets, which he produces with interchangeable parts.
March  – French forces invade the Papal States and establish the Roman Republic.

April  – Two French diplomats to the Second Congress of Rastatt are killed and another badly injured by Austrian cavalry, as they tried to leave the town. An inquiry was held, which blamed French emigres.
October  – War of the Second Coalition: Action of  October  – A Spanish treasure convoy worth more than £,, is captured by the British Royal Navy off Vigo.
July  – At Aboukir, Egypt, Napoleon defeats , Ottoman Mamluk troops under Mustafa Pasha.
July  – In the Egyptian port city of Rosetta, French Captain Pierre Bouchard finds the Rosetta Stone.
October  – HMS Lutine (a famous treasure wreck) is sunk in the West Frisian Islands.

September  – Siege of Malta (–): The French garrison in Valletta surrenders to British troops, who had been called at the invitation of the Maltese. The islands of Malta and Gozo become the Malta Protectorate.
Pierre Coudrin and Henriette Aymer de la Chevalerie found the Congregation of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary in Paris.

July  – The Union with Ireland Act  is passed by the Parliament of Great Britain; the Irish Parliament passes similar legislation in the following month, uniting the two kingdoms and abolishing the Parliament of Ireland.

April 
Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No.  premieres at the Burgtheater, in Vienna.
The Treaty of Constantinople establishes the Septinsular Republic, the first autonomous Greek state since the Fall of the Byzantine Empire.
March  – British Royal Navy officer Henry Waterhouse first charts the Antipodes Islands.
February  – Washington, D.C. is placed under the jurisdiction of the United States Congress.
March  – Henry Addington becomes First Lord of the Treasury and Chancellor of the Exchequer, effectively Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
January  – Toussaint Louverture triumphantly enters Santo Domingo, the capital of the former Spanish colony of Santo Domingo, which has become a colony of Napoleonic France.
June  – Siege of Cairo ends: Cairo falls to British troops.
July  – Napoleon signs a Concordat with Pope Pius VII.
: Senwosret II (Twelfth Dynasty) started to rule. He built Kahun near his pyramid tomb complex at el-Lahun.
: The Mokaya along the Pacific coast of present-day Chiapas, Mexico were preparing cacao beverages.
–: "Pectoral of Senwosret II", from the tomb of princess Sithathoryunet at el-Lahun was made. Twelfth Dynasty. It is now in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
: The oldest known medical text in Egyptian history, the Kahun Gynaecological Papyrus, is written.
: Senwosret III (Twelfth Dynasty) started to rule.

June – The first account of Thomas Wedgwood's experiments in photography is published by Humphry Davy in the Journal of the Royal Institution in London. Since a fixative for the image has not yet been developed, the early photographs quickly fade.
May  – Napoleon establishes the French Legion of Honour (Légion d'honneur).
July  – Gia Long captures Hanoi, completing his unification of Vietnam.
June  – Indigenous Australian Pemulwuy, a leader of the resistance to European settlement of Australia, is shot dead by Henry Hacking.
March  – The Rosetta Stone is presented to the Society of Antiquaries of London, which in turn presents it to the British Museum.
March  – Aargau becomes a Swiss canton.

June  – Napoleon Bonaparte orders the establishment of five military camps to defend the coast of France, located at Bayonne, Ghent, Saint-Omer, Compiègne, Saint-Malo, and one in the occupied Netherlands, at Utrecht. Each one has , infantry and , cavalry to defend it.
July  – The Louisiana Purchase is announced to the American people.
July  – Robert Emmet's uprising in Ireland begins.
January  – Monroe and Livingston sail for Paris to discuss, and possibly buy, New Orleans; they end up completing the Louisiana Purchase.
November  – Said bin Sultan, Sultan of Muscat and Oman, starts to rule.
The Nguyễn dynasty emperor Gia Long changes his country's official name from Đại Việt to Việt Nam.
Morphine is first isolated from the opium poppy by the German pharmacist, Friedrich Sertürner.
John Wedgwood founds the Royal Horticultural Society.
February  – First Barbary War: Stephen Decatur leads a raid to burn the pirate-held frigate USS Philadelphia at Tripoli to deny her further use by the captors.
The Old Man of the Mountain, a natural rock formation in the U.S. state of New Hampshire, is first mentioned by two workmen, Francis Whitcomb and Luke Brooks.
October  – Sweden, led by King Gustav IV Adolf, declares war on France.
August  – Treaty of Bogenhausen is concluded between France and Bavaria forming a military alliance
November  – The Pontcysyllte Aqueduct is opened in Wales; it is , ft ( m) long and  ft ( m) tall.
January  – The Michigan Territory is created.
July  – Invasion of Naples (War of the Third Coalition): Battle of Maida – Britain defeats the French in Calabria.
July  –  Birgu polverista explosion: A gunpowder magazine explosion in Birgu, Malta kills around  people.
April  – Rana Bahadur Shah is killed by his step-brother Sher Bahadur Shah in the late night meeting which triggers the two weeks' long Bhandarkhal garden massacre in Khatmandu.
January  – Battle of Blaauwberg: British infantry force troops of the Batavian Republic in the Dutch Cape Colony to withdraw.
October  – Battle of Schleiz: French and Prussian forces fight for the first time since the war began. The Prussian army is easily defeated by a more numerous French force.
September  – Robert Morrison, the first Protestant missionary to China, arrives in Guangzhou (Canton).
February  – Napoleon leads the forces of the French Empire in an invasion of the Russian Empire, and begins fighting at the Battle of Eylau against Russian and Prussian forces.

December – – Napoleonic Wars: Raid on Griessie – A British Royal Navy squadron attacks the Dutch port of Griessie on Java in the Dutch East Indies, eliminating the last Dutch naval force in the Pacific and concluding the Java campaign of –.
February  – Burr conspiracy: In Alabama, former Vice President of the United States Aaron Burr is tried for conspiracy, but acquitted.
June  – The Duke of Portland is chosen as Prime Minister after the United Kingdom general election.

January  – Rum Rebellion: On the 20th anniversary of the foundation of the colony of New South Wales, disgruntled military officers of the New South Wales Corps (the "Rum Corps") overthrow and imprison Governor William Bligh and seize control of the colony.
August  – Peninsular War: Battle of Vimeiro – British-Portuguese troops under Wellesley defeat the French under General Jean-Andoche Junot.

January 
The importation of slaves into the United States is formally banned, as the  Act Prohibiting Importation of Slaves takes effect. However Americans still continue the slave trade by transporting Africans to Cuba and Brazil.
Sierra Leone becomes a British Crown Colony.

June 
Finnish War – Battle of Turku: The Swedish archipelago fleet defeats the Russians.
English chemist Humphry Davy informs the Royal Society of London of his isolation and discovery of two elements by electrolysis. From lime, he has produced calcium and established that lime is calcium oxide; by heating boric acid and potassium in a copper tube, he creates a substance he calls boracium, which is eventually called boron. This year he also isolates magnesium and strontium.
October  – Banco do Brasil, a major financial group in South America, founded in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
July  – Battle of Wagram begins.
May  – Battle of Aspern-Essling begins.
July  – Peninsula War – Battle of Talavera: Sir Arthur Wellesley's British, Portuguese and Spanish army defeats a French force.
September  – Finnish War: The Peace of Hamina is signed between Russia and Sweden. The future Grand Duchy of Finland is ceded to Russia by the Treaty of Fredrikshamn.
April  – Battle of Ratisbon: Napoleon I fights his last battle during the Bavarian phase of the War of the Fifth Coalition
December  – Manuel Belgrano crosses the Paraná River to Itapúa Department, starting his invasion of Paraguay.
February  – After seizing Jaén, Córdoba, Seville and Granada, Napoleonic troops enter Málaga under the command of General Horace Sebastiani.
March  – Napoleon marries Marie-Louise of Austria by proxy in Vienna.
August  – Jean Baptiste Bernadotte, Marshal of France, is elected Crown Prince of Sweden, by the Swedish Riksdag of the Estates.
June  – Argentina's new junta publishes the country's first newspaper, the Gazeta de Buenos-Ayres, edited by Mariano Moreno.
May  – Peninsular War – Battle of Albuera: Spain, Portugal and Great Britain defeat the French.
July  – British explorer David Thompson posts a notice at the confluence of the Columbia and Snake Rivers (in modern-day Washington), claiming the area for the United Kingdom.
December  – The New Madrid earthquake in the Mississippi Valley, near New Madrid, reverses the course of the river for a while. Other earthquakes along the fault occur on January ,  and February , .
October  – The Argentine Government declares freedom of expression for the press.
July  – The Great Podil fire breaks out in Kiev, Ukraine.
February  – The first Chilean newspaper Aurora de Chile deals with political philosophy, and stands in favor of the new national government.
April  – The capital of Finland is moved from Turku to Helsinki, when Russia's Tsar Alexander I signs an edict moving the Government Council of the Grand Duchy of Finland.
Approximate date – Battle of Shela: The people of Lamu Island are victorious against those from other parts of the Kenya coast.
May  – Russian field marshal Mikhail Kutuzov signs the Treaty of Bucharest, ending the Russo-Turkish War (–) and annexing Bessarabia to Imperial Russia.
May  – John Bellingham assassinates British Prime Minister Spencer Perceval, in the lobby of the British House of Commons.

March 
Napoleonic Wars: The French garrison evacuates Berlin, leaving Russian troops able to reach and take the city without a fight.
Cyril VI of Constantinople is elected Ecumenical Patriarch.
May  –  crossing of the Blue Mountains: Gregory Blaxland, William Lawson and William Wentworth leave on an expedition to cross the Blue Mountains of Australia.
August  – Gervasio Antonio de Posadas joins Argentina's second triumvirate.
February  – Argentine War of Independence: José de San Martín and his Regiment of Mounted Grenadiers gain a largely symbolic victory against a Spanish royalist army in the Battle of San Lorenzo.
November  – An independent government is restored in the Netherlands.
War of the Sixth Coalition – Battle of Fère-Champenoise: Allied army led by Schwarzenberg defeats the French under Marmont and Mortier.

February 
Mount Mayon in the Philippines erupts for the second time; more than , people die and the Cagsawa Church is destroyed.
Lord Byron's semi-autobiographical tale in verse The Corsair is published by John Murray in London, and sells , copies on this day.
War of the Sixth Coalition – Battle of La Rothière: Blücher's Allied army defeats the French under Napoleon.

May 
War of the Sixth Coalition – Barcelona is restored to Spanish Bourbon rule as the French garrison leaves the city.
Venezuelan War of Independence – Battle of Carabobo: Republican victory under Simón Bolívar over Spanish Royalists.
February  – War of the Sixth Coalition – Battle of Garris: An Allied army led by the Duke of Wellington is victorious against the French under Jean Isidore Harispe.

August  – The Anglo-Dutch Treaty of  is signed in London, returning most possessions of the Dutch Empire acquired by the United Kingdom since  to the Netherlands, although Britain retains the Cape of Good Hope and the South American settlements of Demerara, Essequibo and Berbice (later consolidated as British Guiana). In addition, the British cede the island of Banca off the island of Sumatra, in exchange for the settlement of Cochin, India.
January  – War of : British troops capture Fort Peter in St. Marys, Georgia, the only battle of the war to take place in the state.
Battle of Ligny – Napoleon defeats a Prussian army under Gebhard Leberecht von Blücher.
The second wave of Amish immigration to North America begins.
February  – The first Dutch student association, the Groninger Studentencorps Vindicat atque Polit, is founded in the Netherlands. The first rector of the senate is B. J. Winter.

August  – Napoleonic Wars: Representatives of the United Kingdom, Austria, Russia and Prussia sign a convention at Paris, declaring that Napoleon Bonaparte is "their prisoner" and that "His safe keeping is entrusted to the British Government."
January  – Fire nearly destroys the city of St. John's, Newfoundland.

March  – The Gorkha War between the United Kingdom and Nepal is ended after more than a year by the ratification of the Treaty of Sugauli, with Nepal ceding about one-third of its territory to British Indian control.
September  – King Louis XVIII dissolves the Chambre introuvable, the legislature that had been elected after the Second Bourbon Restoration re-established the old monarchy.
May  – Divorce is abolished in France by the Chambre introuvable, after having been permitted following the French Revolution.
August  – Bombardment of Algiers: An anglo-Dutch fleet forces Omar Agha, Dey of Algiers to free Christian slaves.
May  – The General Convention of the Episcopal Church founds the General Theological Seminary, while meeting in New York City.
August  – An earthquake near the site of the ancient Greek city of Helike results in  deaths.
An earthquake strikes Palermo in the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies.

February  – Battle of Chacabuco: Argentine and Chilean soldiers of the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata defeat the Spanish royalist troops in what is now Chile, marking the turning point in the war against European rule of South America.
November  – The Bank of Montreal opens in Montreal.

December  – The Christmas carol "Silent Night" (Stille Nacht), with words by the priest Josef Mohr, set to music by organist Franz Xaver Gruber, is first performed at St. Nikolaus Parish Church, in Oberndorf bei Salzburg, Austria.
August  –  United Kingdom general election for the House of Commons. The Tory Party, led by Prime Minister Robert Jenkinson, retains its control of the government but loses some seats.
February  – Marie André Cantillon attempts to assassinate the Duke of Wellington in Paris.
October  – Claudine Thévenet (known as Mary of St. Ignatius) founds the Roman Catholic order Religieuses de Jésus-Marie ("Religious of Jesus And Mary") in Lyon, France.
The Westmorland Gazette is first published at Kendal in the Lake District of England; in July, Thomas De Quincey will begin a -month term as editor.
January  – The Panic of , the first major peacetime financial crisis in the United States, begins.

A British Arctic expedition under William Parry, comprising HMS Hecla and HMS Griper, reaches longitude °' W in the Northwest Passage, the furthest west which will be attained by any single-season voyage for  years.
July  – German astronomer Johann Georg Tralles discovers what will be called the Great Comet of .
March  – McCulloch v. Maryland: The U.S. Supreme Court rules that the Bank of the United States is constitutional.

November  – A British expeditionary force reaches Ras Al Khaimah in the Persian Gulf, preparatory to the bombardment and invasion of the town, which led to the signing of the General Maritime Treaty of  between the British and what were to become known as the Trucial States.

June 
Élie Decazes, leader of the opposition in France's Chamber of Deputies, introduces the "Law of the Double Vote", a proposal to add to the existing legislators by creating  seats that would be "selected by special electoral colleges" made up of the wealthiest % of voters in each of France's departments.
Delegates in St. Louis in the Missouri Territory approve a proposed state constitution, proclaiming that they "do mutually agree to form and establish a free and independent republic, by the name of 'The State of Missouri'."

Delegates in St. Louis in the Missouri Territory approve a proposed state constitution, proclaiming that they "do mutually agree to form and establish a free and independent republic, by the name of 'The State of Missouri'."
September  – Revolution breaks out in Lisbon against John VI of Portugal.
April  – A proclamation, signed "By order of the Committee of Organisation for forming a Provisional Government", begins the "Radical War" in Scotland.

Construction work is completed on the Citadelle Laferrière in Haiti, the largest fortification in the Americas, built on the orders of Henri Christophe to defend the country against potential French reoccupation.
January  – Peter I Island in the Antarctic is first sighted, by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen.
February  – In Mexico, the Embrace of Acatempan takes place between Agustín de Iturbide and Vicente Guerrero, which seals the peace between the viceroyalty troops and the insurgents.
March  – The Battle of Rieti is fought in Italy between intervening Austrian forces and Neapolitan rebels.

December  – History of the Dominican Republic: On the Caribbean island of Hispaniola, General José Núñez de Cáceres ends the España Boba era of Spanish rule in the Captaincy General of Santo Domingo by establishing the Republic of Spanish Haiti. It will last for three months before being invaded by Haiti.
May  – Greek War of Independence: At the Battle of Gravia Inn, a -man Greek force led by Odysseas Androutsos repulses an Ottoman army of ,.
Boston, Massachusetts, is incorporated as a city following a vote.
January  – The Portuguese prince Pedro I of Brazil decides to stay in Brazil against the orders of the Portugal's King João VI, beginning the Brazilian independence process.
January  – The design of the modern-day flag of Greece is adopted by the First National Assembly at Epidaurus, for their naval flag.
Greek War of Independence: Nafplio falls to the Greek rebels.
December  – Pedro I is crowned as the first Emperor of Brazil.
April  – Franz Liszt, , gives a concert in Vienna, after which he is personally congratulated by Ludwig van Beethoven.

December  – James Monroe first introduces the Monroe Doctrine in the State of the Union address, declaring that any European attempts to recolonize the Americas would be considered a hostile act towards the United States.
November – According to tradition, William Webb Ellis invents the sport of rugby football at Rugby School in England.
Gioachino Rossini's opera Semiramide is first performed, at La Fenice in Venice.
October  – The Lancet medical journal is founded by Thomas Wakley in London.
December  – The first American social fraternity, Chi Phi (ΧΦ), is founded at Princeton University.

April  – The first permanent settlers arrive to construct the new city of Tallahassee, Florida, selected to be the capital of the Florida Territory newly acquired from the Kingdom of Spain; the area has been selected because it is roughly equidistant from the territory's main cities, Pensacola and St. Augustine.
February  – Simón Bolívar is proclaimed dictator of Peru.
October  – The First Constitution of Mexico is ratified, declaring the country to be a federal republic called the United Mexican States (Estados Unidos Mexicanos).

May  – Ludwig van Beethoven's Ninth Symphony (the "Choral") premieres at the Theater am Kärntnertor in Vienna. The deaf composer has to be turned around on the stage to witness the enthusiastic audience reaction.
The United States Postal Service starts a dead letter office.
July  – The U.S. Senate ratifies treaties with the Hunkpapa tribe.
June  – The U.S. Senate ratifies the treaty with the Poncas tribe.

August  – Scottish adventurer Gregor MacGregor issues a £, loan with .% interest, through the London bank of Thomas Jenkins & Company, for the fictitious Central American republic of Poyais. His actions led to the Panic of , the first modern stock market crash, in England.
October–December – Dispute between the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata and the Empire of Brazil over Banda Oriental region led to the Cisplatine War.
December  – Benjamin W. Edwards rides into Mexican-controlled Nacogdoches, Texas, and declares himself ruler of the Republic of Fredonia.

March  – Dom João VI, King of Portugal and former Emperor of Brazil, dies six days after he had been served dinner while visiting Jerónimos Monastery. An investigative autopsy  years later will discover that he had been killed by arsenic poisoning. King João's, Emperor Pedro I of Brazil, sails back to Portugal and briefly reigns as King Pedro IV of Portugal, before turning over the Portuguese throne to his daughter, Maria.

June  – The Pan-American Congress of Panama is opened in Panama City by Simon Bolivar as an attempt to unify the republics of the Americas that have recently declared independence from Spain, or to at least make a federation to agree on a common defense policy and create a common military. The Congress lasts for  days without an agreement.
September  – Construction of the Rideau Canal begins in Canada.
Aniline is first isolated, from the destructive distillation of indigo, by Otto Unverdorben.
John James Audubon begins publication of the -volume The Birds of America, in the United Kingdom.
April  – Greek War of Independence: Battle of Phaleron – Ottoman troops defeat the Greek rebels.
May  – Georg Ohm publishes Die galvanische Kette, mathematisch bearbeitet (tr., The Galvanic Circuit Investigated Mathematically) in which Ohm's law appears for the first time.
October  – Russo-Persian War, –: The Russians under Ivan Paskevich storm Yerevan, ending a millennium of Muslim domination in Armenia.
January  – The first regatta in Australia is held, taking place in Tasmania (called at the time Van Diemen's Land), on the River Derwent at Hobart.
Friedrich Wöhler synthesizes urea, possibly discrediting a cornerstone of vitalism.

December  – An attempt to assassinate Gran Colombia's President Simon Bolívar fails while he is visiting Jamaica. Bolivar accepts a last-minute invitation to be elsewhere and his servant, hired by the Spanish royal government to kill Bolivar, kills Bolivar's paymaster by mistake.
, Angolans are sold in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
The Treaty of Commerce and Navigation is signed between Brazil and Denmark, establishing diplomatic relations between the two countries.
The Office of the Institutions of Empress Maria is established in Russia to maintain the charitable institutions previously under the patronage of the late Empress.
January  – August Klingemann's adaptation of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe's Faust premieres in Braunschweig.
August  – Gioacchino Rossini's opera William Tell (Guillaume Tell) is first performed, in Paris.

April – Popular German conductor Felix Mendelssohn begins his first of  visits to Britain, touring the island until November . This includes the first London performance of his concert overture to A Midsummer Night's Dream, and his trip to Fingal's Cave.
June  – The Swan River Colony (later to become the cities of Perth and Fremantle) is founded in Western Australia. This secures the western third of the Australian landmass for the British.
June  – The Philadelphia Inquirer is founded in the U.S. as The Pennsylvania Inquirer.

September  – Belgian Revolution: The army of the United Kingdom of the Netherlands fails to retake Brussels, a National Congress is summoned to draw up a Constitution and a Provisional Government of Belgium is established under Charles Latour Rogier.
On what is now called "the Ustertag", men of the Canton of Zürich  in Switzerland gather to demand a new constitution.
July  – French invasion of Algiers, leading to creation of French Algeria.
June  – William IV succeeds his brother George IV, as King of the United Kingdom.
November  – The Polish November Uprising begins in Warsaw against Russian rule.
July  – Leopold of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha is inaugurated as the first King of the Belgians, in Brussels.
May–June – Merthyr Rising: Coal miners and others riot in Merthyr Tydfil, Wales, for improved working conditions.
May  – Auxiliary paddle steamer Sophia Jane arrives at Sydney from London, becoming the first steamboat to operate in the coastal waters of New South Wales.
Wesleyan University in Middletown, Connecticut
Xavier University in Cincinnati (as "The Athenaeum")
A cholera epidemic in London claims at least , lives; the contagion spreads to France and North America later this year.
November  – Wabash College, a small, private, liberal arts college for men, is founded.

June  – The Reform Act receives royal assent after passage by the British Parliament, reforming the electoral system and setting uniform law for voting rights in England and Wales, though not in Scotland or Ireland.
Publication begins (posthumously) of Carl von Clausewitz's Vom Kriege ("On War").
January  – Abolitionist William Lloyd Garrison founds the New-England Anti-Slavery Society.

Foundation of:
Kalamazoo College in Kalamazoo, Michigan.
Madras College in St Andrews, Scotland.

August  – Future United States President Benjamin Harrison is born in Ohio. From this date until the death of Former U.S. President James Madison on June  , a total of  Presidents of the United States ( former,  current, and  future) are living; which is more than any other time period in U.S. history.
May  – The Le Van Khoi revolt breaks out in southern Vietnam against Emperor Minh Mang, who has desecrated the deceased mandarin Le Van Duyet.
September  – At least , people are killed when an . magnitude earthquake shakes the Chinese province of Yunnan destroying buildings, homes and temples.

April  – General Antonio López de Santa Anna is elected President of Mexico by the legislatures of  of the  Mexican states. During his frequent absences from office to fight on the battlefield, Santa Anna turns the duties of government over to his vice president, Valentín Gómez Farías.
January  – Zollverein (Germany): Customs charges are abolished at borders within its member states.
July  – The Office of Indian Affairs is organized in the United States.

August  – In the Empire of Brazil, the Additional Act provides for establishment of the Provincial Legislative Assembly, extinction of the State Council, replacement of the Regency Trina, and introduction of a direct and secret ballot.

July  – Imam Faisal bin Turki enters Riyadh and upon entering his father's palace, assassinates his father's murderer, Ibrahim Hamza, and his master; Mishari, and becomes the ruler and founder of the Second Saudi State.
March  – John Herschel discovers the open cluster of stars now known as NGC , observing from the Cape of Good Hope.
Charles-Louis Havas creates Havas, the first news agency in the world (which later spawns Agence France-Presse).
August  – In the U.S., The New York Sun prints the first of six installments of the Great Moon Hoax.
