The first railway in continental Europe is opened between Brussels and Mechelen in Belgium.
August – H. Fox Talbot exposes the world's first known photographic negatives, at Lacock Abbey in England.
Fort Cass is established, the military headquarters and site of the largest internment camps during the  Trail of Tears.
September  – The Riograndense Republic is proclaimed in South America.
The United States Survey of the Coast is returned to the U.S. Treasury Department, and renamed the U.S. Coast Survey.

Eugène Schneider and his brother Adolphe Schneider purchase a bankrupt ironworks near the town of Le Creusot, in the Burgundy region of France, and found the steelworks and engineering company Schneider Frères & Cie.
July  – The Champlain and St. Lawrence Railroad opens between St. John and La Prairie, Quebec, the first steam-worked passenger railroad in British North America.
HMS Beagle, with Charles Darwin on board, reaches Sydney.
August  – The Dutch colonial forces sack the fortress of Bonjol, Indonesia, ending the Padri War.

March  – The Congregation of Holy Cross is formed in Le Mans, France, by the signing of the Fundamental Act of Union, which legally joins the Auxiliary Priests of Blessed Basil Moreau, CSC, and the Brothers of St. Joseph (founded by Jacques-François Dujarié) into one religious association.
February  – Seminoles attack Fort Foster in Florida.
November  – American abolitionist and newspaper editor Elijah Lovejoy is killed by a pro-slavery mob, at his warehouse in Alton, Illinois.
The Olney Friends School is founded in the Appalachian Mountains of the United States.
January  – At Morristown, New Jersey, Samuel Morse, Alfred Vail and Leonard Gale give the first public demonstration of Morse's new invention, the telegraph.
June  – The coronation of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom takes place at Westminster Abbey in London.
November  – Dissolution of the Federal Republic of Central America: Honduras and Costa Rica follow the example of Nicaragua and secede from the federation.
April – – The paddle steamer SS Sirius makes the transatlantic crossing to New York from Cork, Ireland in  days, though not using steam continuously.
May  – Braulio Carrillo is sworn in as Head of State of Costa Rica, thus beginning his second term in office.
November  – The American Statistical Association is founded in Boston, Massachusetts.
January  – Battle of Yungay: Chile defeats the Peru–Bolivian Confederation, leading to the restoration of an independent Peru.
June  – The emperor of the Sikh Empire, Maharaja Ranjit Singh, dies at .

June  – Destruction of opium at Humen begins, casus belli for Britain to open the -year First Opium War against Qing dynasty China. A rapid rise in the sale of opium in China to over , chests (~, kilograms (, lb) per annum) has caused the Chinese government to dispatch scholar-official Lin Zexu to Guangzhou to deal with the growing problem of opium addiction.
June  – Louis Daguerre receives a patent for his camera (commercially available by September at the price of  francs).
March  – Adolphe Thiers becomes prime minister of France.

June  – Maria massacre: British brigantine Maria is wrecked off South Australia. All  passengers and crew make it to the shore but none survive the trek to safety over the following two weeks, most being massacred by Aboriginal Australians.
February  – Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom marries her cousin Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha.
September  – Ottoman and British troops bombard Beirut, and land troops on the coast, to pressure Egyptian Muhammad Ali to retreat from the country.
February  – Damascus Affair: The murder of a Capuchin friar and his Greek servant leads to a highly publicized case of blood libel, against the Jews of Damascus.
June  – The United Kingdom Census is held, the first to record names and approximate ages of every household member, and to be administered nationally.
The sixth bishop of Calcutta, Daniel Wilson, and Dr. James Taylor, Civil Surgeon at Dhaka, establish the first modern educational institution on the Indian subcontinent, Dhaka College.
September  – Sarawak is broken away from Brunei, and James Brooke is appointed Rajah.
May  – New Zealand becomes a separate British colony, having previously been administered as part of the Colony of New South Wales.
November – The settlement of Dallas, Texas, is founded by John Neely Bryan.
Beecham's Pills (a laxative) is first marketed in Lancashire, England, by Thomas Beecham, forming the basis of the Beecham Group and GSK plc pharmaceutical companies.
English palaeontologist Richard Owen coins the name Dinosauria, hence the Anglicized dinosaur.
August  – The Mines and Collieries Act  in the United Kingdom makes it illegal for women and girls of any age, and boys under ten years, to work underground.
May  – The Income Tax Act establishes the first peacetime income tax in the United Kingdom;  pence in the pound, for incomes over  pounds.

April–September –  general strike spreads across England's industrial districts, driven by Chartism. Includes the Preston Strike and Pottery Riots. Protestors are killed by the military in several places.
March  – The world does not end, contrary to the first prediction by American preacher William Miller.
December – The world's first Christmas cards, commissioned by Sir Henry Cole in London from the artist John Callcott Horsley, are sent.
August  – Edgar Allan Poe's short story "The Black Cat" is first published in The Saturday Evening Post.
February  – Giuseppe Verdi's opera I Lombardi alla prima crociata premieres at La Scala in Milan.
Kurdish leader Bedir Khan Beg launched an expedition against the Assyrians in the Hakkari region.Thousands of Assyrians were massacred during the campaign.
December  – Hungarian becomes the official language of Hungary.
Swedish chemistry professor Gustaf Erik Pasch is granted a privilege for his invention of a safety match.
October  –  Salta earthquake. A magnitude . earthquake hits Argentina's Salta Province.
August  – Abdelkader El Djezairi is defeated at the Battle of Isly in Morocco; sultan Abd al-Rahman of Morocco soon repudiates his ally.
June  – Start of the Silesian weavers' uprising. It is crushed by Prussian military on June , with  weavers killed and numerous arrested.
September  – Potato blight breaks out in Ireland, beginning the Great Famine.
October  – Richard Wagner's opera Tannhäuser debuts at the Dresden Royal Court Theater.

November  – Anglo-French blockade of the Río de la Plata – Battle of Vuelta de Obligado: The Argentine Confederation is narrowly defeated by an Anglo–French fleet on the waters of the Paraná River, but the victors suffer serious damage to their ships, and Argentina attracts political support in South America.

March 
Florida is admitted as the 27th U.S. state.
For the first time, both houses of the United States Congress vote, by a two-thirds majority, to override a presidential veto in order to pass legislation.
March  – Stephen Perry patents the rubber band, in the United Kingdom.
October  – At Massachusetts General Hospital, Dr. William T. G. Morton, a dentist, gives the first successful public demonstration of ether anesthesia.
February –March  – Kraków uprising: Polish nationalists stage an uprising in the Free City of Kraków; it is suppressed by forces of the Austrian Empire, supported by peasants.
Fort Wayne Female College is founded in Indiana as a Methodist institution; it will later be renamed Taylor University.
May  – Mexican–American War: The United States declares war on Mexico.
The first higher school of academic learning for women in Denmark, Den højere Dannelsesanstalt for Damer, is founded in Copenhagen.
April  – The Lawrence School, Sanawar is established in India.
The Great Famine continues in Ireland.
November – – James Young Simpson discovers the anesthetic properties of chloroform and first uses it, successfully, on a patient, in an obstetric case in Edinburgh.
October  – German inventors and industrialists Werner von Siemens and Johann Georg Halske found Siemens & Halske to develop the electrical telegraph.
December  – Emir Abdelkader surrenders to the French in Algeria.
Rhodes College is founded in Clarksville, Tennessee, as the Masonic University of Tennessee.
President Napoleon III takes his oath of office in front of the French National Assembly.
July  – Governor-General Peter von Scholten emancipates all remaining slaves in the Danish West Indies
At the Battle of Des, Karl von Urban, with . men, defeats a Hungarian army of . led by Katona Miklós.
The University of Mississippi admits its first students.
August  – Venice (the Republic of San Marco) surrenders to Austrian troops after a -month siege.

October  – Hungarian Revolution of : The  Martyrs of Arad are executed after the Hungarian War of Independence, in repression by the Austrian authorities led by Julius Jacob von Haynau (these martyrs being the generals of the Hungarian revolutionary army, who did not flee from Hungary after the suppression of the Hungarian revolution by the Russo-Austrian forces). Also today, Lajos Batthyány, the first Hungarian prime minister, is executed by Austrian authorities in Pest.

April  – Hungarian Revolution of  – Battle of Isaszeg: The main Hungarian forces, led by Arthur Görgey, defeat the main imperial forces, led by Alfred I, Prince of Windisch-Grätz, forcing them to retreat westward.

February  – Regular steamboat service from the west to the east coast of the United States begins, with the arrival of the SS California in San Francisco Bay. The California leaves New York Harbor on October , , rounds Cape Horn at the tip of South America, and arrives at San Francisco after the -month, -day journey.

Hungarian Revolution of : The Hungarian Revolutionary Army, under the leadership of Arthur Görgey, starts the victorious Spring Campaign, which leads to the liberation of much of Hungary from the Austrian forces.
December  – Members of the Canterbury Association, the first settlers bound for Christchurch, arrive from England at the port of Lyttelton, New Zealand, aboard the Charlotte Jane and Randolph.

April
Pope Pius IX returns from exile to Rome.
Stephen Foster's parlor ballad "Ah! May the Red Rose Live Alway" is published in the United States.
San Francisco is incorporated as a city in California.
Dost Mohammad Barakzai, emir of Afghanistan, captures Balkh.
July  – Twice-served former British Prime Minister Sir Robert Peel dies following a fall from his horse at Constitution Hill, London.
July  – The University of the Pacific is chartered as California Wesleyan College, in Santa Clara, California.
August  – Isaac Singer is granted a United States patent for his improved sewing machine.
February  – In Boston, Massachusetts, members of the anti-slavery Boston Vigilance Committee rescue fugitive slave Shadrach Minkins from a courtroom, following his arrest by U.S. marshals.
April  – San Luis, the oldest permanent settlement in the state of Colorado, is founded by settlers from Taos, New Mexico.
Serial poisoner Hélène Jégado is arrested in Rennes, France. Her trial opens on December ; she is eventually sentenced to death and executed by guillotine.
September  – French engineer Henri Giffard makes the first airship trip, from Paris to Trappes.
July  – Frederick Douglass delivers his famous speech, "What to the Slave Is the Fourth of July?", in Rochester, New York.
March  – Phi Mu sorority is founded in Macon, Georgia.
November  –  United States presidential election: Democrat Franklin Pierce of New Hampshire defeats Whig Winfield Scott of Virginia.
August  – Boston missionary Reverend Benjamin Galen Snow lands on the island of Kosrae in the Caroline Islands (Micronesia) first to bring the gospel to the island.
July  – Outlaw and bandit Joaquin Murrieta is killed in California.

April  – Prince Leopold, the youngest son and the eighth child of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, is born in Buckingham Palace; he has inherited haemophilia. During the labour, Victoria chooses to use chloroform, thereby encouraging the use of anesthesia in childbirth.
October  – In Munich, the art museum Neue Pinakothek opens.
Isambard Kingdom Brunel accepts John Scott Russell's tender for construction of the SS Great Eastern passenger steamer.
March  – Giuseppe Verdi's opera La traviata premieres at La Fenice in Venice, but is poorly received at this time.
The Icelandic trade is opened to merchants other than Danes.
January  – The iron clipper RMS Tayleur runs aground off the east coast of Ireland, on her maiden voyage out of Liverpool, bound for Australia, with the loss of at least  out of  on board.

November
Florence Nightingale and her team of  trained volunteer nurses, having set out on October  from England, arrive at Selimiye Barracks in Scutari in the Ottoman Empire, to care for British Army troops wounded in the Crimean War.
The Mute Rebellion breaks out in Sweden.
November  – Crimean War: Battle of Inkerman – The Russians are defeated.
Bryant & Stratton College is founded as a business institute in the United States.
March  – Taiping Rebellion: A Taiping army of , invades Anhui.

August  – Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom, with Prince Albert, begins a -day state visit to Paris, the first visit of a reigning British monarch to France since . While there, she visits the Exposition Universelle.
March  – The United States Congress appropriates $, to create the U.S. Camel Corps.

October 
Henry Bessemer files his patent in the United Kingdom for the Bessemer process of steelmaking.
Crimean War: Battle of Kinburn – Combined French and British forces subdue Russian shore forts. The successful use of French floating batteries makes this the first use of modern ironclad warships in action.
Palm oil sales from West Africa to the United Kingdom reach , tons.
The -mile North Carolina Railroad is completed from Goldsboro through Raleigh and Salisbury to Charlotte.
April  – The Paris Declaration Respecting Maritime Law abolishes privateering, and regulates the relationship between neutral and belligerent shipping on the high seas.
August  – The Last Island hurricane destroys Last Island, Louisiana, leaving  dead. The whole island is broken up into several smaller islands by the storm.
November  – Niagara University is founded in Niagara Falls, New York.
June  – General Mills is founded in Minneapolis, Minnesota, United States, as the Minneapolis Milling Company.
Kuala Lumpur, the future capital of Malaysia, is founded as a tin mining settlement.
October  – Panic of : New York banks close, and do not reopen until December .
May –October  – The Art Treasures of Great Britain exhibition is held in Manchester, one of the largest such displays of all time.
September  – The SS Central America sinks off the coast of North Carolina with the loss of  lives.
April  – First horse race run at Longchamp Racecourse in Paris.

April –May  – Battle of Grahovac: The Ottomans are decisively defeated by  Montenegrin forces. The Bawani Imli massacre, (April ) where  Indian freedom fighters were hanged to death on a tamarind tree by British colonial forces.
August  – Cyrus West Field and others complete the first transatlantic telegraph cable, after several unsuccessful attempts. The service ends on September , due to weak current.
May  – John Ruskin begins a tour of Europe; he considers it a significant turning point in his life.
The Russian Empire changes its flag.

August  – U.S. President James Buchanan inaugurates the new trans-Atlantic telegraph cable, by exchanging greetings with Queen Victoria. However, a weak signal forces a shutdown of the service in a few weeks.
June  – Charles Blondin crosses Niagara Falls on a tightrope for the first time.
John Stuart Mill publishes On Liberty.
The so-called Pig War border dispute between the Americans and the British, over the San Juan Islands, begins by the death of the namesake pig.
November  – The Treaty of Zürich, reaffirming the terms of the Treaty of Villafranca, brings the Austro-Sardinian War to an official close.
Karl Marx publishes A Contribution to the Critique of Political Economy.
January  – The Pemberton Mill in Lawrence, Massachusetts collapses, killing at least  workers.
October  – The first Convention of Peking formally ends the Second Opium War.
January  – Battle of Tétouan, Morocco: Spanish troops under General Leopoldo O'Donnell, 1st Duke of Tetuan defeat the Moroccan Army.

March  – Sakuradamon Incident: Rōnin samurai of the Mito Domain in Japan assassinate tairō (Chief Minister) Ii Naosuke outside the Sakurada Gate of Edo Castle, disaffected with his role in the opening of Japan to foreign powers.
March  – The First Taranaki War begins at Waitara, New Zealand, when Māori refuse to sell land to British settlers.
Comet C/ J1 (the "Great Comet of ") is discovered from Australia. May : Great Comet
March  – Confederate Arizona: A convention in modern-day Tucson ratifies the ordinance of secession of the southern part of New Mexico Territory.
January  – Florida secedes from the Union.
Kentucky proclaims its neutrality, which lasts until September , when Confederate forces enter the state.
October  – The Toronto Stock Exchange is established in Canada.
December  – General Order No. , which expels all Jews from his military district, is issued by General Ulysses S. Grant. This order is rescinded just a few weeks later.
January  – Hartley Colliery disaster in north-east England:  men are trapped and die underground when the only shaft becomes blocked.
The Bureau of Internal Revenue, the forerunner of the Internal Revenue Service, is established in the United States.
March  – Ironclad CSS Virginia (formerly USS Merrimack) is launched at Hampton Roads, Virginia; the Battle of Hampton Roads starts the same day.
March  – The first railway line in Finland, between the cities of Helsinki and Hämeenlinna, is officially opened.
February  – Alanson Crane of Virginia patents a fire extinguisher.
January  – The first section of the London Underground Railway (Paddington to Farringdon Street) opens officially.

July  – The first formal African American military unit, the 54th Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry, unsuccessfully assaults Confederate-held Fort Wagner but their valiant fighting still proves the worth of African American soldiers during the war. Their commander, Colonel Robert Shaw, is shot leading the attack, and is buried with his men ( Union, along with  Confederate).
January Uprising: The Polish peasant army, now led by Zygmunt Sierakowski, achieves its first victory over the Russian army, near Raguva.
August  – Otago Boys' High School is founded in New Zealand.
November  – A group of Confederate operatives, calling themselves the Confederate Army of Manhattan, starts fires in more than  locations, in an unsuccessful attempt to burn down New York City.
March  – The Red River Campaign begins, as Union troops reach Alexandria, Louisiana.
The January Uprising ends in the defeat of Polish forces.

December 
James Clerk Maxwell presents his paper, A Dynamical Theory of the Electromagnetic Field, to the Royal Society in London, treating light as an electromagnetic wave.
Syllabus errorum: Pope Pius IX condemns theological liberalism as an error, and claims the supremacy of Roman Catholic Church authority over civil society. He also condemns rationalism and socialism.
The Clifton Suspension Bridge across the River Avon (Bristol) in England, designed by Isambard Kingdom Brunel and completed as a memorial to him, opens to traffic.
December – – American Civil War: Battle of Nashville – Union forces decisively defeat the Confederate Army of Tennessee.
January  – American Civil War: Second Battle of Fort Fisher – Union forces launch a major amphibious assault against the last seaport held by the Confederates, Fort Fisher, North Carolina.
July  – The SS Great Eastern departs on a voyage to lay a transatlantic telegraph cable.

March 
The Claywater Meteorite explodes just before reaching ground level in Vernon County, Wisconsin; fragments having a combined mass of . kg (. lb) are recovered.
American Civil War: In Virginia, Confederate forces capture Fort Stedman from the Union, although it is retaken the same day. Lee's army suffers heavy casualties: about ,, including , captured in the Union counterattack. Confederate positions are weakened. After the battle, Lee's defeat is only a matter of time.
The Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution (conditional prohibition of slavery and involuntary servitude) passes narrowly, in the House of Representatives.
August  – The Dominican Republic regains independence from Spain.
June  – Fenian forces skirmish with Canadian militia at the battles of Ridgeway and Fort Erie.
July  – Austro-Prussian War: Naval Battle of Lissa – The Austrian fleet under Wilhelm von Tegetthoff defeats the Italian fleet of Carlo di Persano.
July  – Reconstruction: Tennessee becomes the first U.S. state to be readmitted to the Union following the American Civil War.
June  – The Kingdom of Italy declares war on Austria.
April  – The kingdoms of Italy and Prussia form an alliance against the Austrian Empire.

March  – The British North America Act receives royal assent, forming the Dominion of Canada, in an event known as the Confederation. This unites the Province of Canada (Quebec and Ontario), New Brunswick, and Nova Scotia on July . Ottawa will become the capital.
February  – The United States Congress forbids taxpayer funding of diplomatic envoys to the Holy See (Vatican), begun in , and breaks off relations. Funding resumes, along with relations, in .
Gorse is naturalised in New Zealand, where it soon becomes the worst invasive weed.
January  – Regent's Park skating disaster in London:  people die when ice on a lake breaks.
March – The University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign is established (opened one year later).
April  – The Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute is established in Hampton, Virginia.
February  – In New York City, the Jolly Corks organization is renamed the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks (BPOE).
November  –  United States presidential election: Republican Ulysses S. Grant defeats Democrat Horatio Seymour.

November  – American Indian Wars – Battle of Washita River: In the early morning, United States Army Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer leads an attack on a band of Cheyenne living on reservation land with Chief Black Kettle, killing  Cheyenne.
June  – Mihailo Obrenović, Prince of Serbia, is assassinated in Košutnjak, Belgrade.

March – In Japan, the daimyōs of the Tosa, Hizen, Satsuma and Chōshū Domains are persuaded to return their domains to the Emperor Meiji, leading to creation of a fully centralized government in the country.
May  – John Wesley Powell departs Green River, Wyoming, with a company of nine other men, on a trip down the Green and Colorado Rivers.

December 
Women's suffrage: The Wyoming territorial legislature gives women the right to vote, the first such law in the world.
The first American chapter of Kappa Sigma is founded at the University of Virginia.
August  – Irish scientist Mary Ward is killed by a steam car.
June  – The Cincinnati Red Stockings open the baseball season as the first fully professional team.
January  – A political cartoon for the first time symbolizes the United States Democratic Party with a donkey (A Live Jackass Kicking a Dead Lion by Thomas Nast for Harper's Weekly).

January 
The first edition of The Northern Echo newspaper is published in Priestgate, Darlington, England.
Plans for the Brooklyn Bridge are completed.
The office of the Solicitor General of the United States is set up, to supervise and conduct government litigation in the United States Supreme Court.

April  – The Chicago Base Ball Club, later to be known as the Chicago White Stockings and ultimately the Chicago Cubs, play their first game against the St. Louis Unions of the National Association of Base Ball Players, an amateur league.
October  – The Chinese leaders of June's Tianjin Massacre of foreigners are executed by China's Imperial government.

February  –  French legislative election elects the first legislature of the French Third Republic; monarchists (Legitimists and Orleanists) favourable to peace with the German Empire gain a large majority. The National Assembly meets in Bordeaux.
April  – U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant signs the Civil Rights Act of .
August  – The abolition of the han system is carried out in Japan.
October  – The Royal Regiment of Artillery forms the first regular Canadian army units, when they create two batteries of garrison artillery, which later become the Royal Canadian Artillery.
July –August  – The first ever photographs of Yellowstone National Park region are taken by photographer William Henry Jackson, during the Hayden Geological Survey of .
May  – Victoria Woodhull becomes the first woman nominated for President of the United States, although she is a year too young to qualify and does not appear on the ballot.
May  – The Battle of Mañaria, near Bilbao, Spain during the Third Carlist War (–).

November 
 United States presidential election: Ulysses S. Grant defeats Horace Greeley.
Women's suffrage: In defiance of the law, American suffragist Susan B. Anthony votes for the first time (on November  she is served an arrest warrant, and in the subsequent trial is fined $, which she never pays).
July  – Explorer William Gosse reaches Uluru in central Australia and names it Ayers Rock.
September  – Upon the death of King Charles XV of Sweden and Norway, he is succeeded as King of both crowns by his brother Oscar II.

December –  Major Walter Clopton Wingfield designs and patents a racquet sport, which he calls sphairistike (Greek σφάίρίστική, "skill at playing at ball"), soon known simply as Stické and an ancestor of lawn tennis, for the amusement of his guests at a garden party on his estate of Nantclwyd, in Llanelidan, Wales.
The University of California opens its first medical school in San Francisco.
The Canadian Parliament establishes the North-West Mounted Police (which is renamed the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in ).
July  – Sir Benjamin Pine becomes Lieutenant-governor of the Colony of Natal.
July – The end of the war between the United Kingdom and Ghana's King Kofi KariKari, who is involved in the trading of slaves, leads to the establishment of the Gold Coast Colony.
May  – The first commercial horse-drawn carriage debuts in the city of Bombay, plying two routes.
Bolton Wanderers (as Christ Church F.C.)

April –May  – A group of young painters, Société Anonyme Coopérative des Artistes, Peintres, Sculpteurs, Graveurs, gives their first exhibition, at the studio of the photographer Nadar in Paris. Louis Leroy's critical review of it published on  April gives rise to the term Impressionism for the movement, with reference to Claude Monet's Impression, Sunrise.
November  – John Ernst Worrell Keely demonstrates his "induction resonance motion motor", a perpetual motion machine, which eventually turns out to be a fraud.

August  – Third Carlist War: Battle of Oteiza – Two months after Government forces were repulsed from Carlist-held Estella, in Navarre, Republican General Domingo Moriones makes a fresh diversionary attack a few miles to the southeast at Oteiza. In heavy fighting Moriones secures a costly tactical victory over Carlist General Torcuato Mendíri, but the war continues another  months, before Estella finally falls.

February  – Third Carlist War: Battle of Lácar – Carlist commander Torcuato Mendíri secures a brilliant victory, when he surprises and routs a Government force under General Enrique Bargés at Lácar, east of Estella, nearly capturing newly crowned King Alfonso XII. The Carlists take several pieces of artillery, more than , rifles, and  prisoners.  men of both sides are killed (mostly government troops).
Bizet's Carmen is first performed at the Opéra-Comique, Paris, France, three months before the composer's death.
The first indoor ice hockey game is played at the Victoria Skating Rink in Montreal, Quebec, Canada.
January  – The newly proclaimed King Alfonso XII of Spain (Queen Isabella II's son) arrives in Spain to restore the monarchy during the Third Carlist War.

November  – The Times newspaper in London reveals that Isma'il Pasha has sold Egypt's % share in the Suez Canal to Britain, in a deal secured by Benjamin Disraeli, without the prior sanction of the British Parliament.
November  – The British Colony of New Zealand dissolves its  provinces and replaces them with  counties.

The National League of Professional Base Ball Clubs is formed at a meeting in Chicago; it replaces the National Association of Professional Base Ball Players. Morgan Bulkeley of the Hartford Dark Blues is selected as the league's first president.
Lyford House, by Richardson Bay, Tiburon, California, is constructed.
Emile Berliner invents an improved form of microphone which will be adopted for  Alexander Graham Bell's telephone.
July  – Reichstadt Agreement: Russia and Austria-Hungary agree on partitioning the Balkan Peninsula.
December  – Serbia restates its previous declaration of war against Turkey.
May  –  May  crisis in France: Parliament passes a no-confidence motion against the government appointed by President MacMahon.
May – – At Gilmore's Gardens in New York City, the first Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show is held.
Russo-Turkish War: The second battle in the siege of Plevna is fought.

January  – The Satsuma Rebellion, a revolt of disaffected samurai in Japan, breaks out against the new imperial government; it lasts until September, when it is crushed by a professionally led army of draftees.
The Johns Hopkins University Press, America's oldest university press.
March  – The British Royal Navy frigate HMS Eurydice () capsizes in the English Channel; all but  of the  crew members are killed.
February  – Greece declares war on the Ottoman Empire.
October  – John A. Macdonald returns to office as Prime Minister of Canada.
February  – The British fleet enters Turkish waters, and anchors off Istanbul; Russia threatens to occupy Istanbul, but does not carry out the threat.
October  – The Dual Alliance is formed by Germany and Austria-Hungary.
April – Postman Ferdinand Cheval begins to build his Palais Idéal at Hauterives in France.
Thomas Edison demonstrates incandescent lighting to the public for the first time, in Menlo Park, New Jersey.
October  – Sunderland Association Football Club is formed by a group of schoolteachers in northeast England.
May  – The current constitution of the State of California in the United States is ratified.
The international White slave trade affair scandal in Brussels is exposed and attracts international infamy.

March  – For the first and last time in its history, the annual side-by-side] rowing race between the -member teams of University of Oxford and the University of Cambridge on the River Thames is postponed. The call comes because of a thick fog that makes visibility impossible. Two days later, Oxford wins the race by +⁄ lengths.
July  – Second Anglo-Afghan War – Battle of Maiwand: Afghan troops under Ayub Khan defeat British and Indian forces, under Brigadier General George Burrows.
August  – The SS Columbia completes her maiden voyage, arriving without incident in Portland, Oregon, after a stopover in San Francisco.

January  – Thomas Edison is granted a patent for the incandescent light bulb. Edison filed for a US patent for an electric lamp using "a carbon filament or strip coiled and connected ... to platina contact wires." Although the patent described several ways of creating the carbon filament, including using "cotton and linen thread, wood splints, papers coiled in various ways," Edison and his team later discovered that a carbonized bamboo filament could last more than  hours.
January – – Siege of Geok Tepe: Russian troops under General Mikhail Skobelev defeat the Turkomans.
Abilene, Texas, is founded.
Hattori Watch Shop (服部時計店) is founded by Kanetarō Hattori in Ginza, Tokyo, Japan, predecessor of watch brand Seiko.
February  – Kansas becomes the first U.S. state to prohibit all alcoholic beverages.
March  – Edward Rudolf founds the 'Church of England Central Society for Providing Homes for Waifs and Strays' (later The Children's Society).
A peace treaty is signed between Paraguay and Uruguay.

January 
The Standard Oil Trust is secretly created in the United States to control multiple corporations set up by John D. Rockefeller and his associates.
Irish-born author Oscar Wilde arrives in New York at the beginning of a lecture tour of the United States and Canada.
July – – Anglo-Egyptian War: The British Mediterranean Fleet carries out the Bombardment of Alexandria, its forces capturing the city of Alexandria, Egypt, and securing the Suez Canal.
March  – Polygamy is made a felony by the Edmunds Act, passed by the United States Congress.
St Andrew's Ambulance Association is founded in Glasgow, Scotland; St. John Ambulance Canada is also founded this year.

During construction of the Canadian Pacific Railway in , blasting and excavation reveal high concentrations of nickel–copper ore at Murray Mine, on the edge of the Sudbury Basin, located near Sudbury, Ontario, Canada.
November  – Chile's National Library of Congress is founded.
Construction of Speicherstadt as a free zone in the Port of Hamburg begins.

March  – Demonstration of  March  :  Parisian anarchists, unemployed and carpenters narrowly miss the Presidential palace during a violent protest; first use of the black flag as a symbol of anarchism by Louise Michel.

September 
The Bombay Natural History Society is founded in India.
The University of Texas at Austin opens to students.
Scottish Plymouth Brethren missionary Frederick Stanley Arnot identifies the source of the Zambezi River, near Kalene Hill.
Leicester City F.C. play their first match, as Leicester Fosse Football Club, in England.
January  – German microbiologist Robert Koch isolates Vibrio cholerae, the cholera bacillus, working in India.
August  – The Sino-French War (for control of Tonkin) breaks out (continues to April ).
February  – A New English Dictionary on historical principles, part  (edited by James A. H. Murray), the first fascicle of what will become The Oxford English Dictionary, is published in England.
July  – Sarah E. Goode is the first African-American woman to apply for and receive a patent, for the invention of the hideaway bed.
July – Japan Brewery, predecessor of Kirin Holdings, is founded in Yokohama, Japan.
September  – A train wreck of the P. T. Barnum Circus kills giant elephant Jumbo, at St. Thomas, Ontario.
February  – The first Japanese arrive in Hawaii.
The Home Insurance Building in Chicago, designed by William Le Baron Jenney, is completed. With ten floors and a fireproof weight-bearing metal frame, it is regarded as the first skyscraper.
November  – German inventor Friedrich Soennecken first develops the hole puncher, a type of office tool capable of punching small holes in paper.
August  – The Christian Union (Church of God) is established in Monroe County, Tennessee
May  – A general strike begins in the United States, which escalates on May  into the Haymarket affair in Chicago, and eventually wins the eight-hour day for workers.
April  – The settlement of Vancouver, British Columbia, is incorporated.
July  – Steve Brodie is reported to have made a jump from the Brooklyn Bridge, a claim subsequently disputed.
Tokyo Fire Insurance, predecessor of Sompo Japan Nipponkoa Insurance, is founded.
April  – The final of the first All-Ireland Hurling Championship is held.
June  – The United Retail Federation is established in Brisbane, Australia.
November  – The Coimbra Academic Association, the students' union of the University of Coimbra in Portugal, is founded.
April − – Schnaebele incident: A French/German border incident nearly leads to war between the two countries.

August 
A fire destroys the Main Building, the heart of Wells College in Aurora, New York, causing a loss of $,.
The Oaths Act permits the oath of allegiance taken to the Sovereign by Members of Parliament (MPs) to be affirmed, rather than sworn to God, thus confirming the ability of atheists to sit in the House of Commons of the United Kingdom.

September 
In the United States, George Eastman registers the trademark Kodak, and receives a patent for his camera, which uses roll film.
Mohandas Gandhi embarks on the SS Clyde from Bombay for London.
June  – Handel's Israel in Egypt is recorded onto wax cylinder at The Crystal Palace in London, the earliest known recording of classical music.
The Baldwin School is founded in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, as "Miss [Florence] Baldwin's School for Girls, Preparatory for Bryn Mawr College".
October  – Sofia University officially opens, becoming the first university in liberated Bulgaria.
June  – A Neapolitan baker named Raffaele Esposito invents the Pizza Margherita, named after the queen consort of Italy Margherita of Savoy. This is the forerunner of the modern pizza.

January  – Mayerling incident: Rudolf, Crown Prince of Austria, and his mistress Baroness Mary Vetsera commit a double suicide (or a murder-suicide) at the Mayerling hunting lodge in the Vienna Woods.
December  – The first interurban tram-train to emerge in the United States is the Newark and Granville Street Railway in Ohio.

November 
Argentina is the first country to recognize the abolition of the monarchy in Brazil.
Gustav Mahler premieres his Symphony No. , in Budapest.
October  – The British South Africa Company receives a Royal Charter.
February  – The worldwide insurance and financial service brand Allianz is founded in Berlin, Germany.
September  – Salisbury, Rhodesia, is founded.
William II of Prussia opposes Bismarck's attempt to renew the law outlawing the Social Democratic Party.
January  – Ballet The Sleeping Beauty, with music by Tchaikovsky, is premiered at the Imperial Mariinsky Theatre in St. Petersburg, Russia.
July  – Death of Vincent van Gogh: van Gogh shoots himself, dying two days later.
February  – Springhill, Nova Scotia suffers a serious mining disaster.
February – The Tobacco Protest begins in Iran.
December  – Asteroid  Brucia becomes the first asteroid discovered using photography.
Philips founded in Eindhoven, Netherlands, for the production of carbon-filament lamps and other electro-technical products.
General Nelson A. Miles' forces surround the Lakota in the Pine Ridge Reservation.
May  – The last broad gauge train runs from Paddington on the Great Western Railway of England.
March  – The St. Patrick's Day Snowstorm besieges Tennessee with upwards of  inches of snow, establishing accumulation records that still stand.
September  – Sergei Witte replaces Ivan Vyshnegradsky, as Russian finance minister.
September – Women are first admitted to Yale University's graduate school.
July  – Samoa changes its time zone from  hours ahead of Japan to being  hours behind California, such that it crosses the International Date Line, and Monday, July  occurs twice.
September  – Brothers Charles and Frank Duryea drive the first gasoline-powered motorcar in America, on public roads in Springfield, Massachusetts.

September 
Under pressure of a general strike, the Belgian Federal Parliament enacts general multiple suffrage.
Russian monitor Rusalka sinks in a storm in the Gulf of Finland, with the loss of all  crew; her hulk is eventually discovered in  off Helsinki.
Genoa Cricket & Athletic Club, the oldest Italian Association football club, is formed.
October  (October  O.S.) – In Saint Petersburg (Russia), Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky conducts the first performance of his Symphony No.  in B minor, Pathétique, nine days before his death.
The Independent Labour Party of the United Kingdom has its first meeting.
January  – The Telefon Hírmondó service starts with around  subscribers, in Budapest.

July 
The short-lived Republic of Hawaii is proclaimed by Sanford B. Dole.
The football club FC La Chaux-de-Fonds is founded in Switzerland.
April  – Manchester City Football Club is formed in north-west England under this name.
Coxey's Army arrives in Washington; Coxey is arrested on the Capitol grounds.

July  – The United Kingdom and Japan sign the Anglo-Japanese Treaty of Commerce and Navigation, as the U.K. becomes the first of the Western nations to agree to give up its extraterritorial rights in Japan.

Edward B. Marks and Joe Stern publish the waltz The Little Lost Child in the United States, promoting the playing of the waltz with slides projected by a magic lantern, the earliest version of music video known as the illustrated song.
Britain annexes Tongaland, between Zululand and Mozambique.
January  – A . magnitude earthquake strikes northeastern Iran near the town of Quchan and causes at least , deaths.
August  – The Aljaž Tower, a symbol of the Slovenes, is erected on Mount Triglav.

October  –  Charleston earthquake: A major earthquake occurs near Charleston, Missouri, in the New Madrid Seismic Zone of the midwestern United States. As of , the earthquake risk for the region is being closely monitored.

Venezuelan crisis of : U.S. President Grover Cleveland signs into law a bill resulting from the proposition of House Resolution , by William Lindsay Scruggs and Congressman Leonidas Livingston, to the third session of the 53rd Congress of the United States of America. The bill recommends that Venezuela and Great Britain settle their dispute by arbitration.
May  – Plessy v. Ferguson: The U.S. Supreme Court introduces the separate but equal doctrine, and upholds racial segregation.
The pharmaceutical and healthcare company Hoffmann-La Roche in Switzerland comes wholly under the control of Fritz Hoffmann-La Roche.
March  – The Royal College of St Patrick, Maynooth in Ireland is granted the status of pontifical university by charter of the Holy See.
June  – The . Mw Sanriku earthquake and tsunami kills , in northeastern Japan.
July  – William Jennings Bryan delivers his Cross of Gold speech at the Democratic National Convention, which nominates him for president of the United States.

October 
The Korean Empire is proclaimed, marking the end of the Joseon dynasty after just over  years.
The city of Belo Horizonte, Brazil is created. The construction of the second Brazilian planned city is completed successfully; an immigration of ,, people is estimated.
USS Baltimore (Cruiser # , later CM-) is recommissioned, since , for several months of duty in the Hawaiian Islands.

May  – A patent is awarded for the invention of the first automotive muffler, with the granting by the U.S. Patent Office of application number , to Milton Reeves and his brother Marshall T. Reeves, of the Reeves Pulley Company of Columbus, Indiana.
USS Baltimore (Cruiser # , later CM-) is recommissioned, since , for several months of duty in the Hawaiian Islands.
The city of Belo Horizonte, Brazil is created. The construction of the second Brazilian planned city is completed successfully; an immigration of ,, people is estimated.
The first electric bicycle is invented.
February  – Émile Zola is imprisoned in France, after writing J'Accuse…!.
April  – Spanish–American War: The United States Navy begins a blockade of Cuban ports and the USS Nashville captures a Spanish merchant ship.
November  – Italy sends an ultimatum to the Sultan of Morocco concerning treatment of Italian residents.
In Essen, German company Rheinisch-Westfälisches Elektrizitätswerk RWE is founded.

December  –
Chief Justice Chambers of the Samoan Supreme Court rules that Malietoa Tanus is entitled to become King of Samoa, and holds that Mataafa is barred by the Treaty of Berlin.
French serial killer Joseph Vacher is executed at Bourg-en-Bresse.

February  – Following conviction at court-martial for "conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman" arising from his accusations against Major General Nelson A. Miles, U.S. Commissioner General Charles P. Eagan is suspended from duty for six years by President McKinley.

November  – The siege of Ladysmith begins as armies of the two Boer republics cut telegraph lines connecting Ladysmith to the British colony, and try over the next  days to starve out the British force. The British defenders will hold the fort without surrendering, until the siege is broken on February ,  by a force led by Redvers Buller.
Battle of Colenso: Britain's General Buller loses , officers and men in Natal, the third serious British reverse in South Africa in this "Black Week".
The League of Peja, organized by Haxhi Zeka to lobby for a Kosovar Albanian state within the Ottoman Empire, attracts  delegates to its first convention, held at the city of Peja.
Riro, last of the Kings of Easter Island, on a visit to Valparaíso, Chile, dies either from alcohol poisoning, or an assassination plot by the Chilean government.
March  – A coal mine explosion in West Virginia, United States, kills  miners.
May  – The Chinese province of Manchuria is invaded by the Russian Empire.
Second Boer War: British military leaders accept the unconditional notice of surrender from Boer General Piet Cronjé.
July  – The Federation of Australia is enacted, marking the unification of its colonies into a single country.
March  — Thomas Lambert received a patent for the first indestructible type of cylinder records.
: Pharaoh Senwosret III dies (other date is ).
: Pharaoh Senwosret II starts to rule (other date is ).
–: "Pectoral of Senwosret II", from the tomb of princess Sithathoryunet at el-Lahun was made. Twelfth Dynasty. It is now in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
: Senwosret III (Twelfth Dynasty) died.
: Amenemhat III starts to rule
American businessman William S. Harley draws up plans for his first prototype motorcycle.
December  – The final spike is driven into the Mombasa–Victoria–Uganda Railway, in modern-day Kisumu, Kenya.
December  – Guglielmo Marconi receives the first trans-Atlantic radio signal, sent from Poldhu, England, to St. John's, Newfoundland; it is the letter "S" in Morse code.
Splošno slovensko žensko društvo , the first women's organisation in Slovenia, is founded.
March  – The first large-scale showing of Van Gogh's paintings takes place in Paris, as  are shown at the Bernheim-Jeune gallery,  years after his death.
Clashes between police and Georgian workers led by Joseph Stalin leave  dead,  wounded, and  in prison.
November  – France attempts to neutralize Triple Alliance, signing agreement with Italy to remain neutral in Africa.
July  – Philippine–American War ends.
May  – La Soufrière volcano on the Caribbean island of Saint Vincent erupts, devastating the northern portion of the island and killing , people
August  –  miners die in a pit explosion in Wollongong, Australia.
September – Texas State University in San Marcos, Texas opens as Southwest Texas Normal School.
April  – Atlético Madrid is founded as a professional association football club in Spain.
American motorcycle brand Harley-Davidson is founded in Wisconsin.
December  – The Taj Mahal Palace Hotel in Bombay (now Mumbai), India opens.
January  – The first west–east transatlantic radio broadcast is made from the United States to England (the first east–west broadcast having been made in ).
October – The Daytona Educational and Industrial Training School for Negro Girls, predecessor of Bethune–Cookman University, is opened in Florida by Mary McLeod Bethune.
June  – The International Alliance of Women is founded.
February – – Battle of Port Arthur: A surprise Japanese naval attack on Port Arthur (Lüshun) in Manchuria starts the Russo-Japanese War.
March  – Scottish National Antarctic Expedition: Led by William Speirs Bruce, the Antarctic region of Coats Land is discovered from the Scotia.

May 
British expedition to Tibet: Hundreds of Tibetans attack the British camp at Changlo, and hold the advantage for a while, before being defeated by superior weapons, and losing at least  men.
Pitching against the Philadelphia Athletics, Cy Young of the Boston Americans throws the first perfect game in the modern era of baseball.
Da-Qing Bank, predecessor of Bank of China, is founded in Peiping.
January  – Japan formally repossesses Port Arthur, and renames it Ryojun, holding it for the next  years. The area will revert in  to China, and become the Lushunkou District.
June  – "Pomp and Circumstance" is first played as a graduation march, after Yale University music professor Samuel Sanford invited its composer, Sir Edward Elgar, to receive an honorary degree.
January  (January  O.S.) – The Bloody Sunday massacre of peaceful Russian demonstrators at the Winter Palace in Saint Petersburg takes place, leading to an unsuccessful uprising.
July  – Sixty members of the crew of the USS Bennington are killed in an explosion of the U.S. Navy gunboat in the harbor at San Diego.

April 
The San Francisco Earthquake (estimated magnitude .) on the San Andreas Fault destroys much of San Francisco, California, killing at least ,, with ,–, left homeless, and $ million in damages.
Xerox, the global digital office machine brand, is founded in Rochester, New York as the Haloid Photographic Company.
July  – In the Grand Duchy of Finland, a new electoral law is ratified, guaranteeing full women's suffrage, the first in modern Europe. Women can also stand in national elections.
Valparaíso earthquake: A magnitude . earthquake in Valparaíso, Chile leaves nearly , dead and approximately , injured.
January –April  – The Algeciras Conference convenes, to resolve the First Moroccan Crisis between France and Germany.
June  – Cunard liner RMS Lusitania is launched in Glasgow, as the world's largest ship.
February  – SKF, a worldwide mechanical parts manufacturing brand is founded in Gothenburg, Sweden.
October  – The Hague Convention is revised by the (second) Hague Peace Conference (effective  January ), focussing on naval warfare.
March  – The volcano Ksudach erupts, in the Kamchatka Peninsula.
January  –  Kingston earthquake: A . Mw earthquake in Kingston, Jamaica, kills between  and ,.
July  – Guardians of the Irish Crown Jewels notice that they have been stolen.

March 
The Pretoria branch of Transvaal University College, precursor to the University of Pretoria, is established.
The Collinwood school fire near Cleveland, Ohio kills .
Bank of Communications, a major financial services provider in China, is founded in Beijing,.
June  – Carl Gustaf Emil Mannerheim, a future President of Finland, meets the 13th Dalai Lama in Shanxi, China, becoming only the third European to be granted an audience with him.
July – – The  Hong Kong typhoon sinks the passenger steamer Ying King, causing  deaths.
April  – Frederick Cook claims to have reached the North Pole on this date.
January  – The British Nimrod Expedition led by Ernest Shackleton sets sail from New Zealand on the Nimrod for Antarctica.
January  – The White Star Liner RMS Republic sinks the day after a collision with SS Florida off Nantucket. Almost all of the , passengers are rescued.
April  – Sultan of the Ottoman Empire Abdul Hamid II is overthrown and succeeded by his brother, Mehmed V.
December  – The association football team Borussia Dortmund is founded in Dortmund, Germany.
April  – The Anglo-Persian Oil Company (modern-day BP) is incorporated.
March  – Einar Dessau uses a shortwave radio transmitter in Denmark.
July  – Departure for France of Amenokal Moussa Ag Amastan as part of the Tuareg mission.
Vajiravudh (Rama VI) is crowned King of Siam, after the death of his father, King Chulalongkorn (Rama V).
May  – The second National Association for the Advancement of Colored People meeting is held in New York City.
January  – The Great Flood of Paris begins when the Seine overflows its banks.
June  – DELAG Zeppelin dirigible Deutschland makes the first commercial passenger flight, from Friedrichshafen to Düsseldorf in Germany; the flight takes  hours.
March  – International Women's Day is celebrated for the first time across Europe.
November  – Chevrolet officially enters the automobile market in the United States, in competition with the Ford Model T.
July  – RMS Olympic arrives in Southampton, England, ending her maiden eastbound voyage from New York (having on July  discharged some passengers and mail off Plymouth).
RMS Olympic departs New York for her maiden eastbound voyage home to Southampton, England.
December  – Australasian Antarctic Expedition sets sail from Hobart.
November  – Albania declares independence from the Ottoman Empire.
German geophysicist Alfred Wegener first presents his theory of continental drift.
February  – Arizona is admitted as the 48th state.
August  – A typhoon strikes China, killing at least , people.
A hybrid solar eclipse is the 30th solar eclipse of Solar Saros .
February  – Mexican Revolution: "La Decena Trágica", the rebellion of some military chiefs against the President Francisco I. Madero, begins.
March – – First Balkan War: Battle of Bizani – Forces of the Kingdom of Greece capture the forts of Bizani (covering the approaches to Ioannina) from the Ottoman Empire.
March  – Supporters of Phan Xích Long begin a revolt against colonial rule in French Indochina.

May  – Princess Victoria Louise of Prussia marries Prince Ernest Augustus of Hanover in Berlin, ending the decades-long rift between the Houses of Hohenzollern and Hanover and marking the last great gathering of European sovereigns.

March  – The U.S. Department of Commerce and U.S. Department of Labor are established, by splitting the duties of the -year-old Department of Commerce and Labor. The Census Bureau, U.S. Bureau of Fisheries and U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey form part of the Department of Commerce.

August 
The German Empire declares war on the Russian Empire, following Russia's military mobilization in support of Serbia; Germany also begins mobilisation.
France orders general mobilisation.
The New York Stock Exchange is closed because of the outbreak of the war in Europe, where nearly all stock exchanges are already closed.
Marcus Garvey founds the Universal Negro Improvement Association in Jamaica.
The Panama Canal is inaugurated with the passage of the SS Ancon.

April  – Tampico Affair: A misunderstanding involving United States Navy sailors in Mexico and army troops loyal to Mexican dictator Victoriano Huerta leads to a breakdown in diplomatic relations between the United States and Mexico.

October 
The  Burdur earthquake occurs in Turkey.
The Manifesto of the Ninety-Three is signed by prominent academics supporting the early German war effort.
German troops occupy Luxembourg, in accordance with the Schlieffen Plan.

July
WWI: South West Africa Campaign – The Union of South Africa occupies German South West Africa with assistance from Canada, the United Kingdom, the Portuguese Republic and Portuguese Angola. South Africa will occupy South West Africa until March .
Armenian genocide: , civilians from the Ottoman Armenian population of Trebizond are massacred by Ottoman Turks.

May  – WWI
Sinking of the RMS Lusitania: RMS Titanic's main rival, the British ocean liner RMS Lusitania, is sunk by Imperial German Navy U-boat U- off the south-west coast of Ireland, killing , civilians en route from New York City to Liverpool. The best-known of the celebrities on board is American sportsman Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt (b. ).
Germany captures the Latvian port city of Libau.
June  – Women's suffrage in national elections is introduced in Denmark.
May  – WWI: Italy joins the Allies after declaring war on Austria-Hungary.
October  – William Morris "Billy" Hughes becomes the 7th prime minister of Australia.
Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria dies of pneumonia at the Schönbrunn Palace, Vienna, aged , after a reign of  years and is succeeded by his grandnephew Charles I.
August  – The crew of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition's Endurance is rescued from Elephant Island.
June  – Mary Pickford becomes the first movie star to sign a million-dollar contract, making her one of the highest-paid people in the world.

August  – WWI:
Germany declares war on Romania.
Italy declares war on Germany.
December  – WWI: El Arish occupied by the British Empire Desert Column during advance across the Sinai Peninsula.

November 
WWI: Battle of Cambrai – British forces, using tanks, make early progress in an attack on German positions, but are soon beaten back.
Ukraine is declared a republic.
January  – Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition: Seven survivors of the Ross Sea party are rescued after being stranded for several months.
February  – WWI: The United States severs diplomatic relations with Germany.
April  – WWI: The United States declares war on Germany.
WWI: Battle of Ayun Kara: The ANZAC Mounted Division occupies Jaffa.
January  – The Finnish Declaration of Independence is recognized by Soviet Russia, Sweden, Germany and France.
May  – WWI: The British capture Kirkuk.

March 
The Belarusian People's Republic declares independence.
Karl Muck, music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, is arrested under the Alien Enemies Act, and imprisoned for the duration of WWI.
Proclamation of the republic in Germany by Philipp Scheidemann in Berlin, on the Reichstag balcony. One of several significant events on  November in German history.

June 
Grand Duke Michael of Russia is murdered, thereby becoming the first of the Romanovs to be killed by the Bolsheviks.
WWI: The first airplane bombing raid by an American unit in France is carried out.

January 
The Czechoslovak Legions occupy much of the self-proclaimed "free city" of Pressburg (later Bratislava), enforcing its incorporation into the new republic of Czechoslovakia.
HMY Iolaire sinks off the coast of the Hebrides;  people, mostly servicemen returning home to Lewis and Harris, are killed.
The Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, authorizing Prohibition, is ratified.
September  – Russian Civil War: The last British Army troops leave Arkhangelsk and leave the fighting to the Russians.
November  – Health officials declare the global "Spanish" flu pandemic has ceased.
Rosa Luxemburg and Karl Liebknecht are murdered following the Spartacist uprising.
December  – A referendum in Greece is favorable to the reinstatement of the monarchy.

February  – Adolf Hitler presents his National Socialist Program in Munich to the German Workers' Party (Deutsche Arbeiterpartei), which renames itself as the Nazi Party (Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei).
The Estonian Constituent Assembly adopts the first constitution of Estonia, which will come into effect on December  this year.

December 
The United Kingdom and France ratify the border between French-held Syria and British-held Palestine.
The Government of Ireland Act , passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom, receives Royal Assent from George V, providing for the partition of Ireland into Northern Ireland and Southern Ireland, with separate parliaments, granting a measure of home rule.
October  – The Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe horse race first runs in Paris.
August  – King Faisal I of Iraq is crowned in Baghdad.
July  – A new conservative government is formed in Italy by Ivanoe Bonomi.
Following the assassination of former Finance Minister Matthias Erzberger by right-wing terrorists, the German government declares martial law.
January  – Italian battleship Leonardo da Vinci is righted in Taranto Harbour.
The Australia national cricket team, led by Warwick Armstrong, becomes the first to complete a whitewash of the touring England team in The Ashes, something that will not be repeated for  years.
February – – Modern Art Week in São Paulo marks the start of Modernism in Brazil.

February 
President of the United States Warren G. Harding introduces the first radio in the White House.
In the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic, the Cheka becomes the Gosudarstvennoye Politicheskoye Upravlenie (GPU), a section of the NKVD.
September  – Dutch cyclist Piet Moeskops becomes world champion sprinter.
June  – Subhi Barakat becomes president of the Syrian Federation.

The Irish Civil War and Battle of Dublin begin when the Irish National Army, using artillery loaned by the British, begins to bombard the anti-Treaty Irish Republican Army forces occupying the Four Courts in Dublin. Fighting in Dublin lasts until July .
March  –  The Posey War, the last conflict between American Indians and settlers concludes, ending the American Indian Wars.

September 
The Great Kantō earthquake devastates Tokyo and Yokohama, killing more than , people.
The Kantō Massacre begins and continues for several weeks. Ethnic Koreans are killed by lynch mobs based on rumors that Koreans are committing crimes and plotting to overthrow the government. The death toll (and even the occurrence of) the massacre is disputed, with figures ranging from a few dozen to over , deaths. Most of the deaths were of Korean people, although it is said that other ethnic minorities and even Japanese people with unusual dialects were also killed.
October  – İsmet İnönü is appointed as the first prime minister of Turkey.
August  – The Italian navy occupies Corfu, in retaliation for the murder of an Italian officer. The League of Nations protests, and the occupation ends on September .
The premiere of Bertolt Brecht's play In the Jungle (Im Dickicht), at the Residenztheater in Munich, is interrupted by Nazi demonstrators.

October 
The British press publishes the Zinoviev letter, released the previous day by the Foreign Office. This purports to be a directive from Grigory Zinoviev, head of the Communist International in Moscow, to the Communist Party of Great Britain.
Authorities of the British Raj in India arrest Subhas Chandra Bose and jail him for the next ⁄ years.
September – – The Kohat riots break out in India.
April  – Metro Pictures Corporation, Goldwyn Pictures and Louis B. Mayer Productions are merged to become Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
Treaty of Rome: The Kingdom of Italy annexes the Free State of Fiume, and the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes absorbs Sušak.
May  – Harry Grindell Matthews attempts to demonstrate his "death ray" to the War Office in the United Kingdom.
July  – Meher Baba begins his -year silence.
November  – Formal foundation date of the Schutzstaffel (SS) as a personal bodyguard for Adolf Hitler in Germany.
October – – A brief conflict occurs between Bulgaria and Greece after a Greek soldier accidentally crosses into the Bulgarian side and was shot by border guards.

March 
İsmet İnönü is appointed prime minister in Turkey (Turkey's 4th and İnönü's 3rd government).
Barcelona S.C. founded in Ecuador.
August  – American Gertrude Ederle becomes the first woman to swim the English Channel, from France to England.
August  – In Mexico, the entry into force of anticlerical measures stipulated in the Constitution of  causes the Cristero War from August .
December  – Miina Sillanpää becomes Finland's first female government minister.

Explorer Richard E. Byrd and co-pilot Floyd Bennett claim to be the first to fly over the North Pole in the Josephine Ford monoplane, taking off from Spitsbergen, Norway and returning  hours and  minutes later. Both men are immediately hailed as national heroes, though some experts have since been skeptical of the claim, believing that the plane was unlikely to have covered the entire distance and back in that short an amount of time. An entry in Byrd's diary, discovered in , suggests that the plane actually turned back  miles short of the North Pole, due to an oil leak.
April  – Aarón Joaquín has a vision in the Nuevo León state of Mexico, origin of La Luz del Mundo, a nontrinitarian charismatic restorationist Christian church.

December  – Marion Parker, , is kidnapped in Los Angeles. Her dismembered body is found on December , prompting the largest manhunt to date on the West Coast for her killer, William Edward Hickman, who is arrested on December  in Oregon.
January  – Fritz Lang's futuristic film Metropolis is released in Germany.
August  – The Communist Chinese People's Liberation Army is formed, during the Nanchang Uprising.

April 
The Royal and Parliamentary Titles Act  renames the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland as the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The change acknowledges that the Irish Free State is no longer part of the Kingdom.
April  Incident (Shanghai Massacre): Kuomintang troops kill a number of communist-supporting workers in Shanghai.  The 1st United Front between the Nationalists and Communist ends, and the Civil War lasting until  begins.
March  – A diamond rush in South Africa includes trained athletes, who have been hired by major companies to stake claims.
November  – Turkey passes a law switching the country from the Arabic to the Latin-based modern Turkish alphabet.
June  –  – Aviator Amelia Earhart becomes the first woman to make a successful transatlantic flight, as a passenger in a Fokker F.VIIb/3m piloted by Wilmer Stultz, from Newfoundland to Wales.
September  – Ahmet Zogu, President of the Albanian Republic, declares the country to be a constitutional monarchy, the Albanian Kingdom, with himself as King Zog I.
March  incident: The Japanese government cracks down on socialists and communists, arresting over , people.
October  – The International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement (ICRM) is formally established, with the adoption of the "Statutes of the International Red Cross"
February  – Grand Teton National Park is established by the United States Congress.
October – – Wall Street Crash of : Three multi-digit percentage drops wipe out more than $ billion from the New York Stock Exchange ( times greater than the annual budget of the federal government).
The Kellogg–Briand Pact, renouncing war as an instrument of foreign policy, goes into effect (it was first signed in Paris on August , , by most leading world powers).
May  – "The Battle Of Blood Alley" is fought by a razor gang in Sydney, Australia.
March  – Japanese forces withdraw from Shandong province to their garrison in Qingdao, bringing an end to the Jinan Incident.
November  – Getúlio Vargas becomes president of Brazil.
August – The volcanic island of Anak Krakatau begins to form permanently in the Sunda Strait.
The far-right Lapua Movement marches in Helsinki, Finland.

October  – Ratifications are exchanged in London on the first London Naval Treaty signed in April, modifying the Washington Naval Treaty of . Its arms limitation provisions go into effect immediately, hence putting more limits on the expensive naval arms race between its five signatories (the United Kingdom, the United States, the Empire of Japan, France and Italy.)
June  – Carl Gustaf Ekman becomes Prime Minister of Sweden, for the second and final time.

April  – The Second Spanish Republic is proclaimed in Madrid. Meanwhile, as a result of the victory of the Republican Left of Catalonia, Francesc Macià proclaims in Barcelona the Catalan Republic, as a state of the Iberian Federation.
May  – The Creditanstalt, Austria's largest bank, goes bankrupt, beginning the banking collapse in Central Europe that causes a worldwide financial meltdown.
July  – Norway issues a royal proclamation claiming the uninhabited part of eastern Greenland as Erik the Red's Land.
July  – Emperor Haile Selassie signs the first Constitution of Ethiopia.
May  – Paul Doumer is elected president of France.
June – Lausanne conference opens to discuss reparations, which Germany had not paid since the Hoover Moratorium of June .
May  – May  Incident, an attempted military coup in which Japanese prime minister Tsuyoshi Inukai is assassinated by naval officers. Japanese troops leave Shanghai.
March  – Éamon de Valera is elected President of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State, the first change of government in the country since its foundation  years previously.

February 
The  Winter Olympics open in Lake Placid, New York.
Japan occupies Harbin, China.
November  – German president Hindenburg begins negotiations with Adolf Hitler about the formation of a new government.
The Law for the Prevention of Hereditarily Diseased Offspring is enacted, allowing compulsory sterilization of citizens suffering from a list of alleged genetic disorders.
Formation of new political parties is forbidden.
Leó Szilárd, waiting for a red light on Southampton Row in Bloomsbury (London), conceives the idea of the nuclear chain reaction.
April  – The Stahlhelm veterans' organization joins the Nazi party in Germany.
February  – Adolf Hitler gives his "Proclamation to the German People" in Berlin.
June  – The Indian Reorganization Act is enacted.
March  – Manchukuo, the Japanese puppet state in Manchuria established in , proclaimed a monarchy under Puyi.

October  – Events of October the 6th: the President of Catalonia, Lluís Companys, declares the Catalan State of the Spanish Federal Republic, but Spanish troops swiftly crush the Catalan forces, and arrest him and the members of the Catalan government. The autonomy of Catalonia is suspended until .
The sonoluminescence effect is discovered, at the University of Cologne.
Gaston Doumergue forms a new government in France.
November  –  United Kingdom general election: Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin returns to office at the head of a National Government led by the Conservative Party, with a large but reduced majority.
May  – T. E. Lawrence ("Lawrence of Arabia") is involved in a motorcycle accident, near his home in Dorset, England, resulting in his death a few days later.
Samuel Hoare resigns as British foreign secretary, and is replaced by Anthony Eden.
March  – Reza Shah of Iran asks the international community to formally adopt the name "Iran" to refer to the country, in place of the name "Persia".
March  – King Prajadhipok (Rama VII) of Siam abdicates the throne; he is succeeded by his -year-old-nephew Ananda Mahidol (Rama VIII).
February  – Radium E (bismuth-) becomes the first radioactive element to be made synthetically.

June 
Per Albin Hansson resigns as Prime Minister of Sweden, over the issue of defence policy. He is replaced by the leader of the Farmer's League (Bondeförbundet) Axel Pehrsson-Bramstorp, who also becomes Minister of Agriculture.
The total solar eclipse of June ,  is visible in Greece, Turkey, Russia and Japan. It is part of Solar Saros ; Gamma is a value of .53889.
December  – Xi'an Incident: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China is kidnapped by Marshal Zhang Xueliang.
West China Famine: An estimated five million people die.
September – – English-born aviator Beryl Markham becomes the first woman to make an east-to-west solo transatlantic flight, from Abingdon-on-Thames, England, to Baleine, Nova Scotia.
April  – Frank Whittle ground-tests the world's first jet engine designed to power an aircraft, at Rugby, England.
October  – The Marihuana Tax Act becomes law in the United States.
January  – Water levels begin to rise in the Ohio River in the United States, leading to the Ohio River flood of , which continues into February, leaving  million people homeless and  people dead.

January  – Moscow Trials: Trial of the Anti-Soviet Trotskyist Center – In the Soviet Union  leading Communists go on trial, accused of participating in a plot led by Leon Trotsky to overthrow Joseph Stalin's regime, and assassinate its leaders.
October  – Celâl Bayar forms the new (ninth) government of Turkey.
The  New England hurricane in the United States strikes Long Island and southern New England, killing over  along the Rhode Island shoreline and  altogether.
July  – Howard Hughes sets a new record, by completing a -hour airplane flight around the world.
The last reunion of the Blue and Gray commemorates the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg, in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania.
January  – The Honeymoon Bridge at Niagara Falls, New York, collapses as a result of an ice jam.

October 
French Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet carries out a major purge of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, dismissing or exiling a number of anti-appeasement officials such as Pierre Comert and René Massigli.
At a "friendly luncheon" in Berchtesgaden, German foreign minister Joachim von Ribbentrop tells Józef Lipski, the Polish ambassador to Germany, that the Free City of Danzig must return to Germany, that the Germans must be given extraterritorial rights in the Polish Corridor, and that Poland must sign the Anti-Comintern Pact.
October  – WWII: The Battle of Kock ends the Polish Campaign. Polish resistance moves underground.
British battleship HMS Nelson strikes a mine (laid by U-) off the coast of Scotland, and is laid up for repairs until August .

WWII: Battle of Westerplatte ends when Polish troops on the Westerplatte are forced by lack of food and ammunition to surrender. The garrison of about two hundred had held out against thousands of German forces (many of them naval officer cadets from the Schleswig-Holstein) for seven days.
Faisal II becomes King of Iraq aged three, following the death of his father, Ghazi, in an automobile incident.
Enzo Ferrari founds Auto Avio Construzioni, the company that becomes Ferrari in .

November 
WWII: In response to Germany levelling Coventry  days before, the Royal Air Force begins to bomb Hamburg (by war's end, , Hamburg residents will have died from Allied attacks).
An unexploded pipe bomb is found in the Consolidated Edison office building (only in  later is the culprit, former employee George Metesky, apprehended).
The Jamaica Association of Local Government Officers is founded.
Royal Navy Fairey Swordfish based on Malta bomb Tripoli.

May  – President of the United States Franklin D. Roosevelt, addressing a joint session of the U.S. Congress, asks for an extraordinary credit of approximately $,, to finance construction of at least , airplanes per year.
WWII: Paris is bombed by the Luftwaffe for the first time.

July  – WWII: Winston Churchill, in a worldwide broadcast, proclaims the intention of Great Britain to fight alone against Germany whatever the outcome: "We shall seek no terms. We shall tolerate no parley. We may show mercy. We shall ask none."
August  – The Tiraspol Agreement is signed between Germany and Romania.
August  – The Provisional Government of Lithuania is dissolved.
In Sweden, Victor Hasselblad registers the Hasselblad Camera Company.
April  – The America First Committee holds its first mass rally in New York City, with Charles Lindbergh as keynote speaker.
A German Lorenz cipher machine operator sends a ,-character message twice, allowing British mathematician Bill Tutte to decipher the machine's coding mechanism.

September 
WWII: Erwin Rommel orders a general retreat and carries the German forces of Panzer Army Africa back to the line running from Tel el Eisa – Deir el Shein - west of Deir el Munassib down to the Qattara Depression. Allied forces of the 2nd New Zealand Division and the British 7th Armoured Division ("Desert Rats") begin an assault, but they are repelled in a fierce rearguard action by the German 90th Light Division. During the attack, Rommel loses some , men,  tanks, a similar number of guns, and  vehicles.
The Holocaust: A German attempt to liquidate the Jewish Łachwa Ghetto in occupied Poland leads to an uprising, probably the first ghetto uprising of the war.

February – – WWII: Battle of Sittang Bridge: Indian forces of the 17th Division are ordered to defend the Sittang Bridge, but eventually blow up the bridge to halt the Japanese advance to Rangoon. Survivors of the 17th Division (some . soldiers) swim and ferry themselves over the Sittang River.
Henry Ford patents a plastic automobile that would be % lighter than a conventional car.

June  – WWII:
Free French forces (some , men) evacuate Bir Hakeim and escape through a minefield, where they are picked up by British patrols of the 7th Armoured Division.
Lidice massacre: Units of the Nazi Ordnungspolizei and Sicherheitsdienst shoot all  male residents of the Czech village of Lidice in retaliation for the assassination of Reinhard Heydrich. Of  inhabitants, a total of around  are killed, including  children deported to Chełmno extermination camp, and the remainder are removed. All domestic animals are killed and graves despoiled, the village is burned, remains blown up and the site landscaped out of existence; Nazi propaganda (which is open about the event) states "The name of the village was immediately abolished."

June  – WWII:
Erwin Rommel arrives in Bardia and gives the 90th Light Division orders to attack eastwards. The British 8th Army withdraws to Mersa Matruh, where the Indian 10th Division, elements of the Indian 5th Division and the British 50th Division take up positions.
The experimental early-type nuclear reactor L-IV has an accident, becoming the first nuclear accident in history and consisting of a steam explosion and reactor fire in Leipzig.
September  – Bertolt Brecht's play Life of Galileo (German: Leben des Galilei) receives its first theatrical production, at the Schauspielhaus Zürich.

July 
( GMT (: a.m. local time)) – WWII: Allied invasion of Sicily – The Allied invasion of Axis-controlled Europe begins, with landings on the island of Sicily off mainland Italy by the Seventh United States Army and the British Eighth Army, including the 1st Canadian Infantry Division.
The Holocaust: Jedwabne pogrom – At least  Polish Jews are marched to a local barn, locked inside and subsequently burned to death.
June  – A military coup d'état in Argentina ousts Ramón Castillo.
February  – WWII: North Atlantic convoy SC  is attacked by U-boats, who sink  ships.
WWII: The funeral of Greece's national poet, Kostis Palamas, turns into a demonstration against the Axis occupation of Greece.

January  – WWII:
The Battle of Cisterna opens as United States Army Rangers attempt to break out of the Anzio beachhead.
United States troops invade Majuro, Marshall Islands.
May  – WWII: West Loch disaster: Six LSTs are accidentally destroyed and  men killed, in Pearl Harbor.
Fighting breaks out between Communists and royalists in newly liberated Greece, eventually leading to a full-scale Greek Civil War.
The Red Ball Express convoy system begins operation, supplying tons of materiel to Allied forces in France.
June  – WWII: Battle of Saipan: United States forces land on Saipan.

July  – WWII: Bombing of Aomori – Two USAAF B-29s drop a total of , leaflets on the city of Aomori, Japan, warning civilians of an air raid and urging them to leave immediately. The city was firebombed the next day, killing more than , people.
March – – WWII: The Soviet Red Army carries out the Upper Silesian Offensive.
June  – The Yugoslav Army leaves Trieste, leaving the New Zealand Army in control.
The Soviet Red Army enters Bratislava and pushes to the outskirts of Vienna, taking it on April , after several days of intense fighting.

April  – WWII:
On his 56th birthday, Adolf Hitler leaves his Führerbunker, to decorate a group of Hitler Youth soldiers in Berlin. It will be his last trip to the surface from his underground bunker.
The German city of Nuremberg, previously the site of the Nuremberg rallies, is occupied by American troops.
American troops lead by 2nd Infantry Division and 69th Infantry Division captures city of Leipzig
"Morotai Mutiny": members of the Australian First Tactical Air Force based on the island of Morotai in the Dutch East Indies tender their resignations to protest their belief that they are being assigned to missions of no military importance and in which they are not specialists; a subsequent inquiry effectively vindicates them.
The Chinese Civil War intensifies between the Kuomintang and the Chinese Communist Party.
December  – The Winecoff Hotel fire in Atlanta, United States, kills .
