The . Mw  Vancouver Island earthquake affects the island, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe). Two people are killed.

After more than  years of American dominance, the Philippines attains full independence as the 3rd Republic; Manuel A. Roxas is 5th President of the Philippines. It marks the end of nearly  years of colonial era when the Viceroyalty of New Spain took control since April , .
Direct Action Day: Violence between Muslims and Hindus in Calcutta begins "The Week of the Long Knives", which leaves , dead.

John C. Hennessy Jr. brings the first Volkswagen Beetle to the United States. He purchased the  automobile from the U.S. Army Post Exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, while serving in the U.S. Army. The Beetle is shipped from Bremerhaven, arriving in New York this day.
King George VI of the United Kingdom announces the engagement of his daughter Princess Elizabeth to Lt. Philip Mountbatten.
The Journey of Reconciliation in the Southern United States begins, organized by the Congress of Racial Equality.
In Brussels, , people demonstrate against the relatively short prison sentences of Belgian Nazi criminals.
The Government of the United Kingdom announces the £ million Tanganyika groundnut scheme, for cultivation of peanuts in the Tanganyika Territory.
August  – Whittaker Chambers states that Alger Hiss was a communist on Meet the Press radio.
The murder of June Anne Devaney a -year-old girl in Blackburn, England. To solve the crime, officers take , sets of fingerprints before identifying her murderer.
Charles Warrell creates the first I-Spy books in the United Kingdom.
December  – The United States House Un-American Activities Committee subpoenas and retrieves the "Pumpkin Papers" from the farm of Whittaker Chambers.
February  – Éamon de Valera, Irish head of government from  to , loses power to an opposition coalition. John A. Costello is appointed Taoiseach by President Seán T. O'Kelly, until .
February  – Chaim Weizmann begins his term as the first President of Israel.
August  – The Basketball Association of America and the National Basketball League finalize the merger that will create the National Basketball Association.
October  – China People's Insurance Corporation, as predecessor of China Life was founded.

November  – Winston Churchill makes a landmark speech in support of the idea of a European Union, at Kingsway Hall, London - but does not see UK as part of it, "The British Government have rightly stated that they cannot commit this country to entering any European Union without the agreement of the other members of the British Commonwealth".
May  – The Federal Republic of Germany is established.

November 
The President of Venezuela, Colonel Carlos Delgado Chalbaud, is kidnapped and murdered in Caracas.
A Curtiss Reid Flying Services plane crashes while en route to Paris from Rome, killing all  on board.
March  – The 22nd Academy Awards ceremony is held in Hollywood. All the King's Men ( film) is Best Picture.
United States President Harry S. Truman orders the development of the hydrogen bomb, in response to the detonation of the Soviet Union's first atomic bomb in .
November  – A phenomenal winter storm ravages the northeastern United States, brings – inches of snow and temperatures below zero, and kills  people.

November 
The Colombo Plan for Co-operative Economic Development in South and South-East Asia comes into effect.
Greece and Yugoslavia reform diplomatic relations.

May 
King George VI opens the Festival of Britain in London, including the Royal Festival Hall.
The U.S. Senate Committee on Armed Services and U.S. Senate Committee on Foreign Relations begin their closed door hearings into the dismissal of General Douglas MacArthur by U.S. President Harry S Truman.

March 
Second Red Scare: In the United States, Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are convicted of conspiracy to commit espionage. On April  they are sentenced to death.
Rodgers and Hammerstein's The King and I opens on Broadway, and runs for three years. It is the first of their musicals specifically written for an actress (Gertrude Lawrence). Lawrence is stricken with cancer during the run of the show, and dies halfway through its run a year later. The show makes a star of Yul Brynner.
The 23rd Academy Awards Ceremony is held; All About Eve wins the Best Picture award and five others.
May  – Operation Greenhouse: The first atomic bomb "boosted" by the inclusion of tritium is tested in the "Item" test on Enewetok Atoll in the Marshall Islands by the United States.
May  – The opera house of Geneva, Switzerland is almost destroyed in a fire.
December  – The Marshall Plan expires, after distributing more than $. billion US in foreign aid to rebuild Europe.
December  – Joseph Ivor Linton, the first Israeli Minister Plenipotentiary in Japan, presents his credentials to the Emperor of Japan.
August  – The Grenzlandring racetrack closes in Wegberg, Germany.
September  – The Soviet Union vetoes Japan's application for membership in the United Nations.
September  – The CBC in Montreal, Quebec, goes on air launching television in Canada.

February 
Princess Elizabeth, Duchess of Edinburgh, becomes monarch of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and the British Dominions: Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Pakistan and Ceylon. The princess, who is on a visit to Kenya when she hears of the death of her father, King George VI, aged , takes the regnal name Elizabeth II.
In the United States, a mechanical heart is used for the first time in a human patient.
May – – A tornado outbreak tears through Port Huron, Michigan and Sarnia, Ontario, leaving eight people dead and  people injured.
The  Ionian earthquake of magnitude . totally devastates Cephalonia and most of the other Ionian Islands, in Greece's worst natural disaster in centuries.
June  – Workers' Uprising in East Germany: The Soviet Union orders a Division of troops into East Berlin to quell a rebellion.
The first meeting of Narcotics Anonymous is held (the first planning session was held August ).
November  – First Indochina War: Battle of Dien Bien Phu – French paratroopers consolidate their position at Điện Biên Phủ.
Texas Instruments announces the development of the first commercial transistor radio. The Regency TR- goes on sale the following month.
May  – The common Nordic Labour Market act is signed.
November  –  Berman v. Parker ( U.S. ): The U.S. Supreme Court upholds the federal slum clearance and urban renewal programs.
Adnan Menderes of the Democrat Party forms the new (21st) government of Turkey.
July  – The Fellowship of the Ring, the first of three volumes in J.R.R. Tolkien's epic fantasy novel, The Lord of the Rings, is published in London.

March  – Claudette Colvin, a -year-old African-American girl, refuses to give up her seat on a bus in Montgomery, Alabama, to a white woman after the driver demands it. She is carried off the bus backwards, while being kicked, handcuffed and harassed on the way to the police station. She becomes a plaintiff in Browder v. Gayle (), which rules bus segregation to be unconstitutional.
January  – The Sutton Coldfield rail crash kills , near Birmingham, England.

March  – The movie adaptation of Evan Hunter's novel Blackboard Jungle premieres in the United States, featuring the famous single "Rock Around the Clock" by Bill Haley & His Comets. Teenagers jump from their seats to dance to the song.
October  – The film Rebel Without a Cause, starring James Dean, is released in the United States.
January  – José Ramón Guizado becomes president of Panama.
Tangier Protocol: The international city Tangier is reintegrated into Morocco.
November  – Browder v. Gayle: The United States Supreme Court declares illegal the state and municipal laws requiring segregated buses in Montgomery, Alabama, thus ending the Montgomery bus boycott.
November  – Suez Crisis: The United Nations General Assembly adopts a resolution calling for the United Kingdom, France and Israel to withdraw their troops from Arab lands immediately.
August  –  miners (chiefly Italian nationals) die in a fire at the Bois du Cazier coal mine, in Marcinelle, Belgium.
September  – The submarine transatlantic telephone cable opens.
Aquila Airways Solent crash: A flying boat crash on the Isle of Wight leaves  dead.
May  – Real Madrid beats Fiorentina – at Santiago Bernabéu Stadium, Madrid, to win the – European Cup (football).
July  – Asghar Khan becomes the first native Commander-in-Chief of the Pakistan Air Force and the world's youngest Air Vice Marshal at  years old.
White Rock secedes from Surrey, British Columbia, following a referendum.
July  – His Highness Prince Karim Aga Khan IV becomes the 49th Imam of the Shia Ismaili Muslims at age . His grandfather Sir Sultan Mohammed Shah Aga Khan III appoints Prince Karim in his will.
April  – King Baudouin of Belgium officially opens the world's fair in Brussels, also known as Expo . The Atomium forms the centrepiece.
September  – Jorge Alessandri is the winner of Chile's presidential election.

February  – The Falcons aerobatic team of the Pakistan Air Force led by Wg Cdr Mitty Masud set a world record performing a  aircraft diamond loop in F- Sabres. , people are in attendance including President Iskandar Ali Mirza, General Ayub Khan, Air Marshal Asghar Khan, Air Commodore Nur Khan, C-in-C Turkish Air Force Hamdullah Suphi Göker, Chief of the Iraqi Air Force Abdul Kadhim Abaddi, Chief of the Imperial Iranian Air Force and Chief Guest King Zahir Shah in whose honor the performance has been organized.

March  – A British Commonwealth Trans-Antarctic Expedition team, led by Sir Vivian Fuchs, completes the first overland crossing of the Antarctic, using snowcat caterpillar tractors and dogsled teams, in  days, via the South Pole.
Cuban rebels kidnap five-time world driving champion Juan Manuel Fangio, releasing him  hours later.
May  –  FA Cup Final: Nottingham Forest defeat Luton Town – at Wembley Stadium.
The current (as of ) design of the Japanese  yen coin is put into circulation.

December  – Cold War: Antarctic Treaty –  countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, sign a landmark treaty that sets aside Antarctica as a scientific preserve and bans military activity on the continent (the first arms control agreement established during the Cold War).
September  – The Xerox , the first plain paper copier, is introduced to the public.

June  –  Okinawa F- crash: Twenty-one students are killed and more than a hundred injured when a U.S. Air Force North American F- Super Sabre jet crashes into Miamori Elementary School on the Japanese island of Okinawa. The pilot ejected before the plane struck the school.
The Belgian Congo receives its independence from Belgium, as the Republic of the Congo (Léopoldville). A civil war follows shortly.
The Malagasy Republic (Madagascar) becomes independent from France.
September  – Martin and Mitchell defection: William Hamilton Martin and Bernon F. Mitchell, two American cryptologists, announce their defection to the Soviet Union at a press conference in Moscow.
November  – Mauritania becomes independent of France.

January  – A revised version of the Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security between the United States and Japan ("U.S.-Japan Security Treaty" or "Anpo (jōyaku)"), which allows U.S. troops to be based on Japanese soil, is signed in Washington, D.C. by Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi and President Dwight D. Eisenhower. The new treaty is opposed by the massive Anpo protests in Japan.
August  – João Goulart replaces Jânio Quadros as President of Brazil (he is ousted in ).
September  – In France, the Organisation de l'armée secrète (OAS) slips an anti-de Gaulle message into TV programming.

March 
A ceasefire takes effect in the Algerian War of Independence.
"Nous les amoureux" sung by Jean-Claude Pascal (music by Jacques Datin, lyrics by Maurice Vidalin) wins the Eurovision Song Contest  (staged in Cannes) for Luxembourg.
United States President John F. Kennedy warns the Soviet Union to avoid interfering with the United Nations' pacification of the Congo.

January  – Following a four-day conference in Casablanca, five African chiefs of state announce plans for a NATO-type African organization to ensure common defense. The Charter of Casablanca involves the Casablanca Group: Morocco, the United Arab Republic, Ghana, Guinea, and Mali.

March  – In the United States:
American Airlines Flight  (a Boeing ) crashes on takeoff at New York International Airport, after a rudder malfunction causes an uncontrolled roll, resulting in the loss of control of the aircraft, with the loss of all  on board.
Hulk, created by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby, is introduced by Marvel Comics with the publication of The Incredible Hulk # as the first issue of the comic book, with cover date of May .
The S. S. Kresge Company opens its first Kmart discount store in Garden City, Michigan.

August  – Petit-Clamart attack: An assassination attempt is made against French President Charles de Gaulle by machine-gunning his car in the Paris suburbs. The mastermind, Jean Bastien-Thiry, will later be executed.
İsmet İnönü of the CHP forms the new government of Turkey (27th government, coalition partners; YTP and CKMP).
January  – The Organization of American States suspends Cuba's membership; the suspension is lifted in  ( years later).

July  – Trans-Canada Highway officially opens throughout the ,-mile (, km) between St. John's, Newfoundland, and Victoria, British Columbia, by completion of the Rogers Pass section, making it at this time the world's longest uninterrupted highway.
September  – Rioters burn down the British Embassy in Jakarta, to protest the formation of Malaysia.
December  – Kenya gains independence from the United Kingdom, with Jomo Kenyatta as prime minister.
April  – The U.S. nuclear submarine Thresher sinks  mi ( nmi;  km) east of Cape Cod; all  aboard ( crewmen plus yard personnel) die.
September  – The Centre for International Intellectual Property Studies (CEIPI) is founded.
January  –  Togolese coup d'état: A military coup in Togo results in the installation of coup leader Emmanuel Bodjollé as president.
April  – The U.S. Gemini  is launched, the first unmanned test of the -man spacecraft.

August  – Walt Disney's Mary Poppins has its world premiere in Los Angeles. It will go on to become Disney's biggest moneymaker, and winner of  Academy Awards, including a Best Actress for Julie Andrews. It is the first Disney film to be nominated for Best Picture.

May  – At : a.m., John George Kemeny and Thomas Eugene Kurtz run the first computer program written in BASIC (Beginners' All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code), an easy to learn high level programming language which they have created. BASIC is eventually included on many computers and even some games consoles.
November  – The United States Department of Defense announces the closing of  military bases and facilities, including Fort Jay, the Brooklyn Navy Yard and the Brooklyn Army Terminal.
The National Movement of the Revolution is established in the Republic of the Congo, becoming the country's sole legal political party.
November  – Martial law is announced in Rhodesia. The United Nations General Assembly accepts British intent to use force against Rhodesia if necessary by a vote of –.
December  – The Queensland Elections Act Amendment Bill  passes. Indigenous voting provisions in this Act would be enacted on  February , giving Aboriginal people the vote in Queensland, Australia.
May  – Muhammad Ali knocks out Sonny Liston in the first round of their championship rematch with the "Phantom Punch" at the Central Maine Civic Center in Lewiston.
April  – Rede Globo is founded in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

September 
The Indonesian army, led by General Suharto, crushes an alleged communist coup attempt (see Transition to the New Order and  September Movement).
The classic family sci-fi show Thunderbirds debuts on ITV in the United Kingdom.
Walt Disney records his final filmed appearance prior to his death, detailing his plans for EPCOT, a utopian planned city to be built in Florida.

March 
BOAC Flight  crashes in severe clear-air turbulence over Mount Fuji soon after taking off from Tokyo International Airport in Japan, killing all  people on board.
Merci, Chérie by Udo Jürgens (music by Udo Jürgens, lyrics by Jürgens and Thomas Hörbiger) wins the Eurovision Song Contest  (staged in Luxembourg) for Austria.

December  – The first Kwanzaa is celebrated by Maulana Karenga, founder of Organization US (a black nationalist group) and chair of Black Studies at California State University, Long Beach, from  to .
September  – Hurricane Inez strikes Hispaniola, leaving thousands dead and tens of thousands homeless in the Dominican Republic and Haiti.
The Bechuanaland Protectorate in Africa achieves independence from the United Kingdom as Botswana, with Seretse Khama as its first President.
January  – Canada begins a year-long celebration of the 100th anniversary of Confederation, featuring the Expo  World's Fair.
The first UK colour television broadcasts begin on BBC2. The first one is from the Wimbledon tennis championships. A full colour service begins on BBC2 on December .

March 
The first North Sea gas is pumped ashore at Easington, East Riding of Yorkshire, UK.
Queens Park Rangers become the first 3rd Division side to win the English Football League Cup at Wembley Stadium, defeating West Bromwich Albion –.
March  – Jim Thompson, co-founder of the Thai Silk Company, disappears from the Cameron Highlands.

February 
NASA launches Lunar Orbiter .
Italy's first guided missile cruiser, the Vittorio Veneto, is launched.
General Anastasio Somoza Debayle becomes president of Nicaragua.
Manchester United F.C. wins the European Cup Final, becoming the first English team to do so.
The Pennsylvania Railroad and the New York Central Railroad merge to form Penn Central, the largest ever corporate merger up to this date.

August – –  Democratic National Convention protests: Police clash with anti-Vietnam War protesters in Chicago outside the  Democratic National Convention, which nominates Hubert Humphrey for U.S. president and Edmund Muskie for vice president. The riots and subsequent trials are an essential part of the activism of the Youth International Party.
January  – North Korea seizes the USS Pueblo, claiming the ship violated its territorial waters while spying.
October  – U.S. athlete Bob Beamon breaks the long jump world record by  cm / ⁄ ins at the Olympics in Mexico City. His record stands for  years, and remains the second longest jump in history.
Common African, Malagasy and Mauritian Organization (OCAMM) (Organisation Commune Africaine Malgache et Mauricienne) is established.
September  – An annular solar eclipse is visible in Pacific Ocean and South America, and is the 41st solar eclipse of Solar Saros .

Francisco Franco orders the closing of the Gibraltar–Spain border and communications between Gibraltar and Spain in response to the  Gibraltar sovereignty referendum. The border remains closed until a partial reopening on December , .
The Act of Free Choice for West Irian commences in Merauke, Indonesia.
October  – Experimental research showing that protons were composed of smaller particles, the first evidence of quarks, is published.
February  – The Benavídez rail disaster near Buenos Aires, Argentina (a rear-end collision) kills .

November 
Syrian Prime Minister Hafez al-Assad forms a new government but retains the post of defense minister.
In Ethiopia, the Eritrean Liberation Front kills an Ethiopian general.
Vietnam War – Operation Ivory Coast: A joint Air Force and Army team raids the Sơn Tây prison camp in an attempt to free American prisoners of war thought to be held there (no Americans are killed, but the prisoners have already moved to another camp; all U.S. POWs are moved to a handful of central prison complexes as a result of this raid).
 Australian Senate election: The Liberal/Country Coalition government led by Prime Minister John Gorton and the Labor Party led by Gough Whitlam each ends up with  seats, both suffering a swing against them. The Democratic Labor Party wins an additional seat and holds the balance of power in the Senate. This is the last occasion on which a Senate election is held without an accompanying House of Representatives election.
October  – In Vietnam, the worst monsoon to hit the area in six years causes large floods, kills , leaves , homeless and virtually halts the Vietnam War.
September  – Death of Jimi Hendrix: American rock musician Jimi Hendrix gives his last public performance, two days before his death.
An avalanche at a tuberculosis sanatorium in the French Alps kills , mostly young boys.
The U.S. dollar floods the European currency markets and especially threatens the Deutsche Mark; the central banks of Austria, Belgium, Netherlands and Switzerland stop the currency trading.
Die Sendung mit der Maus airs its first episode on Das Erste.
April  – Palestinians retreat from Amman to the north of Jordan.

October 
The House of Commons of the United Kingdom votes – in favour of joining the European Economic Community.
The United Kingdom becomes the sixth nation successfully to launch a satellite into orbit using its own launch vehicle, the Prospero (X-) experimental communications satellite, using a Black Arrow carrier rocket from Woomera, South Australia.
The Khedivial Opera House in Cairo, Egypt, burns down.
November  – The UNIX Programmer's Manual is published.
Colombian looters find the lost 1st millennium city of Ciudad Perdida; it is not reached by official archaeologists until .
Bobby Fischer defeats Boris Spassky in a chess match in Reykjavík, Iceland, becoming the first American world chess champion.
January  – Independence leader Sheikh Mujibur Rahman returns to Bangladesh after spending over nine months in prison in Pakistan.
September  – The Canada men's national ice hockey team defeats the Soviet national ice hockey team in the eighth and final game of the  Summit Series – to win the series ––.

A bomb explodes at the British Yacht Club in West Berlin, killing Irwin Beelitz, a German boat builder. The German militant group June  Movement claims responsibility, announcing its support of the Provisional Irish Republican Army.

July  – A Delta Air Lines DC- aircraft flying as Delta Air Lines Flight  lands short of Logan Airport runway at Boston, United States, in poor visibility, striking a sea wall about  feet ( m) to the right of the runway centerline and about  feet ( m) short. All  crew members and  passengers are killed; one of the passengers died several months after the accident.
July  – King Mohammed Zahir Shah of Afghanistan is deposed by his cousin Mohammed Daoud Khan while in Italy undergoing eye surgery.
August  – The Norrmalmstorg robbery occurs, famous for the origin of the term Stockholm syndrome.

A large Song dynasty trade ship of c.  A.D. is dredged up from the waters near the southern coast of China with  compartments in its hull. It confirms the descriptions of bulkheaded hull compartments for junks in Zhu Yu's Pingzhou Table Talks of .

October  – Thai popular uprising: Students revolt in Bangkok – In the Thammasat student uprising over , people protest in Thailand against the Thanom military government,  are killed and  are injured by soldiers.
African Youth Amílcar Cabral is founded in Guinea-Bissau.

March 
The Terracotta Army of Qin Shi Huang is discovered at Xi'an, China.
Launch of the Volkswagen Golf in West Germany, a modern front-wheel drive hatchback which is expected to replace the iconic Volkswagen Beetle, holder of the world record for the car with the most units produced.
March  – A group of peasant women in Chamoli district, Uttarakhand, India, use their bodies to surround trees to prevent loggers from felling them, giving rise to the Chipko movement.
June  – Isabel Perón is sworn in as the first female President of Argentina, replacing her sick husband Juan Perón, who dies  days later.
In West Germany, the Bundestag passes the Bundes-Immissionsschutzgesetz ("Federal Emission Control Act").
September  – Sultan Yahya Petra ibni Almarhum Sultan Ibrahim Petra of Kelantan, becomes the 6th Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia.
April  – Vietnam War: North Vietnam concludes its East Sea Campaign by capturing all of the Spratly Islands that were being held by South Vietnam.

September 
Papua New Guinea gains its independence from Australia.
Cape Verde, Mozambique and São Tomé and Príncipe join the United Nations.
March  – Construction of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System begins.

November 
Angola becomes independent from Portugal and civil war erupts.Flag of Angola
Australian constitutional crisis of : Governor-General of Australia Sir John Kerr controversially dismisses the Whitlam Labor government and commissions Malcolm Fraser of the Liberal/National Country Coalition as caretaker Prime Minister.
The first annual Vogalonga rowing "race" is held in Venice, Italy.
The first LAGEOS (Laser Geodynamics Satellite) is launched.
July  – Sagarmatha National Park in Nepal is created.
Landslide disaster in Sau Mau Ping, Hong Kong.
A general strike takes place in the People's Republic of the Congo.
November  – Disappearance of Renee MacRae and her -year-old son Andrew from Inverness in Scotland; this becomes Britain's longest-running missing persons case.

Moluccan terrorists take over a school in Bovensmilde, northern Netherlands ( hostages), and a passenger train on the Bovensmilde–Assen route nearby ( hostages) at the same time. The children are released on May . On June , Dutch Royal Marines storm the train, and six terrorists and two hostages are killed.
January  –  marines from the USS Trenton and USS Guam are killed as a result of a collision in Barcelona harbour, Spain.
SFR Yugoslavia Prime minister Džemal Bijedić, his wife and  others are killed in a plane crash in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
August  – The NASA Space Shuttle, named Enterprise, makes its first test free-flight from the back of a Boeing  Shuttle Carrier Aircraft.

July 
Somalia declares war on Ethiopia, starting the Ethio-Somali War.
New York City is affected by a complete electricity blackout lasting through the following day that results in citywide looting and other criminal activity, including arson.
Stump v. Sparkman ( U.S. ): The Supreme Court of the United States hands down a – decision, in a controversial case involving involuntary sterilization and judicial immunity.

January 
Soviet satellite Kosmos  burns up in Earth's atmosphere, scattering radioactive debris over Canada's Northwest Territories.
Rose Dugdale and Eddie Gallagher become the first convicted prisoners to marry in prison since the establishment of the Republic of Ireland.

April 
New Zealand National Airways Corporation (the domestic airline of New Zealand) is merged with New Zealand's international airline, Air New Zealand.
Dick Smith of Dick Smith Foods tows a fake iceberg to Sydney Harbour.
The Philippine College of Commerce, through a presidential decree, is converted to the Polytechnic University of the Philippines.
November  – China starts an experimental "household responsibility system", in Anhui Province.
January  – Former U.S. Vice President Hubert Humphrey, a Democrat, dies of cancer in Waverly, Minnesota, at the age of .
March  – The first fully functional Space Shuttle orbiter, Columbia, is delivered to the Kennedy Space Center, to be prepared for its first launch.
October  – A tsunami in Nice, France kills  people.

August  – Raymond Washington, co-founder of the Crips, today one of the largest, most notorious gangs in the United States, is killed in a drive-by shooting in Los Angeles; the killers have not yet been identified.
An intense windstorm strikes western Washington and sinks a . km (. mi) long section of the Hood Canal Bridge.
March  – Sultan Yahya Petra of Kelantan, the 6th Yang di-Pertuan Agong (Head of State) of Malaysia, dies in office. He is replaced by Sultan Ahmad Shah of Pahang.
March  – The Norwegian oil platform Alexander L. Kielland collapses in the North Sea, killing  of its crew of .
March  – The Talpiot Tomb is discovered by construction workers in Jerusalem.
July  – Pope John Paul II visits Brazil; seven people are crushed to death in a crowd waiting to see him at afternoon Mass at the stadium in Fortaleza.
June  – A Muslim Brotherhood assassination attempt against Syrian president Hafez al-Assad fails. Assad retaliates by sending the army against them.
July  – A wave of strikes begins in Lublin, Poland.

February  –  Spanish coup d'état attempt ("-F"): Antonio Tejero, with members of the Guardia Civil, enters the Spanish Congress of Deputies and stops the session where Leopoldo Calvo-Sotelo is about to be named president of the government. The coup fails after being denounced by King Juan Carlos.
December  – A coup d'état in Ghana removes President Hilla Limann's PNP government and replaces it with the PNDC led by Flight Lieutenant Jerry Rawlings.
December  – American Brigadier General James L. Dozier is kidnapped in Verona by the Italian Red Brigades.

July 
Mahathir Mohamad becomes the 4th Prime Minister of Malaysia.
 Handsworth riots in Birmingham begin, followed by further  England riots in several urban areas including Liverpool and Leeds.

June 
The first game of paintball is played, in Henniker, New Hampshire, United States.
The E-mu Emulator sampler keyboard with floppy disk operation is unveiled at NAMM international Sound & Music Expo, Chicago. Production Model Serial Number  is issued to Stevie Wonder.
The 54th Academy Awards, hosted by Johnny Carson, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles. Chariots of Fire wins Best Picture and  other Academy Awards.
January  – Air Florida Flight  crashes shortly after takeoff into the 14th Street Bridge in Washington, D.C., United States, then falls into the Potomac River, killing  people.

June 
Falklands War: British supply ship RFA Sir Galahad is destroyed during the Bluff Cove Air Attacks
VASP Flight , a Boeing  passenger jet, crashes into a forest hillside in Fortaleza in Brazil, killing .
The Los Angeles Lakers defeat the Philadelphia 76ers in six games to win the  NBA Finals.
The  FIFA World Cup begins in Spain.
May  – Falklands War: HMS Antelope is lost.

July 
 Sri Lanka Army soldiers are killed during a deadly ambush by the militant Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, thus beginning the Sri Lankan Civil War, which would continue until .
Heavy rain and mudslides in western Shimane Prefecture, Japan, kill .
September  – The GNU Project is announced publicly on the net.unix-wizards and net.usoft newsgroups.
October  – Argentine general election: The first democratic elections in Argentina after seven years of military rule are held.
February  – Giovanni Vigliotto goes on trial on charges of polygamy involving  women.
The Alcalá  nightclub fire in Madrid, Spain, injuring  and killing  people.
March  – General Rahimuddin Khan becomes the first man in Pakistan's history to rule over two of its provinces, after becoming interim Governor of Sindh.
April  – Palestinian gunmen take Israeli bus number  hostage. Israeli special forces storm the bus, freeing the hostages (one hostage, two hijackers killed).

Four African-American youths (Barry Allen, Troy Canty, James Ramseur, and Darrell Cabey) board an express train in the Bronx borough of New York City. They demand five dollars from Bernhard Goetz, who shoots them. The event starts a national debate about urban crime in the United States.
The United States Central Intelligence Agency station chief in Beirut, William Francis Buckley, is kidnapped by the Islamic Jihad Organization and later dies in captivity.
May  – A methane gas explosion at Abbeystead water treatment works in Lancashire, UK, kills  people.
January  – The charity single record "We Are the World" is recorded by USA for Africa.
The Greenpeace vessel Rainbow Warrior is bombed and sunk in Auckland Harbour by French DGSE agents.
May  – Scientists of the British Antarctic Survey announce the discovery of the ozone hole.
January  – Tancredo Neves is elected president of Brazil by the Congress, ending the -year military rule.
June  – Air India Flight , a Boeing , is blown up by a terrorist bomb , feet (, m) above the Atlantic Ocean, south of Ireland, on a Montreal–London–Delhi flight, killing all  aboard.
July  – Australian drug smugglers Kevin Barlow and Brian Chambers are executed in Malaysia.
TASCC, a superconducting cyclotron, officially opens at Chalk River Laboratories.
March  – United States Navy divers find the largely intact but heavily damaged crew compartment of the Space Shuttle Challenger; the bodies of all seven astronauts are still inside.
A hybrid solar eclipse was visible off the coast of Iceland, and was the 53rd solar eclipse of Solar Saros .
February  – The Maxi Trial (Italian: Maxiprocesso) begins in the bunker room of the Ucciardone prison (Palermo). It will be the largest trial against the Sicilian Mafia.
Beginning of the Phosphorite War protest movement in the Estonian SSR.
April  – The governments of the Portuguese Republic and the People's Republic of China sign an agreement in which Macau will be returned to China in .

August  – Rudolf Hess is found dead in his cell in Spandau Prison. Hess, , is believed to have committed suicide by hanging himself with an electrical flex. He was the last remaining prisoner at the complex, which is soon demolished.
July  – The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above the , mark for the first time, at ,..
The followers of the Harmonic Convergence claim it is observed around the world.
March  – The Candle demonstration in Bratislava, Slovakia, is the first mass demonstration of the 1980s against the socialist government in Czechoslovakia.
July  – The Soviet Union votes to end the CPSU's monopoly on economic and other non-political power and to further economic changes towards a less rigidly Marxist-Leninist economy.

December 
Carlos Salinas de Gortari takes office as President of Mexico.
The first World AIDS Day is held.
June  – NASA scientist James Hansen testifies to the U.S. Senate that human-made global warming has begun, becoming one of the first environmentalists to warn of the problem.

March  – Corporals killings in Belfast: Two British Army corporals are abducted, beaten and shot dead by Irish republicans after driving into the funeral cortege of IRA members killed in the Milltown Cemetery attack.

Japanese House of Councillors election: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party loses control of the House of Councillors, the LDP's worst electoral showing in  years, leading to Prime Minister Uno announcing he will resign to take responsibility for the result.
August  – United States Army General Colin Powell became the first Black Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff after being nominated by President Bush.
December  – Hong Kong begins the forcible repatriation of Vietnamese boat people, starting with a group of  who were flown to Hanoi.
The state funeral of Emperor Shōwa (Hirohito) in Tokyo is attended by leaders and representatives of  nations.

August 
Polish president Wojciech Jaruzelski nominates Solidarity activist Tadeusz Mazowiecki to be Prime Minister, the first non-Communist in power in  years.
The Pan-European Picnic, a peace demonstration, is held at the Austro-Hungarian border.
Earth Day  is celebrated by millions worldwide.
March  – "The Second Battle of Trafalgar": A massive anti-poll tax demonstration in Trafalgar Square, London, turns into a riot;  people are injured, and  are arrested.
The Serb Democratic Party (Croatia) declares the sovereignty of the Serbs in Croatia.
First Liberian Civil War: Liberian president Samuel Doe is captured by rebel leader Prince Johnson and killed in a filmed execution.
October  – The remains of the former Estonian head of state, Konstantin Päts, found in the Tver region in Russia, are brought to Tallinn and buried at state expense in the Metsakalmistu cemetery.
February  – The Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization (UNPO) is formed in The Hague, Netherlands.
October  – NASA's Galileo spacecraft makes its closest approach to  Gaspra, becoming the first probe to visit an asteroid.
A . Mw earthquake in Racha, Georgia, kills  people and leaves , others homeless.

February 
 Haitian coup d'état: Haiti's first democratically elected president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, is sworn in. He is ousted on September  and later reinstated in . In response to the coup and in an effort to encourage the coup leaders to restore democracy, the U.S. expands trade sanctions on Haiti to include all goods except food and medicine on October .
The Provisional Irish Republican Army launches a mortar attack on  Downing Street during a cabinet meeting.

Space Shuttle Atlantis leaves an observatory in Earth's orbit to study gamma rays before returning on April . It is followed by Space Shuttle Discovery, which studies instruments related to the Strategic Defense Initiative from April  to May . Space Shuttle Columbia carries the Spacelab into orbit on June .
May  – Capaci bombing: A Mafia bomb on the autostrada in Sicily kills five people, including Italian anti-Mafia judge Giovanni Falcone.
Georgia becomes the 179th member of the United Nations after seceding from the Soviet Union the previous year.
June  – The first World Oceans Day is celebrated, coinciding with the Earth Summit held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
January  – The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia begins to break up; Slovenia and Croatia gain independence and international recognition in some Western countries.
Thai Airways International Flight , an Airbus A310-, crashes into a mountain north of Kathmandu, Nepal killing all  people on board.
July  - A wildfire on the Greek island of Ikaria kills .
December  – The Uruguay Round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) talks reach a successful conclusion after seven years.
Large protests erupt against Slobodan Milošević's regime in Belgrade; opposition leader Vuk Drašković and his wife Danica are arrested.
November  – In a status referendum, residents of Puerto Rico vote by a slim margin to maintain Commonwealth status.

January 
The Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC) is signed by President George H. W. Bush.
Iraq disarmament crisis: US, British and French aircraft attack Iraqi Surface to Air Missile sites in Southern Iraq.
Civil unions between same-sex couples are legalized in Sweden.
September  – President Bill Clinton signs the Federal Assault Weapons Ban, which bans the manufacture of new firearms with certain features for a period of  years.
Danish tour guide Louise Jensen is abducted, raped and murdered by three British soldiers in Cyprus.
The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) is established.

May  – The Flavr Savr, a genetically modified tomato, is deemed safe for consumption by the FDA, becoming the first commercially grown genetically engineered food to be granted a license for human consumption.
April  – Oklahoma City bombing:  people, including eight federal Marshals and  children, are killed at the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building and  are wounded by a bomb set off by Timothy McVeigh.
October  – A fire in Baku Metro, Azerbaijan, kills  passengers, becoming the world's worst subway disaster.
Tansu Çiller of DYP forms the new government (52nd government) of Turkey.
Sudden oak death, the tree disease caused by the plant pathogen Phytophthora ramorum, is first observed, in California, United States.
October  – Tansu Çiller of DYP forms the new government of Turkey (51st government), a minority government which lasts for less than a month.
Faucett Perú Flight  en route from Lima to Rodriguez Ballon airport crashes into a mountain near Arequipa; all  people on board are killed.

November 
A category  cyclone strikes Andhra Pradesh, India, killing at least , people.
NASA launches the Mars Global Surveyor.

First Liberian Civil War: fighting breaks out in Monrovia, Liberia, between various rebel factions struggling for power in the country's interrupted civil war. Several foreign nationals leave the nation.
March  – José María Aznar, leader of the Popular Party, is elected as Prime Minister of Spain, replacing Felipe González.
September  – U.S. president Bill Clinton signs the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty at the United Nations.
Fire breaks out in a pilgrim camp on the Plain of Mena,  kilometres (. mi) from Mecca;  die.
May  – Troops of Laurent Kabila march into Kinshasa.
Hugo Banzer wins the Presidential elections in Bolivia.
October  – Danish escaped criminal Steen Christensen robs the Hotel Palace in Helsinki, Finland, killing two police officers while evading capture.

March 
India's Missionaries of Charity chooses Sister Nirmala, to succeed Mother Teresa as its leader.
The National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China creates a new Chongqing Municipality, out of part of Sichuan.
November  – A Russian Proton rocket is launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, carrying the first segment of the International Space Station, the -ton Zarya Module.
The Galaxy IV communications satellite fails, leaving –% of the US's pagers without service.
January  - Pope John Paul II begins a -day visit to Cuba; Fidel Castro releases  political prisoners in a gesture of goodwill.
September  – At midnight, a shooting occurs aboard an Akula-class nuclear-powered attack submarine of the Russian Navy docked in the northern Russian port city of Severomorsk.
Pokhran-II (Operation Shakti): India conducts three underground nuclear tests in Pokhran, including one thermonuclear device.

March 
One of four bombs detonated in Lusaka, Zambia, destroys the Angolan Embassy.
Rwandan Hutu rebels kill and dismember eight foreign tourists at the Buhoma homestead, Uganda.
The Ottawa Treaty comes into force.
November  – The . Mw  Ambrym earthquake shakes Vanuatu and a destructive tsunami follows, killing  and injuring .
NASA loses radio contact with the Mars Polar Lander, moments before the spacecraft enters the Martian atmosphere.
June  – Thabo Mbeki is inaugurated as the second president of South Africa, marking the first peaceful transfer of executive power in the country's post-democratization history.
November  – China launches the first Shenzhou spacecraft.
February  – Torrential rains in Africa led to the worst flooding in Mozambique in  years, which lasted until March and killed  people.

August  – The Russian submarine Kursk sinks in the Barents Sea during one of the largest Russian naval exercises since the  dissolution of the Soviet Union, resulting in the deaths of all  men on board.

October  – Pakistani authorities announce that their police have found an apparent mummy of an alleged Persian Princess in the province of Balochistan, Pakistan. The governments of Iran, Pakistan as well as the Taliban of Afghanistan all claim the mummy until Pakistan announces it is a modern-day forgery in April .
May  – A new class of composite material is fabricated, which has a combination of physical properties never before seen in a natural or human-made material.
The Longplayer starts playing for , years.
First of the Minoan palaces on Crete. Site of palace complex Knossos started to become occupied.
: Shalim-ahum and his son Ilu-shuma began to rule the city of Assur at around this time.
The Harappa Torso was sculpted by a member of the Indus Valley culture.
Decline of Harappan civilization began.
Stonehenge construction largely completed.
Syria withdraws thousands of forces from a decades-long military presence in Beirut, Lebanon.
Australian federal election: The Coalition government, led by John Howard, is re-elected with a slightly increased majority, defeating the Labor Party led by Kim Beazley.
Dolphinarium discotheque bombing: A Hamas suicide bomber kills  people, mostly teenagers, in the Dolphinarium disco in Tel Aviv, Israel.
March  – Shijiazhuang bombings:  people are killed in a series of bombings in Shijiazhuang, China.
Lithuania joins the World Trade Organization.
February  – UNITA guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi is killed in clashes against government troops led by Angolan President José Eduardo dos Santos in Moxico Province, Angola.
October  – Belarus restricts religious activity outside of the Belarusian Orthodox Church with a new law.

June  –  FIFA World Cup: Brazil beats Germany – in the  FIFA World Cup Final with Ronaldo scoring the two goals; Brazil's captain Cafu, who becomes the first player to appear in three successive World Cup finals, accepts the trophy on behalf of the team.
July  – The Machakos Protocol is signed during the Second Sudanese Civil War, establishing a framework for peace talks and possible independence of South Sudan.
The Catholic Church establishes four new dioceses in Russia, prompting backlash from the Russian Orthodox Church.
April  – The Archaeological Survey of India orders that Hindus be allowed to worship in the Kamal Maula Mosque.
Boumerdès earthquake: a . Mw  earthquake strikes in Algeria, killing over , people.
February  – Millions of people worldwide take part in massive anti-war protests in anticipation of the United States and its allies invading Iraq to overthrow Saddam Hussein's regime.
August  – The discovery of the dinosaur species Rajasaurus narmadensis is announced.
The United Nations Convention Against Transnational Organized Crime comes into force.
May  – Manmohan Singh (a Sikh) is sworn in as India's first non-Hindu prime minister.
March  – Air America, a planned progressive alternative to the popularity of conservative talk radio in the U.S., airs its first broadcast.
July  – The Russian Federation stops recognizing Soviet Union passports as legal identification.
September  – The National Museum of the American Indian opens to the public.
February  – First EuroMillions transnational lottery drawn, in Paris.
April  – The Superjumbo jet aircraft Airbus A380 makes its first flight from Toulouse.
July  – A series of bombings hit the resort city of Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt, killing over  people.
August  – West Caribbean Airways Flight  crashes into a mountain in Venezuela, killing  passengers and crew.
August  – The Al-Aimmah bridge disaster in Baghdad, Iraq kills  Shia Muslim pilgrims who were celebrating a religious festival.
December  – Another second is added, ::, to end the year , the first time since .

August  – The International Astronomical Union defines 'planet' at its 26th General Assembly, removing Pluto's status as a planet and reclassifying it as a dwarf planet  years after its discovery. Ironically, this was in the same year when NASA sent its first probe to the celestial body.
Partial lunar eclipse, visible over most of Africa, Europe, Asia and Australia.

October 
North Korea claims to have conducted its first-ever nuclear test.
Google purchased YouTube for US$. billion.
September  – Annular solar eclipse, visible in Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana, parts of Brazil, and the southern Atlantic.
March  – Microblogging and social networking service website Twitter was launched.
March –April  – The  Cricket World Cup is held in the West Indies with Australia defeating Sri Lanka in the final.
The dwarf planet Gonggong is discovered by astronomers Megan Schwamb, Michael Brown, and David Rabinowitz from the Palomar Observatory.
October  –  Argentine general election: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner becomes the first directly elected female President of Argentina.
Adam Air Flight , en route to Manado, Indonesia, from Surabaya, Indonesia, crashes into the Makassar Strait; killing all  on board.
July  – Live Earth Concerts are held in nine major cities around the world to raise environmental awareness.
November  – Claudia Castillo of Spain becomes the first person to have a successful trachea transplant using a tissue-engineered organ.

May 
An earthquake measuring . on the moment magnitude scale strikes Sichuan, China, killing an estimated , people.
The mummified body of Hedviga Golik is found in her apartment in Zagreb, Croatia  years after her death.
September  – SpaceX Falcon  becomes the world's first privately developed space launch vehicle to successfully make orbit.
October  – Floods affected in Northern Vietnam and Central Vietnam and lasted  days causing flooding in many provinces and cities.
May – – The Eurovision Song Contest  takes place in Belgrade, Serbia, and is won by Russian entrant Dima Bilan with the song "Believe".
June  – Yemenia Flight  crashes off the coast of Moroni, Comoros, killing all but one of the  passengers and crew.
January  – WikiLeaks releases  intercepted telephone recordings of politicians and businessmen involved in the  Peru oil scandal.
The Czech Republic becomes the final member-state of the European Union to sign the Treaty of Lisbon, thereby permitting that document's initiation into European law.
April  - April  – Maersk Alabama Hijacking occurs, the ship being taken over by Somalian pirates off the coast of Somalia.
March  – Rachel Crandall Crocker founds the International Transgender Day of Visibility.
November  – Participants of the  NATO Lisbon summit issue the Lisbon Summit Declaration.

The Finnish Yle TV2 channel's Ajankohtainen kakkonen current affairs program featured controversial Homoilta episode (literally "gay night"), which led to the resignation of almost , Finns from the Evangelical Lutheran Church.
October  – An earthquake and consequent tsunami off the coast of Sumatra, Indonesia, kills over  people and leaves hundreds missing.
The Chadian Civil War officially ends.
October – –  Commonwealth Games takes place in Delhi, India.

October 
Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi is killed in Sirte, with National Transitional Council forces taking control of the city and ending the war.
Basque separatist militant organisation ETA declares an end to its -year campaign of political violence, which has killed over  people since .
January  – The  Egyptian revolution begins.
June –July  – The  FIFA Women's World Cup takes place in Germany, and is won by Japan.

July  – In London, singer Amy Winehouse dies at age  due to alcohol poisoning.
Wenzhou train collision;  high speed trains in Wenzhou, China collided on a viaduct, sending multiple cars off the viaduct and crushing some.  people were killed and  people were injured.
May  – Barcelona beats Manchester United – in the  UEFA Champions League final at the Wembley Stadium.
July  – Turkish adventurer Erden Eruç becomes the first person in history to complete a solo human-powered circumnavigation of the Earth.

October  – November  – Hurricane Sandy, the largest Atlantic hurricane on record (as measured by diameter, with tropical-storm-force winds spanning  miles (, km)), wreaks havoc, resulting in  total deaths and $. billion ( USD) damage.
November  –  United States presidential election: Barack Obama is reelected President of the United States, defeating his Republican challenger Mitt Romney.
November –December  – Typhoon Bopha, known as "Pablo" in the Philippines, kills at least , with around  people missing. The typhoon causes considerable damage in the island of Mindanao.
June  – The Congress of Paraguay approves the impeachment of president Fernando Lugo.

March  – The European Union agrees to a € billion economic bailout for Cyprus. The bailout loan will be equally split between the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism, the European Financial Stability Facility, and the International Monetary Fund. The deal precipitates a banking crisis in the island nation.
May – – The Eurovision Song Contest  takes place in Malmö, Sweden, and is won by Danish entrant Emmelie de Forest with the song "Only Teardrops".
December  – Chinese uncrewed spacecraft Chang'e , carrying the Yutu rover, becomes the first spacecraft to "soft"-land on the Moon since  and the third ever robotic rover to do so.
June  – A bus carrying  Romanian tourists to Tivat, Montenegro, crashes in the Morača canyon in central Montenegro, killing  people and injuring .
September  – Grand Theft Auto V earns more than half a billion dollars on its first day of release.
The San Antonio Spurs defeat the Miami Heat in the  NBA Finals, –, to win their 5th championship in franchise history.
Thai coup d'état: The Royal Thai Army overthrows the caretaker government of Niwatthamrong Boonsongpaisan after a failure to resolve the political unrest in Thailand.
The World Health Organization identifies the spread of poliomyelitis in at least  countries as a major worldwide health emergency.

June  – A Sunni militant group now calling itself the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (also known as ISIS, ISIL or Daesh) begins an offensive through northern Iraq, aiming to capture the Iraqi capital city of Baghdad and overthrow the Shiite government led by Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki.
October  – Stefan Löfven replaces Fredrik Reinfeldt as Prime Minister of Sweden.

May – – Version O of Les Femmes d'Alger by Pablo Picasso sells for US$. million at Christie's auction in New York, while the sculpture L'Homme au doigt by Alberto Giacometti sells for US$. million, setting a new world record for a painting and for a sculpture, respectively.

June – – ISIL claim responsibility for three attacks around the world during Ramadan:
Kobanî massacre: ISIL fighters detonate three car bombs, enter Kobanî, Syria, and open fire at civilians, killing more than  people.
Sousse attacks: -year-old Seifeddine Rezgui opens fire at a tourist resort at Port El Kantaoui, Tunisia, killing  people.
Kuwait mosque bombing: A suicide bomber attacks the Shia Mosque Imam Ja'far as-Sadiq at Kuwait City, Kuwait, killing  people and injuring  others.

Leaders from Russian Federation, Ukraine, Germany and French Republic reach an agreement on the war in eastern Ukraine that includes a ceasefire and withdrawal of heavy weapons. However, several days later, the Ukrainian government and pro-Russian rebels claim that, within its first day, the ceasefire was broken  times, as both sides failed to withdraw their heavy weapons and fighting had continued.

June 
Cuba becomes the first country in the world to eradicate mother-to-child transmission of HIV and syphilis.
An extra leap second (::) is added to end of June. The last time this occurred was in .
February  – Pope Francis and Patriarch Kirill sign an Ecumenical Declaration in the first such meeting between leaders of the Catholic and Russian Orthodox Churches since their schism in .
June –July  – France hosts the UEFA Euro  football tournament, which is won by Portugal.
November  – The number of people globally using mobile devices to access the internet overtakes those using desktop computers for the first time, having been preceded by the U.S. two years prior.
July  –  Nice truck attack:  people are killed and more than  others injured in a truck attack in Nice, France, during Bastille Day celebrations.

April  – Pope Francis' apostolic exhortation Amoris laetitia (dated March ) is published in the Vatican; it appears to amend the Roman Catholic Church's position on the availability of sacraments to Catholics who have divorced and contracted a civil remarriage.
November  – Syrian Civil War: both Deir ez-Zor in Syria and Al-Qa'im in Iraq are declared liberated from ISIL on the same day.
December  – The Walt Disney Company announces that it will acquire most of  Fox, including the  Fox film studio, for $ billion.

August 
The first observation of a collision of two neutron stars (GW170817) is hailed as a breakthrough in multi-messenger astronomy when both gravitational and electromagnetic waves from the event are detected. Data from the event provided confirmatory evidence for the r-process theory of the origin of heavy elements like gold.
 Barcelona attacks: -year-old Younes Abouyaaqoub drives a van into pedestrians on La Rambla in Barcelona, killing  people and injuring at least  others.

November 
Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe is placed under house arrest, as the military take control of the country. He resigns six days later, after  years of rule.
A Leonardo da Vinci painting, Salvator Mundi, sells for US$ million at Christie's in New York, a new record price for any work of art.
The Argentinian submarine ARA San Juan suddenly vanished with  crew members on board whilst on a routine patrol in the South Atlantic. It would be found one year later wrecked  metres (, ft) below the Atlantic Ocean.
The Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons is voted for by  states.

May 
NASA's space probe InSight is launched. It landed on Mars on November  and uses a drill to conduct geological science.
In North Korea, clocks are adjusted to UTC+ (GMT+:) to the same as South Korea

March  – In response to gun violence in the United States, and particularly triggered by the Stoneman Douglas High School shooting in Parkland, Florida, thousands of high school students across the country participate in an organized protest they called the National School Walkout.

May 
The separatist group ETA officially announces its final dissolution after  years of conflict and more than  deaths in Spain.
The  lower Puna eruption causes destruction of structures and forces thousands of residents of Hawaii to evacuate as lava floods the land.
July  – The EU–Japan Economic Partnership Agreement is signed, the world's largest bilateral free trade deal, creating an open trade zone covering nearly one-third of global GDP.
May  – Real Madrid wins the - Champions League held in Kyiv, Ukraine by beating Liverpool in the final –.
February – – The  North Korea–United States summit is held in Hanoi, Vietnam. It is the second summit between U.S. President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.
December  – An annular solar eclipse is visible from South Asia. This is a part of Saros .

Trial of Catalonia independence leaders: The Supreme Court of Spain sentences nine Catalan independence movement leaders to  to  years of prison for sedition and misuse of public funds. Three others are disqualified for  year and  months for disobedience. Violent protests erupt across Catalonia.
Public impeachment hearings against U.S. President Donald Trump begin in the House of Representatives.
Revocation of the special status of Jammu and Kashmir: India revokes the part of its constitution that gives Indian-administered Kashmir special status in an unprecedented move.
Astronomers announce the discovery of the first black hole located in a star system visible to the naked eye.
The Emir of Kuwait Sheikh Sabah Al-Sabah dies at the age of . Crown Prince Nawaf Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah is named his successor.

December 
Media outlets report that astronomers have detected a radio signal, BLC1, apparently from the direction of Proxima Centauri, the closest star to the Sun. Astronomers have stated that this and other, yet unpublished, signals, are thought to likely be "interference that we cannot fully explain" and that it appears to be among the two strongest candidates for a radio signal humanity received from extraterrestrial intelligence so far.
COVID- pandemic: The number of confirmed cases of COVID- passes  million worldwide.
COVID- pandemic: The United States approves Moderna's vaccine for emergency use, the second brand available there.

Chinese Premier Li Keqiang reports that the domestically transmitted epidemic is now under control. Two days later, China temporarily suspends entry for foreign nationals with visas or residence permits, effective midnight on March .
Pope Benedict XVI becomes the longest-lived pope at  years,  months, and  days, surpassing Pope Leo XIII, who died in .

August  – The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change releases the first part of its Sixth Assessment Report, which concludes that the effects of human-caused climate change are now "widespread, rapid, and intensifying".
June  – COVID- pandemic: The number of vaccinations administered worldwide exceeds  billion.

April  – Japan's government approves the dumping of radioactive water of the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant into the Pacific Ocean over the course of  years, with full support of the International Atomic Energy Agency. The decision is opposed by China, South Korea, and Taiwan.
December  – The  Gambian presidential election is held and incumbent president Adama Barrow is reelected.

November 
NASA launches the Double Asteroid Redirection Test (DART), the first attempt to deflect an asteroid for the purpose of learning how to protect Earth.
Magdalena Andersson resigns as Prime Minister-elect of Sweden hours after the Riksdag voted her in as Sweden's first female prime minister. She was due to take office on  November. Instead, she takes office on  November.
The world population reaches  billion.
Russian invasion of Ukraine: The United Nations reports that over a million refugees have now fled from Ukraine to other countries.
January  – A large eruption of Hunga Tonga–Hunga Ha'apai, a submarine volcano in Tonga, triggers tsunami warnings in Australia, Canada, Chile, Fiji, Japan, New Zealand, Samoa, and the United States.

The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, the largest free trade area in the world, comes into effect for Australia, Brunei, Cambodia, China, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam.

April  – The  Slovenian parliamentary election is held to elect all  members of the National Assembly of Slovenia, the lower house of the Slovenian Parliament; the Freedom Movement party becomes the largest party, winning  of  seats.

Gaza war: Hamas launches an incursion into southern Israel from the Gaza Strip, killing more than , Israelis and taking about  hostages, prompting a military response from the Israel Defense Forces. Israel launches numerous air strikes on Lebanon after rockets are fired by Hezbollah and further attempts are made to penetrate Israel.
The United Nations General Assembly unanimously adopts the High Seas Treaty, the first treaty aimed towards marine conservation in international waters.

January 
Burkina Faso requests French forces to withdraw from its territory after suspending a military accord that allowed the presence of French troops in the country.
Tigray War: Eritrean forces withdraw from Shire and other major towns in the Tigray Region of Ethiopia.
Iran and Saudi Arabia agree to resume diplomatic relations which were severed in , at talks mediated by China.
October  – November  – The  Cricket World Cup is held in India, with Australia defeating India in the final.
April  – A total solar eclipse is visible across North America.

September  – The Brazilian Supreme Court upholds a decision to block the social media platform X (also known as Twitter) over what the Brazilian government determined to be rampant disinformation and Elon Musk's failure to name a legal representative to the country.
Said Abdullahi Deni is elected President of Puntland by the Puntland Parliament after three rounds in the  Punttland presidential election.

The Parker Solar Probe breaks the previous record set in  for the closest artificial object to the Sun by . million kilometers (. million miles), becoming the closest and first man-made object to approach and "touch" the Sun.
July  – Landslides kill  people and bury two villages in Geze Gofa, Gofa Zuria, Ethiopia.
October  –  Dutch general election: Social liberal party Democrats  ties with right-wing populist party Party for Freedom in most number of seats.

Egypt announces the discovery of Thutmose II's tomb by a joint British-Egyptian team, the first royal tomb to be discovered since Tutankhamun's in . It is the 15th and final pharaoh tomb from the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt to have been found by archeologists.

March  – More than , people, including civilians, are reported killed in a crackdown by Syrian transitional government security forces in the Alawite region, described as the country's worst violence for years.

Iranian protests: Major protests emerge in Iran following an intense inflation spike that saw a severe depreciation in the Iranian rial. These protests are accompanied with demands for an end to the Islamic republic.

January 
 Potomac River mid-air collision: A United States Army Black Hawk helicopter with three occupants on board, collides with a Bombardier CRJ700 operated by PSA Airlines with  occupants on board in Washington, D.C., United States. There are no survivors.
Ahmed al-Sharaa is appointed as the president of Syria, after a one-month vacancy following the fall of the Assad regime.
May – – The Eurovision Song Contest  is scheduled to be held in Vienna, Austria, following their win at the Eurovision Song Contest .
October –November  – The  Summer Youth Olympics will be held in Dakar, Senegal.
July – If not triggered earlier, the  São Toméan presidential election will be held no later than this date.
The  Peruvian general election is scheduled to be held.
January  – – Iranian protests: Nationwide protests against Iran's clerical regime intensify, with hundreds reported killed and thousands detained amid a severe government crackdown.

– Mentuhotep II, ruler of the Eleventh Dynasty of Egypt in Thebes, completes the reunification of Egypt following his victory over the pharaohs of Herakleopolis, which marks the beginning of the Middle Kingdom.

– – The Third Dynasty of Ur. The Ziggurat of Ur is built. Administrative power in Ur is pushed far, with an Ensi, an appointed civil servant, at the head of the constituencies. A meticulous and finicky bureaucracy manages, counts and controls the whole administration, which is as much concerned with the economy as with war or the service of the gods. The weight of such an administration arguably contributes to the collapse of the empire. Finally, the Elamites sack Ur and the third dynasty comes to an end.
In Chalcolithic Europe, the two circles of bluestones that form the inner part of Stonehenge are erected.
Epic poetry is written in the Sumerian language, including the Epic of Gilgamesh.
Late spring  – Seahenge is built in Britain.

: End of the Old Kingdom of Egypt and start of the First Intermediate Period, the doubtful Seventh Dynasty and the Eighth Dynasty of Egypt with Menkare (these periods may extend to c.  or beyond). The fall of the Old Kingdom may have been caused by a conjunction of severe droughts, strong decentralization of the state and confusion following the extremely long reign of Pepi II.

A solar eclipse on  May and a lunar eclipse on  May occur and are believed to be the double eclipse that takes place  years after the ascension of king Shulgi of Babylon by those holding to the long chronology.
–: The Epic of Gilgamesh is written in Mesopotamia in Akkadian.
: Ancient migrants from India reach Australia and mix with Indigenous Australians.
: Gudea, ruler (ensi) of Lagash, starts to reign.
: Indus Valley Civilisation (Harappan) flourishing in modern-day eastern Pakistan - western India.
– : Stela of Naram-Sin, probably from Sippar, discovered in Susa (modern Shush, Iran), is made. It is now in Musée du Louvre, Paris.
: A Guti army swept down from the Zagros Mountains and defeated the demoralized Akkadian army. They took Agade, the capital of Akkad, and destroyed it thoroughly.
: The beginning of the Meghalayan Stage, the last of the three stages of the Holocene.
– : "Head of a man from Nineveh" (modern Kuyunjik, Iraq) is made. It is now in Iraq Museum, Baghdad.
–: Mesopotamian wars of the Early Dynastic period continue.
: Lugal-Zage-Si of Umma conquers Gu-Edin and unites Sumer as a single kingdom.
: pharaohs Teti, Userkare reign, Pepi I then rules into the  BC.
Dangun establishes Gojoseon, the first Korean kingdom, according to Korean mythology.
: First destruction of the city of Mari.
–: Mohenjo-daro is about  square miles ( km) in size and has a population of c. , to ,.

: By this time, kings in Sumer have ceased to be automatically high priests of the city deity. (Roux ) Infiltration and conquest of Mesopotamia by ancient Semitic-speaking peoples begins. ( RD Almanac)

–: Ebla tablets are collected in the ancient city of Ebla, Syria. Discovered by Italian archaeologist Paolo Matthiae and his team in –, is considered to be the first, if not the oldest, inactive library being the St. Catherine's Monastery Library () the oldest active one.
Earliest signs of Corded Ware culture from the Caucasus. (Encyc. Americana)
: The sculpture Khafre Enthroned is made.
–: Reign of Khafre. the Pyramid of Khafre is built, along with the Great Sphinx of Giza, a monumental sculpture of a pharaoh (either Khafre or Khufu) with a lion's body.
Reigns of Menkaure and Shepseskaf

Mesannepada, who has already dominated the city of Nippur, takes advantage of an eclipse of power in Kish (caused by an incursion by the Elamites of Awan) to seize the city. He becomes the ruler of all of Lower Mesopotamia as he becomes the king of Kish, and his name appears on a pearl in Mari.
–: The Instructions of Shuruppak, the earliest known literary texts, are created in Adab, Shuruppak and Abu Salabikh.

Reign of Mesilim, king of Kish. He was an apparent suzerain over the Lagash king Luga-shag-engur and the Adab king Nin-kisalsi. A conflict between Lagash and the neighboring Umma begins over fields claimed by each of the parties. An initial crisis is settled by Mesilim in favor of Lagash.
Earliest records of oil wrestling from Babylonia and Egypt.

–: Fourth Dynasty of Egypt.
c. –: The reign of the pharaoh Sneferu and his vizier Nefermaat. Sneferu leads a campaign in Nubia and returns with about , prisoners, who would be employed as servants in the royal estates. Sneferu then sends an expedition to Libya which brings back , prisoners and , heads of cattle. Sneferu sends  ships to Byblos for the retrieval of cedar wood for the construction of ships. Under Sneferu's reign and that of his son Khufu, copper mines and turquoise quarries are developed in Sinai. The tomb of Hetepheres I, wife of Sneferu and mother of Khufu, demonstrates that cabinetry and jewelry are well-developed. A depiction of plowing painted in the tomb of Itet and Nefermaat in Meidum is the earliest testament to the technique in Africa.

:
End of the Early Dynastic I Period, and the beginning of the Early Dynastic II Period in Mesopotamia.
Abandonment of the Mature Harappan settlement at Kalibangan in India due to the drying-up of the Ghaggar River.
Supposed reign of the semi-legendary Sumerian king Gilgamesh.
A bronze bar produced in Nippur (Sumeria) defines the cubit.
Earliest records of oil wrestling from Babylonia and Egypt.
: The beginning of statuary in Ancient Egypt, with shale and limestone statues of Khasekhemwy created in Nekhen.
–: Early Dynastic II Period in Mesopotamia.
: Estimated ending of the Cucuteni-Trypillian culture in the region of modern-day Romania, Moldova, and southwestern Ukraine.
Second Dynasty wars in Ancient Egypt.
– : Seated Harp Player, from Keros, Cyclades, is made. It is now at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
: The -day calendar year was installed in ancient Egypt, with fixed lunar months of  days +  epagomenal days.

Suggested date for an asteroid or comet impact occurring between Africa and Antarctica, around the time of a lunar eclipse on May , based on an analysis of flood stories. Possibly causing the Burckle crater and Fenambosy Chevron.
: Beginning of the Early Dynastic Period I in Sumer.
Akkadian language names are recorded from about this time period.
First Mariote Kingdom founded.
: Cycladic civilization in the Aegean Sea starts.
: Aegean Bronze Age starts.
: Death of Egyptian First Dynasty pharaoh Semerkhet, whose name marks the first definitive use of a Nebty name.
: Austronesian expansion begins.
+ BC Prometheus would have sprouted in this century.
?: Predynastic period (Neolithic) ends in Ancient Egypt.
: Oldest adobe building in the Americas was built in what is now Peru.
?: The Anu Ziggurat and White Temple are built in Uruk.
?: The first temple of Tarxien is in use by the Neolithic inhabitants of Malta.
: Polo (Meitei: Sagol Kangjei) was first played in Manipur state.
?: Beginning of the reign of Narmer, first pharaoh to unify Ancient Egypt and founder of the 1st Dynasty.
?: Earliest buildings at the Ness of Brodgar in the Orkney Islands constructed.

: Ljubljana Marshes Wheel is a wooden wheel that was found in the Ljubljana Marsh in Slovenia. Radiocarbon dating showed that it is approximately , years old, which makes it the oldest wooden wheel yet discovered.
?: Crete: Rise of Minoan civilization.
–: Reign of Scorpion II in Upper Egypt..
: Harappan script is developed in Indus Valley
: The Red Temple, the first phase of the Monte d'Accoddi sanctuary in Northwest Sardinia, is built
Ancient Egypt begins using clay, bone and ivory tags to label boxes, possibly an example of proto-writing
: Archaeological evidence suggests the transition from Copper to Bronze took place around

Evidence of proto-Thracians or proto-Dacians in the prehistoric period; Proto-Dacian or proto-Thracian people developed from a mixture of indigenous peoples and Indo-Europeans from the time of Proto-Indo-European expansion in the Early Bronze Age
: First known zoo at Hierakonpolis.
The Sahara desert starts to form from semi-arid savannah, through desertification.
: The Eruption of Mount Isarog in the Philippines.
: Sumerian temple record keepers redesign the stamp seal in the form of a cylinder.
: The oldest estimated germination of Alerce Milenario with more conservative dates of only ‘c.’.
: Pictographic proto-writing starts developing towards writing proper in Sumer, thus starting what is technically considered history.
: Sumerian temple record keepers redesign the stamp seal in the form of a cylinder.
: The oldest estimated germination of Alerce Milenario with more conservative dates of only ‘c.’.
The Sahara desert starts to form from semi-arid savannah, through desertification.
: First known zoo at Hierakonpolis.
Maize is domesticated at Balsas River by the Tehuacán culture
Beginning of the construction of the megalithic Ggantija temple complex in Malta.
In Egypt, evidence found of mummification around this time at a cemetery in Nekhen (Hierankopolis).
Fortified town at Amri on the west bank of the Indus River.
Civilization in Sumer (Uruk period).
The Maykop culture, a major Bronze Age archaeological culture in the Western Caucasus region of Southern Russia, began around .
Indus Valley civilisation in South Asia ().
In the city of Uruk, southern Mesopotamia, groups of tokens representing commercial transactions begin to be enclosed in hollow clay balls and kept in archives.
Settlement of the River area of Barbuda (c. ), formation of sand dunes on Palmetto Point.
In the south of England, a rapid expansion of monument building occurred around .
the first year of the Hebrew calendar
Ubaid period came to an abrupt end in eastern Arabia and the Oman peninsula at .
In Syria, mass graves at Tell Brak, dating from c.  to , have been unearthed, suggesting advanced warfare around this period.
An earthquake near a Neolithic culture at Sotira in Cyprus destroys much of the local infrastructure.
– Disintegration of the Proto-Semitic language
The Post Track, an ancient causeway in the Somerset Levels, England, is built, c. . It is one of the oldest engineered roads discovered in Northern Europe.

The Sweet Track, an ancient causeway also in the Somerset Levels, the oldest timber trackway discovered in Northern Europe, is built in  or ; tree-ring dating (dendrochronology) enabled very precise dating.
Susa is a center of pottery production; c. potter's wheel in Mesopotamia
Clay pots and vats discovered at a sprawling cave system in southern Armenia near the border with Iran shows signs of an organized effort to press and distill grapes
Domestication of the horse
Metallurgy during the Copper Age in Europe
Megalithic monuments are constructed in Brittany (Carnac), Portugal (Lisbon), central and southern France, Corsica and Great Britain
